HEADLINE: U.S. Is Shying From Bosnian Conflict

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
As efforts to stop the Serbian shelling of Sarajevo continue, the pleas of Bosnians for Western military intervention to rescue their besieged capital and dismembered country have fallen on wary ears in the Bush Administration.
President Bush has ruled out sending American ground troops to help end the fighting, but Washington has said it is prepared to lend air and naval support to enforce the embargo against Yugoslavia and safeguard the delivery of humanitarian aid to Sarajevo. 
 Senior Administration officials say those two contingencies are among a range of United States military options, including air strikes against Serbian targets, depending on the effects of the cease-fire that the parties to the Bosnia fighting, meeting in London, agreed to observe beginning Sunday evening. But senior Pentagon officials strongly oppose increased American involvement and there are no imminent plans to intervene militarily.
 
A Quandary for the U.S.
 Bush Administration officials say the crisis in Bosnia poses a difficult quandary for the United States and represents an unwinnable situation for the military.
If Washington does not do more, "the worry is the carnage and the bloodletting goes on and it demonstrates the impotence of the great powers," a senior Administration official said. The alternative is "getting involved in a situation that is in many respects similar to Northern Ireland, and not being able to solve it by military means," the official said.
"If you put enough force in there" you might deal with the fighting, but not with the fundamental religious and ethnic problems that transform the conflict into a guerrilla war, the official said.
Assuming the Administration does not reverse its policy on sending combat ground troops, the options open to the Pentagon include flying air cover for land convoys and supply planes and air strikes against Serbian positions.
 
Administration Reluctant
 Locked in what appears will be a close Presidential race, the Bush Administration appears reluctant to increase American military involvement in Bosnia. But Washington has said that if fighting closes Sarajevo's airfield to the international relief effort now flying in food, medicine and supplies it will contribute aircraft to safeguard the shipments.
A fine line, however, divides two situations: flying protective escort and being drawn into larger air attacks to push Serbian fighters back. Air Force F-16 fighter jets now conducting exercises at Aviano Air Base in northern Italy could attack Serbian mortar and artillery positions in the hills surrounding Sarajevo, but military officials fear this strategy could backfire.
"Air strikes would just make them dig in their heels, fight and inflict greater casualties on Sarajevo," a Pentagon official said. "The Serbs are a hardheaded people who historically have been prepared to take heavy casualties."
A British official familiar with the American military thinking agreed, saying, "A few large explosions would kill a few of them, but you can't intimidate them into stopping by roaring overhead and dropping a few missiles."
Some State Department officials disagree with the Pentagon's analysis, arguing that the Serbs respect military might and that bombing would chase their forces out of the hills.
 
A Need for Artillery
 Air strikes, however, would not achieve much without ground forces to secure the airfield and establish a cordon of 15 to 20 miles around it to protect against Serbian mortar and artillery fire. These forces would have to be equipped with their own artillery to counterattack if necessary.
Officially, the United States has ruled out sending combat ground forces, although planners at the Joint Chiefs of Staff in Washington have drafted scenarios where Marines and the Army's 82d Airborne Division could be sent to Bosnia. Officials say as many as 50,000 troops would be needed, assuming the forces encountered strong resistance from the Serbs.
Pentagon officials say that attacking the 60,000 to 70,000 Serbian regular and irregular troops in the Sarajevo area would toughen the Serbs' resolve and drag American forces into a civil war fed by ethnic animosities that are generations old.
"For us to go in there on the ground would give the existing Government a new rallying point, that outside invaders are besmirching Serbian territory," an Army official said. "We would just become a set of clay pigeons in everyone's shooting gallery."
American ground troops "could be a special target and complicate the situation rather than solve it," Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, said on CNN on July 10.
 
History's Warning
 Military officials say that the tragic images emerging from war-weary Sarajevo coupled with the United States success in the Persian Gulf war has raised unrealistic public expectations that the American military should be capable of quickly ending the fighting in Bosnia.
"People have been mesmerized by Desert Storm," a senior Army official said. "But the Yugoslav military and terrain is totally different. It's far more akin to the kind of fighting that's gone on in Northern Ireland, Lebanon and Vietnam."
History also provides a stern warning. In World War II, Yugoslav partisan forces, including Serbs, tied up 20 Axis divisions in the Yugoslav mountains, even after the Nazis ordered that 100 Yugoslavs be executed for every German soldier killed, military historians said.
State Department and Pentagon officials say that diplomatic efforts under way to negotiate a settlement and the economic embargo of Yugoslavia are the best hopes for a peaceful solution. An eight-nation naval force has sailed into the Adriatic to monitor the embargo.
"From a humanitarian standpoint it's sad," a senior American general said. "But just because it's sad doesn't mean we can solve it."

HEADLINE: Democrats' Spending Gets Mixed Reviews

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
Aside from getting mugged, Ron Squires's experience in New York City last week was a lot like that of many other delegates to the Democratic National Convention.
He didn't spend much money -- no theater, shopping or five-course meals -- but he had a swell time anyway and he doesn't mind talking about it. And therein may lie the story of the true economic effect of a four-day national spectacle to which the city has hitched enormous psychological, promotional and dollars-and-cents hope. 
 Despite reports of booming business from some quarters and city projections that the convention would generate nearly a half-billion dollars in spending, many merchants and service workers -- T-shirt vendors, cab drivers, restaurant owners and department store clerks -- are left wondering, in the words of one erstwhile Democratic Presidential candidate: Where's the beef?
Yet even Mr. Squires, the lone delegate to report being mugged and beaten, was a fount of praise for the city, and many economic analysts say that the good feeling and word of mouth, coupled with media images largely devoid of grime and crime, may be the city's bottom-line benefit.
"The real question is, in light of everything, would the city have done the Democratic National Convention again, and the answer is absolutely yes," said Barry F. Sullivan, the city's Deputy Mayor for Economic Development.
 
City Exceeded Expectations
 Mr. Squires, a member of the Democratic National Committee's Platform Committee from Vermont, will no doubt be back.
Compared with expectations, "The delegates are just impressed with how friendly and helpful the city is; how much cleaner and how much more of a police presence there is," he said.
But for all the good will, there are questions about whether the convention pumped up the economy as much as the city had projected.
Macy's and Bloomingdale's reported significant increases in visitors and strong indications of increased sales -- as did several topless bars. And for clubs and restaurants like Tatou and the Water Club, business was hectic, star-studded, and all that could have been hoped for.
But in the face of projections that delegates, members of the press and others would pour $72,365,353 in personal spending alone into the economy, many business and sales people made the same observation as their counterparts in Atlanta after the last Democratic convention in 1988: in the words of Felicia Sukur, 27, who was handing out free perfume samples at Saks Fifth Avenue last week, "From what I've heard, Republicans spend more money."
 
Prices Deter Spending
 For Byeong D. Park, the owner of Solomon Gifts on Herald Square, an investment in about 100 Democratic National Convention T-shirts, which he was selling for $14.99, proved reckless. "Most of them I stock, I cannot sell -- just 5 percent," he said midway through the convention.
For Gina Amador, cashier at the Eastern News Shop in the lobby of The New York Hilton, which was bedecked with convention paraphernalia and was one of the convention headquarters, only one item was selling heavily -- newspapers.
And for Cheryl To, the general manager at Keens Chophouse on West 36th Street, an expenditure on advertising, mailings to delegates, and elongated hours translated to just 20 and 30 extra lunches and dinners served each day. "I was hoping we'd get bowled over. It's been calm," she said.
Many delegates said their lack of spending could be explained in two words: high prices. Some New York Yankee T-shirts at Eastern News cost more than $30. And as Natalie Davis, a delegate from Birmingham, Ala., pointed out, "To advertise a special at lunch for $19.92 is not, for many people, a bargain."
Betty Lawrence, executive director of the Metropolitan Taxi Cab Board of Trade, which represents 18 large cab fleets, said taxi business remained flat, possibly because visitors got free passes to public transportation in one of their bags of gifts, many of which were handed out at free buffets to which they were transported by free shuttle buses. "My drivers haven't seen what we had hoped to see," she said. "We had hoped it would turn around the summer."
 
An Expanding Prediction
 Gray Line New York Tours, which provided shuttle transportation for the convention, reported that its usual tour business suffered, falling off by about 15 percent.
"The convention displaced some regular leisure travel people who'd be here in town," said Charles J. Flateman, the company's president. In fact, initial indications are that although roughly 20,000 rooms were rented in connection with the convention, boosting the hotel industry during a traditionally slow period, occupancy was still just under 70 percent.
 
Return Business Expected
 The city based its projections for the Democratic Convention on a 1989 consultants' report for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center which estimated that the average trade show visitor spent $290 a day. Accounting for inflation, the city estimated that the typical convention visitor would spend $353.
However, besides receiving many freebies, political convention visitors -- particularly Democrats, according to political observers -- tend to spend less than trade show visitors. In addition, hundreds of delegates and members of the press were from the metropolitan region and did not spend money for hotels. And the cost of hotel rooms has fallen by 20 percent since the period measured in the Javits Center report.
Joseph J. Taggart Jr., 26, a Clinton delegate from Leon, Kan., has many exciting memories of his first visit to the city. There was the cab ride to Macy's. ("I didn't know if I was going to live. I think drivers here think horns are magical.") There was the man in the turban whom he tried to photograph and who chased him through Times Square. ("I don't know who he was or what he was bothered by.") There were the bright lights, the tall buildings, and the feeling of safety.
Until the end of the convention, Mr. Taggart had not spent extravagantly. A major purchase, a bell with a picture of New York City on it for his mother, was from Woolworth's. But he planned to spend more on gifts for his five sisters.
"I'll tell you what," he offered. "I wouldn't mind coming back again."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph A. Taggart Jr., a convention delegate from Kansas, found New York safe and exciting during his first visit. Although the delegates did not spend as much as officials had hoped, many expressed desires to return. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Budget Crisis Forces California Colleges to Bar the Doors

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 18

 BODY:
Like millions of others of his generation, Jorge Garcia took the well-trod road to success in California, parlaying a nearly free public-college education into a good job. Now he must tell those who would follow that the road is closing in front of them.
He grew up in the 60's, the golden days of California's ascendancy. That was when Mr. Garcia, a farm worker's son in the San Joaquin Valley, could pick peaches for 50 hours to earn the $50 needed to enroll at Fresno State College, and then obtain a bargain doctorate at the University of California. Today he is dean of humanities here at California State University, Northridge, where he has had to cut nearly a third of his teaching faculty and tell angry students that many classes will not be available this fall. 
 Similar grim tales are told all across California as its once-flush public institutions face near collapse in the face of the state's gravest budget crisis since the Depression, its public revenues no longer able to support the public services and investment in freeways, dams and aqueducts at the core of the state's historic prosperity. At public schools, universities, state parks, hospitals, AIDS hospices, public libraries, welfare centers and more, staff and clients are preparing for the worst.
 
Cutting $200 Million
 The latest sign of mounting crisis came Friday in San Francisco. The regents of the nine-campus University of California, bracing for a cut of more than $200 million, or 10 percent of its state support, approved an early-retirement plan for senior faculty members, asked staff members to reduce working hours voluntarily and began to prepare for layoffs later this year.
The 107-campus, 1.5-million-student California Community College system recently began to limit admissions for the first time. And some units of the 20-campus California State University system have closed admissions for spring and even plan to eliminate entire academic departments.
"We've lost our ability to meet the demand," Dean Garcia said, before rushing to yet another crisis meeting with the campus president, James W. Cleary.
"This is the worst budget crisis I've seen in my entire career," said Mr. Cleary, set to retire next month after 23 years as Northridge's president. "We are on the borderline between quality and non-quality."
The quandary has called into question the historic definition of California, an inviting land where the streets were figuratively paved with gold. The state offered the ultimate commonweal, a place where the highways were not turnpikes with tollgates but freeways that were free, where going to college at public expense was almost as much a birthright as the warm sun and surf. Some have begun to ask if the state should continue to be so generous.
 
Living on i.o.u.'s
 The state has been without a budget since July 1 and has been paying its bills with i.o.u.'s, or registered warrants, a total of $788 million worth issued by last Thursday. A major crisis looms on July 31, the next payday for state employees, when banks say they may no longer honor the warrants. Already, two credit-rating services in New York have downgraded ratings for California bonds: Moody's Investors Service to Aa1 from Aaa, and Standard & Poor's to A+ from AA. They cited the deadlock between the Democratic-led Legislature and Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, over bridging the $10.7 billion gap in the budget.
Even under the most optimistic outcome of that struggle, public services face severe cutbacks. The 321,900-student California State University system has cut 5,000 class sections since last year, reduced enrollment by 7,000 and raised student fees 40 percent. Now it is seeking early retirement for faculty members and preparing to lay off about 2,200 of its 38,000 employees, mainly nontenured and part-time faculty members.
Notice has been given that no students will be accepted for the spring semester at four campuses: San Jose State and Sonoma State and the California State Polytechnic campuses at Pomona and San Luis Obispo. The Pomona campus has gone to a four-day workweek for the summer, and San Diego State has planned to eliminate nine academic departments, including anthropology, health sciences and aerospace engineering.
"Nothing is sacred, nothing is protected," said Chancellor Barry Munitz at the state university headquarters in Long Beach. "The biggest problem is uncertainty: we have no assurances what we can pay for." He said he was determined to avoid across-the-board cuts, giving priority to keeping the doors open to the non-elite and the immigrants who have come to depend on the C.S.U. system, and to protecting the next generation of faculty.
 
Making Bad Worse
 In Sacramento, the chairman of the state Assembly's Higher Education Committee echoed that concern. "This could not come at a worse time, because the California economy needs more college graduates and the demographics are changing to nonwhite," said the chairman, Assemblyman Tom Hayden of Santa Monica. "The state government is saying, 'Too bad, we are pulling up the drawbridge,' just when minorities are expecting to enter higher education."
But lobbying efforts by the colleges have been undercut by recent disclosures that the University of California regents privately approved a $2.4 million retirement package for President David Gardner, who leaves Oct. 1, and set up a $100 million fund to subsidize home mortgages for faculty and top executives.
The budget crisis has also reinforced the arguments of those who maintain that California should not subsidize the educations of middle-class and wealthy residents. Even with the recent steep fee increases, for example, a year's tuition at the California State campuses is only about $1,400, a bargain by national standards.
"Over the next five years we will see a very different public higher education system," said John J. Kirlin, a longtime student of California government who is a professor of public administration at the University of Southern California. He urges a change to Michigan's system, with much higher tuition but also more aid for the needy. "If we did that, the schools would continue to grow and students would have more incentive to finish their degrees in a timely fashion," he said.
 
Sapping a Campus's Vitality
 Last August, Governor Wilson's Secretary of Child Development and Education, Maureen DiMarco, wrote to Mr. Hayden that the administration and Legislature "must be free to consider significant changes in higher education policies to accommodate reduced funding bases."
For now, reduced financing means big trouble at the Northridge campus here. From a small satellite campus of Los Angeles State College begun in 1956, it has grown with the vast San Fernando Valley it serves into a major university with 30,441 students and 1,521 faculty, the 39th-largest university in the United States. The 353-acre campus, studded with fan palms and oleander, draws students from the nearly endless suburbs of Los Angeles that stretch from Burbank to the rural reaches of Ventura County.
Reflecting the fast-changing population of the area, the college has major programs in Mexican-American, Afro-American and other ethnic studies. It is also home for the National Center on Deafness, a highly regarded program that incorporates deaf students into regular classes.
Uncertain what it will be able to spend, the college recently notified 158 faculty members that they would be laid off or given early retirement. Together with temporary faculty who will not be rehired this fall, that means a loss of 375, or nearly a fourth of almost 1,500 who taught last year. Officials are assuming that the system will lose from $100 million to $120 million, 10 percent or more, of its state support.
 
Losing the Arts
 "The young and dynamic teaching force will leave the state; that's what will happen to California," said Louise Lewis, a professor of art history who is the faculty president. The cuts have fallen very unevenly, mainly affecting departments like art and music that depend heavily on part-time teachers like Mindy Lorenz, who has been teaching a heavy load of four classes a semester in art history.
"I have not known for a good four weeks if I had a job or if I was going to be paid," Ms. Lorenz said.
Last week, the new freshman class members were on campus for orientation, but no one could tell them what the future held for their educations. "Fees are going up 40 percent, and the university's budget is being cut," said Sal Damji, an engineering student who is the student-body president. "We are paying more and getting less."

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
Mirabile Dictu And Wonderful Also to Hear

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
During a break in negotiations on Friday with state legislators, the man who delivered the oratorical jewel of the Democratic convention walked upstairs to the battered third-floor pressroom, shot a little pool on the reporters' table, then settled into a ratty office to discuss his gift.
Like most conventions, last week's was dominated by easy, tub-thumping speeches: politicians who postured for applause after each mundane sentence, who chronicled their personal travails to fill the bathos tub, who led grown men and women in inane chants. 
 "Cheating," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said. "During a speech, I shake off applause. I was talking to Bill Bradley last night after the speeches. Two or three of the best speeches I ever made, I got not a single round of applause until the end. I gave a Lincoln Day speech with Governor Thompson in Illinois. Nothing, and then a standing ovation. Bill Bradley says, 'That's it, no cheap applause lines, you're writing thoughts.' I don't do the cheap lines."
Mr. Cuomo's nominating speech for Bill Clinton hit all themes dear to Democrats, often without directly mentioning them. He never said "pro-choice" or "school prayer." He talked of a Republican attempt "to tell us what God to believe in and how to apply that God's judgment to our schoolrooms, our bedrooms and our bodies."
He has the writer's gift for making ideas visible: children hearing gunfire before they hear an orchestra; Captain Bush lost at sea, in search of imperceptible economic undercurrents; the quiet catastrophes, the rich hiding behind their walls with polo mallets. (He was going to use golf clubs, but too many Democrats golf.)
He didn't have to recite scripture, like Governor Clinton and Al Gore, to tell you he was religious; a passing reference to the "loaves and fishes" of trickle-down economics did it. He didn't tell you he was educated; just used a little Latin, "mirabile dictu" (wonderful to tell). "You write that in for guys like Bill Buckley." With a small ad lib, he included a wing of the party that felt bruised: "Jesse is right. They are our children."
At convention's end it was plain. Governor Clinton and Senator Gore are speechmakers. Governor Cuomo is the party's orator.
For the press corps that covers him daily here, he can be impossible, a maddening nitpicker when challenged. But fanatic attention to detail is where lovely writing comes from. He started Wednesday's speech 10 days earlier, jotting thoughts on note cards. "You go to sleep thinking about it, you think in your sleep and wake at 3 A.M. thinking about it. You're trying to dislodge your mind from the place it's stuck." And then, "probably because of terror," you see where to start. "Oh, my God, here it was, and you don't stop then. You know you have it. If that happens I can write 10 to 12 hours." He wrote in longhand, giving it to a friend to type. The Governor can't type.
"You write a speech different than an Op-Ed piece. I end a lot with periods or pauses or slash marks that aren't really sentences. I write in talking English. Bill Bradley writes a speech the way you write an essay and read an essay." Then rewriting. He had a Quayle joke: "Bill Clinton and I agree on all the important things -- including how to spell potato," but cut it. "Too cheap." He read parts to his son Andrew and aides. He almost dropped the supply-side section, but several of them urged keeping it. Commentators later said that it was the first time anyone made a major audience understand that policy's failings.
Tuesday night he didn't sleep. "Your head's so full." Noon on Wednesday he rehearsed for a small group. Clinton aides asked him to do more to link the two of them. That afternoon he tied the poor of Hope, Ark., to the cities' asphalt streets. He added a dozen Clinton references, including, "I want to march behind Bill Clinton in a victory parade."
Delivery is the easiest part. Like great teachers, writers, athletes, the orator has something magic inside that even a man who works as hard as Senator Bradley can't reproduce if it isn't there at birth.
There was nothing of Mario Cuomo's personal life in his speech. In contrast, nothing was too personal for Governor Clinton, if it was useful, not his mother's breast cancer or Chelsea's birth. (Of course, there was no point going into nonuseful suffering, such as Ms. Flowers.)
"The lawyer, the advocate, doesn't talk about himself," said Governor Cuomo. "He talks about his client." When the speeches ended, many felt the advocate was a size larger than the younger client he spoke for.
"No regrets," said Governor Cuomo. As he'd said all week, he was "four steps from wistful." And with that, the orator left to talk to the Albany press corps about the fiscal bailout for Nassau and Suffolk counties.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Japan Confronts Global Warming

BYLINE: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Japan has adopted one of the world's most demanding programs to control global warming. It sets short-term goals and looks a full century ahead. It envisions brilliant technical fixes to capture heat-trapping greenhouse gases and bravely contemplates massive restructuring of cities and industry to lessen the threat.
But is the program real -- or mostly a charade? 
 Officials in the Bush Administration, sore at being portrayed as the world laggard in confronting global warming, incline toward the latter view. They believe the Japanese, in a craven appeal for environmental applause, are promising far more than they can deliver.
But close up, the picture looks mixed. Japan's program is farsighted -- and less than it seems.
For the coming decade, Japan's effort to curb emissions of carbon dioxide, the chief greenhouse gas, is more demanding, on paper, than the American program. The Japanese have set a goal of capping carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2000, whereas the Bush Administration has opposed caps and timetables, relying instead on a range of programs to reduce emissions.
There is no great virtue in a cap. This page, in fact, has argued that a cap could prove needlessly costly. But the cap can also be seen as evidence of determination, and for that, the Japanese deserve high praise.
The Japanese commitment, however, is much less rigorous than generally understood. Japan has not embraced the goal sought by many environmentalists and some European countries -- to hold total national emissions of carbon dioxide in the year 2000 to the levels emitted in 1990. It has made a non-binding pledge only to hold per capita emissions to 1990 levels, allowing room for emissions to grow as population grows.
That might not accomplish any more than the Bush Administration programs. Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, using population estimates put forth when the pledge was made, says it will allow a 6 percent rise in total emissions. If that is the case, then Japan's emissions will rise just as much as the Bush Administration predicts American emissions will rise. The Japanese environmental agency, using more recent population projections, says emissions can rise only about 3 percent.
The Japanese have also said they will make efforts to stabilize total emissions. But it seems doubtful that current policies can reach even the easier goal. Japan's energy efficiency has leveled off. The Government has shrunk from a carbon tax. And the plan relies heavily on building 40 new nuclear plants over 20 years, a rate that may be hard to sustain over growing opposition.
When the decade ends, observers may well find little difference between the results achieved by Japan and the U.S. Where the two countries differ sharply, however, is on the severity of the global warming problem and the probable need for drastic solutions.
Many Bush Administration officials are skeptics who shy away from corrective action, fearful that it might cause economic harm. By contrast, top bureaucrats and academics in Japan seem convinced that global warming will become serious and require drastic measures, providing profits through new technologies and efficiencies.
What's truly surprising is their extremely long view. Japanese officials say, rightly, that it doesn't make much difference if Japan misses its year 2000 goals. If global warming is a long-term threat, it will have to be met by long-range policies.
MITI has actually issued a 100-year blueprint that lays out, decade by decade, the key steps needed. The plan emphasizes technological breakthroughs. A new research institute is already trying to culture microorganisms to remove carbon dioxide from the air and is looking for processes to remove it from flue gases. Top officials talk matter-of-factly about restructuring industries and cities to reduce the generation of greenhouse gases.
Whether all that will be necessary remains uncertain. But there is little question that, if global warming does become severe, Japan will be in a better position than the United States to cope with it.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Mere 141 Words

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Of the 4,250 words in Bill Clinton's acceptance speech, a grand total of 141 were devoted to international concerns. Those who nodded off briefly at the 40-minute mark of the 54-minute oratorical stew might have have gotten no taste at all of a potential Commander in Chief.
It is hard to avoid drawing two conclusions from this horrendous slighting of foreign affairs: The Democratic Presidential nominee believes that the subject hardly matters to Americans. And he seems to be running away from this unfamiliar international arena for fear of blundering. 
 He should re-examine both judgments.
First, Americans are now far more worried about domestic than foreign affairs, and should be. But they also have to be reassured that Mr. Clinton understands the world sufficiently to be entrusted with their security.
Americans have almost always treated foreign policy as a metaphor for leadership. President Bush knows this full well, and will push his advantages with the voters here. If Mr. Clinton does not take the time to define himself on world politics, Mr. Bush will do the job for him.
International issues were unimportant to the Democratic primaries. And this may have lulled Mr. Clinton and his advisers into thinking the general election will be no different. But neither the Arkansas Governor nor any of his closest aides have ever worked at the center of a national campaign. They soon will discover that Mr. Bush and the press will not leave the world alone. Mr. Clinton's own antsiness about slipping on a foreign banana peel suggests that deep down he grasps this.
Second, Mr. Clinton's limited background on international issues ought to make him wary. But based on the little he has said thus far, he should have the confidence to say more.
Most of the 141 words he uttered Thursday showed good instincts. "I know well that the world needs a strong America," he said, "but we have learned that strength begins at home." An excellent premise that seems to elude Mr. Bush. "The end of the cold war permits us to reduce defense spending while still maintaining the strongest defense in the world." Fine again. He also rightly stressed using force "when necessary," preserving the "common environment" and promoting global democracy and growth.
The two speeches in which he elaborated on these themes were both of high quality. But they left a lot of tough questions to answer and holes to fill.
Mr. Clinton shamelessly dances around free-trade issues. Sometimes he backs free trade; sometimes "fair trade," a code for protectionism. In his acceptance speech, he spoke of "exporting products, not jobs." Code again. To Mr. Bush's great credit, he champions free trade to create jobs.
Mr. Clinton's ambivalence here is particularly distressing because of the centrality he attaches to economics in world politics. He even talks of money-mighty Japan as America's most important partner. If global economics is so crucial, and it is, he ought to give at least one speech saying what he has in mind.
Nor has he been much more specific about how he intends to cut military spending and remain the world's strongest power. He says he would reduce the $300 billion defense budget by $100 billion, but his proposed cuts do not add up to that total.
This is something Al Gore, the Vice Presidential candidate, might have tackled on Thursday. He is an expert. But he, too, skirted national security in his acceptance speech. Of his 2,565 words, a mere 120 dealt directly with world politics.
Mr. Gore's main foreign offering was rather apocalyptic: "The task of saving the Earth's environment must and will become the central organizing principle of the post-cold war world." What on earth does that mean, and how on earth would a Clinton-Gore Administration pay that bill?
The dynamic duo will hurt their campaign if they focus almost exclusively on domestic affairs and virtually brush off international matters. Mr. Bush and the press will knock their heads off.
It may be hard for a team now running more than 20 points ahead in some polls to see this punch coming. But it will come, and land. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore's scant words about revolutionizing national security policy won't protect them, or reassure Americans.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 332 words

HEADLINE: Population Growth Imperils the Planet

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"There's Plenty of Room" (letter, June 30) by Sheldon L. Richman, senior editor of the Cato Institute, merits serious questioning on several counts. 
 It is meaningless, if not outright dangerous, to suggest that population density is unimportant and that there should be no concern about population pressure because the average density per square mile in the world is low. Comparative density figures are useful in describing population distribution, but they take on meaning only related to the opportunities and limitations of the ecological and economic environments.
Mr. Richman dismisses any limitation to population growth that might be caused by resource depletion by claiming that "every resource gets cheaper every year." Are we to conclude that there is a never-ending supply of oil, gas, coal, arable land, tropical forests, fish?
He cites areas and spots with high densities that are well off economically, presumably indicating that high densities are of no concern anywhere. One wonders, however, how many Hong Kongs, Singapores and Taiwans can be expected to achieve viability in the world.
More important, Mr. Richman ignores the evidence of population pressure, including widespread soil deterioration; increasing desertification; landlessness; food shortages, hunger and malnutrition; unemployment and underemployment in rural and urban areas. Perhaps he should look at such cities as Lagos, Calcutta, Kinshasa and Mexico City before reaching the conclusion that high densities are no problem.
To state, as Mr. Richman does, that there is no evidence that population growth impedes economic growth is misleading. Present population growth rates in many African countries, for example, are more than 3 percent a year, while most countries are experiencing growth rates in national incomes substantially lower than that.
 
WILLIAM A. HANCE
Nantucket, Mass., July 3, 1992
 
The writer is professor emeritus of geography, Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Why This Recession Is Different;
A Debt Puzzle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We hear much these days about the Federal debt as a percentage of gross national product. In 1944, under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, it was 110 percent of G.N.P. We won World War II, and there was very little inflation. Today it is only 65.6 percent of G.N.P. We also hear much about Federal spending as a percentage of G.N.P. In 1944, under Roosevelt, spending was 42.1 percent of G.N.P. Today it is only 24.5 percent of G.N.P. 
 Both the Federal debt and spending are lower compared with G.N.P. than they were under Roosevelt in 1944. But we have the highest unemployment since the Depression. What's wrong?
 
BEVERLY KITCHING
Springfield, Ill., July 1, 1992
 
The writer retired as professor of economics, City Colleges of Chicago.

HEADLINE: Dream Team Nightmare

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
I am troubled when I think of the nationalistic gloating that will surely unfold, expecially around the Dream Team, in Barcelona, Spain. 
 There are many disturbing contradictions connected with basketball (as in football and baseball) and its collegiate minor leagues: an increasingly racist and violent white population cheers on a predominantly African-American team -- as in the National Basketball Association arenas; the silence of these superstars about the social and economic deterioration in the nation; the white backlash against affirmative action for youth of color who simply wish an education that ignores the affirmative-action aid for young men and women who are exploited for their athletic ability; the anticipated victory celebration with a president whose policies have meant increased misery for millions, especially people of color, and on and on.
When the Dream Team victory euphoria wears off, as it surely will, the deep divisions we have as a people will remain -- in the South Bronx, South-Central Los Angeles and Ithaca.
 
JOHN MARCIANO
Ithaca, N.Y.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 9; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2206 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Movies of Iran Struggle for Acceptance

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran

 BODY:
THERE ARE NO NUDE SCENES. In fact, men and women rarely ever touch. There are no "Lost Weekends," featuring Iranian Ray Millands, no alcoholics -- no alcohol -- no "Saturday Night Fevers," bars or discos. There is, in short, nothing remotely resembling sex, drugs or rock-and-roll.
But despite the daunting limitations imposed by the Koran, or the Islamic Republic's literal-minded interpretation of Islam's holy book, Iranian film is flourishing. Some 13 years after the revolution that toppled the Shah and his Western-oriented regime, Iran is turning out a growing number of impressive, small-budget, quintessentially Iranian movies. They explore with candor that often borders on bitterness the searing social, economic and personal problems of ordinary Iranians in post-revolutionary Iran. Overcoming the obstacles of censorship at home and suspicion abroad, these films have increasingly been winning critical acclaim and prizes at international film festivals. 
 "In 1990 alone, we had 330 entries in international film festivals, and we won 11 first prizes," said Sayed Mohammed Beheshti, the director of the Farabi Cinema Foundation, the Government-sponsored but quasi-independent group whose mission is to increase the quantity and quality of Iranian films.
Richard Pena, the program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center in New York, called contemporary, or post-revolutionary, Iranian film "one of the most exciting in the world today." In November, the Film Society will present a series of 15 to 20 contemporary Iranian films, a first for the society.
Much is still taboo in Iranian cinema -- women with uncovered hair, women singing on screen or dancing. And Government censors still ban films that they conclude openly challenge the legitimacy of the Islamic republic, of rule by Moslem clerics and of the country's numerous religious martyrs -- first and foremost among them, the revolution's leader, the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, whose stern, unsmiling visage continues to adorn all Government offices and many a private home. But as the revolution has evolved, many of the most fundamentalist and dogmatic film censors have been replaced by younger, better educated men and women, who at least by comparison with their predecessors, are more tolerant.
If post-revolutionary Iranian film is slowly winning international recognition, its success is attributable to the fierce determination of a handful of talented Iranian film makers who have courageously tested and stretched the cultural restrictions of this dour regime. It is also due in part to Mr. Beheshti and his foundation's dogged, politically savvy efforts to promote movies that are original, nonpropagandistic and, in Iranian terms, daring.
Today, about 30 percent of Iranian films are Government-made, work with which Mr. Beheshti has no involvement and for which he has even less regard. But his foundation provided assistance -- such as long-term, low-interest loans, subsidized film and studio facilities -- to about 35 percent of the 70 Iranian movies made by the private sector in 1991.
"Given Iran's image abroad, we've had a hard time overcoming the shock generated by our requests to participate in festivals," said Mr. Beheshti, a 40-year-old, German-speaking film buff who, unlike most Iranian officials, does not sport a beard. "We had four years of correspondence with the Germans before they let us participate in the Berlin festival. It was the same with the Italians. We finally got a booth at the Milan festival in 1986. But few people were willing even to watch our films then. Most just ate a few pistachios and left. So it has been tough persuading people that our films are not just about people praying."
In some ways, the evolution of the Iranian film industry mirrors that of the society itself. For one thing, there has always been censorship in Iran; what has changed is who the censors are and what they censor for.
The first modern Iranian film was produced in 1964, Mr. Beheshti says. After that, the industry grew rapidly, though always under the watchful eye of the Shah's so-called exhibition board. The Shah's regime preferred syrupy melodramas and action films, as did the Iranians, who flocked to the movies, then and now among the cheapest forms of entertainment. But artistic film makers, those who strived to make movies that highlighted the plight of the poor or contained a whiff of criticism of the regime, suffered under the Shah. Their films were often banned. A few had to choose between not making movies and exile.
In the first years after the 1979 revolution, just a few movies were made. Film makers and intellectuals in general were hampered not only by the post-revolutionary chaos and the bloody power struggle that followed the fall of the Shah but also by the Iraqi invasion of Iran only a year after the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had come to power.
Despite the chaos and the war, the Farabi Foundation was established in 1983, and the number of films being made increased immediately. That year, 23 movies were produced. In 1984, the number rose to 57; in 1991, when Iran produced 70 films, the total almost equaled its pre-revolutionary record of 90 films in 1972.
But what delights Mr. Beheshti, he says, has been the improvement in quality and the expansion of subjects now being critically addressed. Today film makers are exploring such politically sensitive topics as the Iran-Iraq war. For example, "Flight Into the Night," made in 1985, is about a group of Iranian soldiers who were either severely wounded or killed after being surrounded by their Iraqi counterparts. "There is no glory or victory for these men," Mr. Beheshti said. "There is no triumph at all in this movie."
Over the objections of the Supreme Defense Council office that was responsible for rallying public support for the war, the film was shown, in Iran and abroad. So was "Marriage of the Blessed," Mohsen Makhmalbaf's savage portrait of the effects of the war, made in 1989. Haji, the film's hero, is a combat photographer who keeps having flashbacks. When he tries to document for his newspaper the misery of the poor in the slums of south Teheran, the only photo the paper publishes is one of a sunflower.
At the office, Haji encounters Youssef, a friend who served at the front with him. Youssef's face has been partially blasted away in battle. "Haji," the mutilated veteran importunes the shocked photographer, who instinctively shrinks away. "Don't you recognize me?"
Haji's marriage to the daughter of a wealthy war profiteer also begins traumatically when the groom, repelled by the lavishness of his own marriage feast, starts ranting about his father-in-law's corruption. "He will defeat the revolution from within!" Haji screams at his host and his stunned bride. "The oppressors are coming back." Haji's subsequent confinement in an isolated, eerie hospital ward filled with other shellshock victims forced audiences to face the unseen victims of the war that the Ayatollah Khomeini chose to continue years after Iraq sued for peace.
"I wouldn't say that Makhmalbaf's films question the revolution itself," said Mr. Beheshti, when asked about the savage attacks in the Iranian press on the director. "I think he's questioning parts of it," he added diplomatically.
But even highly respected directors like Mr. Makhmalbaf, who comes from a devoutly religious family, have run afoul of the censorship system, which under the clerics censors first the scripts and then the final product. The fate of a recent Makhmalbaf film, "The Time to Be in Love," illustrates the often deadening effect and erratic results of persistent clashes between pragmatists and radicals on Iranian culture, and on movie making in particular.
The film, which focuses on a love affair between a married woman and a stranger, was screened and highly praised last year at the Fajr film festival, Iran's own annual festival of Iranian and foreign films. But after radicals savagely attacked the Ministry of Islamic Guidance for approving a movie about the mortal sin of adultery (even though it shows no sex), the Ministry suppressed the work.
One of Iran's best films in recent years and one of the few to be shown commercially in the United States, "Bashu, the Little Stranger," was withheld for three years before its release in 1990, according to its director, Bahram Beizai.
"Bashu" is the story of a 10-year-old stowaway who is adopted by a woman in another part of Iran after his parents are killed and their village destroyed by Iraqi bombs. It was called "small, simple and quietly effective" by Janet Maslin in The New York Times and "pure joy" in The Los Angeles Times.
But Iranian censors did not initially share the enthusiasm, despite the fact that the 54-year-old Mr. Beizai is among the country's most admired directors. "Ershad, the Ministry of Islamic Guidance, objected to the film not only because it was perceived as being antiwar but also because the central character was a woman," he said in an interview at his home in a Teheran suburb. "To this day, publicity posters for the film show Bashu, and not Susan Taslimi, who plays Nai, the main character," he complained.
A few years later, Miss Taslimi decided to go into exile in Sweden. Mr. Beizai says the move reflects the hardships that actors and film makers face in the Islamic republic. Miss Taslimi, whom Mr. Beizai calls one of Iran's finest actresses, came under pressure soon after the revolution to play characters who were Islamically correct. Specifically, revolutionary actors and actresses were expected to take parts in plays that often portrayed various other nations as animals -- mice, cats, dogs. But Miss Taslimi refused, protesting in a letter to the director of the National Theater that this was demeaning for performers. She was fired, Mr. Beizai said, although he continued to use her.
In 1981 Mr. Beizai made "The Death of Yazdgerd," about the death of the last Persian king before the Arabs came to Iran in the seventh century. It has still not been released. "The film really had three strikes against it," said Mr. Beizai, who sports a gray, neatly trimmed mustache. "The censors did not feel that the film's position on Islam was clear. Second, they objected to the fact that the film was made shortly before all women were required to have their hair covered in public. And three, the film's central character was a woman, and that woman was Susan."
When Mr. Beizai made his next movie, "Maybe Some Other Time," the Ministry said it would authorize the script, provided he did not cast Miss Taslimi in the lead role. Mr. Beizai refused. "She was so nervous making it that she broke out in hives," he recalled. "But she was committed to the project and we persevered. However, she left Iran soon after that."
In March, the film was shown on Iranian television, to wide acclaim.
Students of Iranian cinema say that in some ways, the Islamic revolution has not dramatically affected art films. "Before the revolution, there were only four or five directors making intelligent, artistically valuable films," said one film devotee. "Today it is those same people -- Makhmalbaf, Beizai, Darioush Mehrjui and Abbas Kiarostami -- who are still making those films."
Both Mr. Beizai and Mr. Beheshti say they are most encouraged by the new young directors who are finding creative ways of circumventing some of the more unwieldly thematic restrictions and requirements. "Iran is now turning out some 15 first-time directors each year," said Mr. Beheshti.
Mohammad Atebbai, of the Farabi Foundation, agreed. "Many of them deal quite candidly with social and political problems, despite the limitations," he said.
Those limitations are not merely political or religious. They are also financial. "We couldn't make 'Star Wars' or 'Terminator 2,' " said Mr. Beheshti. "They are too technologically sophisticated and expensive for us to produce. The average Iranian film costs $130,000."
But Iranians do see virtually every American movie. While videocassette recorders are illegal in Iran, they are omnipresent in middle-class households. Each week, networks of young free-marketeers deliver door to door the latest, usually pirated, videocassettes, tucked furtively under newspapers.
"Iranians, like most people, prefer American films," said one Iranian journalist. "We're pleased that our films win prizes, but what we really want to see is 'Basic Instinct.' "
No one expects an Iranian director to produce a film criticizing the revered Ayatollah Khomeini or any of the senior clerics who continue to rule. Nor do they expect to see women singing or dancing or without "hejab" or head scarves.
Mr. Atebbai said restrictions had led Iranian directors to be, as he put it, "creative." When a script recently featured a role for a Western woman, one director filmed her with a towel wrapped around her head, as if she had just emerged from a shower.
But what about epic films, such as, say, a movie about the Romans? Mr. Atebbai initially demurred and then allowed himself a tiny smile through his thick black beard. "We don't make films about the Romans," he replied.

HEADLINE: Skippering a Canal Boat

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON; JAMES BARRON is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times.

 BODY:
"IS that one of Libby's boats?" the man in the baseball cap said.
It was more of a greeting than a question. There I was, staring up at him from the bottom of what seemed like a rectangular well. I had nosed in at just the right angle and just the right speed and was hoping that he would not realize that it was my first day on the New York State Barge Canal System, the 525-mile liquid highway that traces the route of the old Erie Canal. I was determined not to slam the bow into the slimy green walls of Lock 26, east of Clyde, N.Y. 
 These days there is no Sal, and no choruses of "low bridge, everybody down" -- things on the Erie Canal are not what they used to be. Runners and bicyclists have replaced the mules that once lumbered along the towpaths. The canal itself, once the lifeline of the industrial crescent that was the Midwest, is now mostly the domain of pleasure boaters. In a week on the Erie, I saw only one big old-fashioned barge, and it was empty.
Libby's boats, as they seem to be known from Albany to Buffalo, are flat-roofed copies of 19th-century canal vessels that can be rented for $1,200 to $1,800 a week; the prices vary by season, with the highest in midsummer. Libby is Elizabeth Wiles Wing, who manages the four-boat rental fleet of Mid-Lakes Navigation Company Ltd. Her father, Peter Wiles, started the company in the 1970's as a cruise line, sailing 65-foot double-deck boats on three-day, two-night trips between Albany, Syracuse and Buffalo.
The smaller rental craft were added in the 1980's. The originals they are modeled on did not have lumbering diesel engines, electricity, showers, gas stoves, steel hulls or something called a bow thruster. But there is another difference. The originals ran on a schedule, leaving the sailors no time to bike along the towpath, buy tomatoes at a farm marvel at how the landscape matches the palette of the Hudson River School or borrow a newspaper from a locktender to find out what movies the local theater was showing.
Every fourth-grader knows that the Erie Canal came along at just the right moment in American history, opening the way to the West despite the objections of Southerners like Thomas Jefferson, who called it "little short of madness." The canal was eventually eclipsed by railroads, yet it remains a throwback to a slower world, one in which bridges are raised at the toot of a horn and lockkeepers polish brass electrical switches.
It was modernized and rerouted twice -- only short stretches of the New York State Barge Canal System follow the channel dug for the original Erie -- but the canal has not lost its idyllic cadences: rain dancing on the metal roof of a canal boat, waves lapping against the bow after the anchor has been dropped in the moonlight, herons flapping by the shore. Canal fanatics insist that the Erie is as picturesque as the Rhine; the 80 or 90 miles that a friend and I traveled last fall was a ribbon of farms and forests and picture-postcard towns like Pittsford and Spencerport and Fairport, which has an odd-looking little liftbridge that we sailed under and, later, biked over.
Our trip was scheduled to begin on a Saturday morning in early September, but in fact it began on Thursday evening at Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, where I packed my 10-speed bicycle off to Albany in an Amtrak boxcar. On Friday, I caught an Albany-bound train, claimed the bike and met my friend, who had driven in. We took the car west on the New York State Thruway, which roughly follows the east-west canal route.
The car was packed with everything we had been told we needed to take -- clothes, food and bicycles -- but we had planned to get up early on Saturday and go to the local supermarket for perishables. There wasn't time. Even though we had spent the night at a bed and breakfast in a 19th-century Greek-revival house not far from the Mid-Lakes dock, Libby was expecting us at 10 A.M. sharp. So we went straight to the pier and decided to buy our chicken and milk once we were under way.
The dock is on the Cayuga-Seneca Canal, which runs through Cayuga Lake, at 38 miles the longest of the Finger Lakes that slice through central New York State. While my friend and I lifted our suitcases and less-than-full picnic basket on board, Mrs. Wing gave the boat, the Owasco, a final once-over, checking the fuel level in the tank, test-blowing the horn, trying out the hand-held two-way radio.
You can't water ski from one of Libby's boats: top speed is about 6 miles an hour. Mrs. Wing says they are the only boats in the United States designed specifically for use on canals with locks. Other boats are built for other reasons -- Boston Whalers are made of low-maintenance fiberglass, which would not withstand a close encounter with a lock wall. So the Wileses designed and built their own sturdy vessels of steel and wood in their own local shipyard.
They are flat-sided but not quite flat-bottomed: they have a V underneath that makes steering easier. They have diesel engines because they are safe: it is hard for a first-time captain to do much damage if he or she cannot go very fast, and diesel fuel is far less combustible than gasoline. Diesels are also economical. The tanks on the Owasco hold 100 gallons of fuel; we used about a third, Mrs. Wing told us after we had returned.
Even as we marveled at the canal's turn-of-the-century engineering, we were never more than a few steps from all the conveniences of home. (Well, all but one. No dishwasher.) Somehow the Wileses squeezed everything into extremely tight spaces without leaving us feeling the least bit cramped. The galley had enough room for a dining table as well as a sink, a refrigerator and a gas stove. We cooked in the whole week. The plates, pots, pans, glasses and silverware came with the boat; so did the mugs, the salt and pepper, the aluminum foil and the dishwashing detergent. All we had to bring was the food.
The boat sleeps six, with two sleeping spaces with double beds and a reasonably comfortable fold-out couch in the galley. There are two heads, two separate bathroom sinks and a shower.
A typical day on the boat? Hardier sailors would have weighed anchor at 5:30 in the morning. I don't think we got going before 10 more than one day the whole week. With no expressway exits or change-in-Chicago airline connections to worry about, it was just traveling from whenever we started until whenever we felt like tying up for the day.
We learned everything we needed to know about piloting a canal boat in the first couple of hours, before Mrs. Wing hopped off and left the navigating to us. It may sound as though you need years of boating experience and a postgraduate course in water safety before casting off, but we had neither. That may explain why, steering with the tiller, I encountered the against-the-reflex problem I always have on British roundabouts: to go left, push the tiller to the right; to go right, push the tiller to the left.
And then there is the bow thruster, a small motor that guides the front end of the boat left or right in short bursts governed by a toggle switch next to the throttle. This is a big help when you are lining up against a lock wall. I am certain that no self-respecting barge captain would use one. I am also certain that we would not have made it through a dozen locks without it.
As Mrs. Wing was showing us the controls, I asked if she worried about turning her boats over to amateurs. "I used to," she said. "The hardest part was not to push them over and grab the tiller and save my boat. It's easier to let them hit. They'll be less likely to do it again." Of course, there is always the $500 damage deposit. (Yes, we got the $500 back after the trip.)
Locking through turned out to be the canal-boat equivalent of parallel parking, except that it takes at least two people: one to steer, the other to handle the lines. Three beeps on the horn or a call on the radio and the huge gates swing open. You glide into the lock, aiming for ladder-like rungs along the lock wall. The person who's not steering stands midships and throws a line around a rung to steady the boat in the water. Enter the lock too fast and you will overshoot the rungs. You could ram the huge iron gate at the far end. Enter at too sharp an angle and the bow will be too far from the rungs, even if the stern is nudging the wall.
When you are down at the bottom of an empty lock, the lockkeeper looms over you like Goliath, 30 or 40 feet above you, on solid, carefully landscaped ground. He flips a couple of levers. Well-oiled gears turn. The water level rises. The boat rises. The person with the line moves the rope up the ladder rungs. The locktender shrinks to normal size as you come up to the top of the lock. A three-minute, three-million gallon miracle.
PULLING away from the Mid-Lakes dock on the Owasco, Mrs. Wing took us on a practice run through a nearby Seneca Canal lock. She choreographed the locking-through like an air-traffic controller guiding a plane to a runway. We followed the instructions, cutting the throttle, edging right and left to line up with the lock and looping the line over the ladder, one rung at a time.
Once through, we turned around and practiced pulling up alongside an abandoned barge until we had the feel of the boat. Then we went through the lock a second time and turned around again -- no instructions this time, and Mrs. Wing did not grab the tiller. Then we tied up and she got off. It was the last time we would see her for a week. Or so we thought.
We chugged north toward the Cayuga-Seneca Canal's intersection with the Erie's east-west spine, in the heart of the Montezuma National Wildlife Refuge. Once mostly marshland, it was drained in the 19th century to build the Erie. Now 300 species of birds live there. We were just getting out the zoom lenses when the engine sputtered. I pushed the throttle to full power. The engine died. I turned the key, but the engine would not turn over. Then I tried to call Mid-Lakes on the two-way radio provided with the boat, but although we had been under way for less than an hour, we were out of range. We drifted from one side of the channel to the other. Eventually, a passing cabin cruiser promised to send help. After another hour, I saw a Mid-Lakes boat in the distance with Mrs. Wing at the helm. It pulled alongside and a mechanic -- the person who had in fact built our boat -- jumped aboard. He lifted our engine hatch and twisted a bolt that regulated air flow to the engine. It ran fine the rest of the week.
By late afternoon, about five hours after we left the Mid-Lakes dock, we reached the intersection with the Erie Canal and the blue-and-gold sign -- Albany to the right, Buffalo to the left. I pushed the tiller to the right, sending us left -- literally into the sunset.
There is a timelessness to this part of the canal, but time was very much on my mind. The locktenders used to be on duty until 11 P.M. To save money in an era of deficit-induced budgets, the state cut their hours back to 7 P.M. We were determined to get through the two locks leading to Clyde and tie up for the night -- there had to be a supermarket within walking distance where we could buy the perishables we didn't buy back in Cayuga. We glided into the second lock with 15 minutes to spare.
In Clyde, founded by 19th-century Scottish immigrants, we tied up under a tall bridge. After a climb up a grassy bank and a 10-minute walk through town, we found the market.
The quiet, meandering sections of canal were an antidote to the telephones, computers, round-the-clock television and harried meals that too often define everyday life in the late 20th century. The long stretch between Clyde and Lyons, where the canal cuts through old farms and fields, is a tableau from the years after the War of 1812. That was when America went canal crazy, building more than 4,000 miles of artificial waterways and opening back-country farms and out-of-the-way mills to hard-drinking, hard-driving canal barge captains. Just after sunset on our second day, the canal was a mirror, framed by tall old trees and steeples -- the churches of Palmyra, which says it has the only intersection in the country with churches on all four corners.
A few miles west are Macedon and one of the best preserved relics of the old Erie Canal -- an original lock, complete with wooden gates. Several hundred yards south of Lock 30 on the modern canal, it is remembered for a 19th- century traffic jam that began when a too-long raft tried to go through. More than 100 boats piled up on either side of the lock, waiting, horns tooting. The lock keepers walked away, leaving the boatmen to sort things out. It took three days, but when the locktenders came back, the raft and the other boats had cleared out. (Other places where the current canal path deviates from past routes are detailed in the "New York State Canal Guide: Everything the Canaller Needs to Know and More," which Mid-Lakes published last year and sells for $19.95 a copy.)
Somewhere at the bottom of the canal between Pittsford and Rochester is a yellow beach umbrella that had been shielding us from the sun. A gust of wind lifted it out of its socket near the tiller; it sank in seconds. This necessitated a mooring at noontime and a fast convenience-store search for a wide-brimmed hat and higher-power sunblock than the SPF 15 we had brought along. Instead of a straw boater, I ended up with a Buffalo Bills cap, which turned out to be a great conversation starter. If only I followed football.
We replaced the much-missed umbrella the next morning in Spencerport in a sleepy-eyed negotiation with a restaurateur. I put $21 on his bar. He put an umbrella from one of his patio tables and a large cup of coffee in our hands. Back on the boat, we lashed the umbrella to a rail to hold it in place. Then we turned around. I had figured that we needed to head back then to make it to the Mid-Lakes dock by the end of our week. But we got to the Cayuga-Seneca turnoff too soon -- we had forgotten to factor in the time we lost to the engine breakdown -- so we decided to keep going east, deep into the Montezuma refuge, where the canal laborers had had to stand waist deep in water as they built the 31 stone spans of the Montezuma Aqueduct. Part of it is still standing, like a single Roman ruin.
The next day, running at full throttle, we got as far east as Lock 24, a marvel of spit-and-polish precision in Baldwinsville. The locktender gave us an impromptu tour, leading us across the bridge formed when the doors of the lock swing shut.
Pride has always been a part of the canal's identity. Gov. DeWitt Clinton's departure from Buffalo in 1825 was signaled "by the booming of a line of cannon stationed at suitable intervals all the way across the state to Albany and down the Hudson to New York City" that took 80 minutes. So Roy G. Finch, the state engineer and surveyor, declared in a pamphlet written for the canal's 100th anniversary. Mr. Finch called it "a grand salute 500 miles long, announcing to the people of the state the completion of the most stupendous undertaking of their time."
Smitten with the Panama Canal a century later, industry was divorcing itself from the Erie. But Mr. Finch trumpeted the advantages of the New York route. "It is 10 times as long as the Panama Canal," Mr. Finch wrote. "It has many more structures than the Panama, and some of its structures are the most notable in the world."
That's typical canal hyperbole, I know, but after a week of locking through, I find it hard not to lapse into it myself.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Today, a Bach Might Have A Hard Time

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein

 BODY:
There was once a time when the early-music movement sought refuge from the contemporary musical scene in an alternative universe of shawms and sackbuts, forgotten repertory and neglected customs; it wanted little to do with ordinary musical life. Faced with the widespread absence of musical education, the movement created its own scholarly universe. Faced with the chasm between art-music listeners and contemporary music, it assembled its own audience. But last month, at the Berkeley Festival and Exhibition in California -- a biannual gathering of the players, instrument makers and scholars who have created this distinctively 20th-century movement -- the once monkish detachment was not to be found; the pressures of the present were evident in many discussions about the past.
In a symposium on Bach, for example, the subject was not historical performance practice or once common debates over style, but the vexing problems of contemporary life. The supposedly pastoral world of early music was appealed to for insights into our own more troubled era: Did Bach's career hold any lessons for the contemporary composer? Did the economic relationship between artist and patron in Bach's time suggest insights into the relationships between the contemporary performer, composer and patron? 
 The discussion left Bach seeming a little less pristine and a little more modern; but the longer I have thought about the subject, the greater the differences between his art and ours have come to appear. Bach, after all, has almost biblical status; we can still react to his music as Goethe did when he first heard "The Well-Tempered Clavier": it sounded "as if the ethereal harmony were communing with itself, as might have happened in God's bosom shortly before the creation of the world." In addition, Bach's genius was accompanied by the composer's apparently humble view of himself as craftsman. He was part of a dynasty of musicians in Eisenach whose name became generic for town musicians -- "die Baache." "I was obliged to work hard," he wrote. "Whoever is equally industrious will succeed just as well." He turned out weekly cantatas for church services, composed for a prince's court, taught schoolchildren; it took a half-century to edit his works.
What would be a contemporary counterpart to such a figure? The only composers who write so often and so routinely, who tailor their music to suit the occasion, who treat music as a craft and patrons as bosses, are those who write for television commercials or the movies. Their music serves a particular function and is often executed with great skill, but no one could associate it with ethereal harmony.
The problem is that even if we imagined a modern composer of Bachian abilities with a munificent patron, we couldn't imagine that music of the importance and range of Bach's would result. Patronage and funding are not determining factors; economics and sociology distract us from more profound issues.
Bach would have agreed. He had different ways of thinking about the world of finance and the world of music. His letters are mostly about business, about accounts, contracts, expenses. His appeals to his bosses begin with almost Uriah Heep-ish submission but end in demands and complaints. Often mistreated, he was hard-nosed, arrogant, petty.
Music was another matter. It should, he wrote, have no aim other than the glory of God and the "re-creation of the soul . . . . Where this is not kept in mind there is no true music, but only an infernal clamor and ranting." Scores bear dedicatory abbreviations like "S.D.G." (for Soli Deo Gloria: To God alone be praise) or "J.J." (Jesu Juva: Help me, Jesus). As for the soul, Bach often seemed to treat it in the cantatas as a sensuous being ruled by reason as well as by faith. His fugues are even greater demonstrations of reason's powers. Bach's themes have distinctive personalities, but they are rigorously controlled by the laws of counterpoint. Each voice seems both idiosyncratically free and indissolubly bound to others. His fugues anticipate the Englightenment; the powers of reason create a community of like minds.
What happened to these notions of higher law? A century after Bach's time, that faith in Reason and in God was less fervent. Their authority was often replaced by a new conception of Art itself. Art set its own laws; it required originality, technical advancement and often provocation. The greatest praise was the assertion that a work was ahead of its time. Great masterpieces flourished in the religion of Art.
But more recently, that aging religion has created caricatures. In the name of "advancement," some music can become private and esoteric; in the name of "provocation," a mannerist avant-garde has developed, with its own cliched conventions. For some, Politics has emerged as a new law, with political opinion providing authority and guidance.
The early-music movement hoped to turn the clock back, at least for its own performances, to find its law in historical authenticity. Now that, too, will no longer suffice. There often seems to be no law other than the marketplace: art, in this situation, can become mere commerce, its highest aim entertainment. This was a fear openly expressed at Berkeley. Bach, in contrast, had it easy.
