HEADLINE: POPULAR CULTURE;
The 'Girls' Talking, With a Black Perspective

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
Lekesia, an issue-conscious woman with dreadlocks, reflects on Mike Tyson's rape conviction: "Did he actually think he could violate someone and not be punished? Who does he think he is? William Kennedy Smith?"
Lydia, a highly educated single mother, chides Vice President Dan Quayle by telling her baby daughter, Aretha, "There is no such thing as an 'illegitimate' child, only 'illegitimate' vice presidents." 
 Monica, a light-skinned black woman with green eyes and long, wavy hair, is fed up with people insisting that she must be of mixed parentage: "Yes, I'm mixed. Try African-American."
These are among the creations of the cartoonist Barbara Brandon, whose weekly strip appears in newspapers in nearly 100 cities across the country. "I'm more concerned with being thought-provoking than funny," said the 33-year-old cartoonist. "I'm concerned with recording the experiences black women are having in this country and how some of us are feeling about them."
The strip, "Where I'm Coming From," is only three years old, but as the only black woman cartoonist who is nationally syndicated, Ms. Brandon seems poised for wide recognition. In her work she explores humorously the serious issues affecting black people and the nation as a whole, from the Clarence Thomas hearings to the Rodney King verdict and questions of equal justice; her aim, she said, is to help "mainstream folk," or whites, better understand blacks. Ideas come from listening to friends and looking at her own life as well as from watching the issue-oriented television programs that her father, the cartoonist Brumsic Brandon Jr., dubs the Sunday "blah-blah shows."
"After the riots in Los Angeles, how many folks were saying how surprised they were that that happened?" Ms. Brandon asked. "If mainstream folk understood the black perspective better, they wouldn't be surprised at the rage we're holding. We know white people because we're exposed to them, but they don't know us. If we're going to have a peaceful existence, they have to understand our perspective."
Ms. Brandon's growing success comes at a time when black women are increasingly prominent in the arts. In recent weeks, four books by black women have been on best-seller lists. Ms. Brandon's success, she acknowledges, is due in part to what she characterizes as "black people coming back into vogue."
While she has been called a racist by some whites, others have told her she speaks for them. Black women have written to say that they see themselves and their friends in her characters. Some black men have been supportive, although others complain that she is interested only in "dogging black men."
"Sometimes men get defensive and assume that, because the characters are all women, the strip is negative," said Ms. Brandon. "I tell them that before the late 60's, caricatures of blacks were drawn by white people, with big lips and pickaninny heads. Black hands were drawing black characters in the late 60's, but the mainstream press wanted those characters to be children saying things that no one had to be afraid of. After all, it was just kids talking.
"You have to give me credit for having adult characters talking about adult things," she said. "I don't try to dog black men. I'm holding up a mirror; that's what I'm doing."
The cities where the strip appears are circled in red on a map in the bedroom of Ms. Brandon's apartment in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn; she works at her father's old drawing table. Readers of such newspapers as The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, The Los Angeles Daily News and The Philadelphia Daily News turn to "Where I'm Coming From" for images of black women who, like Ms. Brandon, offer straight talk.
In her strip, which some people say resembles Jules Feiffer's work in The Village Voice, the nine "girls," as she calls them, represent a patchwork of diversity. "Part of the point is how varied we are," said Ms. Brandon. "We are not a monolithic people as black women. I can't say I'm a spokesman for all black women."
That the characters appear as heads without bodies is a statement in itself.
"We are too often summed up by our body parts," said Ms. Brandon, "and black women are at the bottom of the totem pole. I'm saying 'We have opinions,' and 'Look me in the eye and talk to me.' "
Readers are attracted to newspaper comics but, with the recession, editors have devoted less space to them. Deals with syndicates are hard for cartoonists to come by. Somehow, Ms. Brandon has broken through.
"There are still very few women cartoonists of any race," said Catherine Yronwode, the co-author of the book "Women and the Comics," noting that the first syndicated black woman cartoonist was Jackie Ormes, whose work appeared in black-owned newspapers beginning in the 1930's.
"Barbara's got a good chance," Ms. Yronwode said, "because syndicate talent scouts are looking for fresh stuff from different perspectives and new angles."
Ms. Brandon, the youngest of three children, was born in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn and raised in Newcastle, L.I. As a child she colored in silhouettes and drew borders on "Luther," her father's strip about the adventures of an inner-city child, which was nationally syndicated from 1968 to the mid-80's. According to Ms. Brandon, the strip languished when "black people were no longer in focus."
Mr. Brandon is now a syndicated editorial cartoonist for black newspapers and an Op-Ed columnist for the newspaper Florida Today. Speaking from his home in Mount Pocono, Pa., he said: "I think editors are a little more sophisticated than when I started. Back then, I don't think anybody quite knew what a black comic strip was supposed to do. You could have dipped Charlie Brown in chocolate and had chocolate-covered Peanuts and that would have done it."
After majoring in illustration at Syracuse University, Ms. Brandon applied for a job at Elan, a new magazine for black women, in 1981. The editor asked her to come up with a comic strip, and she brought in samples of what would become "Where I'm Coming From." But the magazine folded before the strip was published. Ms. Brandon became a writer at Essence, another magazine for black women, and stayed for more than five years. The strip gathered dust.
In 1988 The Detroit Free Press wrote Ms. Brandon's father to say that the newspaper was looking for black cartoonists. "He asked me if I had my stuff presentation-ready and I said, 'What does that mean? I'll do it,' " Ms. Brandon recalled.
The Free Press began publishing "Where I'm Coming From" in 1989. The Universal Press Syndicate took her on board in 1990 and plans, through its book division, to publish a collection of her strips early next year. Greeting cards, mugs and T-shirts are also in the works.
Syracuse University recently informed Ms. Brandon that it wanted to give her a "young alumni" award. Ms. Brandon -- who earns less than $25,000 a year from her strip -- told the university she would accept the award, "as long as they realize I still owe six credits."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 35; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1355 words

HEADLINE: Guidebook Games

BYLINE: By MARGO KAUFMAN; MARGO KAUFMAN is the author of "1-800- Am-I-Nuts?" a collection of travel and other essays to be published by Random House.

 BODY:
HOW did Columbus find his way to America without a guidebook? Whenever I set foot on foreign soil my life is controlled by authors I've never heard of, who for all I know consider a hot shower to be as superfluous as a silver toothpaste key.
Left to my own devices, I prefer to heed the advice of Suzanne, my travel agent, whose definition of a dump and mine are fairly congruent. But my husband, Duke, trusts only what he reads for himself. A guidebook addict, he devours them the way others gobble mail-order catalogues. Weeks before we left on a recent trip to Ecuador, he'd scrutinized three books and mapped out an itinerary, while I was still working up the nerve to finish the lengthy sections on health warnings and inoculations (the one part he refuses to take seriously). 
 "They just put those in to take up space," said Duke, who complains that I travel with more drugs than a Rexall. Ever cautious, I went to the doctor and got prescriptions to combat almost everything the book said we could contract and tetanus, gamma globulin, polio and yellow fever shots too. My sore arm wasn't the only irritation caused by the printed page.
We flew into Guayaquil, a muggy port with a malarial air and nervous residents who looked as if they'd just stepped out of a Fellini film. Suzanne had advised that we check into the Gran Hotel, which was well-run, reasonable, and had good coffee, but Duke consulted his book and chose a "top end" selection on the riverside walk, the Malecon.
I was less than enthusiastic because in Chapter One the author had revealed that he traveled with a tent.
Writers of guidebooks tend to fall into two categories. Half are Robin Leaches manques who recommend private barges up the Thames and exquisite little Alpine hideaways that cost $400 a night. The others are Peace Corps alumni who believe big old buses are more fun because of all the passengers getting on and off with their livestock; who are wowed by any accommodation more luxurious than a thatched hut. My husband favors the latter variety.
Sure enough, we wound up in a sleazy overpriced joint with dank carpet, a broken lock, and two soldiers with shotguns stationed in front of the lounge guarding a bat mitzvah.
The next morning, Duke proposed that we fly to Loja, a small town in the Southern Highlands. "We can rent a cabin in Vilcabamba," he said, speaking of a remote village in the Southern Highlands known as the "valley of longevity" because inhabitants live to be over 100. "The book says it's just a two-hour bus ride from Loja."
Guidebooks are loaded with off-the-beaten-track destinations, which frequently require a life-threatening, boat, train, and/or bus journey that I'd just as soon skip. Fortunately, luck was with me. The airline schedule had changed since our guidebook was published (funny, so had the museum schedules); there was no flight to Loja that day, so instead we went to Cuenca, an attractive colonial city on the Rio Tomebamba.
It was pleasant walking around the cobbled streets but I was on guard. The guidebook had warned about a known rapist who asked females to write letters for him to nonexistent friends. He was described as a short dark man, a description that fits a good percentage of the population. I didn't meet him, but I did meet the Devil on Calle Larga.
Duke had just struck a deal with a taxi driver to take us to see the Inca ruin of Ingapirca. He was congratulating himself on getting a good price ($20 for a five-hour excursion) when a short dark man tapped him on the shoulder. "Excuse me," said the Devil in all-too-understandable English. "I heard you bargaining. You must know you're crazy to take a cab. Just go to the bus station." Then he vanished in a puff of diesel smoke from a passing bus.
"The book said there was a bus," Duke said, looking on the map for the station. Yes, but the book also said it was a two-hour ride to the closest town; from there we had to hitch 15 kilometers to the ruins, and pray we could get a ride back. "The book said the bus is only 45 cents," he said.
I pointedly reminded him of our last guidebook inspired economy. We'd just arrived in Albufeira, in the Algarve, in Portugal, after a hellish drive from Lisbon. I wanted to check into a hotel that had earned a small house, the "quite comfortable" rating from my red friend, the Michelin Guide, the one book I totally trust. But Duke was loyal to another volume, which stated if we walked down a certain street and knocked on doors we'd find a charming room for a pittance. In fact, a harried mother with three screaming toddlers offered us a curtained-off alcove filled with laundry.
On the plus side, guidebooks do lessen my fear of the unknown, even though they force me to deal with two unknown quantities -- the country and the author. I wish there was a psychological profile at the back of the book so I could determine if we had anything in common: a limited enthusiasm for churches, for example, or a passion for folk art. Lacking such information, I have my own interpretations of key words: "peaceful," for instance, usually means in the middle of nowhere; "retreat," not on my life, and "overpriced" in my experience is not bad at all.
Which is why, in Ecuador, I was looking forward to the few days we'd planned to stay in Salinas, reputed to be "best" resort in the country, and malaria free. But at the last minute, Duke rerouted us to Bahia de Caraquez, an unspoiled (translation: primitive) port. I was nervous because the major travel agencies in Quito had never heard of Aerotransportes Bahia, the small airline our guidebook claimed flew light planes to nearby San Vincente, and it was six hours by bus but my husband was undaunted. He dismissed my concerns about malaria as "phobic."
CONFIDENT the book would be wrong again, I agreed to go. My blood froze when we returned to Guayaquil and Duke triumphantly led me to a teeny terminal with a nine-seater Cessna parked outside, where he bought $16 tickets. I made him take the seat without the seat belt and gnawed my fingernails. The plane made three heart-stopping stops before finally touching down at what I believed was our final destination -- a narrow stretch of coast with a huge runway long enough for a 747.
I sighed with relief and followed Duke down the airstrip, past a couple of pigs. Twenty minutes later, I was still behind him as we trudged along the shore in the equatorial heat toward a rickety ferry dock. The next thing I knew we were crossing the choppy half-mile-wide Rio Chone in a motorized rowboat equipped with wood slabs for life jackets. The guidebook failed to mention this part of the experience.
The rowboat landed us in Bahia de Caraquez, a shrimp farming center that appeared to have suffered touristus interruptus before developers' plans to turn it into a major resort were realized, leaving a group of unfinished high-rises. I was delighted to discover an "overpriced" hotel right on the beach. Duke incautiously swam with the ebbing tide and was nearly carried out to sea -- but it could have been much worse.
So I was surprised when I woke the next morning, and found my husband looking distressed. He'd been bitten by a mosquito in the night, having turned down my offer of insecticide, and he was worried it might be malarial. When I stopped laughing, I told him I had pills for malaria and he seemed impressed. Later, the manager assured him there was no malaria in town. "Cholera, yes," he said. "We have lots of cases." Duke had just wolfed down a shrimp omelet at a dubious- seeming cafe perched on stilts over the harbor, with no apparent source of running water, but I assured him I had pills for that too. Thanks to my guidebook, I was prepared for everything.
Maybe too prepared because soon after we returned home, Duke immersed himself in a new guidebook for Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia. Thumbing through it I note that in addition to the health hazards we risked in South America, there are warnings about meningitis, diphtheria, sleeping sickness, crocodiles and lions.
I think I'll go buy a Michelin Guide for France.

HEADLINE: JAPANESE FILMS;
Did You Read the Book?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The exaggerated, almost pathological sensitivity of some of the American press to any critical discussion of Japan is exemplified by Vincent Canby's critique of my novel "Rising Sun" and Japanese cinema ["Japan Unfolds Through Many Images," June 14]. Mr. Canby takes an American police thriller, set entirely in America and populated almost entirely by American characters, and compares it to Japanese films about Japanese characters living in Japan. It's not surprising he finds so little similarity. The question is why he should make the comparison in the first place. 
 It is doubtful that Mr. Canby read "Rising Sun," since he fails to identify the book's sole, explicit cinematic reference -- to "The Bad Sleep Well," Akira Kurosawa's 1960 film about business corruption. Many of the novel's images relate directly to that film, since "Rising Sun" is also a story about business corruption -- in this case, corruption involving American politicians and lobbyists and Japanese businessmen.
It is a matter of record that such corrupt relationships exist; several are identified in the novel, and I have included a bibliography for those who wish to know more. I wrote "Rising Sun" to provoke a discussion of such relationships, within the broader framework of America's economic decline.
Instead of that discussion, we have Mr. Canby's focus on Japan-bashing. Not only does he misconstrue my book -- which is far more critical of America than it is of Japan -- but he does not even know the meaning of the words he employs. When he says, "Not since Pearl Harbor has Japan-bashing been such big and popular business," he apparently is unaware that the term Japan-bashing was used in prewar America by apologists for Japan, just as it is today. After Pearl Harbor, Japan had few defenders in this country, and the term Japan-bashing disappeared from use. It reappeared only within the last decade or so.
In an election year when several of our President's campaign advisers are registered foreign agents for Japanese corporations, it seems entirely appropriate for Americans to inquire more closely into the meaning of these relationships, and what impact they may have on the future of the country.
 
MICHAEL CRICHTON
Los Angeles
 
Mr. Canby replies: I wasn't comparing Mr. Crichton's book to great Japanese films. I was noting that it offers a cheaply superficial portrait of a people and a culture. I did trudge through "Rising Sun," but I don't remember many "images," only a cascade of dialogue that evokes "Stover at Yale" more often than even the English subtitles for "The Bad Sleep Well." The last paragraph of Mr. Crichton's letter intrigues me. Just what it has to do with either "Rising Sun" or my essay, I don't know. But it might make a better plot than the one he whomped up for his current best seller. The most valuable thing about "Rising Sun" is its bibliography. It's a very good read.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: U.N. Official to Persevere in Talks To End Standoff Over Iraqi Arms

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 18

 BODY:
A senior United Nations official said tonight that he would continue talks on Sunday with Iraqi officials in an effort to resolve a 13-day standoff between United Nations arms inspectors and the Iraqi Government.
 The official, Rolf Ekeus, head of the commission created by the Security Council to oversee the elimination of President Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction, spent six hours today in largely futile discussions with the State Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Mohammed Saeed al-Sahaf. He agreed to continue talks on Sunday after Iraqi officials said he would meet Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz and Foreign Minister Ahmed Hussein al Simeraei. 
Mr. Ekeus had planned to depart early Sunday for New York, where he is to brief the Security Council on the outcome of his talks on Monday.
 On his arrival here Friday, Mr. Ekeus said he would warn the Iraqi leadership that it faced the risk of attack if it did not comply fully with the terms of the Security Council's Persian Gulf war cease-fire. He said he had come only to explain the Security Council's unanimous view that Iraq must give way and not to negotiate with the authorities. He delivered that warning today, and the Iraqis requested further talks on Sunday.
 For the last 13 days, United Nations arms inspectors have been keeping a round-the-clock vigil in jeeps outside the Iraqi Agriculture Ministry after they tried to gain access after a tip from a Western intelligence agent that Iraq may be storing plans for its banned ballistic missile program there.
 Iraq has refused to grant them access, saying the proposed inspection would violate its national sovereignty.
 Diplomats say the United States, Britain and France are becoming increasingly angry over Iraq's stubborn resistance to the Security Council's orders and are searching for ways of bringing home their displeasure to President Hussein, including a possible resumption of air strikes.
 On July 6, just after the standoff at the Agriculture Ministry began, the Security Council issued a statement saying Iraq had committed "a material and unacceptable breach" of the gulf war peace terms. Those terms linked a cease-fire with the destruction of Iraq's nuclear, chemical and biological weapons program as well as its efforts to build long-range missiles.
 
Relief Agencies Hampered
 The dispute over access to the Agriculture Ministry is only one of a number of quarrels between the United Nations and Iraq.
 Iraq is currently refusing to renew a humanitarian aid agreement with the United Nations that expired last month and is hampering relief agencies in their work.
 It has broken off talks on the Security Council's plan for limited Iraqi oil sales to finance food and medical imports and start compensating victims of its Kuwait invasion.
 Iraq is also boycotting the work of a commission set up to determine its frontier with Kuwait. And it is continuing an economic blockade against Kurdish-controlled areas of the country in the North as well as harassing dissident Shiite Muslims in the southern marshlands.
 In addition, United Nations personnel working here are starting to come under various kinds of attack.
 Unknown assailants have shot dead one United Nations guard working in the Kurdish North and wounded two others. The arms inspectors outside the Agriculture Ministry have faced numerous demonstrations. They have been denounced in increasingly harsh language by the local press and have had paint thrown at their vehicles and their tires slashed.

HEADLINE: Washington Journal;
Urging Blacks to Help Themselves by Buying From Each Other

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The shopping center sits on a small hill overlooking a struggling black neighborhood, a pocket of stores surrounded by poverty and neglect. A few shoppers strolling in oppressive afternoon heat stop to puzzle over a sign in one store's window: "Going out for business."
 But it is not a mistake, as a tall man in a hat and carrying a thick stack of leaflets makes clear. It is part of a new campaign by black merchants and a black business group to promote black-owned companies and to convince black consumers that they are responsible for their neighborhood's economy. 
Buy where WE are," say the leaflets, which urge shoppers to attend a unity rally today. "When you need it, look for and support African-American businesses."
 The store is having trouble all too familiar in this recession. And the owner agonizing over falling revenues is a black woman, which makes the store rare enough for a local black business group to start a self-help campaign to keep its doors open.
 Black businesses are a tiny percentage of the American economy, and Washington is no exception. But unlike other big cities, the capital has a predominantly black population, a black Mayor and a mostly black City Council. Still, the last Economic Census, conducted by the Census Bureau in 1987, shows that only about a third of all businesses here, 8,275 of 29,244, are black-owned.
 Kid-A-Rama is one of those, a children's clothing store that opened in 1984 in the shopping center in one of the city's most economically deprived neighborhoods, Northeast Washington. The owner, Doris D. Williams, who is black, studied business in college but never finished her degree. Still, she worked hard, and the small store flourished.
 "Every year I had increased sales," said Ms. Williams one afternoon this week, standing between the baby shoes and toddlers' discount T-shirts in her store. Business was good enough that in 1990 she moved to a larger store in the shopping center.
 "The decline started last year, and its been totally downhill," Ms. Williams said, her voice firm but tired. Slowly, she began to fall behind in paying taxes and creditors.
"A whole year of that made me stop and think, can I really survive in this neighborhood?" she said.
 Ms. Williams knows that like thousands of small businesses across the country, hers is a victim of the recession. But she also sees a way out, if only black consumers were more deliberate about how they spend their money. Rather than shopping at department stores, they should patronize black businesses to shore up the meager economic base in their neighborhoods, she says.
 Ed Murphy, the tall man with the leaflets, agrees. The energetic chairman of the African-American Business Association mobilized a group of black businesses to help Ms. Williams keep her store open by encouraging blacks to buy from blacks. The group's rally today drew several hundred people; dozens crowded into Ms. Williams's store, generating more revenue than she had taken in in months.
 "The whole idea is self-help," said Mr. Murphy, who opened his first restaurant in 1964. He refused to blame the hurdles black entrepreneurs have commonly faced, like racism, red-lining -- when banks would not loan money to businesses in minority neighborhoods -- and high insurance rates.
 "Our problem has nothing to do with white people, we're not mad at the Koreans, and we're not going to sit back and wait for the government to come and help us," Mr. Murphy said. "Black businesses are dwindling so fast it's shocking. This underlying problem in our community was proven in the Los Angeles riots. If more African-Americans owned businesses, we'd have more to protect."
 Though the nation is about 12 percent black, only about 3 percent of the 13.7 million American companies were black-owned in 1987, the Economic Census found. Those 424,000 black-owned companies generated just 1 percent of American business receipts -- $19.8 billion, compared with $1.9 trillion for all businesses.
 One reason for the disparity is that 94 percent of the black companies are small, mom-and-pop operations. The average income of a black business in 1987 was $47,000, but more than half had receipts of below $10,000.
 Of the black-owned businesses, a mere 189 black businesses had more than 100 employees. "That's not much of an economic base," David Abner, a professor of marketing at Howard University's School of Business, said in an interview.
 Paradoxically, most of the best and brightest black business people are being recruited into white companies rather than starting businesses of their own, Mr. Abner said.
 "For the most part, my students are management oriented towards opportunities in corporate America, not in entrepreneurship," he said.
 Still, Ms. Williams thinks the neighborhood can be persuaded to support black-owned businesses. "We have to show our children this is a black business, this is how it works, and you can do this too if you want," she said.
 The Kid-A-Rama appeal may tug at heartstrings, but it must compete with capitalist instincts.
 "I think it's a great idea and probably I'll shop here more often," Ethellen Richardson, a 55-year-old office cleaner, said earlier this week after learning that the store where she bought her granddaughter's clothes was black owned. "But I'll still look around for the best bargain."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 26, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about efforts to promote black-owned businesses in Washington referred incompletely in some editions to a professor who said many black business people were being recruited by white-owned companies. He is David Abner, a professor of marketing at the Howard University School of Business.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: AUDREY ROWE;
Helping Welfare Recipients Help Themselves

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
THE recent legislative overhaul of Connecticut's General Assistance Welfare Program, which is administered by the Department of Income Maintenance through cities and towns, has set stricter guidelines for eligibility and placed limits on the amount of time someone can receive benefits. People who abuse drugs and alcohol will have to seek treatment to qualify and people who have entered the United States illegally will not be eligible. The state will also begin an employment program to help welfare recipients upgrade their skills and find work. The guidelines went into effect July 1.
Since 1988 the number of people receiving general assistance in Connecticut increased to 34,000 from 11,000. The program, one of several components of the welfare system in Connecticut, provides monthly grants of $314 for people who are able but cannot find work and $356 for those who are unemployable because of medical problems. Audrey Rowe, the Commissioner of the Income Maintenance Department, and a member of a state welfare reform task force formed last year, said that proposals to reform the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program would be examined in the upcoming legislative session. 
 Formerly head of the Human Resources Administration in New Haven, Ms. Rowe began her career 25 years ago as a welfare caseworker in Chicago. She also served for eight years as the Social Services Commissioner of Washington, D.C. Ms. Rowe was appointed commissioner of the Income Maintenance Department in February 1991. In her office in Hartford, she spoke about changes in the general assistance program. Here are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. How has the caseload for general assistance changed?
A. Since 1988 the caseload has changed drastically. In the past it's been a core group of people who have alcohol or substance abuse problems or some disabilities, plus a small percentage of people who were unemployed as a result of changes in the economy. Now you have a much larger percentage of people who cannot find jobs and may not be entitled to unemployment compensation or who have exhausted their unemployment compensation. We also have more and more people who are able bodied but because they are substance abusers cannot hold a job.
Q. How will the employment program affect this new population?
A. Under the plan we'll try to take this recent population and move them from a welfare to an employment situation by returning them and or getting them into treatment centers, so they'll be prepared when the market opens up to move into an employment status rather than sit at home or on a street corner collecting a check.
For the people who are not quite job ready and still need some training -- that mainly includes the first wave of people who were laid off like day laborers, seasonal workers and individuals with minimal skills -- the legislature has appropriated $6 million. The money will go to towns with more than 300 clients to buy additional slots in area job training programs, provide people with the money to take English as a second language classes or complete a G.E.D. program. We're not creating a new employment system, we're simply giving people money to take advantage of programs that already exist.
Q. What about people who are job ready, have good work habits but cannot find work?
A. The legislature appropriated $7.2 million to the Department of Labor that will pay some portion of a salary for these individuals to get on-the-job training. For instance, though there's a mandate in the state to remove lead-based paint from buildings, many towns don't have the dollars to pay someone to do the jobs. This money could go to a nonprofit that has the staff and the capacity to train people to go in and remove paint. And that's a marketable skill that more and more firms and housing projects are looking for.
Another example would be a small shoe repair business. The shoemaker may like to train somebody in this trade, but he doesn't have the resources to hire anybody. The state could help pay for the period of time that the individual is in training by providing health insurance while the employer pays a minimum wage. Once a person is skilled and able to increase the marketability of the business, the owner could make him or her a full-salaried employee.
Q. Before you initiated the reforms, what was the procedure for obtaining general assistance?
A. First of all you never had to prove that you were actively looking for a job. When you first applied you had to register with Job Service and if you were employable you had to put in so many hours a week in Workfare. As long as you did that and had no other source of income you were continually eligible. You didn't have to worry about anything. We paid your rent, you could get food stamps and your medical was covered. And that was one of the system's major errors.
When I looked at general assistance in New Haven my concern was that it enabled people to continue abusing substances, avoid responsibility or doing anything to improve their life styles. And that was similar in nearly all of the state's cities.
Q. Under the new eligibility guidelines, how long can someone receive assistance?
A. Now you're eligible for assistance 9 months out of a 12-month calendar year. However, suppose you've done everything you're supposed to do and you've participated in the employment process and you just can't get a job. We will allow for a town to extend the eligibility for three more months. But towns won't extend someone more than two or three times. The point is that there is an expectation that you will leave this program in nine months and that we will help assist you to meet that expectation. If, through no fault of your own, you don't, then we will continue to assist you.
Q. What if you find someone a job through the employability program and they refuse to take it, or else they take it and then quit or get fired?
A. If we take you to the point where there's a job available and, though it may not be the job you ultimately want, it's a job that meets your skills and pays a livable wage, then you can't say "I want to wait until something better comes along." If you fail to cooperate you will be ineligible for assistance for 90 days. For most people it's better to take that job than to be without an income for three months.
Before, you came back to general assistance if you quit or got fired from a job and there was no penalty. That used to happen all the time where people would go to work, then get angry and quit, or else decide to work only winters or summers. Now you have to prove you quit for good reason or got fired unjustly before you can receive benefits. To determine that, you have to go through a hearing process. If you are denied assistance, then you can appeal the decision.
In addition, it used to be that if you didn't show up for work, you were ineligible for assistance for 30 days. Well, most people can make due without an income for 30 days. Now we've extended that time to three months and I think that will make people think twice about not cooperating.
Q. What about people who are able to work, yet have depended on general assistance for many years?
A. Our employability program will have to work aggressively with them. We will have to tell them that they can no longer do this forever, that they have to move towards economic self-sufficiency. We're saying to this population that we're going to give you the tools to take better care of your life, but if you don't want the tools, then you don't get the cash. The department is no longer going to be there to take care of you. There's going to be some people who are just going to leave, and say "I don't want to do this," but that is their choice.
Q. Can you qualify for benefits if you  abuse alcohol or drugs?
A. Not unless you agree to sign up for a treatment program. The state recently added $3 million to the Commission on Alcohol and Drug Abuse to add more treatment programs. If you refuse to get treatment, then you become ineligible for assistance until you go into treatment or verify that you are on a waiting list. If you deny you're a substance abuser and are trying to get around participating in the employment process, then you've got to go through a screening process. You'll have to have proof that you are unemployable, which means we have to see a medical report that includes a urinalysis. If there's a suspicion that an individual is a substance abuser we can ask them to prove that they are not as a condition of eligiblity.
Q. Are you eligible for assistance if you have entered the United States illegally?
A. In the past if you were a noncitizen, no matter what your status, you could qualify for general assistance. Now if you're a noncitizen you must present proof that you entered the country legally before we will grant assistance.
Q. In the next legislative session you will be examining the Aid for Families With Dependent Children program. What issues will you be addressing?
A. We need to look at the question of whether we should continue giving women more benefits if they have more children. It's a tough question because the reality is when the child gets here, if it doesn't get the care that it needs then we're going to pay more for that kid than if we had gone ahead and paid the benefit. Research also indicates that the woman makes the decision to have the baby not so she can get another grant but because she feels some man loves her and is going to marry her.
So what we need to do is create new incentives and educate these people so that they realize that as a single head of a household the likelihood of their children ever being able to move out of poverty diminishes for every child that they have. Instead of waving dollars we should give these people the resources to move out of a welfare life style.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Audrey Rowe, Commissioner of the Income Maintenance Department, and member of a welfare reform task force. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1331 words

HEADLINE: 200 Years Later, the Xhosa Fight On

BYLINE: By Geoffrey Wheatcroft; Geoffrey Wheatcroft, a columnist for several London newspapers, is the author of "The Randlords," a history of South Africa's mining magnates.

 BODY:

FRONTIERS
The Epic of South Africa's Creation and the Tragedy of the Xhosa People.
By Noel Mostert.
Illustrated. 1,355 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $35. 
 IN 1492, European sailors traveled west to America, and there began a long and, for the indigenous peoples, disastrous conflict. Five years earlier, in 1487, Portuguese ships commanded by Bartolomeu Dias had sailed south, rounded the Cape of Good Hope and landed at Mossel Bay, 200 miles east of Cape Town in what is now South Africa. Local people on the shore threw stones at the Portuguese. Dias, says Noel Mostert in this huge and enthralling book, "picked up a crossbow and shot one of the stone throwers dead: the first indigene to be killed by the white man in southern Africa." But very far from the last. Another great conflict had begun.
The aboriginal inhabitants of the Cape were simple hunter-gatherers, Bushmen and Khoikhoi (colloquially known as Hottentots), and it wasn't until 1498 that Vasco da Gama landed farther up the coast and initiated the contact between Europeans and Bantu speakers that is the subject of "Frontiers."
Although the sea route to the East transformed European trade, sailors considered South Africa deeply inhospitable. They sometimes stopped there to take water for their ghastly journey, but it was only in 1652 that the Dutch East India Company established a settlement at the Cape. Even that remained tiny: At the end of the 18th century, when the population of the United States was already four million, there were no more than 26,000 Dutch settlers at the Cape, along with maybe 30,000 African and Indonesian slaves and as many indigenous people.
The mass of Africans lived east and north. As settlers began to spread out from the Cape they approached them, and in 1702 a party of Dutch hunters ran into the Xhosa -- the nearest great African people to the Cape. There was fruitful and peaceful contact between black and white, but there was also rivalry over cattle and land, and by the early 1780's the First Frontier War had begun. Nine of these "wars" would take place over the course of nearly a century, ranging from skirmishes to bloody campaigns; their fighting and their outcome changed the face of South Africa.
These wars -- the resistance and final defeat of the Xhosa -- are Mr. Mostert's precise theme. As he notes, other confrontations in South African history -- the Zulu wars of the 1870's, the Boer war at the turn of the century -- have seemed more glamorous to previous historians. Yet the struggle in the east Cape was as important in its way, not least as a moral drama. It ended in 1857, when a final catastrophe enveloped the Xhosa. They followed prophesying voices and killed all their cattle, in the belief that two suns would rise and their enemies would be overthrown. Instead the Xhosa starved in the tens of thousands and were broken forever. Or were they?
During the course of this "hundred years' war" one significant change took place: the Cape passed from Dutch to British hands. The English (or their colonial heirs) were fighting other frontier wars at the same time; the conquest of the Xhosa is a story with obvious echoes in American and Australian history, and "Frontiers" has affinities with Dee Brown's "Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee" and "The Fatal Shore," Robert Hughes's story of early Australia. But the differences are as important as the resemblances. Far more than any indigenous American people -- enormously more than the aboriginal Australians, or for that matter their Bushmen neighbors -- the Xhosa were able to resist the Europeans on something like equal terms for generations.
THE Cape was vital to the British because of its strategic position, but they had no great hopes for it economically, even after 1820 when an English settlement was planted in the eastern Cape, close to the Xhosa frontier. "All that South Africa ever seemed to offer was the threat of being a perpetual, accumulative financial demand upon the British Treasury and the imperial military chest," Mr. Mostert writes. It was the continual object of British administrations to hold back frontier expansion. And it was the continual belief of the colonists on the frontier that they were misunderstood by London and by the colonial authorities in Cape Town, with "their callousness with regard to our sufferings from the Kaffirs" (see, too, the Declaration of Independence and its complaint about King George III and "the merciless Indian Savages").
On the British side, many of the civilians and most of the military officers concerned were incompetent to a high degree. Mr. Mostert deals harshly with Gen. Sir Harry Smith, who was only in South Africa because he had served with Wellington, and Henry Somerset, who was there because his father was Governor of the Cape. Another group that stemmed from the British connection was the missionaries. Representing the evangelical conscience, they tried to restrain the settlers and to convert the Xhosa, and ended up despised by both. All the same, it was they who made the conflict with the Xhosa a matter of serious ethical debate, which the far worse treatment of the Australian aborigines did not become.
These were some of the actors on the European side, but Mr. Mostert, who was born in South Africa and is now a Canadian journalist, does justice to the losers also, the Xhosa leaders like Ngqika, Nxele-Makanna and Sandile. Not long ago historians of empire effectively ignored the non-Europeans. Now they try to be even-handed, and Mr. Mostert treats the Xhosa as equal players in the drama. He does not sentimentalize, or only occasionally. "The indigenous languages of South Africa are among the most beautiful in the world," he says, but that seems a little sweeping. And like too many recent writers, Mr. Mostert lauds the "value common to the Bantu speakers and called ubuntu, humanness," which seems a little patronizing.
The truth as it emerges from Mr. Mostert's narrative is that the Xhosa were morally neither inferior nor superior to their foes. The Europeans were rapacious and brutal, stealing African land, shooting and sometimes hanging miscreants. But then again, hanging had something to be said for it against the preferred Xhosa method of execution, in which red hot stones were laid on the victim's body until flesh fell off bones like charred steak.
And yet there is a problem here. Hard as Mr. Mostert tries to treat both sides equally, there is no getting away from the fact that the conquerors not only had firearms, they had that other crucial advantage, literacy. A serious historian, using written sources, is bound to pay more attention to those who wrote them.
Mr. Mostert has in fact mastered a huge range of material in the 20 years or so that "Frontiers" has been in the writing, and his book is a fine work of scholarship. Occasionally one would wish that he had stood back from his sources more, simplified and even condensed. "Epic" in the subtitle is no joke: With its almost 1,400 pages, "Frontiers" fights at the weights with a telephone book. It would be wrong to say that the book is too long but, as Dr. Johnson said about "Paradise Lost," no man would ever wish it longer. The text is in parts as thick as the Transkei bush, and the book would certainly be improved by both a brief chronology of events and a biographical index. Still, those cavils could be made about some of the great Victorian novels, which "Frontiers" resembles in sweep and vigor.
Were the Xhosa broken? I asked earlier. This is the great irony of imperialism. The Xhosas had asked for nothing except to be left alone. Instead, they were conquered and exploited. But if it weren't for that conquest there could be no modern state of South Africa (whose very name is "Eurocentric"), which a largely Xhosa organization, the African National Congress, is hoping to take over under the leadership of a descendant of the Xhosa chiefs, Nelson Mandela.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1748 words

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Aspen

BYLINE: By DYAN ZASLOWSKY; DYAN ZASLOWSKY, who lives in Evergreen, Colo., visits Aspen frequently.

 BODY:
Somehow, summer is the best season to observe Aspen functioning as a wholesome little town, not just as a resort driven by skiing.
People do simple, free things: residents bike to and from work, they play in the parks and older children safely roam the pedestrian mall on their own. So much of what happens in summer occurs beneath one tent or another, but the performances and lectures account for only a portion of Aspen's magnetism. 
 For along with the town's brimming art and cultural fare, it is Aspen's unadorned outdoor beauty that draws ever more devotees.
Few vistas are as gratifying or as easy to reach as the one at the end of the short bus trip from Aspen's Rubey Park Transport Center to Maroon Lake.
From the lake one can tackle a number of hikes of varying difficulty into the back country. Meanwhile, it seems mountain and road biking threaten to overtake hiking in popularity.
After so much daytime exertion, therefore, it is a wonder anyone has the energy to attend a dance concert, a free lecture at the Aspen Institute, a performance at the venerable Aspen Music Festival, or any of the may other entertainments.
Yet they do, although the evening pace slows imperceptibly as the night air cools. After dinner and a concert, the day's last activity is often a gentle mall crawl on Hyman Avenue.
Street performers surge and the sidewalks are full of people well into the night. Some shops stay open to 10 ten pm or or later -- the collegial Explore Booksellers and Coffeehouse at 221 East Main Street is open until midnight in summer, and abuzz with browsers.
 
Events
 After 22 summers of performing in the Aspen High School Gymnasium, the DanceAspen festival now commands a state-of-the-art stage in a handsome new 548-seat auditorium at the Aspen Elementary School, a space designed to accommodate any visiting dance troupe.
DanceAspen features seven companies at its new location. Miami City Ballet will perform on Aug. 10, Hubbard Street Dance Company on Aug. 13. Tickets for the festival, which will run through Aug. 22, cost from $5 for matinees to $30 for evening performances. Tickets can be ordered by phone, (800) 933-3820, or in writing to DanceAspen, Post Office Box 8745, Aspen, Colo. 81612.
The Aspen Music Festival, in its 44th year, will run to Aug. 23. More than 130 events are presented every summer, including orchestral, chamber, opera, choral, jazz and master classes. The violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg will play pieces by Vivaldi and Dvorak on Aug. 6, the pianists Cipa and Misha Dichter will perform on Aug. 13. The season closes with a Beethoven Bash. Tickets from $5 to $35. Schedule and tickets: Aspen Music Festival, Ticket Sales, Post Office Box AA, Aspen, Colo. 81612; (303) 925-9042.
A bus costing $2 each way leaves from Rubey Park to Snowmass Village, 10 miles away, where the Anderson Ranch, an artists' colony that holds gallery exhibitions, is worth visiting. The Anderson Ranch Arts Center Annual Art Auction is Aug. 15; (303) 923-3181.
The Aspen Theatre in the Park performs "Crimes of the Heart," "Burn This" and "The Singular Dorothy Parker" in a tent behind the Aspen Art Museum. Up to four performances a week will be held until Sept. 13.
Tickets are $15 or $17. Call (303) 925-2750 for tickets, or write Aspen Theatre in the Park, Post Office Box 8677, Aspen, Colo. 81612.
The Aspen Historical Homes Tour on Aug. 8 is sponsored by the Aspen Historical Society.
The tour, which will last about two and a half hours, will visit six Victorian and contemporary homes and two gardens and will go backstage at the Crystal Palace Theatre Restaurant, a building that dates from 1891. Tickets are $15 before day of tour and $18 on the day. Ticket information: (303) 925-2750.
 
The Outdoors
 Mountain biking is a particularly aerobic way to see the country. Bikes can be rented at Timberline Cycle Center below the gondola; The Hub of Aspen, 315 East Hyman Avenue; Blazing Pedals by the Mill Street Fountain, and several other bicycle shops. Rates are about $10 and up for road or mountain bikes for a half a day; weekly rates are available. It is an easy half-day trip by paved road from Ashcroft or along Owl Creek Road, while Aspen Mountain's rugged trails are for the advanced rider only; carrying the bike over certain stretches is not unheard of on the most difficult trails.
Another excursion is flyfishing for trout on the Roaring Fork River. Oxbow Outfitting Company, Post Office Box D3, Aspen, Colo. 81612, (303) 925-1505, offers flyfishing clinics every Tuesday from 5 to 7, rents equipment and offers guided flyfishing trips. A half-day trip for one with all gear is $150.
Hallam Lake is in a 22-acre wildlife sanctuary in the heart of Aspen, close enough for small children to walk to. Call (303) 925-5756 for information about programs for children and adults. Programs cost up to $3.
 
Hotels
 One of this season's best deals is the Aspen Arts Package, which offers lodging with one ticket to the music festival, one to DanceAspen and free admission to the Aspen Art Museum and Aspen Historical Society Museum. It also includes a discount coupon to the Aspen Theatre in the Park. It runs through Aug. 22. Three-night economy packages start at $36 per person per night, double occupancy, up to $76. The package, which has to be reserved 10 days ahead, must be booked through Aspen Central Reservations Travel, (800) 262-7736.
Budget: The Snowflake Inn, (800) 247-2069, 221 East Hyman Avenue, is a simple modern three-story establishment half a block from the mall. It has a pool and a Jacuzzi. Rooms for two with kitchenettes begin at $95.
The Limelight Lodge, (800) 433-0832, at 228 East Cooper Avenue, is well-maintained and serviceable, with a good location in downtown Aspen; rooms start at $88 for two in summer, including a Continental breakfast.
Ullr Lodge, 520 West Main Street, (303) 925-7696. A small family-owned lodge. Rooms for two $55 to $85 with Continental breakfast.
Moderate: The Innsbruck Inn, (303) 925-2980, 233 West Main Street, not surprisingly has Alpine-style decor. Its large two-room units cost $130 a night including a copious breakfast in a pretty dining room. Outdoor heated pool and Jacuzzi.
Luxury: Hotel Lenado, (800) 321-3457, 200 South Aspen Street, re-creates something of the atmosphere of an Adirondack lodge; it is small, with 19 rooms and distinctive log furniture. Room range from $135 a night for a room with twin beds to $185 for a room with a queen-sized or king-sized bed with a wet bar and whirlpool bath. Rates include a full breakfast.
Sardy House, (800) 321-3457, 128 East Main Street, is an elegantly restored Victorian brick house that turned 100 this year. Beautifully landscaped, with a heated swimming pool and hidden brick mews. It has 14 rooms and 6 suites. Rooms cost from $145 to $220 a night; suites from $250 to $375. Rates include full breakfast.
The Little Nell, (800) 525-6200, 675 East Durant Street, which bills itself as Aspen's newest lodge of opulence, has something of a corporate feeling in its decor and atmosphere. Rooms have marble baths, two phone lines and gas-burning fireplaces. A room with a mountain view is $235, an executive suite is $750. The outdoor heated pool is tiled in black.
 
Restaurants
 ZG, new this summer at 709 East Durant Avenue in the Aspen Club Lodge (303) 925-4400, sees the return of Gordon Naccarato, formerly the chef at Gordon's. The food is excellent and creative, with Thai, Japanese and American Southern overtones. Gnocchi with crab, Caribbean scallops and light panne cota, a creamy dessert with fruit, are outstanding. Dinner for two with wine about $140.
A plush Colorado-style interior at Pinons, (303) 920-2021, 105 South Mill Street, makes the most of supple deerskin pillows, rough pine beams and braided leather banisters. Specialties are ahi in macadamia nut breading, elk tournedos, lamb loin and lobster strudel. Delicious mashed potatoes accompany most entrees. Dinner only. Cost for two with wine about $125.
One of several restaurants of the same name cropping up around the country, Mezzaluna, (303) 925-5882, 600 East Cooper Avenue, is a very popular spot with both locals and visitors. Excellent pasta, such as the penne with spicy tomato sauce, and a tasty buffalo mozzarella and tomato salad. Service is good despite the frenetic pace, and there is a patio for outdoor dining. Dinner for two with wine about $60.
Boogies Diner, (303) 925-6610, 534 East Cooper Street. This 50's retro clothing, paraphernalia store and an upstairs diner is particularly loved by children. Hamburgers, hot dogs, salads, lunch specials at $6.95.
Poppycocks, (303) 925-1245), 609 East Cooper Avenue, has excellent oatmeal macadamia nut pancakes, plus sandwiches and soups. It is open for breakfast and lunch (it began serving dinner last week) and is ideal for families. Breakfast for two $15.
 
Night Life
 While strolling the mall is probably the favorite evening entertainment, Tatou (303) 920-9091, 419 East Hyman Avenue, a branch of the New York establishment of the same name, is currently the most popular night spot. A jazz band plays between 6:30 and 10:30 P.M., with dinner entrees ranging from $14 to $22. Lunch and brunch are also served, with prices from $4.50 to $9.50. At 10:30 Tatou becomes a night club; the cover varies.
A jazz group, Peer Pressure, performs in the bar at the Little Nell Tuesday through Saturday starting at 9 P.M.
Shooter's, (303) 925-4567, 220 South Galena, is great for country swing music every night, with free country swing dance lessons on Thursday.
 
Shopping
 Unusual and reasonably priced souvenirs from Aspen do exist.
At two-year old Skin, (303) 920-1447, 645 East Durant Avenue, the proprietor Candace Goldflies devises her own formulas for natural soaps, cleansers, balms and ointments, and packages them in interesting ways. Free-form soaps made from oatmeal, comfrey, milk and honey, or tearose are $1.50 an ounce.
The Gypsy Woman Shop (no phone), 227 Main Street, is an unsung institution of Aspen, where a longtime leather worker, Chester Goss, fashions durable deerskin fringed and beaded handbags; prices start at $80.
Crystal Farm, (303) 963-2350, 208 South Mill Street, is for the extravagant budget.
Furniture and chandeliers made from deer antlers are gorgeous to see, if pricey. Chandeliers from nearby Redstone start at $2,250; a fallow deer antler settee is $9,500.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 23; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 939 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Home Is Where the Megabytes Roam

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

 BODY:
New owners of personal computers quickly learn a bitter lesson: There is never enough speed or storage capacity. The hoi polloi of computer users have enough time to cook breakfast while waiting for a puny PC to nibble its way through some poky little program.
But in places like Silicon Valley, a few executives and top scientists, by dint of employment at the right companies, have been able to stuff their dens and home offices with some of the most powerful computer systems in the world. Their experiences offer a glimpse of what home computing will be like for the rest of us by the end of the decade. 
 Take Gordon Bell, who led the Digital Equipment team that invented the VAX minicomputer and who recently was awarded the National Medal of Technology. Back in 1980, Mr. Bell made his office a test site for the VAX, connected to a terminal in his home. "It was great," he recalled. "At the time it was the most powerful computer in the world. And even my kids were using it."
Now, he and his wife, Gwen, own five Macintoshes, and are about to buy a sixth. As a measure of the rate of technological advance, each Mac is at least as powerful as the original VAX.
As a director of the Bell-Mason Group, which programs computers to analyze the strengths and weaknesses of new businesses, Mr. Bell uses his home machines to develop new expert systems software. But really, the Macs "run my life. I'm writing a book, doing slides, conducting my home finances."
Like any good home computing superstar, Mr. Bell has big plans: "My goal by the end of the year is to get rid of all paper -- I want all incoming correspondence automatically filed by the computer. Within three years I want to want to put a videophone on it, so I never have to leave the house." He laughs, "Then maybe a robot of me to look presentable answering the phone so I don't have to do even that."
These days, the muscle computer of choice for the home is the work station; in Silicon Valley, the people most likely to have such a machine work for Sun Microsystems, the leading work-station maker. David Cardinal, director of business development for Sun's technology enterprises subsidiary, has four computers at home, including a Sparcstation, Macintosh, 486 clone and a laptop, "the last so I can work in other rooms or on the road." Mr. Cardinal's machines are not only linked but also hooked to a home PBx for electronic mail. They also run the lights and heater in the house. The one big problem, he said, is the pervasive hum. "You have to put them in a closed room."
Jon Garman, an entrepreneur and former Sun executive, uses his Sun work station to, among other things, run his Los Altos, Calif., household -- outside lighting, hot-water circulation pump, furnace, hot tub, swimming pool and sprinklers. The computer knows the calendar, so it can adjust for weekday, weekend or holiday schedules, and knows the longitude and latitude of the house, so it can determine sunset and sunrise times and turn the lights on and off accordingly. .
"The main reason I set the system up," Mr. Garman said, "is that every time I had a power failure in the neighborhood, I had to go out and reset 15 different timers and clocks." (Now, a battery-powered clock in the work station automatically resets the computer.)
Mr. Garman's next project: a security system that will sense an intruder, notify Mr. Garman wherever he is and let him scare off the intruder through a microphone.
In the countryside near Richmond, Va., lives an executive who may have more computing power in his home than anyone in the country. Jim De Arras, co-founder of Hand Held Products Inc., the company that designed the pocket computers for Federal Express, has wired his entire house and workshop for computing. His two older children, 11 and 7, own Macintoshes and do their homework and play games over computer networks. His wife, Ann, also has a Macintosh and in the bedroom there is another Mac, as well as a Next work station. Its "object-oriented" software, which uses images instead of words, means the Next machine can help family members write computer programs despite their genetic dysgraphia, a writing disability.
And that's just the beginning. Out in the shop, Mr. De Arras has six more computers. The house has two satellite dishes and a ham radio tower for computer data transmission. When hiking or driving, Mr. De Arras carries one of his two Navstar ground positioning computers so he always knows exactly where he is. And, a self-described "time fanatic," Mr. De Arras also regularly taps into both an atomic clock and a satellite time source.
But the person with the largest ratio of computer equipment to other material possessions is probably Steven K. Roberts, a journalist and adventurer. Mr. Roberts, who has been traveling the United States for eight years, has become something of a high-tech celebrity for his specially outfitted bicycle and trailer. Reached on the road in New Hampshire, he described his operation as "two Unix machines -- a Sun color Sparcstation set up so I can wander away from the bike and still use it; a little Tadpole Sparcbook with a color screen; a Macintosh front-end controller" and two I.B.M.-type computers, one with a screen right inside his helmet.
It is at once comforting and distressing for our own future to note that even at the top, the lament is the same. "I always run out of capacity," said Mr. Cardinal, who currently has 1.5 billion -- that's right, billion -- bytes of memory capacity. Mr. De Arras, who has twice that capacity, muttered: "You never have enough speed or storage."

HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE CHIEFS AND CUOMO REACH FISCAL AGREEMENT

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 19

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders agreed today on more than a dozen major bills left over from the legislative session, including fiscal packages for Nassau and Suffolk Counties and an $800 million bond act intended to create jobs throughout the state.
The agreement salvages a legislative session that began with great promise, when a state budget was passed virtually on time for the first time in years, but ended disappointingly with many issues still unresolved. 
 And it represents a victory for Governor Cuomo, who gained assurance that virtually his entire economic-development agenda, including the jobs bond act and expanded powers for the State Thruway Authority, would be passed by the Legislature.
The accord to help Nassau County close its projected $153 million budget gap -- the stubborn issue that had held up everything else -- came after days of excruciating talks in which Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders dealt individually with each bill while vowing that none would succeed unless all the others did, too.
 
A Productive Session
 The agreement would allow Nassau to increase its mortgage-recording tax by one percentage point, to 2 percent, and to issue $59 million in bonds to close its budget gap.
At a news conference late this afternoon, a relaxed Mr. Cuomo said that today's agreement made this year's legislative session the most productive in years, even though two of his pet proposals -- an environmental trust fund and a state takeover of county Medicaid costs -- failed. "We got so many good things done, it's hard for me to be disappointed," he said.
Now that the Governor, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin and the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, have agreed on the bills, they are still subject to approval by the Republican-controlled Senate and the Democratic-controlled Assembly. Little objection was expected to any of the bills in either house. Mr. Weprin and Mr. Marino said they would call their members back to Albany to take up the bills on July 28.
 
Bills for New York City
 The regular session ended in the early morning of July 3 as exhausted lawmakers left Albany without having resolved a passel of important issues. Though the Governor can call a special session any time, timing is important this year because by law the Legislature must pass the proposed bond act by Aug. 3 if it is to be put on the November ballot.
In addition to the economic-development bills, the leaders agreed to a half-dozen bills for New York City, including one that would extend the city's authority to negotiate the sale of its bonds and notes, and another that extends until 1999 a city program that gives tax breaks to companies relocating to areas within the city other than south of 96th Street in Manhattan. The New York City bills, which would usually pass both houses as a matter of course, were held up in the tangle of other issues.
The leaders also agreed to a bill that would authorize $300 million in bonding power for the State Job Development Authority; a bill that would distribute about $45 million in Federal employment funds, and a bill that would prohibit a doctor from referring patients to a health-care service in which the doctor has an ownership interest.
But it was the fiscal packages for the two Long Island counties that clogged the end of the session, adding another layer of complication to the intricate personal and political dynamic that drives agreements here.
 
Fiscal Plan for Suffolk
 Seeking to close their budget deficits, Nassau and Suffolk Counties had both sought permission from Albany to raise certain taxes and borrow money. In the end, the Suffolk package was not difficult to resolve. Late on Saturday, the leaders announced a plan under which Suffolk could borrow $36 million to close its 1991 deficit and then could borrow more money after its 1992 deficit had been certified by an independent auditor and the State Comptroller.
The plan would also allow Suffolk to raise its portion of the sales tax by half a percentage point, to 4.5 percent. That is in addition to the state's 4 percent sales tax.
Nassau County's request was much dicier. To close the county's projected $153 million budget gap in a $1.8 billion budget, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta requested permission to raise the county's mortgage-recording tax, to issue up to $71 million in bonds and to freeze taxes for at least two years.
Because Mr. Marino represents Oyster Bay in Nassau and is a product of the county's powerful Republican establishment, he keenly wanted Mr. Gulotta, who is also a Republican and who is up for re-election in 1993, to receive the package he requested.
 
Unusual Leverage
 But that gave unusual leverage to Mr. Weprin, the Democratic Assembly Speaker, whose own programs are often thwarted by Mr. Marino and the Long Island Republicans. Mr. Weprin kept placing more and more conditions on the plan, insisting, for example, that Nassau submit to an outside financial control board and that the increased mortgage-recording tax be used to pay back the bonds, instead of freezing taxes.
Mr. Weprin, Mr. Marino, Mr. Gulotta and Mr. Cuomo sat with a bevy of aides in Mr. Cuomo's office for much of the weekend, often getting up to huddle in little groups. At several points, the talks appeared to be breaking down.
But the parties, and particularly Mr. Cuomo, persevered. In an effort to resolve the dispute, the Governor made one proposal after another, meeting rejection each time. "They were not able to make a deal, the two houses, and I didn't want to see this thing abort entirely," Mr. Cuomo said. Finally, he suggested that the issue of freezing property taxes be considered separately from the rest of the package, and that is the view that finally prevailed.
The agreement would allow Nassau County to issue up to $65 million in six-year bonds and also allow it to increase the mortgage tax by a percentage point. For the first 16 months, the new tax could be used any way the county saw fit, but for the remainder of the six years, the tax could be used only to pay off the bonds. As with Suffolk, Nassau's budget would be subject to oversight by the State Comptroller and by a locally appointed advisory panel.
The legislation contains no guarantee that property taxes would be frozen, but Mr. Cuomo invited Mr. Gulotta to submit a new request to Albany for such a freeze.
Mr. Marino would not comment on this. But Mr. Gulotta said he was disappointed that he could not guarantee a tax freeze for his constituents, and he warned that the Long Island Democratic Assemblymen who had opposed his request would pay for it politically.
Mr. Weprin said he was satisfied with the final plan, particularly the new oversight mechanisms for Nassau County. "I think it's a fair compromise and we have the results that we wanted," he said.
There was an almost festive mood in the air when the deal was struck, as legislative aides scattered. And Senator Marino, already three days late for a long-planned vacation in Austria with his wife, practically ran down the hall so he could catch the last flight tonight from Kennedy International Airport in Queens to Austria to meet her.
He took the Governor's state plane to Kennedy, and his aides said he had received special permission to board the Austrian flight directly from the runway, without having to go through the terminal.


GRAPHIC: Here are some of the major elements of the package agreed to by state leaders in Albany yesterday:

 * A $300 million bonding authorization for the Job Development Authority, which provides loans to encourage businesses and industrial development.

HEADLINE: Plan to Stock Salmon in River Is Dropped by Trenton Agency

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
New Jersey, facing solid opposition from sport-fishing groups who feared an ecological disaster, has dropped plans to introduce Pacific salmon to the Delaware River watershed in the hope of creating a multimillion-dollar sport fishery.
The state Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife had proposed spending $800,000 to release 300,000 young chinook salmon annually for five years in the Musconetcong River, a tributary of the Delaware. The young fish would presumably have swum out to sea, remained there for about three years while growing to 20 or 30 pounds, then returned to the Musconetcong to spawn. They would then have been fair game for fishermen who, it was hoped, would have poured millions into the local economy. 
 But after receiving the results of an environmental impact study and fielding overwhelmingly negative public comments, the state announced on July 2 that the proposal would not be pursued further.
Officials say the plan was dropped for three reasons: because the study showed that only 240 salmon a year would return to the Musconetcong; because of budget constraints, and because the venture would conflict with plans to build up the Delaware system as a fishery for "warm water" gamefish like shad and smallmouth bass.
 
Proven Program Favored
 "Given the current fiscal crisis facing New Jersey, it doesn't seem prudent to invest that amount of money in a program in which our environmental impact statement shows such dismal returns," said Bob Soldwedel, chief of the Fish, Game and Wildlife Division's Bureau of Freshwater Fisheries. "Our priorities right now are directed toward the warm-water fish program," he said.
Opponents of the plan were delighted. "We feel elated," said Clinton C. Rodell, the conservation chairman of the New York-based Theodore Gordon Flyfishers Inc., one of several groups that banded together in the Delware River Defense Coalition to fight the proposal.
Several states, including Michigan and New York, have introduced Pacific salmon into Great Lakes waters, where they have become the basis of a lucrative industry in the lakes and along their tributaries. Michigan, for instance, estimates that anglers spend $250 million to $400 million a year on salmon fishing, while the stocking costs only $5 million.
But in the Delaware watershed, sport fishermen were almost unanimous in their opposition to the state proposal. They argued that introducing the salmon would disrupt the habitat of the much smaller trout in the Musconetcong and other trout waters in the Delaware watershed, including the Beaverkill of the Catskills, a revered stream among fly-fishers. The opponents also argued that the salmon could introduce disease.
At public hearings, residents along the Musconetcong said that even without the salmon stocking, crowds of fishermen were reducing the quality of life.
The environmental impact study, conducted by Versar Inc., an ecological consulting concern based in Columbia, Md., found that the proposed stocking would have no great ecological impact.

HEADLINE: U.N. Aide Quits Iraq After Failing To Gain Access for Arms Inquiry

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19

 BODY:
Iraq sent a senior United Nations envoy away empty-handed today, citing sovereignty and security as reasons for its latest refusal to allow United Nations arms inspectors into its Agriculture Ministry.
"The Iraqi position is fundamentally unchanged," Rolf Ekeus, head of the commission to eliminate Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, said before he left the country. 
 When Mr. Ekeus arrived on Friday, he said he would warn Iraq that it faced the risk of attack if it did not comply fully with the terms of the cease-fire that ended the Persian Gulf war.
After two days of talks with Iraqi officials here, Mr. Ekeus left for Bahrain before returning to New York to brief the United Nations Security Council on his discussions.
Col. Douglas Englund of the United States Army, who heads the United Nations arms inspectors here, said, "There was nothing I could characterize as progress."
 
U.N. Team Sits in Jeeps
 A team of United Nations inspectors has been sitting in white jeeps outside the Agriculture Ministry since July 5, when they were first refused permission to search the building after receiving a tip from a Western intelligence agency that documents relating to Iraq's banned ballistic missile program might be hidden there.
The United States, Britain and France are becoming increasing irritated over Iraq's stand against the inspectors and a number of other quarrels with the United Nations. Diplomats say they are considering methods of dealing with President Saddam Hussein, including the possibility of an air strike.
On July 6, the Security Council issued a statement calling for the inspectors to be given "immediate access" to the ministry and saying Baghdad is guilty of "a material and unacceptable" breach of its obligations under the gulf war cease-fire agreement.
United Nations officials said the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, showed some slight flexibility when he met with Mr. Ekeus today. But they said they were uncertain whether this indicated that Iraq was considering a change of position.
United Nations officials said the Iraqis appeared worried that granting this request might set a precedent that would allow the inspectors to poke around in other ministries and offices of President Hussein's secretive bureaucracy.
These officials speculated that the Iraqis' real fear might be that the inspectors would find clues to Mr. Hussein's personal movements and pose a threat to his security.
The standoff with the inspectors is only the latest in a series since inspectors began seeking information on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction so they could be disabled.
In all such previous confrontations, Iraq has backed down in the end, under pressure from the Security Council. But on this occasion, the quarrel is only one of a number of disputes, which suggests Baghdad may be adopting a tougher line toward the United Nations.
The work of relief agencies is being hampered by Baghdad's refusal to renew an agreement with the United Nations on humanitarian aid that expired last month. Iraq has turned down a Security Council offer to let it sell some oil to pay for imports of food and medicine and start compensating victims of the Kuwait invasion.
Iraq has also refused to accept the new boundary the United Nations has demarcated with Kuwait. And it continues its economic blockade of Kurdish-controlled northern parts of the country, denying them food and fuel from the south and refusing to pay civil servants and pensioners living there.
At the same time, United Nations workers here have started to come under attack for the first time.
A United Nations guard protecting relief workers in the northern region was shot dead Thursday and earlier this month two others were wounded in attacks by unknown assailants.
