HEADLINE: AIDS-Focused New Parties Are Proposed at Conference

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM, July 19

 BODY:
The eighth international conference on AIDS opened here today with a plea from the chairman for the creation of political parties devoted to AIDS and other health-care issues that would be patterned after the green parties dedicated to the environment.
At the same time, conference officials said they are considering convening a panel to discuss reports about the possibility of a new virus that causes a disease resembling AIDS. 
 The conference chairman, Dr. Jonathan Mann, said that although world leaders express concern about health, "it receives second-class political treatment in almost every country."
The worsening AIDS epidemic, Dr. Mann said, is a stimulus for political parties "to get the political and social commitment to health that everyone says health deserves, yet appears not to be the case."
Dr. Mann, former chief of the World Health Organization's AIDS program, is affiliated with Harvard University. He and his supporters advocate more government involvement in AIDS research and prevention, and a month and a half ago, they significantly increased their projection of worldwide AIDS cases by the year 2000. By then, they estimated, somewhere between 38 million and 110 million adults would be infected.
This projection far exceeded current ones of the World Health Organization. Since AIDS was discovered in 1981, many groups and communities have developed programs to educate people about ways to prevent the disease, which is caused by the human immunodeficiency viruses, or HIV.
 
Complex Influences
 AIDS is spreading rapidly in Africa, Asia and South America, Dr. Mann said, adding that the world needs to recognize that current efforts "will not stem the epidemic." The social, religious and political issues that have worsened the epidemic have not been adequately addressed, he said.
Dr. Mann asserted that health workers had contributed to the problem by playing a secondary, reactive and minor role in community and national politics, adding:
"Why has no government and no society been called to account for failures in health? Why do governments tremble when the inflation rate rises, yet no elections are lost over" health issues like AIDS or infant mortality.
AIDS is generally thought to be caused by two similar viruses known as HIV-1 and HIV-2. HIV-1 causes the overwhelming majority of cases. HIV-2 is limited to West Africa and some other areas of the continent.
From the early 1980's, when HIV was discovered, many specialists have said that additional viruses would likely be found as causes of similar diseases. They have likened the problem to hepatitis, an infection of the liver. In recent years, scientists have discovered several viruses that cause hepatitis.
But despite research in the United States and Europe, no new AIDS viruses have been detected.
The efforts have been stepped up over the last year as a result of published reports of a small number of puzzling cases of symptoms associated with AIDS, in which exhaustive laboratory tests could detect no evidence of either form of HIV.
Yet the patients had infections associated with AIDS, like Kaposi's sarcoma, a cancer, or pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, as well as fungal infections of types known to complicate AIDS.
 
Already at Risk
 Several experts have said in recent interviews that when they talk about such cases, they occasionally learn of an additional one. Although the new cases generate speculation about an undetected virus, the total number of known cases of this kind is estimated at two dozen. For the most part, the patients are among those considered at high risk for AIDS.
Among those who have found such cases are researchers at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York.
Detecting a new AIDS virus would have important health implications. If a virus is found that can be transmitted through the blood, like HIV-1 and HIV-2, it could result in the discovery of more cases of AIDS-like illnesses.
It would also be likely to lead to development of new tests to screen blood for transfusions and to determine whether individuals had been infected with the virus. For several years, blood banks have requested that individuals at high risk for AIDS avoid donating blood or limit donations to uses other than transfusion.
At least two teams of researchers have submitted reports to scientific journals of evidence of a possible new member of the retrovirus family to which AIDS belongs. But no paper has been published.
Virologists express caution about such reports because many initially published hypotheses, particularly regarding retroviruses, have turned out to be wrong. For example, some putative new human retroviruses have turned out to be animal viruses or other contaminants.
AIDS experts said that the discovery of a new virus would be far less important than detecting a mutation of either known HIV virus.

HEADLINE: Shrunken Budget Leaves Many Streets in Dangerous Disrepair

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Street conditions throughout New York City have grown considerably worse in the last year, in some cases becoming dangerous to motorists, because of drastic cuts by the Dinkins administration in the budget for street repair and maintenance, and some community leaders charge that the remaining money is unfairly allocated.
The city's Transportation Commissioner, Lucius J. Riccio, acknowledged that the streets were reaching a state of crisis because of deep budget cutbacks by City Hall and that some roads were in such bad shape that they posed safety hazards for pedestrians and motorists. 
 "We are very concerned about the situation because there are safety issues involved here," Mr. Riccio said. "The problem is that there are just far too many roads that need repair, but unfortunately the budget situation does not allow for it."
But some community leaders charge that areas like southeastern Queens and Throgs Neck in the Bronx receive less than their fair share of even the reduced road-repair work that is being done because they lack political clout at City Hall.
 
A Local Safety Measure
 There is a pothole at the corner of 91st Avenue and 218th Place in Queens Village that is so large and has been there for so long that residents once planted a tree in it to prevent motorists from driving into it.
The tree has since been removed. But the pothole, 6 feet long and 3 feet wide, and hundreds of others in the area have not been repaired, despite repeated complaints from residents to the city's Transportation Department.
"If you drive down this street at night, your life is in danger, not from being mugged but from falling into one of these giant potholes," said Susan M. Noreika, chairwoman of Community Board 13, which helps coordinate city services in the area. "Actually, you can't really call them potholes anymore. A pothole is something that a pot fits into. You could bury a body in those holes."
The city's street reconstruction and pothole repair programs were virtually eliminated in the last two city budgets. The loss of the programs has hit hardest in areas like Queens Village and Throgs Neck, where the roads, which were poorly constructed by private developers and have inadequate drainage, are in great disrepair.
The problem is that many streets in these areas have been targeted for capital reconstruction, which in most cases will be delayed for four years. In general, streets slated for reconstruction are not eligible to be repaved, since they will simply be ripped apart again. Community boards may take a street out of the reconstruction program and ask that it be repaved, but many boards are loathe to do so because they fear necessary reconstruction will never be done.
"I don't think it's fair," said William Scarborough, district manager for Community Board 12 in Jamaica, Queens, where some streets are plagued by an obstacle course of unrepaired potholes. "Horrible street conditions like the ones we have here would not be tolerated in most areas of Manhattan."
Mr. Scarborough said the community board had received dozens of telephone calls and letters from residents who complained they had sustained physical injuries, flat tires and expensive car damage because of poor road conditions, particularly potholes and street cave-ins.
 
Need-Based Repairs
 Richard Ocken, the Transportation Department's acting assistant commissioner for highways, said that there were no "political favorites" in street repair. He said repair was based solely on need and road usage. "It's probably true that you will not find streets in Manhattan like some of the worst ones in Queens, because the Manhattan streets were built much better," Mr. Ocken said. "We certainly don't look at the socioeconomics or race of neighborhoods in prioritizing our repairs."
Commissioner Riccio said the Transportation Department was working with City Hall to restore some street-reconstruction and pothole-repair programs.
Leland T. Jones, Mayor David N. Dinkins's press secretary, said that as the recession wanes and city tax revenues improve, the administration would be able to restore funds to some of the areas most damaged by budget cutbacks. But he noted that department commissioners decide what programs to eliminate from their departments in order to meet their overall budget reduction.
Reconstructing, or totally rebuilding, a city street costs $1 million for every "lane mile," a measure one street lane wide and one mile long. Repaving costs $60,000 a lane mile. City transportation officials said most of the money in the budget is going for repaving and emergency pothole repair until the city's fiscal condition allows more reconstruction.
In the past, the city repaired all potholes reported to a special telephone line (212-POTHOLE) within five working days. Today, while the city still takes complaints over the phone, there is no money to repair the holes, except those that block main thoroughfares.
The last four-year capital budget for street reconstruction was $771 million and included both Federal and city funds. The capital budget for street reconstruction for the next four years has been reduced to a total of $191 million. And the latest capital budget contains virtually no city money, so the $191 million must be spent on Federal highway projects, not city streets. The budget for street resurfacing has remained intact at $55 million a year.
 
A Tin Lining
 So residents in Queens Village, Throgs Neck and other areas where reconstruction has been delayed appear to have little chance of getting their streets repaired, city transportation officials said. In addition, the officials said, in some areas they prefer not to fix the potholes because they provide much needed drainage, and to repair them would result in flooding.
Darren J. Morris, executive director of Deepdale Hospital, in Little Neck, Queens, said he had been trying for weeks to get the city to repair a 4-foot-wide, 2-foot-long pothole near a ramp from the Long Island Expressway that leads to the hospital. Mr. Morris said one doctor drove into the hole and broke an axle, a nurse lost a tire and ambulances nearly collide with cars trying to avoid the hole.
Mr. Ocken said that in some areas that have particularly bad streets, the city and community boards have agreed to limited repaving of those that are in the worst shape, but he acknowledged that some streets will not be repaired.
Hardent Vickram, who lives on 147th Street near Springfield in Queens, came up with a novel solution to the potholes that plagued his block. Mr. Vickram, a nursing-home attendant, decided to fill them in himself with concrete leftover from repaving a deck in his backyard. "I popped so many of my tires in those holes, I had no other choice but to do it myself," he said.

HEADLINE: The Rich Get Richer, but the Question Is by How Much

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Trying to challenge the widespread impression that the rich got a wildly disproportionate share of the gains from the Reagan economic boom, the Treasury has been quietly circulating a "primer" on income distribution to journalists and economists.
The 24-page document, prepared by R. Glenn Hubbard, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Tax Analysis, asserts that the richest 1 percent of American taxpayers reaped only 11.3 percent of the income gains in the 1980's. The Treasury tracked the same individuals -- those who had extremely high incomes in 1979 -- from 1979 to 1988. 
 But experts in the field who reviewed the Treasury's calculation were highly critical, saying that the Treasury economist had fallen into a well-known statistical trap that all but guaranteed that the gains for the top group of income earners would appear modest.
 
Not 'Meaningful'
 "It's not a meaningful calculation," said Lawrence F. Katz, an economist at Harvard University.
The Treasury concluded that the top 1 percent of taxpayers "fared somewhat better on average over the 10-year period than many other taxpayers covered by the Treasury panel, but not very much better (and certainly did not capture a major share of the income gain)."
Its calculation contrasts sharply with one by an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Paul R. Krugman, that the richest 1 percent of American families reaped 70 percent of the growth in average family incomes from 1977 to 1988. Professor Krugman's data are now enshrined in Gov. Bill Clinton's economic program as the Democratic Presidential candidate and dismissed by the Treasury as a "meaningless statistical artifact."
There are many meaningful ways to look at the fortunes of various income groups. But economists said that by arbitrarily defining the top 1 percent as those who were in the group in 1979 -- as the Treasury did -- the study automatically introduces a downward bias in its results. By contrast, the group could have been defined as those who were in the top 1 percent in the midpoint of the 10-year period, or those who fell into the top 1 percent based on their average income over the entire decade.
"It makes a big difference how you define the rich, whether you define them at the beginning or end of the period," said Isabel V. Sawhill, an economist at the Urban Institute, a research organization.
To demonstrate this potential bias, Ms. Sawhill calculated how the income of the top 20 percent of income earners changed between 1976 and 1986.
"If you define the top quintile as people who had high incomes in 1977 and follow them for the next decade, you find their incomes declined by 11 percent," she said.
"But if you define them as people who had high incomes in 1986, and compare them to where they were in 1977, you find their incomes went up by 65 percent."
Researchers can produce skewed results in one direction or another based on whether the group being studied is culled from the year that starts a period or from the year that ends it. Those at the top in one year have only one place to go in subsequent years if they move out of the group: down. Some retire, some are discharged, and others, who may have just had an unusually prosperous year, go on to have more normal earnings. The average gain for this group is dragged down by those whose incomes move down.
Those who were in the top 1 percent at the end of the period under study could have moved up from only one place in the years past: from somewhere below. So the average gain for this group is inflated by people who joined the group by dint of big income gains.
"I would ask Treasury to redo their calculation on the top 1 percent defined by 1988 income, " said Joel B. Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan. "I'm pretty sure the numbers would change quite a bit."
A reporter had, in fact, asked Mr. Hubbard several times to make such a calculation, but he refused on the ground that the results would be uninteresting.
 
'Unevenly Distributed'
 Another statistic -- the Treasury's own -- is not mentioned in the Treasury's primer: In a comparison of the incomes of the top 1 percent of taxpayers in 1979 with those of the top group in 1988, the very rich accounted for nearly half of all taxpayers' gains in income.
"The gains of the 1980's were incredibly unevenly distributed, " said Mark Condon, a researcher at the Urban Institute who was co-author with Ms. Sawhill of a recent study of income mobility.
"That's what the Treasury is trying to refute," he added, "and that's what the Krugman calculation gets across pretty well."

HEADLINE: Allen Newell, 65; Scientist Founded A Computing Field

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Allen Newell, a founder of the field of artificial intelligence and a leader in the study of human thinking, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 65 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.
He died of cancer, a spokeswoman for the family said. 
 Dr. Newell, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, was considered one of the four fathers of artificial intelligence and an expert on how people think. He earned an international reputation for developing programs for complex information processing. He was the founding president of the American Association for Artificial Intelligence and had also headed the Cognitive Science Society.
Last month, President Bush awarded him the National Medal of Science.
Dr. Newell's interest in artificial intelligence grew from his work in the early 1950's on a Rand Corporation project for the Air Force to simulate an early warning monitoring station with radar screens and a crew. In trying to predict how the crew members would react, he became fascinated with the puzzle of how people think and make decisions.
Along with Dr. Newell and Dr. Simon, Marvin Minsky from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and John McCarthy from Stanford University are considered the pioneers in artificial intelligence by experts.
In the 1980's, Dr. Newell developed Soar, a sophisticated software system that learns and solves problems in a manner similar to human mental processes. He was the author or co-author of 10 books and more than 200 academic articles. His last book was "Unified Theories of Cognition" (Harvard, 1990).
Dr. Newell was born in San Francisco. He served two years in the Navy at the end of World War II. He graduated from Stanford University in 1949 and earned a doctorate in industrial administration at Carnegie in 1957.
He worked for Rand from 1950 to 1961, when he joined Carnegie. There he helped create the School of Computer Science and continued as a professor until his death.
His survivors include his wife of 45 years, the former Noel McKenna; a son, Paul, of Manhattan Beach, Calif., and a sister, Ann, of Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: Japan Lures Auto Workers With 'Dream' Factories

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANDA-MACHI, Japan

 BODY:
Move over, Disneyland. Make way for Nissan Human Land, as a company brochure describes the Nissan Motor Company's newest factory.
Here workers toil not in the assembly plant or paint shop, but work happily in the assembly or painting "pavilions." They walk along Palm Street and over Flamingo Bridge. And they eat in an employee cafeteria called the Harbor View Restaurant, with a panoramic view of the loading docks. 
 These attempts to create what Nissan officials call a "dream factory" attest to a serious problem. At a time when thousands of auto workers in the United States are losing their jobs, Japan's world-beating automobile companies cannot find enough people to fill their factories.
With Japan's rising prosperity, it seems, young people are shunning assembly-line work, which many of them view as monotonous, fast-paced and tiring. Young people have tended to favor jobs in the service industries and to avoid manufacturing jobs that are characterized by what are called the three K's -- kiken (dangerous), kitsui (difficult) and kitanai (dirty).
"Japanese are spoiled people nowadays," said Haruo Shimada, a professor specializing in labor economics at Keio University. While the economic downturn here has mitigated the labor shortage in recent months, auto industry executives expect the problem to be a continuing one.
As a result, companies like Nissan are trying to create "friendly factories" that will be easier for workers or will at least improve the image of auto factory work. "We are trying to make the work as fun as possible," said Shinichi Ariizumi, general manager of the plant, which opened in May.
The assembly plant -- er, pavilion -- is highly automated and has done away with the traditional conveyer belt. Each car sits on its own dolly, which can be raised or lowered at each work station so that workers do not have to bend or stretch as much.
"At the end of the day there are much fewer cases of muscle aches and backaches," said Katsutoshi Aihara, general secretary of the All Nissan Motors Workers Union.
But he quickly added: "It's not an amusement park, it's an automobile factory. There is still demanding work that requires muscle power, and workers still are bound by the clock and have to work at considerable speed."
At another factory, Nissan is experimenting with a "silver line" -- a heavily automated assembly line that makes work easier for workers over 50, allowing for recruitment from Japan's rapidly aging population.
And Mitsubishi Motors is allowing workers in its dormitories, where many unmarried employees live, to have their own tiny rooms, instead of having to share a tiny room with someone else.
Toyota, Japan's largest auto company, is borrowing excess workers from two depressed steel companies and plans to eliminate unpopular late-night work at a new plant. And several companies are taking what is still a relatively radical step here -- letting women work in the factory, although mainly in physically less-demanding jobs like inspecting vehicles.
Others note that even if the major auto plants are spruced up, conditions remain much tougher in the factories run by auto parts suppliers, many of which employ immigrant labor, some of it illegal.
 
Workers Were Consulted
 Nevertheless, Mr. Aihara of the union praised Nissan's efforts, noting that worker opinions were considered in the plant's design. Whereas worker amenities are usually added as an afterthought, he said, Nissan chose the site with the best view for the cafeteria, then designed the rest of the plant around it.
The labor shortage has been caused partly by a huge increase in auto sales and production in Japan. Sales in Japan increased to roughly five million cars annually in the last two years from three million in 1986, while production here, including exports, rose to 10 million cars from 8 million in 1986.
Even among the young people who do try auto work, as many as 30 percent quit in their first year at some companies. At Hino Motors, a truck manufacturer, the figure is 50 percent.
The worker shortage has meant long overtime hours, with many employees working 12-hour days and on Saturdays. That has contributed to Japan's image as a nation that cares only about production and not about the lives of its overworked citizens.
The huge bills for overtime and for temporary workers have also eaten into the profits of the auto companies. Labor costs for Japan's auto companies increased 10 percent in the last fiscal year, far faster than inflation, said Richard Ko, an auto analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities in Tokyo.
Actual wages rose only 5 percent. A starting Nissan factory worker makes about $1,200 a month, but more experienced workers can make far more, especially with overtime. Executives here say wages are at or above the levels for American auto workers, although that income provides far less buying power because of high prices here.
And auto executives say the long-term problem will not go away easily. For one thing, the auto makers are being pressed by the Japanese Government to reduce the average number of hours worked to bring Japan more in line with other industrialized nations.
Hence, more workers will be needed, even if production does not rise.
At the same time, Japan's low birth rate means that the population of 18-year-olds is expected to drop from roughly 2 million now to 1.5 million by the end of the decade.
"I don't think there will be a surplus," said Iwao Isomura, senior managing director in charge of personnel matters at Toyota. "In the short term there will be ups and downs."
Numerous tactics are being tried to cope with the recruitment problem, including opening factories in remote areas where there is less competition for workers. The new Nissan factory is on Japan's southern island of Kyushu, where Toyota is also building a plant. One drawback to this is that the auto factories are no longer close to all their suppliers, making it harder to implement such practices as just-in-time delivery of parts -- in which parts are shipped quickly as needed, rather than being stockpiled.
 
An Old Factory
 A better factory environment is another approach. At Nissan's 28-year-old Zama factory outside Tokyo, the body assembly shop is still called the body assembly shop. It is dark and noisy, with no air-conditioning, and temperatures can reach close to 90 degrees in the summer.
A striking contrast is the Assembly Pavilion in Nissan Human Land. The factory is brightly lit, with natural sunlight filtering in through skylights. Air-conditioners keep the temperature at 77 degrees.
At Zama, work is done on a traditional conveyer belt from which cars are suspended. The workers scramble to install parts, sometimes having to clamber into the car and squat on the floor, other times stretching over the front of the car to reach far under the hood. If a worker falls behind, the whole line must be stopped because all the cars advance in lockstep.
At the Nissan dream factory, cars glide along on intelligent motor-driven dollies, an innovation that is also being tried in some other plants in Japan and the United States. There is far less stretching and squatting. In addition, the cars do not all have to move at the same rate, giving a worker having trouble a little more time. When he is finished, the dolly scoots ahead to catch up with the one in front of it.
Automation is also much more evident. Painting and welding, two of the dirtiest jobs, are almost completely handled by robots, as is true in many plants. But in Kyushu, 20 percent of final assembly is automated, one of the highest levels for the auto industry, compared with 5 percent at Zama.
Nissan said the new plant would be able to produce 30 percent more cars per worker than its older plants, although there is some debate among experts about whether such automation really saves the company money once the cost of the robots is factored in.
Even in older factories, improvements are being made. Hatsuo Sato, a welder in the Zama plant for 26 years, said robots had taken over many jobs that once required him to work in dangerous, slippery places wielding a heavy machine.
"Compared with old times, the work conditions are easier," he said, adding that he thinks young people have the wrong image of auto work.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nissan is creating "friendly factories" in an attempt to improve the image of auto factory work, which many Japanese view as monotonous, fast-paced and tiring. At a new plant in Kyushu, Japan, cars are mounted on dollies that can be raised or lowered to allow employees to work more comfortably. (Andrew Pollack/The New York Times) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Chief's Assessment Of Economy Is Awaited

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
After three years of trying to put the economy on track toward a stable, sustainable recovery, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, will try to explain to Congress this week why the central bank's efforts have not succeeded.
On Tuesday and Wednesday, Mr. Greenspan is scheduled to provide his semiannual presentation on monetary policy and the economy. 
 The last two times he made such presentations, in July 1991 and again in February, Mr. Greenspan did his best to sound upbeat.
Last summer, Mr. Greenspan told Congress: "We are well on the path of actually achieving the type of goals which we've set out to achieve" -- namely, a solid recovery, with unemployment down to its lowest sustainable level and inflation wholly under control.
In February, the Fed's outlook was only a bit less rosy, with Mr. Greenspan saying the stirrings of recovery visible then "should take hold in the second quarter."
 
Recovery Loses Momentum
 Since then, unemployment has risen to 7.8 percent, an eight-year high and a full percentage point above where the Fed projected six months ago that it would be by year-end.
Moreover, momentum again seems to be oozing out of the recovery, and money supply growth remains disturbingly slow.
In short, even though the Fed has lowered short-term interest rates 23 times over three years, the country seems to remain trapped in what Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, has called economic purgatory.
For these reasons and others, private analysts are expecting a more sober assessment from Mr. Greenspan this time. And with the November elections less than four months away, Congress and the White House may not like what they hear, the analysts said.
 
'Depressing, Rambling Speech'
 "If I were Mr. Greenspan, I would not be looking forward to it," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "I think we can expect a depressing, rambling speech. But the real problem is that the economy is not responding to lower interest rates."
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank, said: "Mr. Greenspan can say we are in a recovery, but there is no number he could point to to say that it will pick up steam. He has to go in there and say that. There is no way around it."
Although the Fed has been criticized for not easing monetary policy more aggressively up to now, the central bank's decision earlier this month to cut the discount rate to 3 percent and push down the Federal funds rate to 3.25 percent will probably make Mr. Greenspan's time on Capitol Hill a bit easier.
But most analysts say the nation has severe structural problems that are beyond the ability of monetary policy to cure. These stand solidly in the way of a more rapid rate of growth.
 
List of Problems
 Mr. Greenspan touched on some of those problems in February and is likely to spend more time elaborating on them this week.
The list ranges from overleveraged corporate and individual balance sheets to a glutted commercial real estate market and a military-contracting industry that is shrinking. An aging population has cut into demand for goods and services. And fiscal stimulus, which normally accompanies easier monetary policy in bad times, cannot realistically be expected until well after the election this autumn.
Aside from his comments on the economy and its direction, analysts and credit market participants said they would be very interested to hear what Mr. Greenspan had to say about money supply growth, which remains extremely sluggish despite all of the Fed's easing.
A year ago, Mr. Greenspan told Congress that the ideal growth rate for M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, would be about 4 percent a year. But in the second quarter M-2 growth was flat, and for the year it has grown at a pace far below the 2.5 percent level that represents the bottom of the Fed's 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent target range for the year.
 
Mixed Signals From the Fed
 Weak money growth was cited by the Fed as the primary reason it eased monetary policy on April 9 and again on July 2. In between those dates, however, market participants received mixed signals from the Fed about the importance it placed on the performance of the monetary aggregates.
"Hopefully we will learn if the Fed has figured out why easier money isn't working, and if it knows what is wrong with the monetary aggregates," said Alan Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc.
Mr. Fine at Chase said an explanation of that sort does not seem likely.
"Virtually every Fed governor and bank president has said there are parts of the money stock they don't understand," he said. "But bank credit contraction continues at more or less the same pace as last year. As long as that continues, you cannot expect money to grow."

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Details Are Emerging

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
William H. Gates, who dropped out of Harvard to found the Microsoft Corporation, which grew into the nation's largest software company, could conceivably have a little difficulty if he wanted to program computers for a living in Mexico after a North American free-trade agreement was signed.
The agreement would ease temporary-visa rules for Canadian, American and Mexican computer operators who cross borders to find a job. But it requires the operators to have university degrees to qualify for special consideration, so as to prevent hundreds of thousands of Mexicans from flooding north after a few days of vocational training. 
 This is just one of thousands of compromises that trade negotiators from the three countries have struck in the last year. These deals, typically made with little or no public debate, will affect scores of industries the length and breadth of the continent.
 
Curtailing Debate
 The result of the secrecy has been a remarkably successful smothering of debate during an election year on an issue that prompted two months of impassioned debate in Congress last year.
And the Bush Administration has begun to investigate leaks that have occurred. In one recent breakthrough agreement, not previously disclosed, the three countries agreed to treat each other's advertising companies as they treat their own. Asked Saturday morning about this and other recent agreements, aides to Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, not only declined to comment -- on the ground that classified information was involved -- but also immediately began investigating possible sources of the leaks.
By Saturday afternoon, they had already checked the attendance records of senior advertising executives at meetings of Mrs. Hills's private-sector advisory groups and determined that not one of them had shown up for classified briefings at which the issue was discussed, an American trade official said.
 
Under Wraps
 During most of the negotiations, these deals stayed secret because all three countries classified thousands of pages of negotiating documents and conducted their talks with the secrecy and security once reserved for wartime military operations.
Now, with the trade talks entering their final weeks, the broad outlines of the secret arrangements -- and the remaining squabbles -- are beginning to spill out.
In the advertising deal, the principle of "national treatment," already applied in the international trade of manufactured goods, would give American advertising companies the same legal and economic rights in competing for contracts from Mexican enterprises as domestic companies there.
The deal would also exempt American and Canadian companies from the Mexican Government's longstanding requirement that foreign advertising companies open offices and hire staff in Mexico before they may run ad campaigns.
In a separate deal on immigration, rules on temporary work visas will be eased for professionals and executives transferred by their corporations. As chairman of Microsoft, Mr. Gates could presumably arrange his transfer to Mexico if he ever wanted to do so, and thereby qualify under the new rules, a person familiar with the negotiations said.
In another agreement, Mexico has agreed not to pursue a broad exemption from the pact for cultural industries, like films. Had Mexico received such an exemption, Hollywood's ability to compete with Mexican film companies would have been impaired. Canada received such an exemption in its 1988 free-trade agreement with the United States.
In yet another deal, negotiators have come up with a new definition of what constitutes a North American car that can be sold across the nation's northern and southern borders without duties and with fewer customs formalities. The new definition is more detailed than the one in the 1988 free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada and is a little more generous to foreign companies because it allows the inclusion of some administrative costs, like sales offices in the United States, in determining the percentage of a car's value that has been produced in North America.
But this generosity in definitions will be more than offset when the three nations set a higher percentage as the basis for special customs treatment. While the exact percentage will be one of the last decisions made, either at the ministerial or presidential level, people involved in the talks said it would likely be 60 percent or a little higher, compared with 50 percent under the old definition in the 1988 free-trade pact between the United States and Canada.
Detroit auto makers have sought a 70 percent standard, while Canada has sought to maintain the old percentage as a way to encourage further construction of auto assembly plants by Japanese and other foreign car companies.
Remaining issues, like trade in oil services and farm goods, will be addressed in Mexico on Saturday by Mrs. Hills and her Mexican and Canadian counterparts.
People involved in the negotiations said there was a slightly less than even chance of an overall deal being struck on Saturday. Many technical issues still have to be worked out, and American and Canadian negotiators are haunted by the memory that a similar deal by their trade ministers in 1987 had to be renegotiated two months later because niggling technical details proved too controversial for their staffs to resolve after the first meeting.
 
Fear of Publicity
 Mrs. Hills and her office's North American affairs section have imposed strict secrecy on the free-trade talks for fear that public debate would limit the ability of each country to compromise and strike the best possible deal.
Only a handful of copies of the incomplete agreement have been given to Congress, and those are being kept in special, high-security reading rooms and in the safes of several Congressional aides with the necessary security clearances.
Even other Government departments involved in the negotiations have been given information only about their sections of the free-trade accord and not about the overall agreement.
The Administration has maintained secrecy even at the cost of endangering President Bush's effort to maintain China's favorable trade access to the United States market. Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's Subcommittee on International Trade, and who has repeatedly led a group of farm-state Democrats across party lines in the last year to support the Administration's China policy, now says he will no longer back the President actively on China because his subcommittee has been cut off from needed information on the free-trade talks.


GRAPHIC: As negotiations continue to create a free trade agreement that would bind the economies of the United States, Canada and Mexico together into a regional trading bloc with more people and more economic output than the European Community, the Bush Administration has classified all the negotiating texts in an effort to forestall public debate until the agreement is complete. But information is leaking out from many people involved directly and indirectly in the negotiations.
 
Issues Already Resolved
Chart: "Creating a North American Free-Trade Area"
 Advertising -- Each country's laws and regulations would treat all advertising agencies in North America the same. Mexico would allow U.S. and Canadian companies to start doing business without setting up local offices and hiring local staff.
 Banking -- U.S. and Canadian banks virtually barred from Mexico, would be allowed to acquire shares in Mexican banks up to a total of 8 percent of the capital of all banks in the Mexican banking system. All banking investment limits in Mexico would be removed on Jan. 1, 2000.
 Computers and computer parts -- The circutry and half the total content of a computer would have to be made in North America to qualify for duty-free treatment.
 Copyrights -- Mexico has agreed to tighten its copyright, patent and trademark rules to bring them closer to U.S. and Canadian standards.
 Dispute resolution -- Panels will issue nonbinding rulings on commercial disputes like fishing rights. Negotiations continue on panels to issue binding rulings in subsidies and other trade law cases.
 Food safety -- Countries will be allowed to challenge each other's safety standards if they can prove that the standards discriminate against a country's products.
 Insurance -- U.S. and Canadian companies would be allowed to take over insurance companies in which they already hold minority stakes. All limits would be removed on Jan. 1, 2000.
 Manufacturing tariffs -- Customs duties on nearly 20,000 products would be reduced, immediately or in stages over as long as 20 years. Reductions in duties on glass tumblers and stemware and auto windshields are being discussed.
 Securities firms -- U.S. and Canadian firms would be able to buy companies accounting for as much as 10 percent of the Mexican industry's capital. All limits would be removed on Jan, 1, 2000.
 Textiles -- Garments will qualify for duty-free treatment only if the yarn is made on the continent, the cloth is woven from the yarn in North America, and all cutting and sewing are done in North America. Canada is seeking some exemptions from the rule.
 Trucking -- U.S., Mexican and Canadian trucking companies would be allowed to do business anywhere on the continent including on cross-border routes that are now forbidden.
 Temporary work visas -- Corporate executives and some professionals from all three countries will be able to live and work on business anywhere in North America with fewer bureaucratic formalities. The rules are narrowly written to prevent large-scale immigration to the United States from Mexico.
 
Unresolved Issues
 Autos -- Negotiations have agreed to eliminate Mexico's complicated system for requiring a rough balance in the import and export of cars and car parts. But they cannot decide how to do so. New rules have been worked out for measuring the domestic content of cars. The domestic content percentage will be higher than the 50 percent in the 1988 Free Trade Agreement with Canada, but the precise figure has not yet been chosen.
 Energy -- The United States wants Pemex, Mexico's state-owned oil company, to hire American companies for a wider range of oil drilling and refining operations. Mexico has agreed to streamline its process for issuing contracts to foreign companies, and has agreed to pay performance bonuses to oil exploration companies that work quickly and strike oil. It has not agreed to broaden the number of contracts available.
 Farm tarifs -- From avocados and corn to peanuts and sugar, disputes persist over how quickly quotas will be eliminated and tariffs reduced.
Government procurement -- Mexico wants to keep some restrictions on the contracts that its state-owned enterprises award to foreign construction and capital goods companies.
 Investment -- Canada wants to retain its rules for screening foreign investments exceeding $150 million (Canadian), or about $126 million (U.S.). Mexico also wants to maintain some restrictions.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Eric Bogosian Parodies Humanity's Dark Side

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
In the funniest among several new monologues that he performed at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday and Friday evening, Eric Bogosian parodies the popular psychologist John Bradshaw as his philosophy might be merchandized by a caricature of Werner Erhard. Where Mr. Bradshaw's earnest evangelical oratory exhorts people to get in touch with the "inner child" in themselves, Mr. Bogosian's character is a sarcastic, aggressive pitchman who urges people to indulge their "inner babies." The quintessential inner baby experience he describes is the childish happiness of successfully stealing a candy bar while the storekeeper's back is turned.
"Babies don't worry," he declares. "They are connected to the center, they are in the now." By making our inner babies happy with feedings every two hours, he promises, we can make the world a better place. 
 This Swiftian sketch was one of several new monologues in the program titled "Dog Show," which Mr. Bogosian created for Lincoln Center's Serious Fun festival. The narrator was one of several alter egos through whom Mr. Bogosian pretended to come out in various degrees from behind the characters he creates. These possible versions of his true self were sandwiched in between several of the brilliantly realized roustabout characters from his Off Broadway shows "Drinking in America" and "Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll." They included a supercilious English rock star touting a benefit concert for the Amazonian Indians of Brazil and an urban lout chortling to a friend about the previous night's drug-fueled violence.
The new work was an attempt by Mr. Bogosian to shake up a mostly white middle-class audience that has absorbed the shock of his characters, many of whom come from the lower economic strata of American life. Mr. Bogosian's work has always trod the line between incisive character comedy and something deeper and scarier. At the heart of his vision of humanity is the idea that so-called civilized behavior is just a middle-class luxury. And in his newer material, he suggested to his audience that underneath our civilized surfaces, we are all selfish beasts. The inner-baby monologue was a pointed jab at a psychological climate that seems mired in arrested development.
In the show's most prickly sketch, Mr. Bogosian plays a middle-class man reflecting with guilt and fear on the meaning of his personal fulfillment. "Starving Africans spoil everything," he observes in a monologue that becomes increasingly surreal as he portrays the privileged life as one in which people are interactive with and dependent for security upon machines. Darkening this perspective is his nightmarish vision of old age in which he imagines himself a feeble nursing home castaway whose only pleasure in life is the occasional taste of strained peaches out of a can.
As with so many of his other monologues, this one ends with an ironic punch line, as the man who has everything except eternal youth and a clear conscience sarcastically sings, "I'm in with the in crowd."

LENGTH: 424 words

HEADLINE: Help Russia for the Long Haul

 BODY:
The second Russian revolution is progressing only by fits and starts. Its leaders, however bold, won't be able to take many steps forward without taking some steps back.
The risk of a relapse in Russia calls for clarity about America's commitment to assist Russian reform. Yet Congress is slow to vote funds. And instead of clarity, President Bush has sown confusion. He told reporters after the seven industrialized powers pledged new aid earlier this month, "I don't know if there's enough money in the world to instantly solve the problems of the Russian economy." 
 That sort of talk just discourages American aid without spelling out the riskiness of the venture Russia is undertaking or, more important, the stakes America has in its success.
Aid from abroad cannot transform Russia, but it can encourage Russians to transform themselves. Withholding help will only weaken Boris Yeltsin and his band of bold reformers.
Democracy and the rule of law are taking root in Russia's inhospitable soil. In the Parliament new parties form and re-form. But progress is spotty. Parliament is trying to muzzle a vibrant press. And democrats have yet to consolidate their hold on major cities or establish a firm beachhead in the vast countryside. They are under threat from rising nationalism and unemployment.
Andrei Kozyrev, Russia's Foreign Minister, warns of the danger from disgruntled generals who manipulate ethnic conflicts to undermine the Yeltsin Government. The risks are apparent in Moldova, where Russia's 14th Army sides with Russian separatists against the Romanian majority and resists Mr. Yeltsin's order to withdraw.
While radicals try to rush Russia to markets, they face renewed resistance from the commissars of industry whose factories cannot survive without state subsidies or credits. Radical reformers may have the lead for now, but industrial managers who are in no hurry to free up markets are rapidly gaining ground. "We can have the workers in the streets whenever we want," warns their leader, Arkady Volsky.
The U.S. is trying to coax Moscow to markets with conditional aid, but if Russia resists the conditions and tries to find its own way, the U.S. can't refuse all help. In Russia's uneasy state it's dangerous to ignore the counsel that the mayor of Magnitogorsk recently gave: "Don't forget. You can bend a stick up to the point it breaks."
As Russia heads for turbulent times, Mr. Bush has little choice but to help the Russians do their best while reminding Americans of the real risks.

HEADLINE: Disputed Military Aircraft Crashes; 7 Aboard Lost

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
A prototype of the V-22 Osprey, a tilt-rotor aircraft whose future was already the subject of furious debate, crashed today in the Potomac River with seven people on board. Pentagon officials said no survivors had been found.
The aircraft, which takes off like a helicopter and flies like a plane, was headed for a landing at the Marine air station in Quantico, Va., about 35 miles south of Washington. 
 The aircraft was developed by a partnership of Bell Helicopter Textron and the helicopter division of the Boeing Company. Pentagon officials and spokesmen for the two companies said they did not know the cause of the crash but would investigate.
The Osprey has become a symbol of the controversy swirling around Pentagon efforts to cut military spending. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has repeatedly criticized the Osprey program as too costly and has complained that the prototype aircraft was 3,000 pounds over its weight limit.
Mr. Cheney took steps to kill the Osprey, but Congress put money into the budget to build the plane. When Mr. Cheney initially refused to spend it, Congress complained that he was illegally impounding the money.
Finally, on July 2, Mr. Cheney agreed to spend $1.5 billion he had been withholding. His decision allowed work on the plane to continue, but he put off judgment on whether the armed forces should buy the Osprey or an alternative helicopter still in development.
Robert Torgerson, a Boeing spokesman, said prototypes of the Osprey had recorded more than 750 hours of flight time in 635 flights. Four prototypes were flying before today's crash. A fifth prototype crashed on its first flight, in June 1991, at New Castle, Del., where Boeing has a test flight center. Two people aboard suffered minor injuries in that crash.
In today's incident, Sgt. Joseph M. Nuss of the Marines said the Osprey was preparing to land at Quantico when an explosion occurred and the plane plunged into the water at 1:42 P.M. Master Sgt. Paul F. Earle, a Marine Corps spokesman, said the crash resulted from "unknown technical problems."
Two other spokesmen for the Marine Corps, Maj. Barry Moore and Cpl. John W. Fritscher, said there were no known survivors. Mr. Torgerson, the spokesman for Boeing's helicopter division in Ridley Township, Pa., which builds the V-22's fuselage, said four Boeing employees and three Marine Corps employees were aboard. He was quoted by Reuters as saying late today that five of the bodies had been recovered.
 
Increasing Opposition?
 Today's crash may increase opposition to the tilt-rotor plane in Congress. The effect of the crash on Congressional support for the plane will be determined, in part, by the cause of the accident. If there was a fundamental flaw in design of the aircraft, support for its development might wane, say Congressional aides.
The Osprey has retained strong support among members of Congress, especially those from states where the plane is being developed, like Texas and Pennsylvania, which also have large numbers of electoral votes. The Marines Corps has also supported development of the aircraft.
And lawmakers have generally been reluctant to make deep cuts in the military budget despite the end of the cold war, fearing they would increase unemployment in an election year.
Representative Pete Geren, Democrat of Texas, has been a leader of House efforts to continue development of the Osprey. Describing today's crash, Mr. Geren's press secretary, Greta E. Creech, said the aircraft was about two miles away from the runway and was 200 feet above the ground when "two loud bangs or pops" were heard. "Then the aircraft dived into the water," she said.
Marine Corps officials said a search-and-rescue team was dispatched to the site of the crash to look for survivors and said they would try to recover the wreckage 27 feet below the Potomac's surface. Pentagon officials said it might take weeks to determine the cause of the crash.
 
Returning From Florida
 Terry A. Arnold, a spokesman for Bell Helicopter Textron of Fort Worth, a subsidiary of Textron Inc. of Providence, R.I., said the Osprey was flying from Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, where it had undergone testing for exposure to extreme weather.
In six months of laboratory tests at Eglin, the plane was baked and frozen, parched and soaked. It was pelted with water to simulate heavy rain and was exposed to temperatures ranging from 65 degrees below zero to 112 degrees Fahrenheit. It was to undergo further tests at Quantico.
Mr. Torgerson said the crash last year resulted from the improper wiring of flight control computers. The first flight test by an Osprey prototype occurred in March 1989.
Supporters of the Osprey said they hoped the crash would not lead to cancellation of the program.
Representative Curt Weldon, a Republican whose district includes the Boeing helicopter plant in Pennsylvania, said tonight, "From this day forward, our No. 1 priority will be to find out what happened to this aircraft."
The House Appropriations Committee and the Senate Armed Services Committee are scheduled to discuss the future of the Osprey this week.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rescuers searching the Potomac River yesterday where a prototype of a V-22 Osprey, a tilt-rotor aircraft, crashed with seven people aboard as it was preparing to land at the Marine air station in Quantico, Va. Pentagon officials said no survivors had been found; five bodies were recovered. (Associated Press)
 
Chart: "The V-22 Osprey at a Glance"
 The Osprey, a combination helicopter and airplane, can hover and take off and land vertically. The rotors can tilt, allowing the craft to fly like a plane. It is flown with helicopter-type controls.
 
History
 May 2, 1986: Development began under Navy auspices. Six Protogypes were to be produced over seven years.
 March 19, 1989: First flight; airborne test of transition from helicopter to airplane mode in September.
 
Development Cost
 The 1991 fiscal year budget assigned $238 million for research and development and $165 million for production.
 In July, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney agreed to spend an additional $1.5 billion on development.
 
Parts
 Bell Helicopter Textron, Fort Worth, provides wings, proprotor, transmission and engine integration.
 Boeing Helicopters, Ridley Township, Pa., is responsible for fuselage, tall unit, landing gear, aerodynamics and electronic systems integration.
 
Construction/Specifications
 The fuselage: Made mainly of black aluminum.
 The engines: Two Allison T406-Ad-400 turboshafts.
 Top speed: Helicopter mode: 115 m.p.h.; Airplane mode: 316 m.p.h.
 Weight: When empty, 31,886 pounds.
 Fuel capacity: 2,015 gallons, with the ability to refuel in flight.
 Seating: Pilot, co-pilot (and crew chief, if necessary), 24 combat-equipped troops, and two gunners.
 
(Source: Jane's All the World Aircraft 1991-1992) (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
To Boost Economy, Perot Planned to Seek Sacrifices

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Ross Perot's plan for restoring the nation's economic health, nearly complete when he withdrew from the Presidential race last week, included a far-reaching program of investment in education, transportation and communications, as well as higher income taxes for the well-to-do, increased gasoline taxes and holding down increases in Social Security benefits.
The center of the Perot blueprint, his senior aides said, was balancing the budget in five years, with cuts in spending as well as new taxes to reduce the deficit by an average of $150 billion a year over the five years.
 
Gasoline Tax Increase
 The plan, about 50 pages long, included many steps long regarded by economic experts as necessary and by political experts as untenable. Among them were slowing increases in Social Security benefits and increasing the gasoline tax by a total of 50 cents a gallon over five years. 
 "Plenty of people not running for office have made these kinds of proposals time and time again," said Isabel Sawhill, an economist at the Urban Institute. "The problem has been that no one seeking higher office has done so. If Ross Perot can help get such proposals on the table, that would be a big contribution."
Officials of Mr. Perot's campaign said fear of public hostility to the plan was one reason the Dallas billionaire withdrew Thursday.
 
Plan Influenced Decision
 "He is an engineer," said James D. Squires, communication director for the Perot campaign. "He looks at these things. Certainly the prospect of running on this plan had to influence any decision that he couldn't win outright."
The main architect of the economic plan was John P. White, a budget official under President Jimmy Carter.
Many officials of the Perot organization are still pressing for the economic plan to be made public in the next two weeks in the hope that its ideas can influence the Presidential race, even if their candidate is no longer in it.
Mr. Perot said through his secretary today that he had "not yet signed off on the plan." But his aides said they were confident that he would approve it and make it public.
Campaign aides said the plan, some details of which were reported in The Chicago Tribune and The Wall Street Journal, also called for limiting deductions on business entertainment expenses and mortgage interest payments, with some Perot aides wanting to limit deductions to the first $200,000 of a mortgage on a house.
"The principle behind this is shared sacrifice for shared reward," Mr. Squires said. "What we saw is, the poor don't get all the entitlements. The rich and the middle-class get a lot of the entitlements."
Mr. Squires and other campaign officials said the plan also called for raising taxes on the wealthiest Americans -- as the plan of the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, would also do -- but Mr. Perot and his advisers had not yet decided how much such increases should be.
"Each piece of this plan would probably be rejected by a large majority of the voters," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker. "But there is a constituency in the country for facing up to hard truths and taking the bitter medicine."
 
Attacking Sacred Cows
 Linda DiVall, a Republican poll taker, said: "If Perot was going to release something specific he had to do something along these lines, particularly in the areas of sacred cows, especially in entitlements. If people really want change, then they might buy into this plan. His plan probably would have lost some favor with voters, but he probably would have regained it if he had stuck to his guns."
Charles Schultze, an economist at the Brookings Institution who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Carter, said the program was "the best plan I've seen in a long time." He added: "If you are serious about balancing the budget, then there will have to be big tax increases. Gasoline taxes is one way."
Mr. Perot's assistants said the plan also proposed either reducing the cost-of-living increases for Social Security recipients by one-third or increasing the taxes on the wealthier recipients of Social Security. The plan would also have limited cost-of-living increases for Government pensions.
Perot campaign aides said the reductions in Social Security and pension increases would total $50 billion over five years. The plan also considered increasing taxes or premiums for affluent recipients of Medicare.
Other elements of the plan called for eliminating income taxes for new businesses for the first five years, and for making permanent a temporary research and development credit plan, an idea favored by Mr. Clinton and by President Bush. To encourage investors and business to think long term, the Perot plan would also lengthen the amount of time people must hold an investment to qualify for certain reductions in capital gains taxes.
Campaign officials said the public investment program in the plan would be tens of billions of dollars but would be smaller than Mr. Clinton's plan to invest $200 billion in infrastructure, education and job training over four years.
The Perot plan would be financed by selling bonds, especially to pension funds, an idea promoted by Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker. Mr. Perot has known Mr. Rohatyn for years, and he served on the board of Mr. Perot's computer services company, Electronic Data Systems, in the early 1980's.
Mr. Perot's plan would also provide for investment tax credits, and aides said they were also weighing a proposal to tie capital gains tax cuts to how many employees a company hires.
"We're trying to free up money to give it to the rich in the sense that it would go to business to invest in the right way," Mr. Squires said. "You have to make it attractive for the wealthy to create jobs, rather than invest their money abroad or in the gambling house on Wall Street."
Perot campaign officials say the plan was neither liberal nor conservative, borrowing ideas from the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Secretary of Housing Jack F. Kemp.
 
Seeking Higher Growth Rates
 It included tax incentives for businesses investing in depressed urban neighborhoods and proposed more job training for inner-city youths.
"The whole point of the plan is to get higher growth rates," said one Perot campaign official.
Under the plan, Mr. Perot would have cut the military budget by about $40 billion more over five years than President Bush has proposed. The Perot program also called for cuts in subsidies to farmers, with the cuts aimed at larger farmers and corporate farms, rather than small farmers, aides said.
"This plan shows very clearly how tough it is to balance the budget," said Rudolph Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office who was one of the many experts Mr. White asked to go to Dallas to provide information and ideas on policy. "The real question is, if all the issues are laid out honestly, whether any politician who does that can win an election? I'd be pretty pessimistic about a politician who did that being able to win a majority of the vote."
Mr. Squires said Mr. Perot was "more comfortable showing this plan to the country as a noncandidate than he could possibly be as a candidate."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 5; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
No Summer Doldrums In Going After Clinton

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
This is a rough season in politics. Gov. Bill Clinton rolled out of the Democratic convention with an extraordinary surge in the polls, and the Republicans have to stop it. From their perspective, they have little choice but to go on the attack. It is as simple as that.
President Bush generally leaves the job to surrogates at this stage of the campaign, but he took on the job himself today. He said Mr. Clinton's economic plan was nothing but "smoke and mirrors." He said Mr. Clinton had dodged the deficit. He even complained that Mr. Clinton had stolen one of his lines when the Democratic nominee told last week's Democratic convention, "Now that we have changed the world, it's time to change America." 
 Surrogates have gone much further. Last weekend, Senator Jake Garn of Utah warmed up a crowd at a Bush campaign rally by attacking Mr. Clinton's draft record, thus putting that issue back onto front pages and television newscasts. Mr. Garn called Mr. Clinton and Senator Al Gore, his running mate, a team of "pretty boys" who "have spent their entire waking moments since they were teen-agers, planning, plotting, their political careers." (A decidedly different take on the all-baby-boomer ticket.)
Spokesmen for the Bush campaign and Senator Garn said there was no communication between the two about the substance of the attack. "His comments were all extemporaneous," said the Senator's press secretary, Mary Jane Collipriest.
The Democrats were having none of it. "Sure, yeah, right," said James Carville, a top strategist for Mr. Clinton. "There is nothing they do that is not contrived and orchestrated."
Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, said Mr. Clinton's economic plan "gives us enough ammunition to run on till Thanksgiving." On Tuesday, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a partisan warrior of some renown, will hold a briefing on the Democrat's economic policy, which Bush forces assert is the same old tax-and-spend liberalism with some moderate window-dressing. They also say that Senator Al Gore, Mr. Clinton's running mate, is an environmental "extremist." (An issue of some import in the industrial Midwest.)
The Bush campaign also has some "values issues" in its sights, Mr. Black said. Abortion. School choice. Mr. Clinton supports giving students a choice of which public schools to attend, but would not give them vouchers they could use in private or parochial school, as Mr. Bush proposes. This is a matter of interest to Catholic voters, Bush strategists say.
Democrats warn darkly of a coming Republican assault on Mr. Clinton's character; his image only recently began recovering from the primary season, when he spent much of his time denying charges of infidelity and having avoided the draft.
Democrats say that Mr. Bush has no positive message that can win him re-election, so he must rely on the destruction of his opponent. The effort is carefully planned, they say, to protect Mr. Bush as much as possible. "It's always one step away from George Bush," said Ginny Terzano, press secretary for the Democratic National Committee. "It's never his hands on it, or his sound bite. It's always one sound bite away."
The Republicans counter that they are simply running a campaign on the issues. "We don't have anything in mind for the foreseeable future that does not relate to substantive issues," Mr. Black says. They also correctly note that the Democrats at last week's convention were hardly gentle in their assessments of the Bush Administration.
Still, there are risks for the Republicans in going too far. There is the memory of 1988, when the Bush forces ran what was widely considered to be a state-of-the-art negative campaign against Michael S. Dukakis. The Bush campaign drew considerable criticism for its emphasis on the case of Willie Horton, a black convicted murderer who escaped during a weekend furlough from the Massachusetts prison system, and later raped a Maryland woman and stabbed her fiance.
There is the more recent memory of the Bush campaign's surrogate assault on Ross Perot, whose standing in the polls was falling when he left the race last week. The danger for Mr. Bush is that voters come to see him as a man with little more to his campaign than attacks. This is clearly what the Democrats hope to convey.
Mr. Carville says: "When they attack us, we're going to say this: 'That George Bush said he'd do anything to get re-elected. That we know he'll fight with heart and soul to stay in power. But he won't do anything to help the economy. Just do something to help people, Mr. Bush.' "
Whatever the risk, the Bush campaign confronts some basic facts: The economy is still ailing, the President's approval ratings are low, and Mr. Clinton seems to be making substantial progress in redefining himself as the bright young agent of change. Can the Republicans afford to let that proceed? Particularly when their experience shows that he who defines his opponent first wins?
Mr. Bush, who always seemed annoyed by the criticism of his 1988 campaign, talked of himself today as more victim than victimizer. "I have a very quiet confidence that when I take my case to the American poeple, that things will work out," he said in a Rose Garden ceremony when he was asked a sympathetic question about his treatment by the news media. "But you know, to be very honest, it's not pleasant. It's not pleasant."
The one certainty about the next few weeks is that it will not be pleasant.
