HEADLINE: An Industry's Winners and Losers Once a Free-Trade Pact Is Signed

SERIES: A New North America -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARTINSBURG, W. Va.

 BODY:
The West Virginia glass industry has become a kind of prism through which North America's steady march toward a sweeping new free-trade agreement can be seen.
The new pact with Mexico and Canada, which the three Governments now seem likely to reach within weeks, will clearly have widespread economic ramifications. 
 It will add jobs, wealth and economic activity throughout the continent, economists say, but at the same time will bring hardship to a minority of individuals.
 
Job Gains for Some
 The treaty will, among other things, provide businesses in the United States, Canada and Mexico with a market of 370 million consumers -- greater than the European Community -- with each country gaining millions of new customers.
And consumers of all three countries will be able to buy an increased variety of goods, at reduced prices.
Nowhere are forces of change that have brought the three countries together now or the ramifications of a new treaty more evident than in the glass industry of West Virginia.
The 660 workers of the automated Corning Inc. factory here, for example, can expect greater job security than they have now, and new jobs may be added. Their employer, like scores of other big American corporations that have become much more international in the last decade, has formed an alliance with an overseas competitor -- in this case, Vitro S.A., the giant glass company of Mexico. Corning is expected to gain substantially from rising sales as Mexico cuts its tariffs.
But about 2,000 workers in small handmade-glass factories 160 miles to the west, on the other side of the Appalachians, face possible financial ruin. Even with tariffs that currently add up to 38 cents to the cost of each dollar's worth of imported glass, half the local industry has already gone bankrupt in the last decade, partly because of Mexican competition.
"If that duty is released, it's just going to kill us," said Michael Hall, president and part owner of a small company, Mid Atlantic of West Virginia Inc., which makes high-quality glass flower vases and drinking glasses in two kilns set up in a warehouse in rural Ellenboro.
And experts say the changes will reverberate throughout the region, For example, United States exports to Mexico accounted for nearly a tenth of all economic growth in this country since President Bush took office and should increase even faster.
Intense negotiations to complete the treaty have been held in secret and all negotiated texts have been classified. Nevertheless it is known that broad agreements have been reached on issues involving many important industries, including banking, advertising, securities, insurance and trucking. Deals in some other areas, like the auto industry and farming, are nearly complete, and top trade officials from all three countries will meet on July 25 in Mexico to iron out as many remaining details as possible.
Although the other big glass producers -- Libbey Glass Inc., the Anchor Hocking Glass Company and the Indiana Glass Company -- are still working fiercely to maintain high tariffs, particularly on tumblers and stemware, their ranks are now split by the defection of Corning, the largest glass maker in the country, and once a powerful and influential opponent of reducing import duties on glass that now aggressively advocates the free-trade agreement.
Another of the biggest and oldest supporters of glass tariffs, the Anchor Glass Container Corporation of Keyser, 50 miles west of here, was purchased by Vitro several years ago.
Lobbying by companies like Corning and Anchor in the glass business, and their counterparts in many industries, has raised the chances of the pact's signing and eventual passage by Congress. By contrast, resistance to the free-trade pact from West Virginia's many small, handmade-glass companies and their employees has been virtually nonexistent or ineffective.
The employees' national union, the American Flint Glass Workers, has not been visible since organizing a large letter-writing campaign a year ago against the opening of negotiations with Mexico. The union, which has never called a strike at Corning, now is also divided and has been especially quiet about the planned agreement.
And the small producers are leaderless. Their trade group, dependent on foreign makers of glass-making equipment for much of its annual dues, has been paralyzed. When Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, asked 16 small companies for their views, he received only three short replies.
"When you're salesman, president and janitor, it's hard to have the time to lobby," said Kenneth B. Dalzell, who heads the 60-employee Dalzell Corporation in New Martinsville. He did not reply to the Senator's letter.
 
The Losers
A Venerable Craft Faces Extinction
 Mid Atlantic's kiln in Ellenboro is the size of a two-car garage. Glass blowers work there at a craft that has changed little since the 19th century when the industry grew up along the banks of an Ohio River that provided easy barge transportation for the needed sand.
In front of each of a half-dozen white-hot kiln portholes, several middle-aged workers dressed in T-shirts turn molten glass into flower vases with iron pincers and the strength of their lungs.
Standing in the heat, S. Douglas Davis takes a five-foot hollow stainless steel tube that two other men have prepared and pushes it into the glowing, molten glass. He slowly twirls it to gather an even layer of glass around the tip, then withdraws the rod and passes it to James C. Davis, a glass blower who is not related to his co-worker.
James Davis breathes gently through the rod until the soft, clear goo has expanded to the desired length and diameter. Then he places the glass in a vise-shaped mold at his feet, clamps the vise shut with a foot pedal and blows a little more air through the rod so that the hot glass fills the mold. He releases the foot pedal and hangs the rod and newly blown flower vase upside down on a metal rack. Other men -- the only women in the factory pack boxes with finished glass -- will shape the base and then use iron pincers to sever the vase from the rod.
The job takes a year or two to learn properly, and pays about $10 an hour. Labor accounts for half the cost of making glass in West Virginia, and natural gas accounts for another fifth. Mexican wages are $1.50 an hour and gas there is 15 percent cheaper.
Mid Atlantic has a tenuous grip on its business. It sells many of its drinking glasses to the nearby Fenton Art Glass Company, which paints or carves them with the brand names of beers and soft drinks.
When Fenton set up its decorating operation in the mid-1980's, it bought blank glasses from Vitro. Fenton switched to Mid Atlantic after Mr. Hall and a friend bought the 50-year-old factory in 1987 and reduced prices by eliminating health insurance and vacations and cutting wages by 25 percent.
But George W. Fenton, the president of the company, said that even with these drastic economies, glass from Mid Atlantic was only competitive with Vitro's glass because of the current tariffs.
With even a small drop in tariffs, Mr. Fenton said he might switch back to Vitro. "There's not a lot of difference price-wise" with the tariff included, he said. "They do a good job."
If small-town glass factories in West Virginia are forced to close, job prospects for their employees are not good. Doddridge County is the seventh poorest of West Virginia's 55 counties and has an unemployment rate of 11.5 percent. A quarter of the county's population receives government assistance.
Blowing glass is a highly specialized skill not needed by other industries. And most of the workers in the industry are lifelong West Virginia residents with little preparation and scant interest in moving to cities hundreds of miles away in search of work. If the factory closed, James Davis said: "There's nothing I could do. I'd just go home and see about going on food stamps."
The trade talks have proceeded for 13 months. Yet only in the last month have Administration officials begun to review seriously how much money, if any, they should scrape together in the Federal budget for workers who may lose their jobs as a result of the pact.
The workers themselves, who will bear much of the burden of the free-trade accord, see few ways to influence the outcome. One older glass man walking between the Fenton's kilns in Williamstown confided that he thought the free-trade agreement "stinks." But he had not sent any letters to his senator or representative.
"I can't write," he said. "I don't know how to spell right."
 
The Winners
A Chance to Win New Customers
 Corning's patented glass and ceramic mixtures, which can tolerate sudden temperature changes, were developed during the 1950's for use in the nose cones of American space rockets and nuclear-tipped missiles. Corning built its factory here in 1960, putting cold war technology to civilian use in casserole dishes and pots that could go from the refrigerator to the oven.
With $150 million invested over three decades, the factory now produces Corning's latest clear pots and dishes, the Visions line, which can be used over an open flame. The main building stands several stories tall and covers the area of two football fields. At one end squats a tank that is full of molten glass and as big as a two-story house. Corning is spending $6 million here this summer to speed the time it takes to change the colors of the pots and pans.
Day and night, seven days a week, the molten glass, heated to 3,100 degrees Fahrenheit, pours into molds made from a specially hardened steel alloy first used in aircraft turbines.
David G. Lyons, plant manager at the Corning factory here, made his company's strongest argument for a free-trade agreement with Mexico while standing next to a four-armed machine here that grabs glass pots and sticks flowery decals on them. Mr. Lyons said he and his wife still used a set of blue flower-motif Corning dishes received as a wedding gift 26 years ago.
"That's one of our problems, it lasts so long that we've got to be continually putting out new products and decorations," he said as he walked on toward the oven where the decals are fused to the pots.
By eliminating tariffs and other trade barriers along the nation's southern border, a free-trade accord will ease sales to 90 million increasingly prosperous Mexicans whose kitchen cabinets are not yet crowded with Corning's cookware and plates.
Nor are the workers at Corning complaining, even as the plant expands to meet export demand and some adverse effects of the trade-agreement become clear to them.
Max J. Corbin, the vice president of the factory's chapter of the American Flint Glass Workers, said about the pact: "If you're thriving, then you don't hear about it. But if you're down crawling, on unemployment, then you're going to start crying out."
 
The Theories
Weighing Effect Of Ending Tariffs
 Economists say the free-trade treaty will benefit customers, retailers and manufacturers while creating jobs. "We're talking about, on net, 100,000 jobs in the U.S., broadly scattered, and increased efficiency" as companies locate their factories in whichever country provides the best combination of labor, investment and transportation, said Gary C. Hufbauer, an economist at the Institute of International Economics, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.
Even without the elimination of import duties, these movements are under way and are strongly defended by corporations. In the consumer glass market, imports have captured two-fifths of the United States consumer glass market, and Richard Dulude, a vice chairman of Corning who heads the joint venture with Vitro, said the Mexican products would replace imports from Europe and Southeast Asia instead of competing with small West Virginia companies. Vitro currently controls only 4 percent of the overall United States glass market, but has larger market shares for some types of glass produced by small West Virginia factories.
The United States, Mexico and Canada have negotiated schedules for eliminating tariffs on all but a couple of hundred products, including many types of glass, of the 20,000 different product categories at issue.
While tariffs for most products will be eliminated immediately or over 5 or 10 years, tariffs on most consumer glassware are almost certain to be placed in the longest phase-out category of 12 to 20 years to help the small glass makers adjust. Even under the longest schedule, tariffs will have fallen significantly by the end of the decade.
Yet so far the issue of compensating losers from an agreement has received limited attention. The reason is partly the Federal budget deficit but also the Administration's position that Government should not interfere in the market by helping any specific industry.
"Who knows where the American economy will be in 15 or 20 years?" one senior official said when told of the glass workers' worries. "Maybe there will be jobs for them in the service sector, maybe computer catalogue jobs."

HEADLINE: BAKER AND RABIN NEAR A LOAN DEAL

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 20

 BODY:
A deal seemed to be shaping up today for housing loan guarantees from the United States to Israel, in which Washington would give the Israelis the guarantees they are seeking in exchange for broad limits on settlement-building activity, but not a total freeze.
A senior State Department official briefed reporters after the second day of talks here between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Israel's new Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin. The official said he was now hopeful that an arrangement for loan guarantees could be worked out in a way that would "match their needs as well as ours." 
 Israel is seeking $10 billion in guarantees from Washington to help it provide housing and jobs for immigrants from the former Soviet Union.
 
Election-Season Bonus
 The conclusion and announcement of a deal would be left for a meeting between Mr. Rabin and President Bush that is expected to take place at Mr. Bush's Kennebunkport, Me., home some time early next month. In an election year, Mr. Bush would presumably like to gain the greatest political benefit he can with Jewish voters by announcing a deal with Mr. Rabin at his side.
Mr. Baker seems to be trying to set up the basis of that deal on this trip, before his expected resignation as Secretary of State and move to the White House to help steer Mr. Bush's re-election campaign and shape overall Administration policies.
An announcement of Mr. Baker's job switch could come as soon as the end of this trip on Sunday. After his swing around the Middle East, Mr. Baker will fly to Manila for a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
Neither Israeli nor American officials would provide details of the loan guarantee arrangement they are working on. But they said that in broad outline it involves Israel announcing its intention to substantially limit all settlement activity in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as a condition for the American guarantees.
The United States is apparently ready to allow the Israelis to finish a certain number of housing units under construction in the territories, as well as permit a limited degree of "natural growth" in existing settlements in the Jerusalem area and the Jordan River valley. Mr. Rabin considers both of these security regions where some building must be allowed.
 
Calculus of Vital Interests
 The Jordan valley divides Israel and Jordan, and the Israelis have military installations there. Jerusalem has been reunited as the Israeli capital since East Jerusalem was captured from the Jordanians in the 1967 war. Every Israeli Government has insisted on building in and around Jerusalem to emphasize that the city will not again be divided.
Natural growth would involve either adding rooms to existing houses or constructing roads and bridges to accommodate growing families. Israeli and American officials stress that the exact numbers in these categories was still to be determined.
Mr. Rabin's officials are still sorting through the records of the previous Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, trying to get a grip on what sort of building commitments it had undertaken in the West Bank and Gaza, Israeli officials said. The officials added that the records were a mess and that there was a lot of activity they were not yet fully aware of.
While Mr. Baker and Mr. Bush had told the previous Government that they would allow it to finish housing units under way in exchange for loan guarantees, they were strict on the numbers involved and the limits on natural growth. Given Mr. Rabin's intention to shift spending away from the territories, the Bush Administration is ready to be somewhat more flexible with him.
Today, the Prime Minister had his Finance Minister, Avraham Shochat, and the Governor of the Bank of Israel, Jacob Frenkel, brief Mr. Baker on the general economic policies of his Government. The officials made clear that Israel intends to transfer as many resources as possible from the occupied territories to towns and factories inside the nation's pre-1967 boundaries.
Speaking to reporters after that briefing, Mr. Baker said: "We just had a full discussion with our colleagues about the reordering of national priorities that the new Government is undertaking. I hope and believe that I have made it clear to the Prime Minister and his colleagues that President Bush and this Administration in the United States attach a very high priority to the absorption of immigrants to Israel."
Nevertheless, American officials say, what is still needed is wording that will demonstrate that the Bush Administration is maintaining its position that settlements do not "promote peace" while at the same time allowing enough of a loophole for Mr. Rabin to finish a certain number of houses previously contracted and to augment those settlements he considers vital to national security.
Mr. Baker and Mr. Rabin were discussing the precise wording of that diplomatic formula tonight.
 
Considering Palestinians, Too
 Such a formula also has to be one that the Palestinians can live with. Palestinian leaders say they cannot go on cooperating with Washington if it is perceived to be subsidizing Israeli settlement building.
Mr. Baker and other American officials met today with a Palestinian delegation led by Faisal al-Husseini and Hanan Ashrawi. During their talks, the Secretary apparently told the Palestinians that whatever deal he worked out with Mr. Rabin would involve broad limits on settlement building, with some small exceptions.
He seems to have urged them to keep their eye on the broad limits and not get caught up in the exceptions, inasmuch as Mr. Rabin is clearly shifting Israeli priorities.
Mrs. Ashrawi, speaking to reporters right after the talks, signaled that the Palestinians had gotten the message and were apparently willing to tolerate such a deal, provided that it really does involve a near-total freeze on settlements and provided that the Americans insure that none of their funds would be spent in the occupied territories.
Mrs. Ashrawi said the Palestinians would not demand "a total settlements freeze before negotiations" with the Rabin Government, just as they did not insist on such a freeze as a condition for talks with Mr. Shamir. They would prefer a freeze, she said, but are realistic about the situation.
She added that the Palestinians could tolerate a granting of loan guarantees by Washington and would not walk out of the peace talks "if the U.S. insures that its funds are not used for settlement activities and has the ability to adequately monitor" Israeli spending.
The loan guarantees that Israel is seeking are not grants. They involve the United States' guaranteeing repayment of loans Israel takes out from private banks in the event of an Israeli default on those loans. The guarantees will enable Israel to get loans at favorable interest rates.
The cost to Washington would be several hundred million dollars that the Treasury would set aside to cover potential defaults, with the exact amount depending on the total of the Israeli loans.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hanan Ashrawi of the Palestinian delegation said yesterday that the Palestinians will not demand "a total settlements freeze before negotiations" but would prefer a total freeze. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Citing Fear of City Crime, Nassau Raises Police Salaries

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 20

 BODY:
In suburbia, where the police are hailed as heroes -- and given some of the highest salaries in the country -- the onset of fiscal problems can produce particularly wrenching conflicts.
When a retired carpenter, Frank Abrami of Seaford, stood at a meeting of the Nassau County Supervisors and warned that a new police contract approved today could push the county toward fiscal ruin, "down the slippery slope like New York City," county officials were not amused by the comparison. 
 "Nassau is not going to be New York City," said the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican. Referring to the audience, made up almost entirely of off-duty police officers, he added, "the people who are behind you are going to make sure that is not the case."
So it went as the Nassau County Board of Supervisors, in a fit of New York City bashing, approved a contract that would grant police officers perhaps the highest pay of any large department in the country, with raises far beyond the rate of inflation.
By a vote of 4 to 2, the supervisors raised police salaries to an average of $59,000 in 1995. The action came at a time when the county has laid off or demoted 2,300 other county workers and is seeking to borrow $65 million to keep its budget in balance.
But Benjamin Zwirn, the supervisor from the town of North Hempstead, his voice rising in outrage, said criminals were now stealing his neighbors' cars in broad daylight. "And they are heading west, not east," he said, motioning toward the boundary that divides the county from the big city to the west.
The police officers cheered. There were so many of them filling the Board of Supervisors chambers here -- 600 of the county's 1,600 or so Patrolmen's Benevolent Association members showed up for a rally outside -- that other citizens who had something to say were forced to wait in the hallway until it was their turn to speak.
Under the four-year contract, the police agreed to some concessions, including a freeze on wages this year, givebacks for newly hired officers, and deferral of some pay.
 
Increases Top Inflation
 In return, salaries for officers will raise to the highest level in the metropolitan area. Officers with 20 years' experience will see their pay rise by 1995 to $64,442, from $51,124, an increase of 26 percent, according to the police union. For the most experienced officers, pay would top $64,400.
In June the annual rate of inflation in the metropolitan area was 3.4 percent.
The police union says the contract all but pays for itself. But the contract was challenged by anti-tax advocates and by the Long Island Association, a major business group, which concluded that it would eventually cost the county $75 million.
Opponents of the settlement said that new longevity payments -- increases based on length of service -- would increase the salaries of many officers even further, bringing raises of as much as 55 percent for some officers.
When the contract was first negotiated by Mr. Gulotta, members of the Board of Supervisors from both parties grumbled about the cost. But when it came time to vote, all three Republicans and one Democrat, Mr. Zwirn, voted yes. Some were enthusiastic, some said they voted for it out of fear that the alternative -- binding arbitration -- could be worse.
Mr. Gulotta offered ebullient praise for the police and scorn for the critical business group.
"Let them go out and risk their lives and tell us what this contract is worth," he said.
 
Memorial for a Taxpayer
 Moments before the vote, Pat Friedman, from Garden City South, a leader of a tax revolt group here, announced that taxpayer groups would hold a mock funeral procession bearing the casket of a "dead taxpayer" and a grieving mother, through the streets of Nassau County to protest taxes and spending.
"We are dead and we will demand a funeral procession for Nassau County taxpayers," she said.
But she was applauded by the audience when she declared that she was not anti-police -- her brother was a New York City police officer -- and said she understood that police officers in the county were pressing for more money because "they cannot afford to live here either."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Attacks Clinton Economic Plan as 'Big Mistake'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
President Bush today delivered his strongest attack to date on the Democratic Presidential candidacy of Bill Clinton, calling the Arkansas Governor's economic proposals "smoke and mirrors" and "a big mistake" that would increase the Federal deficit.
Mr. Bush said a 27-page economic plan Mr. Clinton issued in June would damage the economy by raising taxes and the deficit. He also said Mr. Clinton's proposals to save money by streamlining programs and reducing "overhead" were illusory. 
 "What I see is a program that does not address itself to the deficit," Mr. Bush said in a Rose Garden talk with members of Boys Nation, an American Legion civics program. "I think we've got to get the deficit down. I don't think you need to go raise taxes on people right now. I think that's a big mistake. I think it's counterproductive."
 
Bad News on Economy
 The comments came as Mr. Bush's advisers gave him a mid-year report on the nation's economy, which most economists agree is stumbling partly under the weight of the Federal budget deficit that has doubled, to almost $400 billion a year, during Mr. Bush's tenure.
Mr. Bush's economic adviser, Michael Boskin, told the President that the annual rate of economic growth had declined in the second quarter from the 2.7 percent rate of the first three months of 1992, said one official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The President's remarks appeared to signal the opening of a tougher and more personal campaign style by Mr. Bush, who trails Mr. Clinton in public opinion polls by 20 points or more. Until now, Mr. Bush has left it to his aides and other Republican surrogates to mount direct attacks on Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee.
Mr. Bush has long said he would refrain from attacking his opponents directly until after the Republican convention next month, a pledge his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, repeated today. On Saturday morning Mr. Bush stood offstage at a rally in Provo, Utah, as that state's retiring Senator, Jake Garn, criticized Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore as "pretty boys" who had never held jobs in the private sector, and assailed Mr. Clinton's efforts to avoid the military draft during the Vietnam War.
Mr. Clinton's spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, ridiculed Mr. Bush's statement today, saying the Clinton campaign would match its economic proposals "up against his any day of the week."
"George Bush has the worst economic record of any President since Herbert Hoover," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "If he wants to debate it, we're ready."
Mr. Clinton proposes $220 billion in spending on new public works programs, education and tax cuts for families by 1996, to be offset by almost $300 billion in spending cuts.
The combination of spending cuts, improved productivity and higher economic growth would cut the Federal deficit by $150 billion over that four-year period, Mr. Clinton argues.
In his comments, the President said that he and Mr. Clinton "have a big difference on the economic approach" that the White House planned to highlight in the fall campaign. But the two Clinton proposals that drew much of Mr. Bush's fire today, commitments to reduce Government waste and to raise taxes on the wealthy, are as notable for their political significance as any money they would produce.
Merely making unspecified administrative changes, Mr. Clinton argues, would save $22 billion by 1996 and streamlining the Pentagon's inventory would save $9.8 billion. Mr. Stephanopoulos said today that the savings would be produced by applying private business practices to the Federal Government and imposing a 2 percent cut in Federal spending on items other than payrolls.
Mr. Clinton's savings proposals recall Ronald Reagan's pledge, as a Presidential candidate in 1980, to reduce 2 percent of all nonmilitary Federal spending by cutting "waste, extravagance, abuse and outright fraud." Many critics accused Mr. Reagan of engaging in sophistry at the time, and Mr. Bush said the same of Mr. Clinton today.
"When you analyze the program, they have this expression around here -- 'smoke and mirrors,' " Mr. Bush said of Mr. Clinton's savings plan. "You're going to save it all by eliminating overhead, eliminating waste, and there's billions of dollars that is earmarked to do that, and I just don't think that's practical."
The President also attacked Mr. Clinton's proposal to raise $83 billion over four years, primarily by raising the tax rate for the top 2 percent of wage earners and placing a surtax on $1-million-plus incomes.
 
'Spending Too Much'
 "I think the Government is spending too much," he said. "I don't think people are taxed too little. I mean, I don't think that's the problem." The President called tax increases "a big mistake" that would prove "counterproductive," a reflection of the Administration's belief that tax increases reduce money for investment and stifle economic growth.
Mr. Stephanopoulos agreed today that the Clinton plan called for more taxes on the wealthy, but he said some of that money would be returned to the middle class through a tax cut or a tax credit for children.
Other Administration officials expressed anger at Mr. Stephanopoulos's challenge to compare the Bush and Clinton programs, noting that many elements of the Clinton plan were identical with Mr. Bush's proposals. They include proposals for a national integrated computer network, investments in magnetically levitated trains and "smart" highways monitored by computers, tax credits for research and development, urban enterprise zones and incentives to convert defense industries to civilian uses.
"The one huge, screaming difference is that Clinton's is financed by a $150 billion tax increase, and ours is financed by cuts in entitlement spending and nondefense spending," said one senior Administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The group to which Mr. Bush spoke today, Boys Nation, teaches the tenets of democracy and politics by staging mock elections and legislatures, and by exposing young people to leading public figures. One person who got his first taste of politics at Boys Nation was Mr. Clinton, who still boasts a photograph of himself shaking the hand of President John F. Kennedy at a 1963 meeting of the group.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush with members of the American Legion's Boys Nation program during a question-and-answer session in the Rose Garden. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Tour Touches Small-Town America

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Ohio, July 20

 BODY:
The crowd that streamed into Utica, Ohio, Sunday night doubled the town's population of about 2,000, clogged streets and yards that had to be turned into parking lots and spilled over onto side streets for blocks around.
And when the Clinton-Gore motor tour reached the Clinton County Courthouse here today, this time in the middle of a workday, a similar crowd waited, patiently standing under a broiling sun for a rally that started more than an hour late. 
 The thousands of people who have come to hear Bill Clinton and Al Gore have appeared along the route because they have seen the candidates on television or been invited by officials of the state Democratic Party. But they have also come to hear what the two men have to say.
"Ladies and gentlemen, you have some clear choices in this election," Mr. Clinton said today, practically thundering into the microphone in the picturesque town square here. "They go way beyond party politics, beyond Republican and Democrat, beyond liberal and conservative to the heart of the question. Are we for the future or the past? Are we going to go on to a new direction or have four more years of the same?"
 
Lennon, Not Sousa
 The music has changed at the rallies as the new ticket has discovered that their relative youth is an advantage. There is more John Lennon ("Power to the People") and John Mellencamp and less John Philip Sousa.
And although the traditional roster of politicians attends the rallies -- Senators Howard M. Metzenbaum and John Glenn in Ohio or Gov. Jim Florio in New Jersey -- they seldom share the stage.
The candidates' day usually begins with a jog before they climb onto their luxury buses for the trip to the first midmorning event. Mr. Gore, who began the trip by giving full, slightly blustery speeches about the state of the nation, has now begun to devote more of his remarks to praising Mr. Clinton and introducing their wives.
Both men touch on the same themes of change, renewal and the future, and their comments vary little from stop to stop. They have even begun to perfect a tandem question-and-answer style that allows Mr. Clinton to pass on the questions he seems less sure of.
 
An Unexpected Question
 But Mr. Clinton, who is fond of fielding questions at town meetings, did get one surprise this evening when a Louisville, Ky., television station used a taped question from a prominent citizen, Vice President Dan Quayle.
Mr. Quayle was in Louisville last week and taped the question directed to Mr. Clinton, criticizing an economic plan that the Vice President said would raise taxes.
"Why is a tax increase the centerpiece of your economic growth agenda?" Mr. Quayle asked Mr. Clinton in the taped piece. "Now, I know you'll say you're just going to tax the wealthy, but we've heard that before. When you Democrats start defining wealthy, it becomes defined as anyone who has a job.
"I don't buy this idea that it's just going to be a few that are going to be taxed," he said. "When you start talking about tax increases everyone gets hit."
Mr. Clinton responded, "Read my lips," and the audience burst into laughter.
"No responsible person would ever do what George Bush did and say 'Read my lips,' " Mr. Clinton said. He added that the question was not "entirely straightforward."
The candidates' message of change is a tireless repetition of the theme that the Democrats are convinced will give them the advantage in November. They hope that by winning over the independents and Republicans who have said they were profoundly disillusioned with politics and government, they can maintain the edge they have gained in public opinion polls.
 
Pounding Home the Message
 The bus tour, which left New York City on Friday with plans to cover 1,000 miles through eight states before ending Tuesday in St. Louis, has taken the reinvigorated Democratic Presidential campaign to the sort of setting Mr. Clinton likes best and is most familiar with after 11 years as Governor of a small, mostly rural state.
By pounding home the message that they will be able to change a country that polls have shown many Americans think is on the wrong track, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore are presenting themselves as the very essence of everything new and improved.
Along the route, the two Democrats are offering a laundry list of sweeping policy promises for voters: "to rebuild the economy, secure their future, build up their children's education, provide health care for all, liberate the energies of the American people and make America win again," as Mr. Clinton said today in Wilmington, about 50 northeast of Cincinnati.
But the towns are almost always small, the crowds largely white and the events carefully planned to be colorful and camera-friendly.
 
'I Like the Vision'
 "I like the things they're saying about change," said Ira Rubins, 41 years old, an association executive who had driven two and a half hours from Cleveland to Utica, about 30 miles northeast of Columbus, with his wife and sister-in-law to catch a glimpse of the Clinton-Gore ticket. "I like the vision they have. They have experience in the kinds of things running government takes."
His wife, Cathie, added, "They have a lot of specifics to say."
Such words, coming from a couple who hauled lawn chairs to Utica and patiently waited five hours for the candidates to appear, are exactly what the Clinton-Gore campaign advisers are dying to hear.
"We don't have the answers to every problem," Mr. Gore said today. "But we've got a brand new approach to governing that puts people first for a change."
In these appearances, Mr. Clinton often wears plaid shirts instead of suits. Seated on a hay bale next to his wife, Hillary, on Sunday, he actually chewed on a piece of straw. And Mr. Gore and his wife, Tipper, offer the very picture of a middle-American couple. Together, they project the image of the family values ticket, a challenge to Republicans who have said Democrats are too far out of the mainstream.
Neither Mr. Clinton nor Mr. Gore resists naked political pitches to Ross Perot supporters, and Perot supporters in Kentucky planned to meet with Mr. Clinton in Louisville. The candidates also seem delighted when the Republican opposition attacks.
"What are they going to do?" Mr. Clinton asked in Utica. "They're going to run us down. They've already started. They say: 'You vote for Clinton and Gore, those guys are kooks.'
"Look, the crowd in Washington now, they raise the taxes on people who drive pickup trucks and lower them on people who ride in limousines," he said. "Who are they to talk about tax and spend?"
The crowds are easily stirred these days, and even when the motorcade snarls highway traffic, trapped motorists generally smile, wave or grab their cameras to take pictures of the decorated buses. Mr. Gore has taken the chant he started last week at the convention, on the road.
He shouts: "What time is it?"
The crowd chants back: "It's time for them to go."
Or, as one young man did today in Columbus: "It's 10:15."

HEADLINE: SARAJEVO AIRLIFT SUSPENDED BY U.N. AFTER TRUCE FAILS

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovi na, July 20

 BODY:
The first 24 hours of a cease-fire negotiated by the European Community passed today amid such heavy fighting that the United Nations military commander here closed Sarajevo Airport and suspended the airlift of food and medicine that has been sustaining this besieged city.
Because of the airport closing, ordered by Maj. Gen. Lewis W. MacKenzie of Canada, no relief aircraft flew in here for the first time in 23 days. 
 The United Nations airlift began immediately after President Francois Mitterrand of France visited here on June 28. Until today, it stood as virtually the only breakthrough in outside efforts to mitigate the bitter war that has engulfed this newly independent republic.
 
Capital's Mood Is Grim
 At dusk today, artillery, mortar and sniper fire continued to resound around Sarajevo, as it had from the moment the cease-fire was scheduled to take effect at 6 P.M. on Sunday. But the mortar battle across the airport that prompted General MacKenzie to halt all aid flights appeared to have eased. United Nations officials said that if security in the airfield area continued to improve, they hoped to resume the 20 daily relief flights on Tuesday morning.
The mood in this capital after a day of the most intense shelling in a month was grim. The attacks added to the distress of a population that has spent the last eight days with little or no electricity and running water as a result of Serbian attacks on the major power lines running to the city.
According to figures compiled from Sarajevo hospitals, the shelling, apparently originating from Serbian forces on the hills surrounding the city, killed at least 15 people and wounded more than 100.
 
Not Peace, but Terror
 Most of the casualties resulted from mortar attacks of the kind that have killed and wounded thousands of civilians in Sarajevo since the war began early in April. The effect was to turn what was to have been a peaceful day to one of terror, with people running in panic from explosions that left as many as 15 people at a time lying in pools of blood in the street, some dead and others grievously wounded.
One mortar shell struck a narrow street near the old military hospital in the city center shortly before noon, killing 2 people and wounding 12. David Turnley, a photographer for The Detroit Free Press, said that he followed the wounded to a hospital and saw a man of about 60 lying dead beneath a blanket in a corridor, still clutching two loaves of bread bought at a bakery near where the shell hit.
He said a middle-aged woman who was severely wounded in the attack, on learning that her 9-year-old son had been killed, cried out repeatedly, "Bush! Bush!" apparently a plea of the kind often made here for American military intervention.
Other mortar shells struck near the Magribia Mosque in the city center and in front of the Presidency building, the seat of the Government. Still others fell in the western suburbs of the city, including Dobrinja, where 35,000 people have been surrounded by Serbian forces for nearly 80 days.
One of the worst attacks, in Vojnicko Polje, a suburb close to Dobrinja, hit four teen-age girls taking the evening air on Sunday.
Dr. Abdulah Nakas, chief surgeon at the old military hospital, said that one of the girls, aged 15, was in a coma from the head wounds inflicted by shrapnel and was unlikely to recover.
One of the girl's friends, in an adjacent ward, said they had taken the walk an hour after the cease-fire was to have begun. "We thought it was going to be quiet," she said.
The failure of the cease-fire surprised few here, after a succession of truces in recent weeks that were broken as soon as they began. But it attracted more attention than earlier ones that were negotiated by United Nations military commanders here, in part because it was reached in London after negotiations led by Lord Carrington, the former British Foreign Secretary who is chairman of the European Community's Conference on Yugoslavia.
General MacKenzie, announcing the airport shutdown at a news conference at the United Nations headquarters here, expressed a wearied view of the situation born of his own repeated frustrations in obtaining signed commitments to cease-fires that turned out to be meaningless.
"I had held some hope that since the cease-fire was negotiated at a high level it would be more successful than previous ones," he said, "but quite frankly it seems that the level of the fighting is proportional to the level at which the cease-fire is negotiated."
 
General's Assignment Ending
 For the general, the collapse of the cease-fire was a major disappointment, coming as it did only 10 days before his assignment here is scheduled to end.
When General MacKenzie, who is 52 years old, announced last week that he would be returning to an army command in Canada at the end of the month, he denied speculation here that he was being removed by the United Nations because of the animosity toward him by Bosnian Government officials. These have accused him of leaning toward the Serbian side in the delicate negotiations that he has conducted during his months here.
The general said that the 850-member Canadian battalion that has provided the bulk of the United Nations military force here would be returning at the end of the month to United Nations cease-fire units in Croatia. Under standard United Nations practice, he said, the Sarajevo command will pass to a general from one of the three countries that will be providing detachments to replace the Canadians, France, Egypt and Ukraine.
 
Gorazde Suffers Again
 Elsewhere across this republic, the amateur radio operators who are the only link between Sarajevo and a few remaining Government-held towns reported that intense Serbian attacks continued throughout the first day of the cease-fire.
The starkest report came from Gorazde, the only predominantly Muslim town in eastern Bosnia not to have been captured by Serbian troops who have swept through the region in what Serbian political leaders have described as a campaign to "cleanse" the entire area of Muslims.
In one radio report from Gorazde, a man's voice told of artillery attacks so heavy that wounded had to be left lying in the streets. "Please tell the world that this is what the Serbian promises in London have come to," the man said.
Alija Izetbegovic, the Bosnian President, renewed his appeal for United States military intervention, saying that American bombing attacks on the Serbian gun positions around Sarajevo would be enough to break the siege and give Government defenders a chance to fight on a more equal basis. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Europe's Cold Shoulder
 BRUSSELS, July 20 (Special to The New York Times) -- The European Community declared today that it would oppose the membership of the Yugoslavia composed of Serbia and Montenegro in international bodies, sealing that federation's isolation in Europe.
At its monthly meeting of foreign ministers here, the community accepted the opinion of its legal experts that the state formed by Serbia and Montenegro is not the successor to the former Yugoslavia and thus must be admitted anew to the United Nations, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and more than 40 other international bodies.
The new state had already been suspended by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and the Council of Europe. Each body has its own criteria and the European Community's opinion is not binding.
The foreign ministers approved the allocation of $168 million made earlier in the month by the European Commission for Bosnian refugees, but made no decision about where the money would be applied or whether individual community countries would accept refugees. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.N. Delays Action
 UNITED NATIONS, July 20 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Security Council delayed taking action today on the crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina. After an informal meeting, delegates said that the Council would most likely limit itself to urging the warring sides to observe the cease-fire agreement.
The Bosnian Foreign Minister, Haris Silajdzic, met with several members of the Security Council to urge them to take more decisive action, but said afterward that he was disappointed by the lukewarm reaction he received.
"This cease-fire plays into the hands of the aggressors," Mr. Silajdzic said.

HEADLINE: Congress Opens Midsummer Session With Bills on Spending and Abortion

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Congress today began a four-week session, wedged between the two political conventions, that will be devoted to both scoring campaign points and passing legislation to keep the Government in cash and to settle complex issues like energy and cable television.
Only one bill with clear implications for the Presidential campaign will come up in both houses of Congress this session, the Freedom of Choice Act, which would prohibit most state restrictions on abortion. The House will also take up a tax bill aimed at increasing the tax on people who earn more than $1 million a year in order to subsidize food and social services for needy children. 
 Otherwise, most of the major activity in this session will deal with appropriations bills and complex, important, but not especially partisan measures like reinstituting the regulation of cable television and developing national energy policy.
Still, there is a strong political motive behind fast action on essential measures like spending bills. After these four weeks, Congress recesses for the Republican National Convention and two more weeks of campaigning of its own, and then returns for only three or four weeks before quitting for the year.
 
Lots of Work, Little Time
 "We've got a very full agenda and not much time for it," said Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota.
In the House, the political initiatives will come largely from the Democrats. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, said that while it was late in the Congressional session to develop new partisan legislation the bill to aid children "uniquely" fit that category.
He said the measure -- sponsored by Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk, and called for by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential nominee -- not only aided children but also "taxes the wealthy as the Clinton economic plan said we should."
The waning weeks of the session provide new urgency for another Gephardt effort, the effort to forge at least Democratic agreement on a bill to control the nation's spiraling health-care costs.
"We've got to get it out of committee," Mr. Gephardt said. "That, to me, is the most important bill we've got before us."
 
G.O.P. Focuses on Insurance
 If Mr. Gephardt can secure approval of a health-care bill in the Ways and Means Committee, the legislation may come to a vote on the floor in September. But Republicans will be ready with a substitute that could command wide Democratic backing. The substitute focuses chiefly on health insurance problems, like the difficulties in obtaining small group insurance policies if employees have had health problems.
Comparable efforts by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, to gain agreement on health-care legislation that is probably broader in scope also face an uncertain future.
Aside from abortion, the most likely prospect for a partisan fight in the Senate will come next week, when the Finance Committee takes up legislation for enterprise zones intended to pump economic life into the cities.
The Bush Administration may try to resurrect its call for cuts in capital gains taxes and advantages for home buyers as a way to make its argument that the flagging economy is not its fault. The problem with this approach is that most Senate Republicans, unlike their House counterparts, saw little merit in the Administration's plan when it was first offered last winter.
Senator Mitchell said he hoped there would not be a prolonged effort to restart the Administration program. "I hope we can do the urban aid bill," he said today.
 
Abortion Battle Looms
 Abortion is the one issue sure to lead to confrontations in both houses. Democratic leaders, with substantial Republican support in the Senate, are pressing ahead on the bill to prohibit almost all state restrictions on abortion except statutes requiring parental consent for teen-age abortions.
Supporters contend that if some states make it very hard to obtain an abortion, pregnant women who are poor and have to travel will be denied their constitutional right to equal protection of the law, and interstate commerce will be burdened.
Democrats have the votes to pass the bill in both the House and the Senate, though not enough to override a veto by Mr. Bush. But their ability to draw that line clearly between the Democrats, including Mr. Clinton, and the President could be thwarted by a Senate filibuster.
Senator Mitchell, the chief sponsor of the bill, said "I don't know" when asked if he had the 60 votes needed to cut off debate. He said he would bring the bill up next week.
Action in the House will come later in the session.
On all sides this is clearly a political issue. Both passionate advocates and opponents of the measure see political advantage in getting their votes on the record. Democrats can tell advocates of abortion rights that if Mr. Clinton is elected such a bill would become law. The President can tell opponents of abortion that his re-election is the only thing keeping the legislation off the books.
 
Some Legislative Uncertainties
 It is not yet clear whether the Senate will go forward with House efforts to enact trade legislation intended to identify and put pressure on trading partners who restrict imports from the United States.
Nor is the Senate sure to carry through the House effort to shift some money from foreign aid to highway building, requiring an amendment of the 1990 budget act. Action on that question, and on foreign aid spending itself, is unlikely before September.
But aid for the republics of the former Soviet Union seems to have lost its potential for partisan conflict. House Democrats had kept it off the schedule until domestic measures like extended unemployment benefits and urban aid were dealt with. With those bills now settled, Mr. Gephardt said the aid measure would be scheduled for a vote before Aug. 17, when the Republican convention begins.
This week's schedule has few major partisan conflicts on it. The House will deal with efforts to block most-favored-nation trading status for China and, as it has before, will pass such a bill with Republican help. But the Senate still lacks the votes to override a Presidential veto, and the schedule there is uncertain.
The House also has spending bills and the cable television measure before it. The Senate will deal with energy legislation later this week.
But first it debated garbage legislation -- really. Without taking any votes, the Senate argued about the Interstate Transportation of Municipal Waste Act. It would allow governors to prohibit the importation of trash into their states.

International

HEADLINE: A Campaign to Pull Scranton Back From Disaster

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCRANTON, Pa., July 20

 BODY:
At a news conference that drew somber city officials and community leaders, state officials today released the outlines of a Draconian financial plan intended to halt Scranton's march to certain insolvency this fall.
The state developed the plan after city officials, who were unable to agree on a proposal of their own, filed what amounted to a bankruptcy petition last year. Scranton, the fifth-largest city in Pennsylvania, is by far the largest of 10 municipalities in the state to seek this solution. 
 This city of 81,000 people, a high proportion of them elderly, has a 1992 budget of $40 million and a deficit of $7 million.
Over the past 50 years, the anthracite coal industry has declined and the city has lost nearly half of its population, but it has not made proportional reductions in services. Residents had become accustomed to a high level of services and, until the recession bit even more deeply into revenue, officials found it easier to raise taxes than lay off workers.
 
Budget Out of Kilter
 About 85 percent of the city's budget goes for payroll costs, a far higher percentage than in most cities. Scranton has a fire department with twice as many firefighters as cities of similar size elsewhere in the nation. The city also has the highest taxes in northeastern Pennsylvania, and it cannot raise them without driving away more residents and businesses.
In part because of the city's financial problems, city officials have long been in a political paralysis, said Charles W. Waters, executive director of the Pennsylvania Economy League, a nonprofit research organization. The league, under a state contract, developed Scranton's recovery plan.
"City governance has lost the respect of its citizens to such an extent that even efforts by the city to act responsibly are usually misconstrued and seldom obtain the desired outcome," Mr. Waters said today.
Under the state Financially Distressed Municipalities Act of 1987, a city's elected officials apply to the Department of Community Affairs for designation as a distressed municipality. If a city meets the criteria, the state agency steps in with technical assistance and aid. The state also has wide latitude to reorganize municipal goverment, raise temporary taxes and even dictate terms of labor contracts while the three-year plan is in effect.
Once in the program, cities must adopt the state plan or substitute one that the state agency accepts. If a city does not adopt an approved plan, the state can withhold subsidies.
The state would provide Scranton a $2 million interest-free loan and help it secure private financing to close the rest of the deficit. The 250-page plan also provides a $450,000 grant to help the city study ways to become more efficient. It authorizes a temporary 0.6 percent income tax on about 18,000 nonresidents who work in Scranton. Most savings, though, would come from a 40 percent reduction in health benefits for city employees and a 12 percent reduction in the work force, now at 628, over three years.
It is not yet clear how the everyday lives of Scranton residents will change, although eventually virtually every city service will be affected. It is known that the fire department would take the brunt, losing 50 of 200 firefighters, and about 10 of 140 positions in the police department would be eliminated. Most cuts would be made by attrition because many employees are expected to retire in the next 17 months.
Employees who choose to retire in that period would not be covered by labor contracts, whose terms will call for greatly reduced health benefits for retirees, according to the plan announced today.
 
Fewer Firemen
 After Mr. Waters gave a brief summary of the plan, several officials, including Mayor James P. Connors, praised the effort but said they would not comment until they had reviewed it.
Union leaders were more vocal. "People are going to lose 25 percent of their fire protection," said Terrence F. Osborne, president of the local chapter of the International Association of Firefighters.
Many community leaders support the proposal. "It is strong medicine for a very ill city in some respects, but it has to be taken," said Austin J. Burke, president of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce.
The state agency has scheduled an Aug. 5 public hearing on the plan, and by Aug. 15 will submit a final plan. Then the Mayor and City Council will have 14 days to accept the plan or submit an alternative one.

HEADLINE: New Orleans Journal;
Citadel of History Rises From the Ashes (Again)

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, July 20

 BODY:
Here in South Louisiana where floods, hurricanes, termites, Byzantine politics and subtropical rot come with the territory, a late-18th-century building is rising from ashes, again.
The Cabildo, a survivor of French and Spanish colonial days that was once City Hall and is now a state museum, sits in the heart of the French Quarter beside the St. Louis Cathedral, facing Jackson Square and the Mississippi River in one of the world's most graceful landscapes. 
 Inside, workers are putting the 193-year-old building back together, repairing the wreckage from a fire on May 11, 1988. A spark from a sheet-metal worker's torch is believed to have ignited the fire, which destroyed the third floor. Smoke and water blackened and soaked the remainder.
The fire was only the latest calamity to strike the Cabildo. Formosan termites munched at the foundation during the 1980's. Rioters attacked it in the 1870's. And a 1788 fire that leveled fourth-fifths of the city razed an earlier Cabildo.
"It's one of the most important historic buildings in the country, comparing with Independence Hall in Philadelphia," said Samuel Wilson, the city's leading preservationist architect. The building's graceful arches, shady arcade and handsome wrought iron railings conjure visions of sleepy Spanish colonial capitals -- if the viewer can block out the incongrous Frenchified mansard roof.
The museum, which has a wide-ranging (some would say jumbled) collection that includes art as well as historical objects, was closed from late 1984 to 1986 for lack of money. And even after it reopened its future was precarious. Louisiana's oil-driven economy had been in a recession for much of the decade, and state money was scarce.
"The fire as tragic as it was has turned out to be a blessing in disguise," said James F. Sefcik, a historian who is director of the state museum system. "Now we have money."
The Cabildo (Spanish for town hall) is being rebuilt with $6.5 million from insurance policies and money left from unrelated state capital projects. At the same time, four nearby museum buildings will be fireproofed.
An additional million dollars, raised privately, will finance the permanent exhibit. Without the fire, "we would never have raised a million dollars for an exhibit," said Robert Cangelosi, a former president of the Friends of the Cabildo and the architect overseeing the restoration.
The Cabildo's finest year was 1803, when France sold the Louisiana Territory to the United States for $15 million. Inside the Cabildo on Dec. 20, 1803, the signatories used a silver quill pen to scratch their names on papers that doubled the nation's size.
Over time, the Cabildo became a museum stuffed with objects, many irrelevant to Louisiana's history, like a French tank from World War I. One of the most popular exhibits was a death mask of Napoleon.
The mask, one of four made after Napoleon's death in 1821, was still in the Cabildo when the building burned. As Mr. Sefcik ran up the stairs during the fire, looking up at flames, he suddenly remembered the mask and was elated to find it unharmed.
When the museum reopens next year, exhibits will interpret Louisiana's periodically lurid history, including the unsavory parts.
Changing times complicated replacement of the the third floor and roof. The originals were of virgin cypress, but those were no longer common in the swamplands. Instead, the 42-foot long, 12-inch thick cypress beams supporting the roof had to be cut and milled in Florida and prefabricated in New Hampshire.
While the restoration is supposed to be complete early next year, Mr. Cangelosi said control of the voracious Formosan termite will be "ongoing." The termite, like the Cabildo itself, is a survivor. "Even after the fire," he said, "we found termites eating away in the ashes."

HEADLINE: Currency Intervention Stems Slide in Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
World stock markets fell precipitously yesterday and the dollar flirted with its record low against the German mark before the United States and its economic allies moved forcefully to support the dollar and in the process stabilize other financial markets.
At least 13 central banks bought dollars in the foreign exchange market. The concerted intervention came at a time that the mood of investors was already very bearish about the dollar and becoming negative about stocks as well. 
 A sharp decline in stocks began on Friday, the day after the German central bank raised a key interest rate over the opposition of the United States and its European allies. The German move in one stroke seemed to sour investors' hopes for stronger economic growth and earnings this year in the United States and Europe.
 
Investors' Gains Are Threatened
 "The main driving force for any rally this year has been taken away," said Guy Rigden, global equity strategist at UBS Philips & Drew in London. "You don't have a win situation right now, and if you ask me how much farther markets can go down, I say I don't know." The yearlong rallies in some markets, like Britain and France, have now evaporated. And in Germany, the gains have been cut substantially.
The intervention did help the dollar rebound and did stop the fall of some stock markets yesterday. But it is not yet clear if this signal of economic cooperation can change the ugly mood in the equity markets.
The question remains whether the dollar can be prevented from falling to new lows while higher interest rates in Europe make the world economic outlook even more fragile. The recovery in the United States is still teetering, Japan's economy is in a slump and the British cannot seem to emerge from their recession.
What happens next will depend in some part on what Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, says today in his semiannual testimony to Congress. Investors will be assessing his statements on the economic outlook in the United States, the chance for another Fed easing of short-term interest rates and the level of his concern about the falling dollar.
But Mr. Greenspan is in a difficult position. For example, if interest rates were lowered further to keep the economic recovery going, the cut in rates would probably lead to a weaker dollar by making it less attractive to foreign investors.
Before the intervention yesterday, stock markets around the world had dropped sharply. In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 44 points, but it closed off 28.64 points, or 0.86 percent, at 3,303.00. In Europe, the Financial Times index of the London market plunged 2.7 percent, then came back to close down 1.2 percent. There was a similar rebound in France, where the CAC index ended down 1.9 percent after being down by 3.7 percent. In Germany, there was no rebound after the intervention, and the DAX index closed 3.1 percent lower.
Stock markets across the rest of Europe also declined sharply. In Italy, where the market was also rocked by the assassination of an anti-Mafia prosecutor, the Milan bourse index was in a free fall, dropping 5.8 percent.
In Latin America and Asia, markets also fell yesterday. The Tokyo market plunged 4 percent, and stocks fell 2.3 percent in Hong Kong, which has had the best-performing stock market of the year.
As for the dollar, it just missed establishing a record low against the German mark before the intervention by central banks induced traders to buy dollars. The dollar then rose sharply, although it is still not far from its record low. The dollar closed at 1.4735 marks, down from its high for the day of 1.4965 marks. The dollar's lowest New York close since the mark was created in 1948 was 1.4475 on Feb. 11, 1991. Yesterday, the dollar fell as low as 1.4473 marks.
In general, the dollar has been pulled down mainly by three forces. The economic recovery here has not been strong enough to attract foreign investment. Short-term interest rates in Europe are about three times higher than they are here, which makes it a losing proposition for foreigners to invest in dollars or dollar-based securities unless they expect a big rally in the dollar. And the uncertainty caused by the Presidential election campaign is worrying some investors.
 
The Final Straw
 The downturn of the markets has been brewing for weeks. Mr. Rigden of UBS dates it from Denmark's rejection on June 2 of the Maastricht Treaty outlining the next steps to achieve European unity by the end of the century. "The Danish vote blew out the smokescreen of hope that Europe was marching nicely into the future," he said.
But the final straw came on Thursday when the German central bank, the Bundesbank, raised its discount rate to 8.75 percent from 8 percent. Although bank officials tried to argue that the rise in this interest rate should not lead to higher rates in the future, investors were not believers.
Today, one Bundesbank official, in an effort to reassure investors, said that the discount rate increase should not lead to a jump in the far more important German Lombard rate, which directly affects short-term interest rates.
For investors, the Bundesbank move means that an expected decline in interest rates in Europe, which had been a reason for some stock market rallies, will probably not occur until next year. In addition, the high level of rates will mean that forecasts for economic growth and for increased corporate earnings would have to be scaled back.
Some analysts also saw a souring of the mood because it appears to investors that the United States and its allies cannot work together to get the world economy out of the doldrums, as the increase in German interest rates while the United States is cutting rates shows.
"This is the backwash from the economic summit in Munich, which was clearly a failed summit," said Neil M. Soss, the chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. He said that the inability of the United States, Japan and Germany to find a common approach to interest rates means "there is less growth out there than there was before the Munich summit so earnings have to be weaker and stocks have to be weaker.
"What kind of world economy do you have without coordinated leadership from the Group of Seven?" he added, referring to the nations, led by the United States, Germany and Japan, that met at the summit conference in early July. And he said he was not sure the coordinated intervention yesterday would send a convincing signal that the cooperation is still effective.
In the past, heavy intervention has worked for a sustained period only if it was combined with policy moves. In this case that would mean raising interest rates here and cutting them in Europe. This would narrow the enormous interest rate differential that is an important factor in undermining the dollar.
If the intervention yesterday and future intervention can keep the dollar from plummeting, it could ease a lot of the pressure in Europe. When the dollar rises against the German mark, that tends to weaken the mark against other European currencies. Because European currencies are linked to each other in the European Monetary System, the weakening of European currencies against the German mark is one factor that is forcing interest rates to stay high.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sales of Arms to the Third World Declined by 22% Last Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Arms sales to the third world fell sharply last year as the United States, the Soviet Union, France and China all cut back sales, the Congressional Research Service reported today.
Total sales fell 40 percent, to $24.7 billion, the lowest level in at least seven years, from $41.1 billion in 1990, the research agency said. 
 The United States, which surpassed the Soviet Union as the biggest supplier in 1990, accounted for 57 percent of all sales in 1991, the report said. United States sales to Saudi Arabia alone exceeded the total value of Soviet weapons sales to the third world last year, the report said.
Saudi Arabia, the biggest United States customer, spent $5.6 billion, accounting for nearly 40 percent of total United States sales to the third world last year.
 
Sharp Drop in Soviet Sales
 Soviet arms sales to the third world fell 55 percent last year, to $5 billion, from $11.2 billion in 1990. Moscow was still the second-biggest supplier, but the value of its arms-sales agreements last year was far below the peak of $24.8 billion in 1986.
The report, delivered to Congress today, is based on data supplied by the Defense Department and United States intelligence agencies.
Richard F. Grimmett, a defense specialist who prepares the report each year, cited various reasons for the reduction in arms sales: the end of the cold war, the erosion of the Soviet Union, which was dissolved in December, and the enforcement of an arms embargo against Iraq, which had been one of the biggest buyers.
 
A Shift in the Market
 In addition, Mr. Grimmett noted, organizations like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank were encouraging third world countries to curtail military spending as a condition of getting economic aid.
French arms sales to the third world plunged 87 percent last year, to $400 million, from $3.1 billion in 1990. Chinese sales fell 86 percent, to $300 million, from $2.1 billion.
A major reason for the decline in Chinese sales is that the Soviet Union replaced China as the main supplier of weapons to Iran. Moscow sold no arms to Teheran in 1984-87, but since then has sold $4.8 billion worth of weapons, including warplanes, tanks and submarines, the research service said.
At the same time, the Soviet Union lost some of its biggest customers. Iraq had been making multibillion-dollar arms deals with the Soviets every year, but can no longer do so because of the embargo imposed by the United Nations in August 1990.
Moscow has eliminated the big subsidies offered to its friends in the past, Mr. Grimmett said. As a result, Cuba, Vietnam, Syria and India are buying much less. Indeed, the report says Cuba, which bought $11.9 billion worth of weapons in 1984-87, concluded no purchase agreements with Moscow in the following four years.
United States arms sales to the third world had risen to a record $18.2 billion in 1990, partly because of large contracts signed with Saudi Arabia after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Sales fell 22 percent last year, to $14.2 billion.
From 1988 through 1991, the United States accounted for half of all arms sales to the Middle East: $36.5 billion out of a total of $73 billion. Those sales accounted for three-fourths of the value of all weapons the United States sold to the third world in that period.
With cuts in the Pentagon budget resulting from the end of the cold war, Mr. Grimmett said, arms manufacturers are trying to increase sales to foreign countries to compensate for "lost domestic orders." But, he noted, Britain, France and other countries are trimming their military forces, so their arms makers also want to sell more overseas.
"More and more arms suppliers are likely to be pursuing a smaller and smaller list of buyers with the ability to pay," Mr. Grimmett said. "In the next few years, economic factors may be more significant than any arms control regime in restraining the international arms trade."

HEADLINE: BankAmerica Posts $240 Million Net

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 20

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it earned $240 million, or 63 cents a share, for the second quarter, in what analysts and bank executives called an impressive show of strength after its acquisition of the Security Pacific Corporation last year.
BankAmerica agreed to acquire its California rival last August in a $4 billion deal. The combination of the two largest banks in the West created the nation's second-largest banking company, after Citicorp. Because this was the first quarter in which the resulting company reported combined results, financial performance cannot be directly compared with previous quarters. 
 The bank said that earnings would have been higher except for $181 million in nonrecurring expenses primarily related to the merger. These expenses included restructuring expenses and income tax adjustments but were offset somewhat by a net gain related to the sale of the payroll processing business of its main subsidiary, the Bank of America.
BankAmerica also said it had unusually high legal expenses relating to lawsuits in the quarter. Excluding these expenses, the corporation's operations profits for the quarter were $421 million, or $1.19 a share. Wall Street analysts' estimates for operating earnings had ranged from about 85 cents to $1 a share.
The stock market reacted positively, and BankAmerica closed up $2.875, to $44.375, on the New York Stock Exchange on a day when stocks were generally lower. The stock was the second-most-active issue on the Big Board, with more than 2.4 million shares changing hands.
"This is just a starting point, but it was a terrific quarter," said Ronald L. Mandle, a financial analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein in New York. "The first rung of the ladder was higher than we thought it would be."
Analysts and company officials said that the savings associated with the merger would first be seen later this year. The company has said its goal was to cut $1.2 billion in costs because of savings from eliminating employees and branch offices.
"We're feeling pretty good about getting off to a strong start with this merger," said Frank N. Newman, BankAmerica's chief financial officer. In the short term, the company has no plans for further significant acquisitions, he added.
The bank is facing a difficult economic climate in California and a particularly difficult situation in commercial real estate in Southern California, Mr. Newman said. But because it has diversified significantly beyond the state, he said, the company is insulated from some of the impact of the recession.
Financial analysts also saw good news in the company's loan loss reserves, which were lower than expected.
The bank said it had $4.56 billion of loans that were not earning interest, with the bulk in the construction, development and commercial and industrial categories. The bank said it was also disposing of $4.4 billion in loans, primarily from Security Pacific.
BankAmerica has said it would form a unit, called a "collecting bank," to handle some of its problem United States assets acquired from Security Pacific. The company said the stock would be distributed to holders of BankAmerica or sold.
Earnings for the first six months of 1992 were $543 million, or $1.74 a share. In 1991, BankAmerica's second-quarter earnings totaled $272 million, or $1.16 a share. Earnings for the first six months of 1991 were $554 million, or $2.41 a share.
Noninterest income for the second quarter of 1992 was $1 billion, which included a nonrecurring gain of $157 million related to the sale of Bank of America's payroll processing business. Total noninterest expense was $1.98 billion in the second quarter, including a one-time charge of $395 million for the estimated expenses related to restructuring after the acquisition.
The company also said it had received regulatory approval in mid-July for its acquisition of H. F. Holdings Inc., and its subsidiary HonFed Bank, which is the third-largest financial institution in Hawaii.

Marine Midland Profit
 HONG KONG, July 20 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- The Marine Midland Banks reported a second-quarter profit of $41 million, compared with a loss of $37 million in the comparable 1991 quarter.
The Buffalo-based bank, a unit of HSBC Holdings of Hong Kong, had losses of $295.6 million for all of 1990 and $189.9 million for 1991.
In the first half of the year, Marine Midland had profits of $43.6 million, compared with a loss of $109.3 million in 1991's first half.
The 1992 quarter included a extraordinary gain of $11.7 million; the holding company did not give the details of the gain.
Marine Midland, which has $16.5 billion in assets, benefited from non-recurring recoveries from its loan portfolio and sales of foreclosed real estate, said John R.H. Bond, the president and chief executive.
