HEADLINE: Market Place;
Basic Assumption Is Being Doubted

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AS share prices tumbled around the world yesterday, there were many explanations offered, ranging from a Mafia bombing in Italy to political polls in the United States. But at the heart of the slide may be a growing fear that economic growth -- and the profits that it brings for stock owners -- is no longer to be taken for granted in the world.
In the United States, most economists think the recession that began in 1990 ended either in the spring of 1991 or early this year. But just as growth in the two years preceding the recession was substandard, the recovery has been weak. 
 In Europe, Germany's decision on Thursday to raise interest rates yet again, a further reaction to mistakes made when East and West Germany were unified on highly inflationary terms, seems likely to prolong the British recession and weaken other economies. And Japan's economy has been stumbling as stock prices have lost more than half their value since the end of 1989.
These events have challenged the comfortable assumptions that economies are sure to rebound from recessions, even if the timing is uncertain, and that share prices should be bid up in the assurance that business will soon improve.
Yesterday's slide in stock prices, which began in Tokyo and then spread as different world markets opened for trading, was halted at least temporarily after the New York markets opened and central banks intervened to support the dollar as it was nearing a record low against the German mark.
Perhaps more important than the actual results of the intervention was the fact that the major governments were capable of concerted action. At the economic summit meeting earlier this month, there was talk about agreeing on a long-delayed trade accord, but little action on anything.
"A lot of the economic problems confronting the U.S. are global in nature," said Edward Yardeni, the chief economist of C. J. Lawrence. "But rather than seeing a global coordinated response, instead we have policy discord." He noted the Germans had raised interest rates despite American pressure to lower them, and he said he would have been more impressed with the dollar-support operation if it had been accompanied by a statement from the Group of Seven leading industrial nations that the dollar had fallen far enough.
In any case, the dollar rebounded after the central banks' interventions, and the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell more than 44 points in early trading, stabilized and then recovered somewhat. It ended down 28.64 points, at 3,303.00. Some European markets also recovered part of their losses after the interventions.
There were, of course, lots of reasons offered for lower stock prices. Italy, whose market fell more than others in Europe, was reacting in part to the assassination of an anti-Mafia judge, and some analysts in the United States pointed to concerns by money managers, most of whom are Republicans, about Bill Clinton's lead in the polls.
But the widespread declines tended to reduce the importance of individual country issues and to provide a reminder that the engines of economic growth are not running on all cylinders anywhere. "Germany is raising interest rates for its own reasons, but that is one more reason that economies are sputtering in Europe," said Byron R. Wien, the chief United States equity strategist for Morgan Stanley.
The Bush Administration's effort to promote economic growth has focused almost entirely on lower interest rates, to the exclusion of fiscal policy, and until yesterday, the official attitude toward the dollar's fall could at best be viewed as benign neglect. The combination of a deadlock with Congress and huge budget deficits has blocked meaningful fiscal action.
The weak markets around the world mean that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, will be watched even more closely when he testifies today in a Congressional hearing. He may well be quizzed about the competing priorities of stimulating the economy and protecting the dollar from a free fall. Lower interest rates have hurt the dollar, especially with rates in Europe and Japan generally higher than in this country.
Worldwide growth can reinforce itself, just as a worldwide slowdown can. The United States has tried to stimulate exports to aid growth, but this drive has stumbled, in part because of weakness in the economies of many trading partners. Similarly, the drop in American imports has helped to depress other economies.
Fears of a new recession have grown, and to many economists the rebound in corporate profits that began in the first quarter may already be fading. Disappointing profit reports from such companies as I.B.M. and Coca-Cola, as well as numerous smaller companies, have bothered many investors.
Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers and one of the more optimistic of the Wall Street seers, said he saw "straws in the wind" of a pickup in economic activity this month, and he noted that many companies were reporting improved second-quarter earnings.
But, he added, the reports are generally "about profit gains at the expense of wage earners," who have been denied raises or even laid off. "You can't have that in perpetuity and make it a recovery," he said. "For profits to continue their positive rebound, there must be enough growth to go around."

HEADLINE: In Albany's Card Game, Long Island Is Trump

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 20

 BODY:
When Ralph J. Marino, the State Senate Majority leader from Nassau County, stalked out of the Capitol in a huff recently, he held up the passage of more than a dozen bills dear to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and to New York City.
But in the partisan world of Albany politics, Mr. Cuomo and the Democratic leadership in the Assembly, had their own political card to play: a pair of fiscal aid bills for Nassau and Suffolk counties. 
 In the end everyone won, something.
Over the weekend, Mr. Cuomo gained his pet economic-development project, an $800 million bond act intended to create jobs around the state; Long Island avoided huge budget cuts and property tax increases, and New York City got an extension of its right to negotiate its bond sales and an extension of a program that shifts economic development incentives from below 96th Street in Manhattan to the other boroughs.
However, the city didn't get everything it wanted when agreement could not be reached on Medicaid.
The legislative results make clear the importance of Long Island in Albany and speaks to the growing independence of Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin.
On July 3, in the last moments of the legislative session, deals between the Governor, Mr. Marino and Mr. Weprin seemed near on all those measures. But everything suddenly unraveled when an indignant Mr. Weprin refused to give Mr. Marino his Long Island package. And then the Long Island bills, of middling importance in the scheme of things, became the linchpin for every other piece of unresolved legislation.
Without the Long Island bills, Mr. Marino shouted at Mr. Weprin over the telephone early that morning, none of the other bills had a chance. Unless he got most of what he wanted, Mr. Cuomo threatened later, there would be nothing for Long Island.
A cooled-down Mr. Marino was prevailed upon to return to Albany last week to continue discussions, and the Suffolk piece came together without much trouble. Then, after hours of talks between Mr. Marino, Mr. Weprin, Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and the Governor, a deal for Nassau was struck, allowing the county to borrow up to $65 million in six-year bonds and to double its mortgage-recording tax to 2 percent, also for six years.
With Nassau cleared up, like an overheated car being removed from a road it had blocked, everything else could move again, too. Those measures included an $800 million bond act to create jobs around the state; a plan to broaden the powers of the New York State Thruway Authority, and the half-dozen bills for New York City that would usually have passed with little trouble.
But virtually the entire weekend was devoted to the fight over Nassau, an extraordinary battle of wills in which Mr. Gulotta -- speaking for the Long Island Republicans and for Mr. Marino -- drove a hard bargain, often leaving the conference room to whisper to aides or to telephone Joseph N. Mondello, the powerful Nassau County Republican leader.
 
Standing Up to Cuomo
 He met a formidable opponent in Mr. Weprin, who refused to make many concessions on a deal he said was politically motivated and would too easily benefit Mr. Marino and Mr. Gulotta. Fighting over relatively minor points -- like whether Nassau County should be allowed to borrow $71 million, or $65 million -- Mr. Weprin asked how far the extra $6 million would go toward freezing taxes in a budget of $1.8 billion in which the projected deficit was more than $150 million.
Mr. Weprin, new to the Speaker's job after Mel Miller's conviction on Federal fraud charges last December and known for being friendly and accommodating, emerged as a tough leader who could stand up not only to Mr. Marino, but also to Mr. Cuomo. At one point, according to people in the room, the Governor yelled at Mr. Weprin to give in, saying that the Speaker was holding up his legislative agenda. But Mr. Weprin retorted that since his house had already passed the Governor's bills, if anyone was blocking anything, it was the Long Island Republicans. And the deal they finally reached was tougher on Nassau than Mr. Cuomo had originally suggested.
The Long Island deal made neither Mr. Weprin nor Mr. Marino particularly happy. But it was a compromise that allowed both parties to save face: Mr. Weprin because he had put new restrictions on the package, and Mr. Marino because there was a package at all.
The one person it benefited the most was Mr. Cuomo, who returned to Albany from his home-run speech at the Democratic National Convention last week to yet another success. With the notable exception of several environmental bills and a bill that would gradually transfer the counties' Medicaid costs to the state, Mr. Cuomo achieved nearly everything he wanted, particularly his bond act. If it is approved by the voters in November, its supporters say, it could mean tens of thousands of new jobs and an untold amount of new business around the state.
For Long Island, the deal enables Nassau and Suffolk counties to borrow money and raise some taxes in order to close their budget gaps and begin to put their finances in order. And it provides political benefits to the Republicans who run those counties and who desperately need to be able to keep property taxes down.
For New York City, it means getting the bonding authority and the extension of other programs, including one of economic incentives to businesses in distressed areas.
The agreement on those bills was a relief to the city. But another bill it wanted, under which the state would gradually take over localities' Medicaid costs, died last week, a worrisome development because the city already accounted for the extra money in its four-year financial plan.

HEADLINE: Brighton Beach Development Gains Backing

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
A much-disputed plan to replace the historic Brighton Beach Baths with a large housing development cleared a major hurdle yesterday when it won the endorsement of the New York City Planning Commission.
However, approval of the Brooklyn project, known as Brighton-by-the-Sea, came only after the developer agreed to several changes, including scaling down the project and adding subsidized housing and more open space. 
 The project's developer, Alexander Muss & Sons, had twice before scaled down its plans after failing to win the city's approval. But opponents said yesterday that they would continue to fight the project, which cannot go forward without the backing of the City Council. The opponents said the development was still too large and did not provide enough affordable housing or adequate access to the beach from public areas.
Michael Clendenin, a spokesman for the Council's leadership, said yesterday that Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone had not taken a position on the issue.
Marcia Reiss, policy director for the Parks Council, an advocacy group, said the project was "a giant step backward" in the planning and design of New York City's waterfront because it would limit public access to the beach and hinder enjoyment of it, while giving the developer tremendous economic benefits.
Mayor David N. Dinkins -- who exercises considerable control over the Planning Commission by appointing 7 of its 13 members -- has the power to veto the proposal but has expressed his support for the revised project.
 
Changes in Zoning
 Shelley Friedman, a lawyer for Alexander Muss, said the developer was "obviously pleased with the commission decision," and added that if the panel had rejected the plan the developer would have abandoned the project.
In a 10-to-2 vote, the commission agreed to change the zoning of the project site to a high-rise residential area from its current status as a commercial zone; allow the developer to build on space that had been designated for city streets; and grant a permit to build a 1,701-car parking garage and to waive set-back requirements for high-rise buildings.
The project, which was initially proposed as a five-tower, 1,600-unit complex, has been scaled back to four towers with 1,500 units.

HEADLINE: Has Delaware's Insurance Chief Gone Too Far?

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
At a time when states are feeling increasingly poor, David N. Levinson might seem a white knight, having brought more than $100 million in investments into the state from companies operating outside its borders.
For seven years Mr. Levinson, the state's elected insurance commissioner, has put pressure on the insurance companies he regulates to invest in a list of local businesses drawn up by his office. What's wrong with hitting up these Goliaths for what amounts to small change, Mr. Levinson argues, to help a tiny state create desperately needed jobs? 
 But what Mr. Levinson sees as economic development, a growing number of lawmakers here see as a conflict of interest that falls somewhere between the blatantly bizarre and the oddly corrupt. They say Mr. Levinson is the latest example of just how far the state regulation of insurance can go awry.
 
Critics in Legislature
 A rising chorus of critics in the State Legislature say Mr. Levinson strong-armed insurance companies to invest in the companies he favors -- including those whose executives contributed to his campaigns. And he has forced contributions, they say, to one of his favorite and strangest causes: the betterment of Latvian-Delaware relations.
State Representative David H. Ennis, the Republican chairman of the House Banking and Insurance Committee, said he had received several complaints from insurance companies although none were willing to state publicly their objections for fear of retaliation. But the national trade group in Washington representing life insurers said it was troubled by the economic development program in Delaware. "We believe there is an inherent conflict of interest on the part of someone who on the one hand regulates the solvency of insurers and on the other hand is involved in promoting investments in the state," said Henri Bersoux, a spokesman for the American Council of Life Insurers.
Perhaps what frustrates his critics most is that Mr. Levinson seems unruffled by the accusations. He sees himself as "the toughest commissioner in America" and does not think fair-minded people would think he is acting in conflict. As he contemplates an independent run for governor, Mr. Levinson argues that he has become the victim of a powerful industry that punishes insurance commissioners who slip off its leash.
"I brought jobs to Delaware and refused to bow down to multibillion-dollar insurance companies and the lawyer/lobbyists to whom they pay millions of dollars per year to do their dirty work," Mr. Levinson said. "The industry went berserk."
The Delaware controversy comes at a time when the nation's system of state insurance regulation is under fire from members of Congress and state auditors who say that slipshod performance by insurance departments resulted in major insurance failures. The National Association of Insurance Commissioners has been aggressively developing new and higher regulatory standards for departments across the country.
One powerful Democratic Representative, John D. Dingell of Michigan, recently introduced legislation calling for Federal regulation of the industry in part because quality varies greatly from state to state. While states like New York and California are known for their vigorous enforcement, regulators in many states have long been criticized for being too cozy with the industry and its lobbyists. The image of the state-run system of insurance regulation was tarnished further by the conviction in the last two years of commissioners in Louisiana and Wyoming for corruption.
In Delaware, the state's House of Representatives this year investigated Mr. Levinson's program to promote economic development. Last month the House voted to prevent the commissioner from regulating companies that he has approached for investments or had personal financial dealings with. It also voted to turn over the records of its investigations to Federal and state law enforcement officials. The move failed in the State Senate, which instead voted to have the State Ethics Commission investigate, which now must render a decision.
Until now, Mr. Levinson had generally won praise for hiring a team of financial experts, computerizing a department with fewer than 100 employees and modernizing its operations since he was first elected in 1984.
The commissioner, whose father was a small-town mayor and well- known veterinarian in the state, was educated at Harvard, and made millions in the real estate business in the Midwest. He returned to Delaware in the early 1980's to enter public life. Tall and slender with an easy charm, Mr. Levinson has both dazzled and enraged politicians here who described him, varyingly, as brilliant and arrogant.
"The commissioner has done an exceptionally good job of running his office," said Edward J. Bennett, a Democratic State Representative. "But he has taken personal loans, trips, introductions across the oceans and still has not recused himself from decisions on the companies that gave them those things."
Mr. Levinson says he sees no reason why he should.
The House committee investigation found that in June 1989, a Delaware-based insurance concern, the American Centennial Insurance Company, made a loan of $3.6 million to a Missouri real estate partnership in which Mr. Levinson had a 40 percent stake. A company affiliated with American Centennial, Wesco, purchased land from another partnership in which Mr. Levinson had been a member.
What troubled the committee most, said W. Minor Carter, its counsel, was that just two years earlier the commissioner had approved the spinoff of American Centennial from the Beneficial Corporation. The deal required the parent company to commit an additional $200 million to American Centennial's loss reserves.
Legislators question whether a quid pro quo might have been at work. "There are significant facts missing," Mr. Carter said. Further investigation, he said, would show "either a clear violation of law, both Federal and state, or simply incredibly poor judgment."
 
Levinson's Side
 Mr. Levinson said he became involved in the deal to develop 162 acres before he was elected commissioner and that it was conducted at arm's length by a partner, Leonard Saxon, and was structured to permit Mr. Levinson to be bought out on the day the loan was signed.
Asked whether the transaction could give an appearance of impropriety, Mr. Levinson said he did not think so at the time and said that as a lifelong real-estate developer it was necessary that from time to time some of his investments would involve insurance companies.
"I didn't deal with the company at all," Mr. Levinson said. "There was no quid pro quo."
Another aspect of the controversy involves Mr. Levinson's program of "economic development" for the state. Mr. Levinson said he was highly troubled when he took office that most companies domiciled in Delaware and requiring Delaware regulation kept their headquarters and jobs elsewhere. He said he presented companies with the choice of moving their home office to other states, bringing their headquarters to Delaware -- and proposed a bill that would do the same -- or of making contributions to Delaware companies that would create local jobs. The program, he said, has resulted in more than $100 million in investments.
But critics, including Representative Ennis, say that insurance companies have complained that Mr. Levinson threatened to withhold or slow regulatory decisions if companies did not contribute.
 
'Off the Wall'
 "Companies in Delaware have said to me that he has approached them, businesses that he regulates, and asked them for loans for personal business enterprises that he has been involved in," Mr. Ennis said. "When they refused he has become angry. He has gone off the wall."
In one case, Mr. Carter said, the department pressed insurers to invest in a project proposed by Swearingen Aircraft of San Antonio to build an aircraft manufacturing plant in the state if it could raise $35 million. Among the $20 million pledged, Mr. Levinson said, the largest amount was from American Reinsurance, which lent $12 million. The aircraft project has since stalled, he says, and so far no jobs have been created.
Mr. Levinson said he never used threats, but "would hope" to receive contributions from executives of state companies that benefited from state programs. Such contributions, he said, were commonplace for elected officials in Delaware and other states.
National Reinsurance, a company that underwent a leveraged buyout under Mr. Levinson's regulation in 1990, contributed $50,000 to Forward Central Delaware, a nonprofit business development group, and $30,000 to establish a Latvian trade mission office in Delaware. The Latvian mission so far has created no jobs for Delaware citizens. Mr. Levinson persuaded the Government of Latvia to place its trade mission in Delaware after making trips last year to Latvia, Russia and other former republics of the Soviet Union where he helped establish a Western insurance code. Mr. Levinson's grandfather emigrated from Latvia.
 
Money for Trips
 Forward Central Delaware has contributed to one of the trips. American Reinsurance paid for another. American Re's parent company, the the Aetna Life and Casualty Corporation, signed an agreement with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company last month for a $1.2 billion leveraged buyout of the Delaware-based reinsurer, the largest leveraged buyout ever involving an insurance company.
The general Counsel for American Reinsurance said that it had agreed to pay for the trip only after it was approved by the State Ethics Commission.
Mr. Levinson said he often accepted payment for trips from insurance companies when he made major speeches or carried on other state business. It saves the state money, he said. Helping revive the Latvian insurance industry, he said, is state business since the Federal Government does not have the skills to assist the former Soviet Union on insurance matters.
It may have been more than coincidence, he said, that the attacks began just as he was discussing organizing a third political party for an independent run for governor.
"I am the one who kept the pressure on," Mr. Levinson said. "It didn't make me popular. But prophets never are."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David N. Levinson, Delaware's Insurance Commissioner, is under fire from some state legislators for trying to persuade some of the insurance companies he regulates to invest in local businesses. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities went through considerable gyrations yesterday, driven by developments on world equity and currency markets. But by the end of the day, prices were narrowly mixed.
The sharp drop in stock prices on major foreign stock exchanges, and the expectation that shares would be hammered once trading shifted to the United States, sparked a run into short-term Treasury notes and bills during trading in Asian and European financial markets. 
 But that move ended abruptly after the Federal Reserve and at least a dozen other central banks surprised currency traders by intervening to defend the dollar.
"When the Fed and the other central banks intervened, that seemed to fuel a belief that if the authorities were intervening in the foreign exchange market then the Fed would not be willing to cut rates any further," said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
As Mr. Brachfeld suggested, the move to support the dollar put upward pressure on short-term interest rates, and had an impact on bids for new three-month and six-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday.
 
3-Month Bills: 3.16%
 At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.16 percent, down from an average rate of 3.22 percent at last week's auction. Before the Fed's support of the dollar, the three-month bills were trading on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 3.10 percent.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 3.24 percent, compared with an average rate of 3.31 percent a week ago.
While the Fed's action to support the dollar seemed to suggest the central bank would not risk another cut in short-term rates, analysts said that at this point shoring up the currency was not the Fed's primary consideration.
"The fundamentals on the dollar are still bearish for as long as the United States economy looks weak and Germany is fighting an inflation and monetary growth problem," Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Economics, said.
"But the economy, not the dollar, will dictate whether or not the Fed eases policy again."
The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, may be questioned about the implications of yesterday's activity in the foreign exchange markets today when he testifies before Congress on the economy and monetary policy.
The last two times he delivered the so-called Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, Mr. Greenspan surprised the markets with generally upbeat views on the recovery.
Few analysts are expecting a similar assessment this time.
"Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins hearing should prove friendly to the market as he highlights a positive inflation outlook and sluggish money supply," Peter McTeague, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said in his daily market commentary.
 
Long-Bond Yield Off
 Anticipation of the testimony, as well as a drop in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of spot commodity prices to a six-year low, helped buoy bond prices somewhat.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 103 30/32, up 7/32, to yield 7.65 percent, compared with 7.68 percent late Friday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 10/32, up 1/32, to yield 6.88 percent. The 6 3/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 102 15/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 5.79 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 3/8, down 1/32, to yield 4.25 percent.
 
Commonwealth Edison Offering
 In the corporate bond market, new-issue activity was highlighted by a $500 million four-part offering of securities by Commonwealth Edison through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
A total of $300 million worth of one-year, three-year and five-year debentures were sold with yields from 4.23 percent for one-year securities to 6.611 percent on debentures maturing in 1997.
The remaining $200 million were offered as 30-year first-mortgage bonds maturing July 15, 2022.
The 8.50 percent bonds were priced at $99.329 to yield 8.562 percent, 90 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The debentures are rated Baa by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Moody's has awarded an A-3 rating to the first mortgage bonds. Those securities are rated A- by Standard & Poor's.
Activity was sluggish in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said.
Prices of most widely quoted securities rose by about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: Rupert Murdoch, In Hollywood, Learns The Value of 'No'

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, July 20

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch slouched on the sofa of his surprisingly spare office at the Fox Studios near Century City, saying with a faint smile that his voyage into the movie business still left him just a bit uneasy.
"This is a very creative, ambitious community," said the 61-year-old media mogul, speaking in his lazy Australian drawl. "Everybody's got their own agenda, their own schemes, their own projects. You've got to pass on 90 percent of them. Making films involves saying 'no' a great part of the day. What worries me are the commercial judgments in Hollywood. Not here, in this studio, but among some of our competitors." 
 It has been more than five months since Barry Diller abruptly stepped down as chairman of Fox Inc., whose parent company, the News Corporation, a media conglomerate spread across four continents, is owned by Mr. Murdoch. The apparently amicable departure of Mr. Diller, who wants to establish or buy his own network, led Mr. Murdoch to take over direct, hands-on control of Fox Inc. and to plunge into the movie and, especially, the television business.
Seated beneath an Australian Impressionist painting and sipping a diet soda, Mr. Murdoch was by turns reticent and enthusiastic about his involvement with Hollywood, the anxieties of the movie business, his hopes for Fox Television and his fascination with Los Angeles after living in New York. Mr. Murdoch was, for a while, the owner of both New York magazine and The New York Post, among other publications.
 
Fun and Heartbreak
 "I loved New York, but then I was running a newspaper," he said. "For all its inadequacies, and the things we didn't do, the resources we didn't have, we still had a real influence on that city. To be involved, hands on, in the issues of the streets and the city every day -- it was a lot of fun. Absolutely! And it was a heartbreaker. Mission impossible. Afterward I was lost and kind of depressed."
Mr. Murdoch, one of the most powerful, if private and detached, millionaires in Hollywood, has been an American citizen since 1985 and a resident of Los Angeles for more than a year. He and his wife, Anna, a novelist, have four children.
The move to Los Angeles, largely the result of his purchase in 1985 of 20th Century Fox, has proved exhilarating for Mr. Murdoch, who arrives at work each morning at 6:30 to start making phone calls to his companies abroad.
"Living here reminds me a lot of living in Australia," he said. "The weather. The openness of the society. I don't mean Hollywood, but Los Angeles. This is the modern melting pot. There's not much history here, and that leads to good things and bad things. I mean, there are no rules here. That makes it very open on the one hand. On the other hand there's perhaps less taste about it."
The glitz of Hollywood both appalls and bores Mr. Murdoch, who is rarely seen at Hollywood premieres and parties. "I'm not into that," he said. "It's a crazy business. I enjoy the risk factor. I enjoy exercising one's taste and judgment."
 
All Business
 By all accounts, Mr. Murdoch has left the movie business largely in the hands of Joe Roth, the chairman of the studio, except for decisions where major risks and major expenses are involved. Mr. Roth, who chafed under Mr. Diller's episodic but powerful control, says that he feels quite liberated under Mr. Murdoch and that conversations with his boss have focused almost entirely on the business side of movies. The two men are about to start renegotiating Mr. Roth's contract.
"Rupert has not dealt on the editorial side," Mr. Roth said in an interview. "He has not said, 'I don't want to make a movie because it's politically or morally reprehensible.' He has not told me I could not make a project. We have accounting conversations. We talk about margins and operating profits."
Mr. Murdoch's company also owns TV Guide in the United States, Sky Broadcasting in Britain and an array of newspapers and magazines around the world.
Mr. Murdoch says that he has never quite encountered anything as surrealistic as the economic and, for that matter, the creative side of the film business. Such big-budget bonanzas as "Hook," made by Sony's Tri-Star Pictures, in which the stars and the director, Steven Spielberg, walked off with millions of dollars despite the film's less than smash performance, bewilder him, he says.
"The impulse is for you, the studio, to take all the risk, and if you clear something at the end of the day, good luck to you, and if you don't, forget it, let's go on to the next thing," said Mr. Murdoch. "I'm not frightened of the risk. I'm looking at the risk and the reward. There's not enough reward for the risks involved. The secret is you don't have to make expensive movies to be successful. Look at Disney and 'Sister Act.' It looks like it was made on half a sound stage. But it works."
 
Hopes for Smaller Projects
 Mr. Murdoch insists that so far he has not played a role in approving projects. "Joe Roth green-lights things," he said. "If it's a very big film we'll sit and talk about it, whether it's really wise or not." But he said he was hoping to make a growing number of "smaller," or cheaper, films in the near future. "Of course, we all say say that, everybody says that," he added with a laugh. "Let's be honest."
Mr. Murdoch said the waste of money in movie making startled him a bit. "Every day we're shocked at the risks involved, by the excesses of money, by what you pay people, by what what you waste," he said. "But anything that's creative, I suppose, has got to have some waste. You produce a great newspaper, you leave a lot of stories on the spike, too."
Fox has had a mixed record at the box office, dominated by one huge hit, "My Girl" (with Macaulay Culkin among others), which has grossed more than $285 million. Mr. Murdoch said he was very disappointed in the failure of "Dutch," the gangster film about Dutch Shultz, and of "For the Boys," the Bette Midler musical about a pair of U.S.O. performers. "Although it was beautifully made," he said tartly of the Midler movie, "It wasn't much of a story."
It is television, especially television news on the Fox network, that is consuming much of Mr. Murdoch's attention. "We want to get away from the old-style news, which is driven by pontificating, high-priced anchors, to news that covers all the important events but has a real pace," he said. "It's got to tell a story. A face reading a teleprompter doesn't really help news. You've got to tell it in pictures, voices, reporters, good writing. People the next day will remember a big story told brilliantly in 30 seconds more than a big story told a mediocre way in three minutes."
Mr. Murdoch rejects criticism of the Fox network's so-called "reality" shows -- re-enactments of real-life events -- which have been assailed as exploitative. Fox spawned many of these extraordinarily successful shows, including "America's Most Wanted," "Cops" and "Current Affair," and other networks have emulated them. Mr. Murdoch points to the highly successful afternoon talk shows as far more tasteless examples of exploitation.
"Look, is there anything more exploitative than the most successful show on the air, Oprah Winfrey?" he said with a laugh. "Donahue, too. He copies her. She copies him. I don't know. They get these unfortunate people -- it's like a freak show every day. Intrusive? Yes. Entertaining? Yes. It's gotten to the stage where whatever station has "Oprah" in the afternoon is the dominant station in that market."
Certainly the most embarrassing episode so far in Mr. Murdoch's tenure was his recent dismissal of Stephen Chao from the presidency of Fox News. Mr. Chao was summarily dismissed for hiring a man to strip during a speech he was giving about censorship at a Fox Inc. meeting in Aspen, Colo. Mr. Murdoch recently named Van Gordon Sauter, the former head of CBS News, as Mr. Chao's successor.
"Yes, it was a loss," said Mr. Murdoch, who spoke warmly of Mr. Chao's skills as an executive. "But there's more than one fish in the ocean."

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Yoo-Hoo! Is Anybody Home? It's Mets and Yanks Calling

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Not only are fans not watching the Mets at Shea Stadium in mass quantities, they're not watching them in droves on television.
Through Sunday, the Mets' average Nielsen rating on WWOR-TV has tumbled 27 percent, from 7.3 after 47 games last year to 5.3 now. By comparison, the Yankees' rating on WPIX-TV through 29 games has risen to a 4.8 from 4.6 last season. 
 Ratings on the stations generally reflect viewing on SportsChannel and the MSG Network, the Mets' and Yankees' cable outlets, respectively.
With few important games, the Mets' television performance has stagnated for two months -- coinciding with the team's decline -- and has not recovered since June 2, when the team reached its highest post-opening day prime-time rating of 7.9.
The Mets rose a bit on the Nielsen meter over the weekend with ratings of nearly 5.5 for victories against the San Francisco Giants.
Lower ratings mean reduced ad revenues for WWOR. Tom Ryan, WWOR's general sales manager, said:
"We're in the same recession everybody else is in. We're not that far off last year. But the third quarter is not strong."
The bulk of WWOR's commercial time on Mets' games was purchased before the season, but the station isn't getting any extra gravy from new clients signing up during the season with short-term commitments.
Mike Siegel, senior vice president of Vitt Media International, a media buyer said, "Nobody's been clamoring for the Mets or Yankees."
The Yankees' ratings on WPIX, which finished at 4.4 last year, haven't had as far to fall as those of the Mets, who wrapped up 1991 at 6.1.
The Mets have fallen hard when compared with last year, but the Yankees have stumbled badly in the last two months, experiencing a 28 percent ratings downdraft since May 22. In that period, the Mets' rating is flat.
No Yankee game has rated above 5.0 in a month. Sunday afternoon's game against the California Angels rated a mere 3.0, the nadir of the season.
Yet, Yankees advertising sales are up about 15 percent over last year. MSG, which sells ads for itself and WPIX, enlisted more upfront sponsorships this year.
"Advertisers feel the team has been competitive all year and they're fun to watch," said Andi Poch, MSG's director of ad sales. "It's live, fresh summer programming that advertisers find appealing."
Baseball ratings and advertising often reflect how successful or promising a team is, not necessarily whether fans love Tim McCarver's analysis on WWOR or can't figure out whether WPIX's Phil Rizzuto is on Earth or Pluto. But for those who care about the coverage, the TV announcing teams offer wide variety:
McCarver-Ralph Kiner (WWOR): They define teamwork better than the others. On top of his skillful, punnish and puckish analysis, McCarver's care and feeding of Kiner is masterly. Ralphie Boy is at his best when spinning yarns and McCarver is ever eager to lead Kiner into temptation. Theirs is the best example of bantering that doesn't require a play-by-play man to right them. Kiner's malaprops are legendary, but part of the texture of his work; they are easily forgiven because they're funny and Kiner is engaged in the games.
Tony Kubek-DeWayne Staats (MSG): The most straightforward duo. Kubek is McCarver's equal as an analyst, but looks pained to show a lighter side when Al Trautwig tries to prod him into humor. Kubek and Staats are the "Dragnet" team, giving just the facts. Kubek fits more analysis into 60 seconds than most of his colleagues offer in 60 minutes; his tendency to be harsh on players shows an admirable independence.
Kiner-Fran Healy-Rusty Staub (SportsChannel): Serviceable but bland. Staub and Healy are not distinguished analysts by any measure, and Staub stumbles over his thoughts too often, even in taped segments. Healy and Staub are close friends and know baseball, but their voices and insights are not clarion calls to listen. Neither elicits what McCarver does from Kiner, who seems less interested in the games on SportsChannel.
Rizzuto-Tom Seaver-Bobby Murcer (WPIX): PHIL'S WORLD! PARTY TIME! EXCELLENT! A frat party at each game, overseen by chief chaperone Rizzuto. Phil's fans suggest you have to let Rizzuto be Rizzuto. Maybe. But if Rizzuto were less engaged, he'd spend all nine innings on the George Washington Bridge. "Are you listening to me, Seaver?" he keeps asking. Vintage Rizzuto used to listen to his partners better, which sparked the broadcasts. Listening to Seaver and Murcer sans Rizzuto is becoming a marginally more rewarding experience if you want to know what's happening in the game.
On the radio side, WFAN's Bob Murphy and Gary Cohen are a sparkling duo on the Mets, who improve year-to-year. Murphy's word images and Cohen's straightforward, playful style make for lovely listening.
On WABC's Yankees broadcasts, all one can say is, "Poor Michael Kay." He will never learn anything positive from partner John Sterling, whose shilling for George Steinbrenner and digressions from the game are poor examples for the rookie announcer. Kay has a weak radio voice and is too absolute in his judgments.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
A Candidate Proposes Radical Sacrifice Play

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
Bob Watson's plan is so bold it sounds like a Presidential candidate's program to erase the national debt.
Watson, the Houston Astros' assistant general manager, has seen baseball decline in popularity among minority groups, especially inner-city children, and believes some radical program has to be implemented to reverse the trend. 
 "If we don't do something to save our game, we won't know it in 8, 10, 12 years," Watson said. "The talent pool will continue to shrink. You go to the ball park now, both in the majors and the minors, you hear scouts talk about where are the players going to come from. If we don't do something about reviving baseball in our country, the game will not be as we know it today. That might seem farfetched, but to save this game, the players, baseball and corporate America are going to have to make some sacrifices."
The Watson plan calls for the creation of baseball academies in every major league city. About 20 clubs currently have academies in Latin American countries. Watson envisions the academies as places where children generally could be turned into productive citizens and specifically could be developed as future players.
"And if they don't turn into players, they could be fans," said Watson, who was a major league player for a decade and a half. "Our minority fan base is way down. Some of it is economics, but also baseball hasn't done the best job of promoting itself. Basketball and football have done a fantastic job of promoting themselves. Baseball is losing good athletes and fans."
Under the Watson plan, funding for the academies would come from players, major league baseball and corporations. Players, he proposes, would give 10 percent of the total value of their contracts to the project, and those sums would be matched by both major league baseball and participating corporations.
"I have some ideas that I think I could sell the owners and corporate America, and I know I have some ideas I could sell the players," Watson said. "The players would be tougher because I would take some of their money, but they'd get a tax credit and they'd get credit for the academy."
Using Cal Ripken Jr. as an example, Watson said that if Ripken were to sign for, say, $30 million with Baltimore, he would put $3 million into the inner-city program in Baltimore. "Yes," Watson said, "he's giving up $3 million, but how much is enough? No way you could tell me Cal Ripken ever thought he was going to get $30 million. They're giving up money they wouldn't have had five years ago, and they still have a lot. Ripken gets a tax writeoff and his name goes on the building and is etched in baseball history."
He wouldn't be on poverty row, Watson added, and corporate Amercia and baseball would match his contribution and "you have $9 million."
Watson, who has worked diligently and intelligently in his effort to become a high-ranking baseball executive, is prepared to talk about this idea and others when he is interviewed next month for the job as National League president. Bill White is leaving at the end of his term next March 31, and Watson is an announced candidate.
He is in that position because when he was a batting instructor in the Athletics' organization, Sandy Alderson, the Oakland general manager, gave him opportunities coaches seldom have and because John McMullen of the Astros is a color-blind owner.
Among Watson's ideas are two that would be an improvement over the policies of the incumbent: easier accesibility and tougher discipline. White, who was a very public person in his 18 years as a Yankee broadcaster, has been an invisible executive, making himself inaccessible to the type of people with whom he once had contact.
White has explained that talking with members of the news media was not part of his job description, but even some of his supporters among the owners feel he has carried that policy to an extreme, refusing to be a spokesman for the league. Watson said he would have no problem dealing with the news media or any other part of the public.
Because he was a player himself, White has been viewed as soft on players in disciplinary matters. Watson said his status as a former player would not influence his disciplinary decisions.
"Our whole fine system is in the dinosaur age," Watson said. "It doesn't make sense to have fines of $250 or $500 and guys are averaging $1 million a year. If we had a new system in place, where you could take a day's pay, approximately $6,000 on $1 million, that would get a guy's attention. A $250 fine is tip money to these guys. They have it in their money clip."
Watson, who knows that any effort to change the disciplinary system would incite a fight with the union, said he also would propose a different way to handle bench-clearing brawls triggered by a batter's charging the mound. He would call for an automatic suspension without pay for players who join the fight.
"It should be a deterrent," he said. "I won't be easy on players, but by the same token, I wouldn't be easy on umpires. I think umpires should be fined and disciplined the same as players. I'm a realist. I understand there are things that won't change, but I'm a doer and I'll try to get some things done."
If Watson is so good at getting things done that he gets players to give up 10 percent of their contracts, maybe he should run for President of the country instead of the National League.

HEADLINE: Creeping Democracy in Mexico

 BODY:
Until very recently, all Mexican elections conformed to a predictable pattern. The Government always declared that its candidate had scored a resounding victory; opposition parties always protested that they had been victimized by outright fraud.
That pattern put Mexico out of step with the rest of the Western Hemisphere, where honest, democratic elections have increasingly become the rule. Credit is now due to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, himself the beneficiary of a tainted election four years ago, for rewriting the old, rigged rules. 
 Mexican elections remain far from pristine, but the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has now learned how to acknowledge defeat. That's welcome news, not only for Mexico but also for the U.S., as the two countries move toward close economic integration.
On Sunday the state of Chihuahua became the second in the country to certify an election victory by the National Action Party, or PAN. Baja California Norte was the first, three years ago. The business-oriented PAN, which shares the Government's outlook on basic economic issues, has now achieved at least a grudging legitimacy within what was a one-party system.
But the more radical Democratic Revolutionary Party, or P.R.D., continues to face official resistance. The P.R.D. was ruled to have lost last week's race for Governor of Michoacan, its main state stronghold. The voting was marred by abuses, but these were probably not enough to have decided the outcome. The popularity of the P.R.D. has been waning, largely as a result of successful Government economic policies. Still, a transparent process would have made the outcome more credible.
Mexico's moves toward an open political system still lag behind its efforts toward a more open economy. Few expect a truly democratic presidential contest in 1994. And PAN needs to fight for its electoral gains. But the Chihuahua results represent real progress, unthinkable even four years ago. Americans can welcome these signs of creeping democracy, even as they recognize that true pluralism is not yet at hand.

HEADLINE: A Mideast Boost for Mr. Bush

 BODY:
In a fallow political season for the Bush Administration, unexpected succor beckons from the Holy Land. Secretary of State James Baker is back on the Mideast shuttle trying to restart the stalled Arab-Israeli peace talks. Israel's new Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, is in Cairo today for the first such meeting in six years with President Hosni Mubarak. All this underscores a promising shift in Israeli diplomacy, from the blame game to let's make a deal.
The new outlook is evident in Sunday's decision by Mr. Rabin's Cabinet to halt new settlements in the West Bank and Gaza pending review of all construction approved by the previous, hard-line Government. This moves Israel closer to the freeze demanded by Arabs and sought by President Bush as the precondition for $10 billion in U.S. loan guarantees for resettling Russian immigrants. 
 It is true that Mr. Rabin has yet to distinguish precisely between "political" settlements, which he opposes, and "security" settlements, which he favors, presumably in East Jerusalem, the Jordan Valley and the Golan Heights. But his Labor-led coalition asserts that these exceptions entail nothing like the 16,500 housing units feverishly begun under former Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.
Secretary Baker was right to praise Labor's path-breaking concession, and right to call for matching gestures from the Arabs. One possible deal has long been on the table. Mr. Baker a year ago urged Arabs to end an injurious and spiteful economic boycott of Israel in return for a freeze on new settlements. The idea won the support of Egypt and, more surprisingly, Saudi Arabia. But the deal was dismissed out of hand by Mr. Shamir, on grounds that the embargo was illegal while settlements, in his view, were not.
What Mr. Rabin has done is to move the dispute from legalism and ideology to a pragmatic concern for peace and security. In his inaugural address the Prime Minister movingly appealed to Israelis to overcome "the sense of isolation that has held us in its thrall," to join the global movement toward peace and to do everything possible to fit into a new world. This is a welcome change from sullen defensiveness.
It is a change, moreover, that augurs well for the Bush Administration's patient brokering of peace talks, which began in Madrid, continued inconclusively in Washington and will resume in Rome. Mr. Baker now has a chance to capitalize on a warmer atmosphere, and to persuade Israel's adversaries to abandon all-or-nothing for give-and-take. The familiar dangers abound -- zealotry, self-delusion and terrorism -- yet amazingly, this caravan is still moving.
Meantime, Americans will hope that Secretary Baker can make a good case to Congress for approving loan guarantees, so that Israel may get on with providing homes and work for its newest settlers. That's a bounce the Bush Administration will have earned and deserves.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
So Long, Suckers

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Ross Perot still has two important things he can do in American political life. One is to shut up and the other is to get out.
That is not meant simply as a piece of unpleasantness, although that is certainly one intent. It is an alert to him, to his friends and family and to all who once put their hopes in him. 
 Mr. Perot now suggests to those he betrayed that if they want him, why, he may lead or guide their political movement even though he has quit as Presidential contender.
Just suggesting that adds serious injury to serious insult. He can be neither leader nor guide. The reason is that former Lieutenant Perot is otherwise occupied, facing a moral court-martial by his countrymen on these charges:
1. AWOL in the face of political combat. Self-explanatory.
2. Abandonment of his troops. Self-explanatory.
3. Falsification of intelligence.
Less than 24 hours before he withdrew he was still encouraging top aides, getting them ready for battle. If some mysterious something came up that knocked him out, he should have revealed it. If he quit because he decided he did not have the stomach or the background for political combat or the Presidency he should have said that too.
If he decided he did not want to spend the time or money, although he had promised he would spend as much of both as needed, he should have said that.
Instead he announced the discovery that the election might go to the House of Representatives, this Texas Christopher Columbus. That phony spiel embarrassed his close confidants even as he spoke. If they keep on apologizing for him they jeopardize their reputations. Handy reference: "Othello," Act III, scene iii, 155.
4. Violation of the code. Ross Perot failed to follow the code of taking personal responsibility for error, taught at Annapolis.
If he had spoken honestly, either of a sudden disqualifying circumstance if there was one, or of his lack of strength to carry on, he would have been a failed politician, but perhaps a respected one. He chose instead to prove his enemies were right when they said he could not even surrender like a gentleman or officer.
5. Contributing to a moral and political disorder: cynicism. Quitting as he did, he made millions more Americans suspicious of their country, its leaders and the business world.
The leaders did their own contributing. President Bush gave up fishing time to throw an embarrassing line at Mr. Perot. Governor Clinton said he was deeply moved by the Perot statement. To nausea, I trust.
Myself, I had thought Mr. Perot was worth listening to. He was shaking up both political parties. And he was the hope of many Americans longing for the kind of change that would reaffirm American economic, moral and democratic worth.
And he was worth listening to -- then. But no, not now that he has quit cold on American voters, raised anchor and semaphored the motto on his escutcheon: So long, suckers.
The day before he deserted them, Mr. Perot was urging on the experts who had worked out his domestic and foreign policies. He was supposed to disclose them this week.
But aside from any secret that may exist, he was losing total control of his world, which he so craves. He was obviously too weak to live without total domination.
He had had to answer the press about his life and businesses. Now he would have to try to grasp and justify policies that could never be his own. They did not come from his own brain, background or experience.
It must have been like one of those nightmares where you find yourself in costume before an opera audience. The lights dim, baton is raised. And you know neither the words nor music. I could almost feel sorry for the man, if only he had said, "I don't belong here -- I can't sing."
But he won't walk off the stage, even now. So if he does try to lead or guide a movement created by his followers out of their own hopes he will injure them further. He will create even more cynicism about the system that made him a billionaire and Presidential contender.
Happily for the Republic, Americans do not court-martial political contenders. In return for this grace, former Lieutenant Perot should not add to the list of charges by continuing to impersonate a leader.

HEADLINE: Model Cities Work, but Enterprise Zones Won't

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In an editorial 26 years ago, give or take a few months, you proclaimed the Model Cities program (then called Demonstration Cities) dead. You predicted that the program -- concentrating billions of dollars in demonstration grants to cities -- was doomed to defeat in Congress and destined to fail as too cautious a response to urban problems. 
 You were wrong then. Model Cities, far from expiring or being insufficient, became law and continued to survive under different names in hostile or indifferent administrations down to the Reagan Administration. Today it is acknowledged, not only for its capacity to stimulate physical and social renewal in neighborhoods but, more significant, for encouraging grass-roots political participation. Many inner-city residents moved from their first venture in Model Cities politics to elected and appointed leadership positions in our cities.
So, 26 years later, in "The Muddled Model Cities Model" (editorial, July 3), you are wrong again. With no attention to the now well-documented record of how the program began and how it expanded, you fall back on the dubious 1970 figures of neoconservatives who asserted that a "few" cities grew to 75 and then to 150.
Let me testify, as chairman of the task force under President Johnson that recommended Model Cities, that the original proposal was for 82 cities and that the subsequent expansion came over two years of planning grants. Even at 150 awards (for large, medium-sized and small cities), more than one-third of Congress never had, in your terms, "a slice of the pork." The program remained selective, a first example of the politics of innovation, instead of the politics of distribution. Set down insufficient resources to the Vietnam War.
Finally, comparison with enterprise zones is misleading. The Model Cities program, as Browning, Marshall and Tabb show in "Protest Alone Is Not Enough," an award-winning 1989 book, built a record of accomplishment in stimulating renewal and empowering citizens across the country.
In contrast, 37 states have tried enterprise zones with disappointing results, as reported by the General Accounting Office in 1988. Model Cities was the product of empirical, verifiable evidence produced by social science research; enterprise zones spring from the loosely woven tapestry of ideology, where aspirations lose touch with reality. Whatever the appropriations, they won't solve the fundamental problems of jobs, education and security that beset our cities now.
 
ROBERT C. WOOD
Middletown, Conn., July 6, 1992
 
The writer was Undersecretary and Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, 1966-69.

HEADLINE: U.S. Social Ills Become Medical Problems

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Many Americans favor a Canadian-style, single-payer health care system. The real question is how a Government-run system based on the Canadian model would work in a country that has social problems that countries like Canada and Germany don't share to the same extent. 
 Health care systems are best evaluated by cost, access and quality related to outcomes, not by life expectancy and infant mortality. These last indicators more properly measure a country's health status and are influenced by its demographic and socioeconomic makeup. For example, our high poverty rate surely lowers our overall life expectancy and raises our infant mortality rate.
In addition to the greater influence of poverty on our health status, more Americans engage in high-risk behaviors than people in other developed countries. Such conduct leads to more drug-abuse-related illnesses; more AIDS; more pelvic inflammatory disease; more teen-age, out-of-wedlock pregnancies, resulting in more premature and sick babies; more homicides and assault injuries, and more accidents, especially among the young. All these conditions require intensive and expensive treatment.
These behaviors, linked with such social pathologies as the breakdown of the family structure, chronic unemployment, homelessness, violence and despair, cause Americans to end up in overwhelming numbers in the emergency rooms, intensive-care units and morgues of our hospitals. The United States is paying dearly for its social and behavioral problems once they became medical problems.
The United States must commit itself to resolving its social problems before they become medical problems while addressing its vast health care needs. The challenge is to extend American health care, research and technology, often the best in the world, to all of our population, which includes the poor, at an acceptable cost.
 
LEROY L. SCHWARTZ, M.D.
MARK W. STANTON
Princeton, N.J., July 1, 1992
 
The writers are, respectively, president and vice president of Health Policy International, a nonprofit research organization.

HEADLINE: Fired Up With a Love of the Feared Reading Tests;
Koslin's Specialized Exam Wields a Powerful Influence on Millions of Students

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

DATELINE: BREWSTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
One thing that qualifies Dr. Bertram L. Koslin to design the reading tests dreaded by many of one million New York City students and their teachers is that he likes to read -- almost anything.
The mound of papers scattered across his desk takes the rough shape of a volcano, with dozens of articles about politics, science and history, and a few unpaid bills, spilling down the sides like lava. He is making his way through a book about winemaking. And at bedtime, he picks up one of the Seven Deadly Sins mysteries by Lawrence Sanders. "I'm up to the Fourth Deadly Sin," he says. 
 Dr. Koslin is, in short, not a faceless and bloodless academician but a man of varied and idioscyncratic tastes whose life has its unruly moments.
Still, he makes his living trying to place children into micrometer-precise categories of reading ability. He even believes that literature can be finely calibrated so that someone who scores 59 on his test can comfortably tackle "To Kill a Mockingbird" while someone who scores 69 will not be intimidated by "Jane Eyre."
His test, known as the Degrees of Reading Power, wields a powerful influence on not only New York City's students, but three million others in Connecticut, Virginia and New York, three states where the test is given statewide, and 1,000 school districts elsewhere.
It has become an annual rite of passage. Students first take the test in second grade and may continue to encounter it through 10th grade. Along the way it is used to determine which students must repeat a grade, which are placed in classes for gifted or slow learners, and which can qualify for Federal remedial-education money.
More informally, the tests are used to evaluate teachers, principals, even Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and Mayor David N. Dinkins. Just last month, Mr. Fernandez and City Hall traded blame for a citywide decline in reading.
Over the years, critics have wondered whether the test is as reliable as it claims, whether it is used for purposes for which it was never intended, like comparisons of school performance, and whether scores can be massaged. Many worry that teachers spend too much time preparing students for the test.
These questions have periodically drawn attention to Dr. Koslin and the testing company he heads, Touchstone Applied Science Associates, in a two-story steel and tinted glass building in the dense woods of this northern Westchester County town.
Dr. Koslin, 62 years old, is a stout native of the Bronx with a cheery, avuncular disposition and some very fixed and sometimes cranky opinions.
Philosophically, he is a supreme rationalist who believes education can be systemized with objectives and tasks -- and tests that measure how those objectives are met. Politically, he describes himself as a New Deal Democrat comfortable with Rockefeller Republicanism.
For recreation, he concocts such French dishes as duck and olives, sometimes tossing in vegetables from his garden. One reason he likes meeting educators in New York City is the chance it affords to savor an authentic corned beef sandwich.
Until recently, Touchstone was virtually a mom-and-pop business, run with his wife, Sandra. But the Koslins divorced recently, though his wife remains at the business. And in June, with $2.5 million a year in sales, Touchstone went public, opening on the Nasdaq exchange for $5 a share. Dr. Koslin, the company's president, is paid $110,000 a year, and he owns 24 percent of the business.
 
'Helpful to Parents'
 Robin Willner, the Board of Education's director of strategic planning, said Dr. Koslin's test, which the city has used since 1986, was chosen over others because it evaluated only reading comprehension and not discrete skills like word recognition and usage that have a more arguable bearing on reading comprehension.
"It's helpful to parents in terms of understanding what does this score correspond to," Ms. Willner added."Does this score correspond to whether my children can read 'Goodnight Moon,' or 'Nancy Drew'? "
But Deborah Meier, a Manhattan principal, said students who could comprehend even intricate prose might not be deft at filling in the answer spaces under time pressure.
Dr. Koslin said his test was distinctive because it did not depend on students' background knowledge. The information needed for every question about a reading passage is contained within the passage itself. Therefore, he argues, the test cannot be faulted as culturally biased.
To write the passages that are the hallmark of his test is part fine art, part science, Dr. Koslin maintains. His writers follow an explicit manual. First, broad subject areas like bridge construction are chosen based on topics with the longest entries in the Encyclopedia Britannica. Then the writers bore in on narrower subtopics -- the engineering of the Brooklyn Bridge, for example -- scouring nonfiction books and magazines like National Geographic for material.
They write passages of roughly 300 words each, with seven words left blank, and invent five options for each blank, though only one makes sense in the context.
"It's a linguistic puzzle to do it," Dr. Koslin said, sympathizing with his writers. "It's unforgiving out there if you make one lousy mistake."
Critics claim the prose that emerges from Dr. Koslin's process is about as tasty as packaged white bread, lacking in pungency and whimsy. But Dr. Koslin defends it.
"It's good scientific writing," he says. "It has a voice in it, the voice of exposition."
He also maintains that the difficulty of the prose can be quantified according to half-century-old linguistic principles that take into account the length and rarity of the words.
Any single test is assembled from the more than 800 passages that are kept inside 300 Manila envelopes stacked on slender Lucite shelves in a locked office. Most tests use questions that appeared on earlier tests because, like fresh bread vs. day-old bread, new questions cost more.
Dr. Koslin, who grew up on the Grand Concourse, often watched his father, an abdominal surgeon, perform operations with what he calls "Matisse-like strokes." He attended public schools and recalls that when a teacher smacked his left hand with a ruler in an effort to force him to write with his right hand, he grabbed the ruler and smacked her back. He was sent to the principal.
"School in large measure was one standing quiz and I remember nothing else," he said. "They were constant demonstrations of whether you learned something or not. But if you couldn't, it was not a God-awful disaster. Somebody helped you over the hump."
Dr. Koslin was very good at tests, but he spurned the elite Bronx High School of Science, where his brother had gone, for DeWitt Clinton High School because Bronx Science required that students take a course in mechanical drawing. "That's engineering, that's not science," he said, "and I didn't want to do engineering."
 
Diverse Interests
 As a biochemistry major at Johns Hopkins University, he felt at a disadvantage with prep school graduates more learned in the classics. So he spent much of college filling those gaps, cultivating a lifelong affection for poets ranging from John Donne to Wallace Stevens.
"Intellectually, I range over a lot of fields," he said. "I think the wide range of backgrounds put me in good stead to listen to what it is people wanted by way of a new reading test."
He entered New York University Medical School, but quit after a year, deciding that doctors must be alert to abnormalities while he was more intrigued by "commonalities" among people. This outlook, he acknowledged, may explain his enthusiasm for grouping large numbers of children by reading levels.
During three years of travel abroad, he was fascinated by cultural differences in behavior, and he enrolled in the doctoral program in social psychology at the University of Oklahoma.
After teaching at Bard and Princeton in the late 1960's, he got to know Dr. James E. Allen, at the time New York State's Education Commissioner, who also believed education could be systemized. Dr. Allen asked him to devise a new reading test.
Dr. Koslin concedes deficiencies with his test, but argues that all tests suffer from these flaws and, practically, little can be done.
For economy's sake, students who take the Degrees of Reading Power test are not measured against a true national sample but against a contrived assemblage of 25,000 New York State students whose ethnic, religious and income characteristics mirror a national cross-section.
A student who scores at the fifth-grade level is reading at the average level achieved by fifth graders in the contrived national sample, which is not the same as reading at a level educators may regard as appropriate for fifth grade.
Given his fascination with measurement, it is surprising that Dr. Koslin cannot pinpoint his own reading level. He said he took an I.Q. test in graduate school and scored 140 -- a genius level.
"What does that mean?" he asks self-effacingly. "You can't eat it and you can't drink it."

 The first universities emerges at the end of the 11th century and beginning of the 12th. These institutions were not founded on ant particular date or created by ant formal action. Nobody actually [1] them. Instead, they developed gradually in places like Paris, Oxford, and Bologna, where scholars had long been teaching students. At first, these tutors had not been associated with one another. Rather, they they had been, [2] . But, over time, they joined together to form guilds.
 The guilds, which were associations of societies of tradespeople, were somewhat like modern unions. In the Middle Ages, all the crafts had such [3] . The scholars' guilds built school buildings and evolved an administration which charged fees and set standards for the curriculum. The guilds set prices for members' service and fixed requirements for entering the profession.
 Professors were not the only people in schools who formed groups. In Italy, students joined guilds to which teachers had to swear obediance. The students set strict rules, fining professors for beginning a class a minute late. Teachers had to seek their students permission to marry, and such permission was not always granted. Sometimes the students [4] . Even if they said yes, the teacher got only one day's honeymoon.

HEADLINE: A Whole New Political Ball Game?

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley is professor of history at Columbia.

 BODY:
On Thursday, as I was walking into a meeting in midtown Manhattan, I stopped to talk with two volunteers collecting signatures to put Ross Perot on the New York State ballot. They gave me an amateurish, crudely printed brochure and seemed puzzled and disappointed when I declined to sign their petition.
"Don't you understand that Ross is our only hope?" one said. Two hours later, when I came back out to the sidewalk, Mr. Perot's candidacy had vanished. And so had his volunteers. Where they are going is a question in which both major parties have a large stake. The collapse of the Perot movement, even more than its emergence, has the potential to create a genuine political realignment -- a redefinition of party loyalties that could transform the fortunes of the Democrats and Republicans, not just in 1992 but beyond. 
 Some Perot supporters will drift back to the parties they left, as many would have done anyway. But what of the true believers -- the people to whom "Ross" was "our only hope," the people to whom mainstream politics has become anathema?
Mr. Perot and some of his followers talk wistfully of keeping the "movement" alive, using it to press the major parties to respond to their demands. But such efforts will certainly fail. It was Mr. Perot himself who gave the movement whatever unity it had. His supporters have no concrete program to thrust upon the major parties. All they had was a candidate, and he has now deserted them.
And yet while Mr. Perot clearly meant very different things to different people, he did come to symbolize two large concerns that most of his followers apparently embraced. Evidence that other candidates share those concerns is what Perot's supporter will be looking for as they consider the appeals Bill Clinton and George Bush are beginning to make to them.
One was the illusion Mr. Perot created that the "people" -- the volunteers who put him on the ballot -- were the real decision-makers in his campaign and would be in his administration. It is clear now that Mr. Perot really listens to only one person, himself, as his abrupt withdrawal from the race made clear. But one reason his withdrawal shocked his followers was that he had persuaded them to believe otherwise.
Mr. Perot managed to revive the belief that an active, engaged citizenry can seize control of the political system and make it work. He convinced previously disaffected voters that it was possible to make government into a direct expression of popular will. He restored to politics something of the joy of participation that has been largely missing from national campaigns for generations.
If the allegiances of his supporters depend on their finding a similar sense of engagement and empowerment in one of the major parties, they almost certainly will be disappointed. National politics doesn't work that way anymore, if it ever did. And neither party is likely to be able to create even the illusion, let alone the reality, of genuine popular participation in its national deliberations.
But Mr. Perot's popularity was also a sign of another feature of contemporary politics: the impatience among much of the middle class with the way both major parties seem to have defined the role of government.
The Democrats have suffered for years from the popular (and in many respects false) impression that they are committed to using government to transfer wealth and power from the middle class to minorities and the poor. But the Republicans, having succeeded perhaps too well in exploiting the Democrats' weaknesses, are suffering from an equally damaging (and also not entirely accurate) popular impression: that they will not use government at all.
The result is a major political vacuum in the center that Mr. Perot moved to fill. He avoided both the redistributive image of the Democrats and the anti-statist image of the Republicans and promised instead to make politics work better to serve the interests of the middle class.
He allowed his followers to imagine an active, effective government that would revive the economy and provide them with the services they have come to expect and demand. Unlike the illusion of direct democracy, this is a vision that the major parties can appropriate as they scramble to pick up the pieces of the Perot movement.
The Bush campaign, which believes the core of Mr. Perot's support consisted of disaffected Republicans, expects many of those people to support the President almost reflexively. But the history of earlier third party and independent movements does little to support their optimism.
The Anti-Masons of the 1830's, Know-Nothings of the 1850's, Populists of the 1890's and followers of George Wallace in the 1960's all profited, briefly, like the Perot movement, from a gulf between the ideological positions of the major parties and the sentiments of much of the public.
None of those movements prevailed, but all served as vehicles by which people severed existing party affiliations and created new ones. The Wallace movement in 1968, for example, attracted large numbers of traditional Democrats; when George Wallace left the scene, many, perhaps most, of his supporters began voting Republican.
There is no guarantee Mr. Perot's Republican supporters will switch to the Democrats in 1992 (although early polls suggest many are leaning in that direction for the moment). But the rise and fall of the Perot movement has helped create the conditions for the kind of party realignment that transformed politics in the 1850's, 1890's, 1930's and 1960's.
The Clinton campaign is already working skillfully to push that realignment along. It is not trying to persuade these frustrated middle class voters that government does not and cannot work, as the Republicans of the 1980's did; nor is it arguing that government's principal task is to help the dispossessed, as many Democrats did in the 1960's and 1970's. It is trying to persuade them that government can be made to work for them.
The challenge facing the Republicans as they try to win back Perot voters -- a formidable challenge given the anti-statist posture of the party for 12 years -- is to do the same.
