HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Pact a Spur To Canada

SERIES: A New North America -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, July 21

 BODY:
New economic studies indicate that Canada has become more competitive as a result of its trade agreement with the United States and, some analysts believe, is about to outpace all major industrial nations in economic growth. Yet Prime Minister Brian Mulroney faces a herculean task over the next six months in getting the House of Commons to ratify an expansion of the treaty to include Mexico.
The Prime Minister's Government is expected reach agreement on the treaty with Mexico and the United States in coming weeks. 
 Despite the signs of increased strength -- manufacturing output rose four tenths of 1 percent in 1991, for example -- Canada is still suffering, along with much of the rest of the world, from the persistent effects of recession. And the current trade agreement between the United States and Canada, which came into force Jan. 1, 1989, is getting much of the blame; Canadians are upset about recent plant closings, continued joblessness and the flight of some businesses to the United States.
From a three-way arrangement, Canada is looking not only to preserve trade gains with the United States but to increase its access to Mexico's thriving market.
Canada's trade with Mexico is still modest -- $3 billion a year of two-way business, or only 1.5 percent of exchanges with the United States. Mexico enjoys a huge surplus -- $2 billion last year, chiefly reflecting shipment to Canada of Mexican-assembled cars of the Big Three. Canada last year, for example, imported 41,000 Cavaliers. Canadians also bought nearly $100 million of Mexico's fruits and vegetables.
"People are really very angry," Joan Fawcett, a Liberal Party member of the Ontario Provincial Parliament, said. "They feel these closings are a direct result of free trade -- and that the Canadian Government sold them a bill of goods."
Polls show ardent criticism of the 1989 agreement. The latest survey of the Angus Reid Group has found that 64 percent of Canadians oppose the proposed North American treaty -- and 66 percent are still against the initial agreement with the United States.
Only 6 percent believe that Canada has won any benefits at all in the accord with Washington, which by 1999 virtually eliminates all trade barriers between the two nations.
The provincial governments of Ontario and British Columbia have gone so far as to demand that Canada walk away from the negotiating table.
Many Canadians think that President Bush wants a new free trade deal to boost himself politically. Ontario's Trade Minister, Ed Philip, sounded a popular note here when he commented the other day: "Helping to get George Bush elected by signing on to a dubious free trade deal is not part of Canada's economic agenda."
Still, no one expects Mr. Mulroney to pull out of the talks, and in the end most analysts think the Canadian Parliament will go along with the agreement -- that its great economic dependence on the United States leaves it no other choice.
In fact, neither the United States nor Mexico was initially keen on Canada's participation, fearing Ottawa would only complicate already fiendishly difficult negotiations. But Canada insisted on joining because of its "vital interests," a term Ottawa used repeatedly.
Canada, Mexico and the United States are now trying to create what eventually would become a single market for North America's 370 million people. The agreement is expected to be initialed within a few weeks and come up for ratification later in the legislative bodies of all three countries.
Despite the naysayers, many Canadian economists insist that treaty has had strongly positive effects. New studies are showing that free trade has quietly helped manufacturers reverse a long-term decline in productivity, made Canadian enterprises more global and given Canada a supranational judicial process providing a measure of protection against arbitrary American trade decisions.
A University of Toronto analysis has found that freer trade has stimulated growth, lowered the rate of inflation and lessened the severity of the recession. The researchers found that Canada's output of goods and services last year was four-tenths of a percent higher than it would have been without the free trade agreement; unemployment was down one-tenth of a percent and inflation was seven-tenths of a percent lower. The International Monetary Fund and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have both recently predicted that Canada, energized by free trade, is about to become the fastest growing of the major industrial countries.
"Things are looking up," said Allan R. Taylor, chairman of the Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's biggest bank, adding, "It is ludicrous to argue, as many are doing, that Canada would somehow have been more protected in the current recession without the free trade agreement."
Trade liberalization, combined with anti-inflation policies, deficit control and industrial deregulation have put Canada in the position, according to Mr. Taylor, where "our costs and prices are finally under control," adding that "they are now running below those of the United States."
 
The Results
U.S. Companies Expand in Canada
 In contrast to the highly publicized plant closings, many large companies are quietly expanding in Canada to serve the North American market. American multinationals in Canada, it is estimated, have created at least as many jobs as they have terminated.
Figures from the Government's Statistics Canada agency show a net loss of 403,000 manufacturing jobs and a net gain of 185,000 service jobs since Jan. 1, 1989. But Doug Drew, manager of the statistical agency's Labor Force Survey, said it was not clear how much of the changes reflect freer trade and how much Canada's recession.
The stakes for Canada in an expanded trade zone are unusually high because trade with the United States is so closely linked to its own prosperity. More than 75 percent of its exports went to the United States last year, while almost 70 percent of its imports came from the United States. Exports to the United States, a market 10 times larger than Canada's, account for 20 percent of Canada's gross domestic product. No other country -- not even Germany's trading partners in Europe -- are so economically dependent on a neighbor.
Together the United States and Canada do $200 billion of trade with each other, representing the largest commercial relationship in the world. The opening up of new markets in Mexico should help diversify Canada's trade and reduce dependence on the United States.
Procter & Gamble, with 94,000 employees worldwide, says it has capitalized on freer trade to create 200 additional jobs in Canada in the production of specialty soaps and hygienic products for North American distribution. At Pointe Claire, outside Montreal, it has a new pump-soap production line. At Belleville, in southern Ontario, it has just started another operation for the Always panty liner.
"We've been able to take the opportunities created by the free trade agreement for moving product and raw materials across the border more cheaply," said Margaret Bawden, manager of public affairs for Procter & Gamble's Canadian subsidiary. "We find some operations in Canada now more cost effective."
Others taking advantage of lower tariffs to expand are Dow Chemical, Cargill Foods, Du Pont, Rubbermaid, GTE Sylvania, Hughes Aircraft and Kodak.
Freer trade has also accelerated industrial reorganization, as companies seek to operate more efficiently and cut their production costs. The readjustment has been painful in some instances. Jobs indeed have been lost, though in some cases the cause may be an isolated downturn in business, not the lower trade barriers.
Cooper Industries, for example, recently closed a plant near Coburg in southern Ontario that employed 200 people who made hand-held steel files for removing and smoothing metal or wood. Brock McCloskey, a vice president of employee relations, said the operation was consolidated in Cullman, Ala., where the company already had a larger file-making plant.
He said the move had "nothing to do with free trade," adding, "We had excess capacity in both plants and consolidated into one to best utilize manufacturing capacity."
 
The Rivalry
Canadians Remain Suspicious of U.S.
 If free trade has become the agreement the Canadian people love to hate, part of that feeling stems from the belief among not only the people but also Government officials that the United States continues to use its economic power to keep Canada down in a number of critical sectors, including autos, lumber, steel, beer and apparel. Or, at least, to exact as many advantages as it can before 1999.
Even Mr. Mulroney, who usually strikes a friendly pose toward the United States, has been hotly critical, using terms like "unacceptable" and "counterproductive" and accusing Americans of "sideswiping Canada." And, illustrating the degree of resentment are the widely quoted remarks of Simon Reisman, the man Mr. Mulroney appointed to lead the Canadian free-trade negotiating team in the late 1980's. "The Americans are bastards," he told an interviewer earlier this year. "They're behaving like real thugs these days in protecting their interests."
In recent weeks the United States has threatened to hit Canadian exports of steel and beer.
American steelmakers have accused the Canadians of "dumping" steel, or selling it in the United States at below cost, a violation of United States law. If the American industry can prove its case, higher tariffs would be forced on Canadian steel.
But the Canadians say any such action would make a mockery of free trade. They say that because of the recession and the high degree of integration of the North American steel market, they cannot help but sell below cost in the United States.
The American complaint "amounts to taking advantage of people on the downside of an economic cycle," laments Roger Phillips, president if Ipsco Inc., a $500 million a year company that makes tubular steel in Regina, Saskatchewan, and Calgary, Alberta.
Backed by Ottawa, the Canadian companies have opened negotiations with their American counterparts on a potential peace formula -- a pact that would reflect the integrated nature of the steel market and prohibit antidumping measures if imports are either priced to meet the competition or do not have a substantial market share.
In beer, the United States has accused Canada of lacking good faith in removing trade barriers against American beer and has threatened to retaliate to recover $80 million of lost business. Washington has cited what it calls discriminatory practices by Ontario and Quebec. Particular anger has been voiced against an Ontario tax of 10 cents on all cans of beer sold in the province. Most of the American beer is sold in cans.
And Canada's apparel industry says it is fighting for its life in the Mexico-Canada-United States talks because of American demands for restrictive North American content rules. To placate the powerful American textile industry, Washington is insisting that clothing be cut and sewn in North America from fabric and yarn made on this continent before it can be traded duty-free among the three countries.
Yet virtually all the fabric in the Canadian dress and sportswear industry is imported from outside North America. "We search the world for great sources of supply, and we sell the niches; we're masters of nichemanship," says Jack Kivenko, vice president of Jack Spratt Manufacturing Inc. a jeans and workwear producer in Montreal and president of the Canadian Apparel Manufacturers Institute, a trade group.
If the American demand is accepted, he said, "it will mean that Canadian manufacturers will have to close down and locate manufacturing outside of Canada." The Canadian apparel industry employs about 125,000 people, 60 percent of whom work in the province of Quebec.
 
The Politics
Trade Issue Could Dominate
 If the treaty does come up for ratification next year, the timing could not be worse for Mr. Mulroney, who may find free trade dominating the general elections. Although he has come up a little in the polls, a negative popular attitude toward the treaty is not what he needs. Only a few months ago his was the least popular administration since poll-taking started a half-century ago.
The Mulroney Government must call elections at least by the fall of 1993, and many expect the call next spring. But that is just when the North American agreement would be headed for final ratification by Congress and the two Parliaments.
Even if the Canadian Government tries to ignore the matter or play it down, the treaty's opponents do not plan to let that happen.
Lloyd Axworthy, a Liberal Member of Parliament from Winnipeg, Manitoba, and a leader of the opposition to free trade in 1988, said, "We will be much better prepared this time."
The Conservatives then won 169 of the 295 seats in the House of Commons, but they did so with less than half the votes cast -- 43 percent out of 13.1 million. Under Canada's plurality system, a candidate need poll only one vote more than the runner-up to win a seat, no matter how many votes the other candidates amass. The fact that the Liberal and New Democrat parties, both of which oppose free trade, were able to pick up 53 percent combined is cited by free-trade opponents as a justification for continuing their struggle.
Maude Barlow, an adviser on women's issues during the early 1980's Liberal leadership of Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, heads the Ottawa-based Council of Canadians, the chief lobby against free trade. She said her group would begin a campaign this fall to abrogate the 1989 pact "with brochures, buttons, cross-country tours, town hall meetings, the works" and is "forming alliances with like-minded organizations in the United States and Mexico, to bring our experiences to bear."
The free-trade opponents include a powerful coalition of labor and farm interests and social activists, who cite not only high joblessness (the latest unemployment rate was 11.6 percent of the labor force) but also what they see as greater American economic leverage over Canada and a resulting diminution of sovereignty.
Government officials insist that free trade is getting a bum rap.
"It's time to blow the whistle on the free- trade blame game," said Michael Wilson, Canada's International Trade Minister. "Despite the problems generated by a tough global recession, a spate of difficult disputes with the United States and a deep slide in public support for the free trade agreement in Canada, there is now clear evidence that the free trade agreement is working."
In addition to the University of Toronto, the O.E.C.D. and the International Monetary Fund studies, the Government points to a recent survey by a consulting firm, DRI Canada, that found 97 Canadian manufacturing industries gained or maintained their American market share in the last three years, while only 11 lost market share.
Also underscoring the gains from the pact, the Government statistics that show manufacturing output per person rising four-tenths of 1 percent in 1991 represent an exceptional gain for a recession year, economists say.
Every $1 billion of new Canadian exports translates into roughly 15,000 new jobs. Canada's exports rose to $103.4 billion in 1991, a 5 percent increase over 1989, according to Statistics Canada, still another sign that the pact may be working in Canada's favor.
Over the same period, Canada's trade surplus with the United States increased from $10.6 billion to $17.2 billion, which is about a third the level of Japan's.
In Mexico, Canada sees openings chiefly for exports of financial services and high-technology electronics and telecommunications. Some 200 Canadian companies showed up at a trade fair earlier this year at Monterrey, Mexico, and, according to the Canadian Trade Ministry, are filling their order books.
These companies represent the new competitive edge that Canada is getting in international trade. They have become so aggressive, said Mr. Wilson, the trade minister, that "they are not even waiting for the trade agreement."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: In the Heartland;
Candidates and Issues Stir Small-Town Frenzy

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANDALIA, Ill., July 21

 BODY:
When Gov. Bill Clinton and his bus caravan across the American heartland arrived here tonight nearly two hours late, he was still cheered like a rock star by a large crowd that had been gathering for seven hours.
Spontaneous enthusiasm for Mr. Clinton appeared to have pulled many in the crowd of about 8,000 people out of their homes and kept them patiently waiting in the streets and on the lawn of the old State House on this rain-laced night. 
 But curiosity at such a huge spectacle in such a small town, the hard work of local Democratic volunteers and a five-member Clinton advance team also helped get some out for the rally.
The building of the crowd began days before the Clinton caravan was anywhere close to this town of 6,100 people, when Lisa Sims, a Clinton campaign worker from Pittsburgh moved into an inexpensive motel on the outskirts of Vandalia and went to work.
 
Seeking a Crowded Heartland
 It is Ms. Simms's job to help make sure that the Arkansas Governor and his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, have plenty of people to wave to. It looks so much better on the evening news when the heartland is crowded.
She arrived in Vandalia, which is about 50 miles northeast of St. Louis, on Saturday and got busy. She had 1,000 fliers printed up announcing Mr. Clinton's visit and recruited 9- to 14-year-old members of a 4-H club to distribute them to the outlying towns of 200 and 400 residents, towns surrounded by soybean and corn fields and weathered farm houses. She taped Clinton posters to lamp posts on the streets of Vandalia and asked merchants to put them up in their windows next to the Abraham Lincoln souvenirs.
But Ms. Simms said she found that because Vandalia is a small town, surrounded by even smaller towns, word travels like lightning here.
"We're all excited," said Virginia Mabry, the owner of a downtown gift shop. "We're all having a ball."
Ron Kretzer, a 41-year-old school teacher, said he waited several hours to hear Mr. Clinton speak because he was a loyal Democrat. Campaign aides said the caravan was late because it made several unscheduled stops so Mr. Clinton could address crowds that had gathered along the highway.
"When do we ever get a chance to see a Presidential candidate," Mr. Kretzer said. "People want to be part of politics. Politics has to come back to the people and that's what Bill Clinton is trying to do."
Ms. Simms said Mr. Clinton's visit had been big news here for days, broadcast almost hourly on local radio stations. Television newscasts and newspaper articles have added to the flood of free publicity.
People said they had come out to see and hear Mr. Clinton for the spectacle and because they were curious about his message. Life is pleasant in Vandalia, many said, but it is slow. Marie Siebert, 37, said she had not seen so much excitement around here since someone thought they spotted Cher at the local Pizza Hut five years ago.
"This town was buzzing then," Mrs. Siebert said. "The Pizza Hut was swamped."
 
Reluctant Support for Clinton
 Throughout the day volunteers set up chairs and sold Clinton-Gore T-shirts at $10 apiece. Allen Blurton, 57, a foreman at a plastics company, stood under an awning. A Democrat, Mr. Blurton said he would reluctantly vote for Mr. Clinton.
"I think our candidate is as weak as our country," Mr. Blurton said. "He's not addressing the real needs. We're not down and out, we're the middle class. We have to do something about the underprivileged. If we ignore the poor we're all going to be dragged down."
Vandalia is the state's former capital and the white brick State House where Mr. Clinton spoke this evening is the site of some of Lincoln's first attacks on slavery when he was a young legislator.
 
Visit 'Is Good for Business'
 The Clinton visit has caused excitement across party lines.
Never mind that Lamire X. Wiss is as Republican as Abe Lincoln, whom he named his real estate business here after. Mr. Wiss said that he was happy to see the Democratic Presidential nominee come to town and that he planned to attend the rally.
"I have no intention of voting for him," Mr. Wiss said. "But Clinton's visit is bringing lots of people to Vandalia and tons of free publicity. And that, my friend, is good for business."
Business has not been good in these parts for a while. Vandalia is the seat of Fayette County and in May the unemployment rate in the county was 11.6 percent, as against 7.8 percent statewide.
 
'Things Are So Bad'
 Fayette County and Vandalia are about equally divided between Republicans and Democrats, although Republicans have only won one of the last four Presidential elections here. That was in 1980.
"If I vote for Clinton it will be for economic reasons but I won't like it," said Jeff Hurst, a Methodist minister from nearby Brownstown, Ill. "I think Clinton is going to have a lot of trouble around here because of his pro-abortion position. This is pretty conservative country."
His wife, Brenda, said she had not made up her mind about who she would support in November because she, too, was deeply troubled by Mr. Clinton's support of abortion rights.
"It seems like the Democrats have a lot of bad morals," she said, "and the Republicans are just for the rich. You try to weigh which ones are more important: the economy or morals."

HEADLINE: U.S. Was Aware the Iraqis Were Buying Technology

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
A year before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, American intelligence agencies had amassed evidence of President Saddam Hussein's vast network set up to buy Western military technology, including an Iraqi-owned front company based in Cleveland, according to documents disclosed today by Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat.
Representative Gonzalez, chairman of the House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs, also released documents that illustrate the disarray within the Administration that resulted from President Bush's order on Oct. 2, 1989, to use political and economic incentives to moderate the Iraqi leader's behavior. 
 Among them was a declassified November 1989 State Department memo that expressed confusion about whether to approve transfers of sophisticated equipment that could be diverted to Iraq's extensive nuclear program.
"The problem is not that we lack a policy on Iraq; we have a policy," read the memo, written by an official in the Bureau of Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs. This was the State Department office responsible for insuring that American-made equipment would not be diverted into nuclear weapons projects abroad. "However, the policy has proven very hard to implement when considering proposed exports of dual-use commodities to ostensibly nonnuclear end users, particularly state enterprises."
 
Export Licenses Considered
 The memo went on to recommend approval or disapproval of several export licenses. Among the items approved -- with a warning that they not be put to nuclear use -- were machine tools that could be used in the Mr. Hussein's nuclear program. High-speed photography equipment was also approved because while it was deemed suitable for conventional military uses, it was regarded as "far too slow for nuclear applications."
Throughout the Iran-Iraq war, which ended in 1988, Mr. Hussein was remarkably successful in buying weapons, primarily from the Soviet Union and France. But he also developed extraordinary complex state-run military-industrial complexes to build his own nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and ballistic missiles.
In a speech on the House floor, Representative Gonzalez asserted that the documents provided further evidence that the Bush Administration permitted Iraq to acquire sensitive Western technology for use in its domestic arms-making programs.
Before the new documents were made public today, little had been disclosed about what the Central Intelligence Agency and the nation's other intelligence agencies knew about Iraq's global strategy to obtain technology for its home-grown projects. Mr. Gonzalez today referred to several more still-classified United States intelligence reports in 1989 and 1990 that he said provided information about both the procurement networks in the West and the military complexes inside Iraq.
One of the documents Mr. Gonzalez discussed was a June 1989 intelligence report stating that the procurement network was so extensive that it included the Matrix Churchill Corporation, a Cleveland-based tool machine supplier bought in 1987 by a company owned by the Iraqi Government. Matrix Churchill was shut down and its assets seized after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.
An intelligence report dated July 1990 titled "Iraq's Growing Arsenal: Programs and Facilities" captures the deception in Iraq's procurement program, saying, "We believe many entities are false end users, passing the materials acquired from foreign suppliers directly to state enterprises involved in military projects, including chemical and biological warfare programs."
Representative Gonzalez also charged -- without offering any evidence -- that the intelligence community had extensive knowledge of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro's global activities. This was the Italian bank whose Atlanta branch was under Federal investigation for a multibillion-dollar bank fraud revolving around the bank's loans to Iraq.

HEADLINE: 90 HAITIANS DROWN AS BOAT CAPSIZES

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 21

 BODY:
About 90 Haitian refugees were reported to have died at sea on Sunday when their small boat capsized and sank about 20 miles to the north of the capital, the authorities here said today.
Haitian officials said the badly overloaded boat carrying about 100 refugees failed shortly after it was launched from the town of Source Matelas. By Tuesday, 15 of the passengers' bodies had either washed ashore on nearby beaches or were recovered from the sea. 
 An official of Haiti's provisional Government charged with refugee affairs, Marlene Dorfeuille, told Haitian radio stations today that an account of the boat sinking was given by nine would-be refugees who were forced off the boat for lack of space before it left.
According to United States diplomats in Haiti, the sinking was the first known case of a boat carrying Haitians seeking to flee their country since mid-June.
 
Sanctions Hurt the Poorest
 Officials said that a policy introduced in May of immediately returning Haitians intercepted at sea had seemed to effectively discourage would-be emigrants from setting out in small, fragile craft.
Thousands of Haitians had sought to reach the United States in that way in the months after the violent overthrow of the country's President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in September.
The United States contended throughout the crisis that the bulk of the boat people fleeing Haiti were doing so for economic reasons. In punishment for the coup against Father Aristide, the Organization of American States imposed a hemisphere-wide embargo that has had a crushing impact on the economy of Haiti, already the hemisphere's poorest country.
International advocates for the refugees have asserted since Father Aristide's overthrow that political violence and widespread repression were major factors in setting off the exodus from the country.
In the most recent wave of violence here, at least four bullet-riddled bodies turned up in the streets of the capital today. Foreign human-rights advocates say similar incidents are common in the countryside as well.

HEADLINE: Debate on Trump's West Side Proposal

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
Reacting in staunch opposition to the proposal of Donald J. Trump's plan to develop 74.6 acres along the Hudson River, Community Board 7 on the Upper West Side yesterday issued a draft resolution that listed 69 reasons that the project should not go forward.
The resolution, issued last night before the first of three public hearings scheduled for consecutive evenings at Martin Luther King Jr. High School, set the stage for a noisy and contentious session, the latest round of debates over the proposal by Mr. Trump's Riverside South Planning Corporation. 
 The hearing last night was evidence of the issue's volatility; of the 600 people who showed up, more than a third stepped to the microphone to speak. In numbers, testimony tilted slightly against the proposal, but overall the debate presented a wide spectrum of concerns by New Yorkers who perceive the proposed development as either a potential threat to or a potential enhancement of their life styles.
The plan calls for the development of Penn Yards, Manhattan's largest undeveloped waterfront property, which builders and community leaders have been wrestling over for a decade. The hearings are part of the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, the process set up in the City Charter under which proposed changes in land use are analyzed, modified and put into practice.
 
The Public Is Heard
 The proposed development, now known as Riverside South, would convert the site -- which stretches from 59th Street to 72d Street between the Hudson River and West End Avenue and Freedom Place -- into a complex of 14 apartment buildings, a 1.8-million-square-foot film production studio topped by twin office towers and a 21.5-acre public park along the waterfront. It would also extend Riverside Drive from 72d Street to 59th Street, and reroute the West Side Highway so that it is no longer elevated and runs farther inland, separated from the Hudson by the new park.
At the hearing last night at the school, on Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street, the project was called gross and grotesque, sensible and reasonable. For all those who complained that their river views would be blocked by new skyscrapers, there were others who looked forward to jogging in a new riverside park.
For all those who questioned the neighborhood's ability to support added pedestrian and vehicular traffic, there were those who argued that the project would create thousands of construction jobs, rejuvenating the city's recession-enervated building trade.
Of course the oratory was colorful. Sylvia Gould, a woman who said she spoke on behalf of the Gray Panthers, said, "Future generations will be appalled by the audacity and greed of those forcing this on the community."
The veiled implication was to Mr. Trump, who was not at the meeting but who bore the brunt of the evening's name-calling. At one point it was suggested he be tarred and feathered.
 
'Where Do You Live?'
 Also unsurprising was that passions occasionally erupted. One speaker, who said the project was "a fantastic opportunity for all New Yorkers," was roundly booed.
And when Robert P. Maguire, the vice president of the Building Trades Council, said, "I implore the Community Board to endorse Riverside South," he was heckled unmercifully.
"Where do you live? Where do you live?" people shouted from the audience. He replied, shouting into the microphone and pointing, "Shame on you!"
Community Boards have only advisory power in the approval procedure. For this reason, and because residents have the most at stake, community boards have frequently played the devil's advocate in the process, forcing consideration of the smallest matters to keep developers and city agencies from proceeding with what they regard as undue haste.
The board is to vote on the draft resolution tomorrow and no one expects it to be favorable, least of all Richard A. Kahan, chiarman of the Riverside South Planning Corporation.
"The vote will be negative," he said. "They have legitimate issues which will be discussed over the last five months, and the plan will be improved from what it is now. But for them to vote yes at this point simply takes them out of the process."
 
Litany of Complaints
 Critics have contended, among other complaints, that the $3 billion project, which would comprise 8.3 million square feet of space and add 5,700 apartments and a film production studio to the area, would further burden the already precarious infrastructure of the Upper West Side, particularly taxing the North River Sewage Treatment Center and the 72d Street subway station.
The board's resolution included both specific recommendations -- for example, that the development be limited to 6.9 million square feet of space -- and nonspecific expressions of discontent. Item 25 reads, for example, referring to the proposed riverside park: "Rethink the freshwater pool."
Proponents of the project argue that the current plan, which arose as an alternative to the second of two previous proposals by Mr. Trump for even larger projects (he has owned the site since 1964) is committed to "reasonable development" of the West Side.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Community Board 7 on the Upper West Side has issued a draft resolution listing 69 reasons why Donald J. Trump's proposed Riverside South development should not go forward. Community Board members discussed the project last night around a model during the first of three public hearings. (Budd Williams for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "What Happens Next: Hurdles for a Trump Plan
Members of Community Board 7 on the Upper West Side of Manhattan yesterday began considering Donald Trump's Riverside South project, a mixed-use project of offices, retail space and housing from West 59th Street to 72d Street along the Hudson River. The project, certified as complete in May by the New York City Planning Department, is subject to public hearings and cannot begin until the seven-month approval procedure is completed. Following are steps the project faces:
Community Board 7: The board held a public hearing yesterday and plans another for today on the project. After a third hearing tomorrow, it is expected to vote. Community Boards have only advisory power in the process.
Borough President: The proposal is expected to move to the office of Ruth W. Messinger on July 27. Ms. Messinger, who has scheduled public hearings for Aug. 3 and 4, has 30 days to make a recommendation.
City Planning Commission: After the community board and the borough president, the proposal goes to the planning commission. The commission, which has 60 days to render a judgment, can approve the proposal, reject it or ask for changes. A tentative public hearing is set for Sept. 5.
City Council: The proposal then goes the City Council, where it will be reviewed first by a subcommittee of the Land Use Committee, then by the entire committee. The full Council will vote on the plan after it comes out of committee. If the Council makes changes in it, it goes back to the planning commission for 15 days, then returns to the Council.
The Mayor's Office: After being approved by the Council, the proposal would then go to the Mayor, who has five days to act. If the Mayor vetoes the proposal, the Council has 10 days to override the veto. A two-thirds majority vote would be needed for an override.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Says Cleaners Overcharged

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Dozens of tenants at the World Trade Center were overcharged by a total of almost $1 million for cleaning services over the last year because of inadequate monitoring by officials of the Port Authority, the executive director of the agency said last night.
In acknowledging the failure in oversight, the executive director, Stanley Brezenoff, said he was reassigning two top officials who were responsible for managing the trade center and its contracts with Ogden Allied Services Corporation, which has cleaned the offices in the twin towers since the mid-1980's. The Trade Center is owned by the Port Authority. 
 The disclosure and the quick action underscored the sensitivity of top Port Authority officials to suggestions of mismanagement, after reports that millions of dollars were wasted on major projects that were later abandoned at Kennedy International Airport. While those projects and the cleaning contracts with Ogden preceded Mr. Brezenoff's arrival at the agency, the poor supervision of cleaning services persisted under his tenure, which began in 1990.
A senior vice president at Ogden, Murray Rosenblatt, declined to comment on the Port Authority's disclosure when reached at his home last night.
 
'Inadequate Monitoring'
 One of the Trade Center officials reassigned as a result of the audit is Frank Garcia, a 34-year veteran of the Port Authority who oversaw the Trade Center's business operations from May 1990 until January, when he was named director of the agency's economic development department. The other is August K. Preschle, who has been with the agency 23 years and who oversaw the Trade Center's maintenance and daily operations.
Mr. Preschle did not return a phone message left at his home last night. Someone who answered the phone at Mr. Garcia's residence said Mr. Garcia would not answer questions on the matter.
Mr. Brezenoff said the overcharges -- which he estimated at between $800,000 and $1 million -- were discovered during an internal audit that he commissioned earlier this year. The audit, which reviewed the Trade Center's cleaning-services contracts and is close to completion, "concluded that there were inadequate monitoring and oversight of billing and charges to the Port Authority and to tenants," Mr. Brezenoff said.
Mr. Brezenoff said the agency would move aggressively to recoup the extra charges and would consider suing the company if the money was not returned. He said the agency would not decide the fate of the company's current cleaning contract with the Trade Center, which expires in December, until the overcharges were resolved.
Since the company has not responded to the findings of the audit, he said it was too soon to say whether the overcharges were deliberate or a result of sloppy bookkeeping. He said that the agency was not considering pursuing a criminal complaint.
Under a $24 million annual contract that was last renewed in January 1990, the agency said, Ogden provides basic office cleaning for the tenants of the Trade Center, which include the Port Authority itself. In addition to overseeing that contract, the agency also monitors several dozen contracts -- totaling an additional $4 million to $6 million -- that individual tenants have signed with Ogden to provide more specialized and intensive cleaning services.
 
Renovations Needed
 Under the main contract, tenants are provided with such basic services as vaccuuming, dusting and the cleaning of bathroooms. Tenants negotiate the additional contracts to arrange for more frequent visits from cleaning crews and for extra services like furniture polishing.
It was under these additional contracts, Mr. Brezenoff said, that Ogden charged tenants rates that exceeded what it had negotiated with the Port Authority. Agency officials said they had not yet determined how many tenants had been overcharged and they declined to identify any of the tenants involved or detail the amounts individual tenants overpaid.
The disclosure of the audit comes as the Trade Center, one of the premier corporate locations in Manhattan, is in need of hundreds of millions of dollars in renovations if it is to hold on to its place in a competitive real-estate market. And the audit that uncovered the overcharges was conducted in part to help retain that competitive edge, Mr. Brezenoff said.
Mr. Brezenoff said he began taking steps soon after he joined the Port Authority in the fall of 1990 to shore up the center's management. Those steps included creating a new division within the Port Authority specifically to oversee the twin towers, and, earlier this year, beginning internal audits to assess operations.
"You fight tooth and nail to attract and retain tenants and you hate to run the risk of a facility getting a reputation for being overpriced on services," Mr. Brezenoff said. "The individual contracts were supposed to be reviewed and they were not."
Ogden Allied Services, the principal subsidiary of the Ogden Corporation, is a nationally known company that also handles cleaning and general maintenance at the metropolitan region's three main airports, which are also operated by the Port Authority. Ogden also used to handle cleaning and booking of trade shows at the Jacob J. Javits Convention Center, but the company was recently dropped at the center in a cost-cutting move.
In the wake of the overcharges, Mr. Brezenoff said the Port Authority would overhaul the Trade Center's cost-accounting system.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The State Department;
Eagleburger Is Viewed As the Likely Successor

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
A move by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to the White House would be likely to leave the State Department in the hands of Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and the outlines of United States policy virtually unchanged, Administration officials said today.
Several officials said that to their knowledge the move, which is expected to occur in August, had not yet been discussed by Mr. Baker and Mr. Eagleburger. 
 In Congress, several Democrats complained that President Bush -- whether he decides to leave Mr. Baker's seat vacant or fill it with a new Secretary -- would be "decapitating" the department in the eyes of a world facing multiple crises, putting politics ahead of statesmanship.
 
Call for Resignation
 At a minimum, Democratic members of Congress say, Mr. Baker should resign formally so that full authority can be given to Mr. Eagleburger or another appointee and the State Department, now run by a close circle of Baker confidants, is not left on hold.
Mr. Baker is expected to resign rather than take a leave.
"We are making the painful transition into a world where regional conflict in breaking out everywhere," Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said, adding that Mr. Eagleburger has the experience to take charge of policy operations but might not accept a caretaker role.
"There is no more important job in the United States Government than the Secretary of State and that office has to be up and running at all times," Senator Moynihan said. "We can't put off crises until December. They don't arrange crises according to our electoral calendar."
 
Not in Inner Circle
 Administration officials and policy analysts suggested that while Mr. Baker's preference might be to go on leave from his job in the hope of easily returning as Secretary of State after the election, a leave would be unworkable, and politically unwise. But they contend that major policies are in place and functioning and could probably weather a three-month hiatus under an acting secretary. There is less certainty about how the Administration would cope with an unexpected crisis.
Mr. Eagleburger has not been a member of Mr. Bush's inner circle of advisers, suggesting his influence would be limited. As a longtime associate of Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, Mr. Eagleburger has never been popular with conservative Republicans.
The Middle East peace process, given a boost by the election of a new government in Israel and Mr. Baker's trip this week to the region, can move mostly of its own volition to a new round of talks between Arabs and Israelis, probably in September.
Mr. Eagleburger has already taken much of the responsibility -- and been the target of Democratic criticism -- for policy in other areas, such as Yugoslavia and the former Soviet Union. But the Deputy Secretary, who is directing Administration aid efforts to Russia and other republics, would have to take on the added task of persuading Congress to back the Russian aid package, which has yet to clear the House of Representatives.
Beyond his involvement in policy on Yugoslavia and the former Soviet republics, Mr. Eagleburger has also taken prominent roles in areas for which Mr. Baker has had little interest. In many such areas, most notably the continuing standoff on Haiti, the Secretary of State has left assistants in charge.
 
Internal Policy Debates
 The President, the Secretary of State and the National Security Adviser, Brent Scowcroft, long ago established a pattern of debating the most important policies among themselves, sometimes also involving Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, or a few other officials.
Mr. Eagleburger has remained largely outside this circle.
In the Department, only a handful of officials -- among them Margaret D. Tutwiler, the spokeswoman; Dennis B. Ross, director of Policy Planning, and Robert B. Zoellick, the department counselor and also the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs -- have had regular access to Mr. Baker, who is widely regarded inside and outside the Administration as a hard working and skillful manager, but not a warm personality able to relax and listen to the ideas of a wide range of people. The three aides might all end up moving with Mr. Baker, Administration officials said.
His management of the Department has left many officials feeling left out in shaping policy in areas where they have expertise.
But there is wide respect for Mr. Baker's dedication and managerial skills among diplomats and foreign leaders who have dealt with the Secretary of State. Arab delegation heads to several rounds of Middle East talks said that Mr. Baker had gained the confidence of Arab leaders who had long been of the opinion that the United States would automatically back Israel in any dispute.

HEADLINE: RUSSIANS OFFERING NUCLEAR ARMS FUEL FOR U.S. REACTORS

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Desperate for hard currency, Russia offered yesterday to sell the United States tons of uranium from retired nuclear arms, saying the concentrated material could be diluted into fuel for civilian reactors that make electricity.
Any East-West deal that turned nuclear swords into plowshares would be a milestone in dismantling the cold war's machinery. For the Russians, the main alternative is to store highly enriched uranium in underground bunkers. Some Western experts say they fear that material put in storage might eventually find its way back into bombs. 
 Victor N. Mikhailov, head of Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy, yesterday discussed the potential sale of Russian uranium in Washington with top officials of the Energy Department, which oversees the nation's production of nuclear arms and civilian reactor fuel.
 
'A Lot of Hurdles'
 "The Russians are very serious," said Dr. Thomas B. Cochran, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council who has discussed the proposed sale with Mr. Mikhailov. "But there's a lot of hurdles that have to be overcome, so he's over here to cement the deal."
The Russians have also reportedly talked to France and Japan about possible sales of uranium derived from warheads. There is no indication that the Russians have tried to sell highly enriched uranium to any other countries.
Mr. Mikhailov and his aides have lined up several American companies eager to dilute highly enriched Russian uranium from warheads and to sell it as reactor fuel. Yesterday he lobbied for the plan with Federal officials, who must approve any deal.
Among the major questions are whether Russian bomb-grade uranium can be shipped overseas without theft or accident and whether it can be sold without sending the world uranium market into a tailspin.
Already, cash-starved Russians have sold large amounts of natural and mildly enriched uranium in Western commercial markets, feeding a price decline that has driven some uranium producers out of business and threatened the uranium enrichment business of the Energy Department, the world's largest supplier of commercial reactor fuel.
Private experts say that, despite the potential problems, the Federal Government might eventually approve the sale since revenues could help Moscow dismantle its nuclear arsenal and aid the ailing Russian economy.
Several American companies are clearly eager to make agreements, including Allied-Signal Inc., a aerospace and chemicals giant based in Morristown, N.J., that recently signed a preliminary agreement with the Russians.
"We hope to start the processing work next year and eventually to build a plant in Russia," said Michael J. Ascolese, a company spokesman.
Walter A. Simon, vice president for business development at General Atomics, a San Diego company also talking with the Russians, said recycling bomb material into reactor fuel had benefits beyond economics. "It's better than having it stockpiled for military purposes," he said in an interview.
Yesterday the Energy Department said Mr. Mikhailov met with Energy Secretary James D. Watkins and other departmental officials to discuss the potential uranium sale.
"We agreed to try to come to an early determination" about the deal's feasibility, said William H. Young, the department's assistant secretary for nuclear energy, adding that no timetable for a decision had been set.
The United States has 110 operating nuclear reactors, all of which must be at least partly refueled with fresh uranium every 12 to 18 months.
The retirement of thousands of warheads from the arsenals of East and West, as called for by recent accords, will free hundreds of tons of plutonium 239 and uranium 235, the two main fuels of nuclear warheads. So far, few decisions have been made about the final disposition of this material. The main options are to store it, to recycle it into new arms or to transform it into reactor fuel.
For a host of technical and political reasons, such conversion is more difficult for plutonium than uranium. By and large, the plutonium is slated to be stored.
Natural uranium ore is made up of a mix of isotopes. Only 0.71 percent of it is uranium 235, the fissionable isotope used in bombs and reactors. Uranium for most American nuclear power reactors is enriched to a level of about 3 percent, while fuel for bombs has more than 90 percent.
The plan now under discussion is to reverse that enrichment process, diluting uranium 235 from bombs with natural uranium for use in commercial nuclear power plants.
Dr. Thomas L. Neff, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has long advocated the sale of bomb uranium, said in an interview that the dismantlement of Russian nuclear arms might yield up to 20 tons of highly enriched uranium a year, which in diluted form could annually power about 20 commercial nuclear reactors.
Conversely, Dr. Neff said, that same uranium could fuel about 1,500 Hiroshima-sized bombs.
Since the Russian stockpiles of weapons-grade uranium are so large, it seems unlikely that the West would be able to purchase enough of it for reactor fuel to insure that it did not get into unfriendly hands.
At least four American companies have negotiated with Moscow in recent months to buy highly enriched uranium. One team is composed of General Atomics and Babcock & Wilcox, and the other partnership is Allied-Signal and Nuclear Fuel Services of Erwin, Tenn. All the companies have nuclear expertise. In addition, Babcock & Wilcox and Nuclear Fuel Services have plants that process highly enriched uranium, mainly for the Federal Government.
On July 3 in Moscow, Allied-Signal and Nuclear Fuel Services signed a tentative agreement with the Russian Ministry of Atomic Energy and the Russian Academy of Sciences to buy enriched uranium, according to a copy of the protocol. It calls for an "interim arrangement" in which 11 tons of highly enriched uranium would be purchased by mid-1993, with similar amounts thereafter annually.
No price is disclosed in the document. But Dr. Cochran of the Natural Resources Defense Council said 11 tons of bomb material might fetch up to $100 million if diluted for the reactor fuel market.
The tentative accord calls for the joint venture with Allied-Signal and Nuclear Fuel Services to eventually set up a plant in Russia where enriched uranium would be diluted for sale.
Reactor fuel produced by the East-West venture would be sold "to or through the U.S. Department of Energy for use in the world commercial fuel market, or on terms acceptable to both parties" in a way to minimize any disruption of world uranium markets, the agreement says.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Optimistic but Cautious

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave an only faintly upbeat forecast today, saying the economy would gain momentum soon. But he failed to say how soon and added that the jobless rate -- the most politically sensitive economic indicator in an election year -- would remain above 7 percent for the rest of 1992.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony before Congress is likely to give the White House little encouragement that the economy will bolster President Bush's faltering re-election campaign. The Fed chairman characterized current economic activity as dull and gave no firm indication that it would pick up before Election Day. 
 Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential nominee, who leads Mr. Bush in the public opinion polls by 20 points or more, has made the Republicans' stewardship of the economy a central campaign theme. The Democrats contend that Republican policies have mired the nation in its longest slump since World War II.
 
 
Sees No Triple Dip
 In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan, the nation's most influential economic policy maker, rejected the idea of a triple-dip recession, saying the economy "is likely to strengthen moderately" between now and the end of 1993. He added that the jobless rate, now 7.8 percent, would fall to a range of 6.5 to 7 percent by the end of 1993.
In a triple dip recession, the normal recovery after an initial downturn would give way to two substantial dips in output.
"I expect that the economic expansion will soon gain momentum, which lower inflation should help to maintain," he said. He said industrial production was increasing in July, based on preliminary reports, after declining in June.
Mr. Greenspan appeared before the Senate Banking Committee, as he is required by law to do twice a year, to discuss monetary policy and the state of the economy. The hearing was unusually testy, with several senators attacking the Fed chairman for acting too slowly to cut interest rates and asking why they should believe this forecast when several of his recent predictions had been wrong.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan made these other points:
*It would be risky to use fiscal stimulus, like increased spending, to spur the economy, because that would produce a higher deficit and could push up already high long-term interest rates. Some Democrats in Congress are considering such a package of fiscal stimulation.
*The American economy would not benefit from letting the dollar fall. On Monday, the Fed joined a dozen other central banks to buy dollars, in an effort to keep the currency from falling to record lows against the German mark.
*Cutting the capital gains tax rate would help lift investment -- a position he espoused even before he became Fed chairman. The Bush Administration plans to push Congress to pass a capital gains tax cut and a tax credit for first-time home buyers, among other measures, to enhance growth. Many Democrats frown on cutting capital gains taxes, believing it would help the rich while doing little to stimulate investment.
 Mr. Greenspan said one reason the economy should pick up soon was that with profits up, many banks had become healthy enough to make more loans. He said many households had reduced their debt, laying the foundation for increased consumer confidence and household spending.
But Mr. Greenspan added that growth would continue to be held back by the large burdens of debt still held by households and businesses.
"Last year, I characterized this process as the economy struggling against a 50-mile-an-hour headwind," he said. "Today its speed is decidedly less but still appreciable."
The Fed has lowered interest rates to the lowest level in 29 years, and he said it was now considering another way to spur lending. The central bank might ease the ratio of capital to assets that banks are required to meet, he said.
 Democrats questioned Mr. Greenspan's prediction that the economy would soon pick up, implying that he was seeking to help his Republican friends. "I speak to people across the country, and you're about the most optimistic person I've talked to," said Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the committee.
Mr. Riegle and other senators were skeptical of Mr. Greenspan's forecast, noting that he had said in January that the economy would pick up in the second quarter. Instead, the jobless rate soared, and Mr. Greenspan acknowledged today that growth in the three months that ended on June 30 would be about 2 percent, appreciably below the 2.7 percent of the January-March quarter.
In July 1991, Mr. Greenspan said the nation was moving toward "a solid recovery," but after that the economy dipped steeply, with growth falling to an anemic four-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter.
"Why is there any more reason for us to think that you're right this time," Mr. Riegle asked, "when we look at the record and see that you've said essentially the very same thing before in past months, and it's turned out not to be right?"
 As senator after senator criticized him during the four-hour session, Mr. Greenspan sat stoically, his head propped up on his left hand. Occasionally he interrupted them in mid-sentence to defend himself, just as they often butted in during his testimony to air their disbelief or unhappiness.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, joined Democrats in saying the Fed chairman did not show enough urgency about the economy. After the hearing, Mr. D'Amato called on Mr. Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to step down and recommended that Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp replace Mr. Brady.
 
 
Sees Lower Jobless Rate
 Mr. Greenspan said that growth for the year would be between 2.25 and 2.75 percent, rising to 2.75 to 3 percent in 1993. He said the Fed was predicting that the jobless rate would fall to between 7.25 percent and 7.5 percent by the end of this year.
Mr. Greenspan devoted much of his testimony to explaining why the economy remained weak even after the Fed cut the Federal funds rate -- the rate at which banks lend each other money -- 23 times since mid-1989.
He explained that the surge of debt in the 1980's caused consumer and business spending to fall when the value of assets stopped increasing. He said rate cuts failed to stimulate activity as much as expected because many banks, shocked by bad loans, were reluctant to lend, and many consumers and businesses, weighed down by debt, were loath to borrow.
Although he acknowledged that monetary growth had fallen well below its targets this year, he said the Fed had provisionally adopted the same monetary growth targets for next year that were set for 1992. The Fed is aiming for growth of 2.5 to 6.5 percent for M-2, the most closely watched gauge of the money supply, and of 4.5 to 8.5 percent for debt.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Campaign Focuses on Baker As Bush Stumps in Northeast

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARFIELD, N.J., July 21

 BODY:
President Bush's campaign has always had the sense of a political operation waiting for something to happen. On the campaign trail today, waiting for James A. Baker 3d has simply added a new tang to the air of expectancy.
Months ago, the question was whether Mr. Bush would name a new chief of staff and when he would pick his campaign team. That done, Bush advisers wondered when he would announce his candidacy and answer demands for action on the economy. Then, it was whether he would mount an attack on Congress, and after that, whether he would replace his new chief of staff. 
 Today the questions that campaign aides were asking focused on Mr. Baker as Mr. Bush campaigned in Philadelphia and here in Bergen County, trying to shore up two groups that help make up the Republican base: supporters of Federal subsidies for parochial schools and people of Eastern European ancestry.
Some Bush aides cautioned against seeing Mr. Baker as a solution to all their problems. Mr. Bush's campaign, a Washington aide said, is "so far in our own end zone that we're going to have to throw something high and very risky to get back in the game."
But Mr. Baker was seen as a figure who could impose order and energy on the disorganized and desultory Bush team and, perhaps most important, act as the peer that Mr. Bush has been lacking to give advice and, when necessary, prod him to action.
The President himself did not mention Mr. Baker today. But the course of the campaign was clearly on his mind as he talked in Philadelphia of "the funny period we're in." There were times when he, too, seemed to be waiting as he went through the motions of campaigning in the weeks before the Republican National Convention, which opens on Aug. 17, in Houston.
And there were moments when his mind did not seem to be entirely on the business at hand.
At a question-and-answer session at Archbishop Ryan Catholic School in Philadelphia, Mr. Bush had to pause for a second to recollect where he was on his frenetic itinerary. "I am determined not to bring into this lovely school arena -- gymnasium, or whatever lovely auditorium we are in -- a lot of partisan politics," he said.
Later, a woman who said she was concerned that middle-income Americans were not getting enough help, asked Mr. Bush if there was an income ceiling on his proposal to give families $1,000 to spend on the school of their choice -- public, private or religious.
"In this program that we're talking about here today, there is no means testing," he replied, using the bureaucratic term for a program in which people above a certain income are not eligible. "A family like yours would be covered," he added, apparently believing the woman was referring to herself when she mentioned families earning $40,000 a year.
He was partly right. Campaign aides later acknowledged, with some embarrassment, that there is an income ceiling in his proposal. It is $40,000.
Mr. Bush's campaigning recently has been aimed largely at two things: seizing back the "family" agenda that the Democrats tried to appropriate at their convention in New York last week, and dispelling the lack of resolve that haunts the Bush team.
He has taken every opportunity to reassure his supporters that he intends to fight hard for re-election, as he did on Monday night, when the President's aides arranged a satellite broadcast to 34 gatherings of supporters in 27 states. "The Democrats have had their day, and next month it's our turn," Mr. Bush said. "And we're going to come out of Houston strong."
Today, in this industrial city in northeastern New Jersey, Mr. Bush addressed an enthusiastic crowd outside the Three Saints Russian Orthodox Church to commemorate "National Freedom Day," a celebration of the crumbling of Communist power in Eastern Europe.
"The family is under siege, and the choices in this election are clear," he said. "On one side the advocates of the liberal agenda, on the other side are you and I and those values of family that we share."
He added, "They want public schools to hand out birth control pills and devices to teen-age kids."
Mr. Bush closed with a new assurance of his determination, delivered in a shout: "I will not let you down! I will fight for the faith! I will fight for the American family! We are one nation, under God, and never forget it!"

HEADLINE: People Who Need Care Find Men Are Giving It

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
By day, Albert C. Wiltshire is a no-nonsense chief executive running the Brooklyn Navy Yard with a powerful grip -- his staff irreverently calls him Darth Vader.
But at night, he turns into Big Al, a 55-year-old bachelor homemaker who cooks, shops, cleans and supervises school work for his 10- and 12-year-old grandsons who have lived with him since his daughter's marriage foundered a year ago. 
 His dual-track life makes Mr. Wiltshire one of about 12.7 million older men looking after children and grandchildren or providing hands-on care for ailing or disabled relatives, friends and neighbors, according to the Commonwealth Fund, a New York foundation specializing in issues involving health care, the aging and the work force.
After surveying 2,999 Americans age 55 and over, the study concluded that while women still are the major providers of care for other people, men are taking an increasingly bigger role.
How much bigger is tough to measure because, until recently, researchers paid little attention to the role of men, said Lenard W. Kaye, a Bryn Mawr professor who has done studies of men involved in providing care.
"These men are unsung heroes, standing outside the spotlight," said Professor Kaye. "They are the husbands, sons, sons-in-law, brothers and other men who provide about a third of the care for the elderly. Their number is likely to grow because women as caregivers are reaching the saturation point and the need for caregiving continues to increase."
Dr. Robert N. Butler, chairman of the Department of Geriatrics at Mount Sinai Medical Center, says the change in men's roles has been stimulated by economic, political and cultural changes.
"Increased longevity, the high costs of health care and the feminist movement all are moving society in the direction of greater shared responsibility," he said. "We also are seeing in many cultures evidence that gender roles can change in the middle years, women becoming more assertive and less likely to accept automatically the caregiver's role and men showing more interest in nurturing."
The Commonwealth Fund and others including the Brookdale Center on Aging of Hunter College said the new survey is probably the most comprehensive statistical effort to measure the providing of care by gender, age, income, race, employment and marital status. Based on data developed by Louis Harris and Associates, ICF Inc. and the University of Massachusetts-Boston, the survey showed that half the men over 55 who have children or grandchildren are caring for them.
And other researchers suggested that the survey may in fact underrepresent the number of male providers. For example, they said that members of minority groups were probably underrepresented because they were more likely to care for family members without reaching out for help from social-service agencies and thus they were more difficult for researchers to find.
 
An Unknown Dimension
 Another unknown is the dimension of the providing of care in the gay community by younger men helping partners with AIDS, said Dr. Robyn Stone, a senior policy analyst at Project Hope, an international health foundation in Chevy Chase, Md. Dr. Stone, who has studied the frail and elderly and is planning to look at younger male helpers, also said that more is needed to be learned about the scope of male providing of care, how much of it is intermittent help like grocery shopping and how much of it is full-time personal, hands-on care.
The Commonwealth study did not address this question specifically, but it did make clear that those providing care were doing more than an occasional good deed. It found that men spend an average 15.9 hours weekly as providers of care and women 22.8 hours.
According to the Commonwealth study, among married couples, 1.6 million men and 1.8 million women are caring for a sick or disabled spouse; 1.2 million men and 1.9 million women are caring for a sick or disabled parent, and 2.1 million men and 3.1 million women are caring for a sick or disabled friend or neighbor.
Hispanic people are more likely than whites or blacks to help their children, and both Hispanic people and blacks are more likely than whites to take care of grandchildren and great-grandchildren.
 
Doing Double Duty
 Even the researchers say the studies so far do not reflect the range of experiences of men who have served both as helper to an ailing parent or spouse and simultaneously as homemaker for children.
A case in point is Joseph O'Mara, who cared for his gravely sick wife for two years and also looked after their young children.
When his wife died seven years ago, Mr. O'Mara said, he considered returning to Ireland with the five children, then ages 4 to 14, but decided instead to stay put among the neighbors and friends who had poured out support for the family, especially during his wife's illness.
"I didn't do it alone, everybody helped," said Mr. O'Mara, who turns 55 in October and has worked as a cook for 20 years at the Mad Hatter, an Upper East Side restaurant just around the corner from the family's walk-up.
For starters, there was Dolly Benn Epstein, a widow, who ran a nearby thrift shop for charities and looked out for clothes that would please the children, and James Levett, a next-door neighbor, who saw that they kept doctors' appointments, and Laura Kaye-Stewart, who secured a $25,000 school tuition fund for them -- all five attended St. Stephen's of Hungary -- and Bob Keon who kept an eye on the younger ones as they played on East 78th Street, and Paulette Meiselas, a social worker from Spence-Chapin who stayed at their side through many a family crisis.
 
Rugby Club Pitches In
 High on the list of helpers is the entire New York Rugby Club, which bought the family a station wagon so Mr. O'Mara could keep up his habit of collecting a dozen or more neighborhood children on Saturday mornings for an outing to Randalls Island even though his arthritis keeps him from playing the game himself.
"I guess a lot of us helped the family," said Rose Garvey, whose family lives close by, "but the bottom line is Joseph always is there for us too when we need him."
Both Mr. Wiltshire and Mr. O'Mara said they had grown accustomed to their bachelor head-of-household roles.
"I put the bar in the cellar and turned my den into a second bedroom," said Mr. Wiltshire. Two bicycles are parked in the living room now and he's buying another for himself, he said, adding, "We're doing just fine."
Nonetheless, they are constantly reminded that they are breaking new ground. At parent-teacher meetings, Mr. Wiltshire occasionally gets to his feet to complain that all the advice he hears seems directed at the working mother, demanding, "What about fathers -- and grandfathers?" Mr. O'Mara was the only man in a single-parent club run by the Rev. Vincent Biagi at Xavier High School.
"There needs to be more attention paid to men who head families," said Mr. Wiltshire. "If the idea was more widely accepted, more of us would get involved. It's just society that hangs on to the stereotypes that taking care of children is women's responsibility."
Mr. Wiltshire, who was divorced 16 years ago, said he regarded his help to his grandsons as "a second chance to do what I should have done for my children." He was particularly proud when 12-year-old Vernell Sullivan won a medal in June for the biggest improvement in his class.
The experiences of men moving into caring roles already has demonstrated a need to provide men with more opportunity for training and assistance, said Dr. Albert Hollenbeck, assistant director of the Andrus Foundation of the American Association of Retired Persons, which sponsored Professor Kaye's survey. "Men often do not bring to caregiving the typical skills of a homemaker such as cooking. Neither do they have the support networks to sustain them emotionally."
When men began turning up for a course in providing care at the Office for the Aging of Orange County in Goshen, N.Y., Bobbi Hull, a special programs director, was not surprised because, she said, "we saw this trend emerging as more men took on the job of helping spouses and parents who suffered from Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, stroke and other disabilities." The 12-hour course includes psychological counseling and practical demonstrations by nurses in how to bathe and transfer a patient from bed to wheelchair.
 
Unreal Expectations?
 In a typical class of 30, 5 to 11 participants are men, she said, and a number are holding jobs as well as providing care. The course, created as one of 17 countywide programs financed by New York State, has drawn men and women from Delaware, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, she said.
New York City's Department for the Aging, which conducts lunchtime seminars on providing care for employees of corporations, has found a significant increase in men attending, said Commissioner Prema Mathai-Davis. "When we began five years ago, two or three men would show up. Now regularly one-third of the audience are men and sometimes a half. This certainly shows men feel they have a need to know what services are available for the elderly, such as home-delivered meals or other help."
Despite the evidence that men are getting more involved in caring, Dr. Katrina W. Johnson, a research administrator of the National Institute on Aging, cautioned against unreal expectations. "We think of men these days as being more willing to demonstrate they are caring, sensitive people as we see them on television shows," she said. "It's one thing to picture the male as willing to be a caregiver and help an adorable 4-year-old orphan who may grow up to be President. But is a would-be Alan Alda ready to care for his ailing, elderly mother?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph O'Mara, a restaurant cook who has also cared for his five children since his wife died seven years ago, at home with his family. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Campus Journal;
Vote to Sell TV Station Splits Iowans

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa, July 21

 BODY:
In 1950, an unexpected windfall led to a visionary idea, and leaders at Iowa State University bought a commercial television station. The station has been a laboratory for students in both journalism and meteorology ever since, while at the same time serving as a network affiliate station for central Iowa.
But in June the Iowa Board of Regents, which runs the state's three public universities, voted to sell the station. Along with an expected $14 million, the vote produced a lawsuit. 
 Calling themselves Iowans for WOI-TV Inc., a group of faculty members, former regents, students, alumni, Iowans and former Iowans who oppose the sale asked a state court to stop the transaction. Neil Harl, a professor of agriculture and economics who is the group's president, said the group believed that WOI is an important educational and economic asset for the university and that the regents did not have the authority to sell it.
The group maintains that the Regents by law have the authority to manage and control the three universities but not to sell their assets. The regents have a date in court next month to defend the sale.
The Regents say owning a commercially profitable television station does not fit into the university's mission, and that if it ever lost money it would have to borrow funds from the university. They voted to sell the station, an ABC affiliate, on June 17 to the Capital Communications Company, a joint venture of the Citadel Communications Company of Bronxville, N.Y., and the Lynch Corporation, a Connecticut concern.
The transfer will take about a year to complete. In addition, the sides have yet to work out several details, including whether the station will continue to use students as interns.
In the meantime, students, along with paid full-time employees, continue to work at the station in the middle of campus.
Mr. Harl said WOI was owned directly by the university until 1987, when the Iowa State Broadcasting Corporation was established so that it could operate independently. But it has consistently contributed profits, nearly $400,000 annually in recent years, to Iowa State, he said. The station also pays $80,000 a year in rent.
The station employs students as camera operators, reporters and weather forecasters. And WOI and its equipment serve the university's Distance Learning program, which sends lectures by satellite to students far from Ames. The program has transmitted lessons to Czechoslovakia and has plans to send transmissions to the former Soviet Union.
Students in the broadcast journalism program are required to work at the station for one course, and some classes have been held in its building. Rod Fowler, a full-time anchor at WOI and a recent Iowa State graduate from Tama, said his time at WOI was invaluable. He said the station helped him decide to enter the university's journalism program.
"From beginning to end, students get the hands-on experience that they need," he said.
Iowa State established WOI in 1950 with funds left over from a Federal grant it received for work on the Manhattan Project, the World War II project to build the atomic bomb. Two Iowa State professors and four graduate students produced tons of high purity uranium for the bomb project.
The station was the first commercially operated television station owned by a university in the country. Joe Esser, associate editor of Broadcast and Cable Marketplace, said there were only two other university-owned commercial television stations in the nation: WNDU at the University of Notre Dame and KOMU at the University of Missouri at Columbia.
Mr. Harl said the money from the sale, which will be placed in trust, could not make enough in interest to offset the income the university now receives, and could later receive, from the station.
Iowa State's president, Martin Jischke, and several campus groups oppose the sale. "Everybody concludes that the stream of benefits would be greater if I.S.U. kept the station," Mr. Harl said.
But Marvin Pomerantz, a prominent Iowa businessman and chairman of the Board of Regents, said the board had considered the decision carefully. "The quality of our educational programs will improve, and the university will benefit financially from the sale," he said.
