HEADLINE: For Inner-City Students, a Program Offers a Taste of Private-School Life

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Picture a private school setting, with all of the educational extras such schools can afford. Open the campus for a summer school that aims to help inner-city adolescents. Then recruit as instructors bright high school and college students considering teaching careers.
Give the students, all of whom are in middle school, rigorous instruction in math, science, history and language, combined with electives in the arts and sports. Offer hugs and support; then listen to the students who are accepted to the tuition-free, six-week program called Summerbridge. 
 "I wish there were public schools like this," said Manuel Billups, an 11-year-old who is enrolled in the Summerbridge program at Riverdale Country School in the Bronx and who will be a seventh grader at Intermediate School 164 in Harlem in the fall. "You have to go to a private school to get all of this, and even then privates don't offer all of this."
As educators and policymakers continue their search for ways to help students from the inner city, Summerbridge demonstrates what can be done with hard work and a spending level that corporate sponsors and other contributors call cost-effective. As a result, it has been copied in nine cities since 1990.
 
Two Summers of Work
 Founded in 1978 by Lois Anderson Loofbourrow, a former public school teacher in San Francisco, the program seeks to lift students both academically and personally. For two summers, youngsters have class in the morning and pursue elective subjects and sports in the afternoon. In the intervening school year they receive tutoring.
Summerbridge says the approach has paid off: 92 percent of the 700 students who have gone through the San Francisco program since 1978 have enrolled in top-tier private college-preparatory high schools, most on scholarships, or won admission into competitive public high schools. Some graduates are now attending Ivy League universities or highly selective public institutions.
And it is a double success, in that 64 percent of the high school and college students who have taught in the program have gone on to pursue careers in education.
For 12 years San Francisco had the only such program, but since 1990 others like it have been established in New York; Miami; Louisville, Ky.; Providence, R.I.; Manchester, N.H.; Ross, Calif.; Cambridge, Mass., New Orleans and Hong Kong. Six more are scheduled to open next summer in New Haven; Cincinnati; El Paso; Bethlehem, Pa.; Kansas City, Mo., and Portland, Ore.
The program's cost -- about $1,000 per student -- is borne by the host private schools, which donate their campuses and supplies, and by the InterPacific Group, a San Francisco company, as well as other corporations and foundations. Salaries for teachers are $500 for high school students and $750 for college students, and some college students are given extra money in the form of financial aid.
Since 1988, InterPacific, which manages and owns resorts and other businesses, has contributed $600,000 to $750,000 to Summerbridge in San Francisco, said Charles Frankel, the company's director of community support. The company has also given $25,000 grants to start programs in the other cities.
 
Class Consciousness
 But the program's use of affluent private schools instead of public schools has raised concerns among some of Summerbridge's teachers.
"I don't know that by bringing them to a private school we are sending a message that says, 'See what you can have if you work hard,' or 'See what you can never have,' " said a teacher in the New York program, Michelle Celestine, who will be a senior this fall at the University of California at Berkeley, majoring in English. "That's something the national office should look into."
Mrs. Loofbourrow, however, responds that students need to learn about the economic divide. Others, like Mr. Frankel, say the program is intended to give students not only an academic jump-start but also exposure to an economic level to which they should aspire. "That's what this program is all about," he said.
About 75 percent of Summerbridge's national enrollment of 1,000 students this summer come from poor neighborhoods in the cities in which it operates. Generally, the students the program chooses are those who perform well on standardized tests but who have difficulties in the classroom.
The response from students is usually overwhelming. Summerbridge in New York received 170 applications and enrolled about 60 students this summer. Neither the students nor the teachers receive credit for their work, but for many the experience is enough.
"It is much different from my school," said Douglas Cajas, a 14-year-old completing his second summer in the San Francisco program. "The academics are harder, but that's good."
Douglas, who will enter a private college-preparatory school this fall, came to Summerbridge last summer to work on his writing. Last year, he said, he had difficulty composing a simple paragraph, let alone writing and organizing an essay. Although he says his writing still needs work, Douglas said that he could now put together a competent essay, and that his confidence has soared as his abilities have improved.
 
Small Classes and Innovation
 Much of the program's success stems from the small size of the classes and the innovative way lessons are taught.
At the Riverdale Country School, Nika Lee, a freshman at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, divides her six students into two teams and conducts a French class as if it were a game show. To choruses of good-natured laughter, students help each other produce the correct response as they practice greetings and basic commands in French.
"I've learned that school can be fun," said Sandra Gutara, a 12-year-old who is taking Ms. Lee's French class and who will enter the seventh grade this fall at St. Philip Neri in the Bronx. "After all we've done here, it's going to be hard to go back to regular school."
For many of the student teachers, Summerbridge has been an educational nirvana. The days are long, usually 14 hours, but the experience of teaching and drawing up their own curriculums far outweighs the low pay, said many of the teachers.
Like their students, they have to apply for admission to the program, describing how they would design a course or a curriculum around that course. Their progress is monitored by teachers who work in the private schools where the program is held and who, in many cases, were once Summerbridge teachers themselves.
"The kids teach you about yourself," said Nancy Nagramada, 20, who is teaching for a second summer at Summerbridge in New Orleans. "They teach you what your limits are and where you need to grow as a teacher."
Themselves not much older than their students, the teachers say it is easier for them to recall their own adolescence and what it was like for them in school. Most recall their middle-school years as relentlessly boring and so are determined to present invigorating lessons.
In her class this summer, for instance, Ms. Nagramada taught her students how the heart works by drawing the organ on a large piece of paper, putting it on the ground and then telling her students to walk through the chambers of the heart pretending they were blood cells. Last year, it took two days of classroom lectures before her students learned the information; this year, using the walk-through method, she said, her young charges knew the material in 30 minutes.
"It proved to me that learning occurs more quickly by experiencing," said Ms. Nagramada, who plans to attend Hunter College in New York this fall to major in education. "The best thing you can do for these kids is don't give them any label of any sort and give them your time and your love and to let them know they matter."

HEADLINE: A Last Resort In College Aid: The Kindness Of Strangers

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
It was another turn-down day at the Andriekus home outside Lansing, Mich. In the mail was a bill for $9,999, one semester's tuition and housing at the University of Pennsylvania, where 16-year-old Amy E. Andriekus had been, to her unanticipated delight, accepted.
Also in the mail the same day last week was a standard rejection letter from former President Ronald Reagan, one of more than 800 people to whom Miss Andriekus has written to ask for contributions after Penn told her that the only financial aid she will get is a $2,500 loan. 
 Although soliciting donations was an unusual response to her financial emergency, Miss Andriekus is a good example of the middle-class squeeze that so infuriates families today.
Her father, Paul, is an assembly line electrician at General Motors. Her mother, Martha, is a paraprofessional in the local schools. Their total annual income last year was $58,892 and her brother, Kenny, will also start college in the fall, at Lansing Community College.
"We never thought of ourselves as rich," said Miss Andriekus, who graduated from Waverly High School with a grade point average of 3.99 out of a possible 4.0. She said her family cannot afford to pay more than $20,000 a year to put her through the Wharton School at Penn. Penn essentially disagreed. The differing views reflect a common clash that is also a continuing source of middle-class anger.
 
More Aid Than Ever
 Penn and other expensive universities offer more financial aid than ever, but it goes to the most disadvantaged students. Amy and her parents are willing to pay a big part of the cost of a college degree, but they do not believe they should have to deplete their life savings to do so.
The situation is complicated by the fact that Amy has other choices. She has been accepted at the University of Michigan, which costs less than $10,000 a year, and has been offered a $6,500-a-year scholarship at Alma College in Alma, Mich., where the total annual cost is about $16,000.
She said she is determined to go to Wharton because it is the best place to study economics, no matter the cost. Using her mother's computer, she typed out a spunky letter describing her thrill at being accepted and her disappointment about the financial obstacles.
 
'Beginning of a Journey'
 "In the course of human events," she wrote, unself-consciously borrowing a phrase, "there always seems to be thrown in the path of those who endeavor to make their life eventful, rewarding, and meaningful for the betterment of others, that one rock, which blocks their way. I have hit that rock."
She spent the first weeks of her summer vacation writing to 800 company executives from the Fortune 500, former United States Presidents, newspaper and magazine editors and anybody else who could give her the money to pay for her education. She plans to send a total of 1,000 letters.
So far, 85 have come back with polite rejections. The only positive response came from Harper's Magazine, which plans to publish an edited version of her letter in its September issue, and pay her a $75 fee.
She has until Aug. 6 to pay her first semester bill if she is to attend Penn in September.
Miss Andriekus said she feels betrayed by Penn. When she visited last November, an official told her that if she got accepted Penn would make sure she could afford to be there. The problem for the Andriekus family and many others of middle income is defining what affordable means.
"What usually happens is not an income problem," said William M. Schilling, director of student financial aid at Penn. "It is a problem of family expectations."
Mrs. Andriekus said she and her husband had saved for their children's education, often spending vacations at home and doing without fancy clothes.
Last year, when interest rates dropped, they put most of the money into stocks. Along with savings, this produces about $11,000 a year in interest and dividends.
Mr. Schilling cannot discuss an individual student's finances, but he said that universities consider stock holdings to be at least partially available for education, even if they must be sold at a loss.
Mrs. Andriekus also said that her husband considers it his moral obligation to provide the same help to each of his children, even though Amy's bills at Penn would exceed $20,000 a year and Kenny's bills at Lansing Community College will be just over $5,000.
The Andriekuses are giving each child $10,000 a year. But under the formula used by Penn and other universities, the family contribution for Kenny would be the cost of his education; the rest would go to Amy.
 
Father Strives to Be Fair
 "My father wouldn't do that," Miss Andriekus said. "It's not fair." She said Kenny will put the unused portion of his money toward completing his last two years at a four-year college.
Mr. Schilling said that universities cannot be swayed by a family's values. "Families make a lot of choices, and we can't necessarily consider all those choices in what we're doing," he said.
Miss Andriekus has tried everything she could think of. General Motors has scholarships for minority students but not for her. Her father was born in Lithuania, but Lithuanian aid societies said she was not Lithuanian enough: her grandfather was born in the United States.
Mrs. Andriekus has even considered writing to Japanese automobile companies and offering to let them put Amy in a commercial saying the Japanese helped her when General Motors would not.
"My kids mean more to me than supporting my husband's employer," she said. "If they can't help me and a foreign company can, well, hey. You know?"

She has accumulatd a pile of rejection letters, including one from former President Ronald Reagan. (Robert Killips for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profits Up at Citicorp and 3 Other Big Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citicorp, recovering from loan losses that all but wiped out its profits in the last two years, said yesterday that it earned $171 million in the second quarter, up from $11 million a year earlier.
The improvement at Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, was similar to recent earnings reports by many other banks. While increases in loans to individuals and businesses have been meager at most banks, the industry's profits have improved, thanks to reduced losses from bad loans, a widening spread between interest rates paid to depositors and those charged borrowers, and cost cutting. 
 Among other large banking companies, the Chemical Banking Corporation said cost savings resulting from its merger with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation were accumulating faster than expected and helped raise its profit 20 percent, to $240 million.
In California, where the downturn in real estate prices came later than in other parts of the country, the Wells Fargo Corporation of San Francisco announced an unexpected increase in delinquent and other troubled loans. Although Wells earned $82 million, up nearly sixfold from $14 million a year ago, its loan problems led some analysts to reduce their earnings estimates, and caused Well's stock to fall $2.50, to $70.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, the nation's most active acquirer of other banks, reported a 30 percent gain in profits to $181 million. Its record as one of the nation's most profitable banks enabled Banc One to increase its quarterly dividend to 32 cents a share from 29 cents, and lifted its stock price enough to make it easier for it to buy other banks by issuing new shares.
Following are details of the banking companies' results:
 
Citicorp
 Citicorp's second-quarter profit, equal to 32 cents a share, raised the banking company's profit for the first half of the year to $354 million, or 69 cents a share, from $104 million, or 5 cents a share, in last year's first half. Second-quarter profits were reduced by a special charge of $95 million related to various cost-cutting programs.
While Citicorp's profits are on the mend, the banking company still needs a substantial decline in troubled loans to begin earning profits commensurate with its size. Citicorp's earnings, for example, were equal to only 31 cents per $100 of assets, compared with 70 cents at Chemical and $1.52 at Banc One.
"Citicorp is over the worst of its loan problems, but they remain at a very high level," said Thomas Hanley, a banking analyst at First Boston. Still, now that Citicorp has reduced expenses and seems committed to keeping a lid on future increases, Mr. Hanley said, "their earnings can really explode late next year and in 1994," assuming that problems with bad loans subside by then.
In the second quarter, Citicorp wrote off as a loss $705 million of business loans (including $100 million to Olympia & York Developments), and $784 million of consumer loans. Combined, those figures were down slightly from the first quarter. Although Citicorp's biggest problem, losses from commercial real estate loans in North America, rose to $355 million, from $108 million a year ago, Citicorp officials say they expect losses from bad loans to subside in the second half of this year.
Citicorp has continued to gradually increase the size of its reserve for loan losses it expects in the future. That reserve was increased by $181 million in the second quarter, and is now $900 million greater than a year ago. Reserves for losses on loans to less-developed countries continue to be reduced in light of new agreements with main borrowers like Brazil and Argentina.
Other parts of Citicorp's business are faring better. The consumer banking business, which includes credit cards and branch banking, earned $234 million in the second quarter, up 34 percent from a year ago.
The corporate finance business, called global finance at Citicorp, earned $294 million, in contrast to a $10 million loss a year ago.
 
Chemical Banking
 At Chemical Bank, the second-quarter profit equaled 83 cents a share. Per-share profit was reduced because the company sold 57.5 million additional shares earlier this year.
Walter Shipley, president of the company, said that savings this year from the merger of Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover were expected to total $280 million, up from the company's previous estimate of $225 million. The two companies expect to begin closing more that 70 branches in the New York area during October. By 1995 they expect savings from the merger, mostly through the elimination of about 6,200 jobs, to exceed $750 million.
Much of the improvement at Chemical came from the increase in the spread between interest rates it pays depositors and the rates it charges borrowers. That spread was 3.69 percentage points in the second quarter, up from 3.16 percent a year ago.
Chemical's holdings of delinquent loans and or real estate acquired through foreclosure increased $95 million during the quarter to $5.1 billion. The company wrote off $345 million of loans as a loss, and added an equal amount to its reserve against future losses.
 
Wells Fargo
Wells Fargo's earnings of $82 million, or $1.33 a share, were up from $11 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier.
Carl E. Reichart, the chairman, blamed the weak California economy, noting that "loan demand remains weak, and asset quality is slow to recover."
Wells said that its holdings of badly delinquent loans, or loans so troubled that they are not expected to be repaid in full, totaled $2.33 billion, up from $2.068 billion March 31. The company charged off as a loss $184 million of bad loans and provided $300 million to its loan-loss reserve, increasing the reserve by $116 million.
 
Banc One
The Banc One Corporation, whose emphasis on consumer and small business lending enabled it to aovid the worst of the loan problems that have plagued other banks, remains one of the nation's most profitable banks.
First-quarter earnings were equal to 87 cents a share, compared with 70 cents in last year's first quarter. Nonperforming assets, either badly troubled loans or property acquired through foreclosure, fell to $621 million, from $644.5 million on March 31.

HEADLINE: Banks' Rates On Deposits Drop Again

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Banks and savings institutions across the country continued to reduce interest rates on consumer deposits in the last week, though the declines were smaller than earlier in the month.
Even though some bankers have been worried that already-low rates may make it difficult to impose still lower ones on their customers, data compiled by The Bank Rate Monitor show that many banks have for the first time moved below 3 percent for three-month and six-month certificiates of deposit. Rates of less than 3 percent on money market accounts were already common. 
 Bank deposit rates have been falling for more two years and in some cases are half the level they were a year ago. In the Treasury bill market, a benchmark used by banks in setting their rates, new three-month bills sold Monday at an average rate of 3.16 percent, down from 3.22 percent a week earlier and 5.60 percent a year ago.
The most recent round of rate cuts quickly followed the move on July 2 by the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates, and the banks' own move to reduce their prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 6 percent.
In general, each half-point cut in the prime means rates paid on deposits fall by 25- to 33-hundredths of a percentage point. Robert Heady, editor of The Bank Rate Monitor, noted that the cut in rates seems to have occurred more quickly this month, rather than being spread over the usual span of six weeks or so.
In the New York City area, the average rate paid by commercial banks on money market accounts fell to 2.88 percent on July 21 from 2.90 percent a week earlier and 3.09 percent before the latest round of interest rate cuts.

HEADLINE: Europe Caught in Crosscurrents

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 20

 BODY:
Germany's stubborn determination to place its fight against inflation before any concessions to spurring a European economic recovery is causing increasing political tensions across the Continent.
Indeed, a worrying question is now pressing with increasing insistence on Europe's governments: could the high cost of unifying Germany, which is fueling the country's unfamiliar problem with inflation and leading it to impose high interest rates, cause such resentment elsewhere that Europe's drive for unity will stall? 
 The catalyst for the recent sharp falls in stock markets, as well as the weakness of the dollar, was the German Bundesbank's decision Thursday to raise a key interest rate. The central bank's action was its latest attempt to stanch inflationary pressure stemming from the unexpectedly high costs of absorbing the economy of the former East Germany.
But the decision also underscored Europe's fundamental economic paradox: its biggest economy, Germany, is taken up with fending off the specter of high inflation that unification has brought, while other nations like Britain are looking to stimulate their recession-hit economies through cuts in interest rates.
Tension is rising over this split just as Europe is trying to move toward greater economic union through ratification of the Maastricht Treaty, which calls for a single European currency by 1999. The threat, in the view of several economists and political analysts, is that Maastricht and European union could be the victims of the growing rancor that Germany's economic problems are causing.
High interest rates attract investment money, and thus usually strengthen a nation's currency. So the high German rates, which tend to bolster the mark, virtually compel other European countries to raise their rates because the European Monetary System obligates members to maintain their currencies within a narrow exchange-rate band.
The German decision last week has thus convinced many that the stagnation in Europe will continue because the current high cost of money discourages investment and spending. Reckoning that corporate earnings will be hurt by the continued slowdown, a selloff on stock markets began.
The dollar also suffered because United States interest rates are at their lowest levels in 30 years while German rates are at their highest since World War II. Low interest rates in the United States discourage people from buying dollars when they can get a much higher return on their money in Europe.
The popularity of the idea of European unity is being battered by these economic tensions just as France prepares for a crucial referendum on the Maastricht Treaty on Sept. 20.
The problem facing Europe is that Germany, with its particular phobia over inflation stemming from its experiences with hyperinflation earlier in this century, is unlikely to be budged from its present course in the near future.
"We cannot accept that others push us around on interest rates," said George Grosche, a senior official at the German Finance Ministry. "We have a temporary problem right now with our huge transfers to the East, and we have to keep our belts tightened."
An estimated 180 billion marks -- about $121.6 billion -- will be transferred to eastern Germany this year, increasing the German budget deficit and stimulating inflationary pressure.
 
A Hangover From the 20's
 "We don't like inflation," said Klaus Friedrich, the chief economist for Dresdner Bank. "Germans are still somewhat shaped by the hyperinflation of the 1920's."
But as Germany pursues its stubborn course, others are beginning to suggest that the current situation offers a foretaste of a European monetary union, as laid out in the Maastricht Treaty, that is neither desirable nor possible.
If other European economies already feel burdened by the yoke of German policy, the argument goes, how much worse will it be when the envisioned single currency creates an even tighter bond with the Continent's biggest economy?
Already, several leading economists in Britain have suggested in the last week that the country should leave the European Monetary System so that Britain will have the flexibility to cut interest rates by as much as two percentage points to stimulate the economy. Up to now, Prime Minister John Major has firmly resisted such calls.
In France, the current German policy is increasingly being portrayed as the harbinger of what life would be like under the European central bank envisioned by the Maastricht Treaty. The treaty's insistence on low inflation and low budget deficits is being vociferously criticized as little more than a Bundesbank-dictated recipe for further deflation at a time when a slump already exists.
 
Attacking the Treaty
 "The criteria of Maastricht, imposed by the Bundesbank, are contrary to all good sense," a former Socialist minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, wrote in Le Monde last week. "How many million more unemployed people will have to pay for the blindness of European technocrats in the service of financial capital?"
Already, the proportion of opponents of Maastricht in France has surged in recent weeks to 42 percent from 35 percent, according to one survey. A French rejection of Maastricht would kill the treaty and probably create turmoil as markets reassess the future of European integration.
A fear of such a fragmentation appears to many to lurk behind the current nervousness afflicting investors. Optimists believe Europe can keep on track while Germany gets its domestic problems under control. But the camp of the pessimists is growing.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, contained few surprises for the credit markets yesterday, and prices of Treasury securities were little changed.
In his remarks, Mr. Greenspan expressed confidence that the economy was expanding and that a sustainable recovery would be under way soon. This echoed the views he presented to the Senate Banking Committee a year ago, and again in February. 
 By law, the chairman of the Federal Reserve is required to testify before Congress semiannually on the economy and monetary policy. Mr. Greenspan will go before a subcomittee of the House Banking Committee today.
For a day at least, traders interpreted his remarks to mean that the Fed has finished easing monetary policy.
"He didn't say anything unexpected, but on balance it doesn't seem to be good news for the front end" of the maturity spectrum, one government securities trader said. "And in these politically uncertain times, nobody wants to buy bonds."
Meanwhile, some economists said they were disappointed that Mr. Greenspan was not asked how surprisingly bad June economic data fit into his mildly optimistic outlook.
 
Fed Raises Its Forecast
 Reflecting a rosier view, the Fed raised its 1992 growth estimates to a range of 2.25 percent to 2.75 percent, from the 1.75 percent to 2.50 percent range it forecast in February.
But some economists wondered if the weaker June numbers were reflected in the forecast presented yesterday by Mr. Greenspan. Some noted that the Fed met to prepare its forecast before June employment data were released earlier this month.
"I think June represented a rather dramatic event in the development of this recovery, because with the exception of car sales none of the numbers pointed in the direction of recovery, " said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. "Private sector forecasts have been lowered dramatically since those numbers came out."
Joseph Coyne, a Fed spokesman, said Fed governors and bank presidents had the option of revising their forecasts after the June employment data were released. He said he did not know how many had chosen to exercise that option or how it might have affected the forecast.
 
Long Bonds Up Slightly
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 103 31/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.65 percent, unchanged from late Monday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 14/32, up 5/32, to yield 6.86 percent. The 6 3/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 102 17/32, up 3/32, to yield 5.77 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 11/32, down 1/32, to yield 4.26 percent.
The sense that monetary policy is on hold pushed up rates on short-term Treasury bills.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.18 percent, up 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.24 percent.
A number of issues were priced in the investment-grade and tax-exempt municipal bond markets.
 
Utility Sells Notes
 By far the biggest issuer was the Tennessee Valley Authority, which offered a total of $1.25 billion worth of seven-year and 10-year notes at competitive bid. The sale was the largest competitive bid offering ever by an American utility company.
Bids from a group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company won both parts of the offering.
The seven-year securities were reoffered to investors with a 6.25 percent coupon at a price of $98.47 to yield 6.526 percent, 15 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The 10-year notes were reoffered with a 6 7/8 percent coupon at a price of $98.585 to yield 7.075 percent, 19 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
In the asset-backed securities market, FCC National Bank, a subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation, priced $1 billion worth of certificates backed by credit card receivables through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The securities, which have an average expected life of 5.07 years, carry a 6 1/4 percent coupon and were priced to yield 6.353 percent, 55 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
New York Refunding Bonds
 An offering of more than $372 million worth of New York State general-obligation refunding bonds was well received by investors.
Yields on the serial bonds sold range from 3.0 percent in 1993 to 4.90 percent in 1997, 5.75 percent in 2002, 6.05 percent in 2007 and 6.15 percent on bonds maturing from 2010 to 2015.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager for the negotiated sale.
The bonds are rated A by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues were unchanged.
Participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market said prices of most widely quoted securities had risen by an eighth of a point to a quarter of a point.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
McElligott Wright Unravels In Full View of the Industry

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
AN AGENCY founded with much promise less than two years ago is floundering amid conflicts and unusually public squabbling involving its partners.
McElligott Wright Morrison White, a creatively focused shop in Minneapolis with billings estimated at $30 million, is quickly coming apart in the wake of disagreements among its four principals: Tom McElligott, chairman, chief executive and creative director; Tony Wright, president; John Morrison, associate creative director, and Rob White, director of planning. 
 How McElligott Wright fares is being closely watched not only by its employees and clients, but also by the many people in advertising who have followed Mr. McElligott's career since the talented copywriter helped craft memorable campaigns for Porsche and Lee jeans. To them, the agency's fate typifies the promises and the enormous pitfalls inherent in that most courageous and foolish of moves: the entrepreneurial agency start-up.
"We may be seeing the passing of the phenomenon of the agency built around the cult of a personality," Tom Weyl, president and chief creative officer of Martin/Williams Advertising, said in a telephone interview yesterday from Minneapolis, where his agency and McElligott Wright are tenants in the same office building.
"Maybe there's something to be said for the venerable names of Batten, Barton, Durstine and Osborn," he added, referring to the long-ago founders of the giant BBDO agency. "Nobody's seen them for a long time."
The latest development in the implosion of McElligott Wright came yesterday, when Andy Berlin, president of DDB Needham New York, said that Mr. Wright and Mr. Morrison were in discussions to join his agency in Manhattan.
"We're very excited about the possibility of doing something with them," Mr. Berlin added, confirming recent reports in Adweek. "But it is still only a possibility at this point."
Regarding Adweek's speculation that Mr. Morrison and Mr. Wright were seeking to bring clients and employees of McElligott Wright with them, Mr. Berlin said, "They need to determine what is precisely in the best interests of their clients and their careers."
Among the agency's clients are The Washington Post and the Easy Spirit footwear line of the U.S. Shoe Corporation; one client, the Ringer Corporation, a maker of pesticides, has said it will probably put its $5 million account into review.
Candace Medd, The Post's director of circulation marketing, said the newspaper would "provide whichever agency they affiliate with the opportunity to give us a creative capabilities presentation."
Bob Burton, a spokesman for U.S. Shoe in Cincinnati, said, "We have found their work to be good, and we are waiting to see what their longer-term plans are before making any decision."
As for those plans, Mr. White, in a telephone interview, said that negotiations among the partners and Claire Canavan, the agency's former director of finance and administration, were nearly completed.
"We are trying to come to an agreement among all five partners, in an amicable and constructive manner, on how the agency should proceed," he added. "And we're making definite progress."
Mr. White said that "family reasons prevent me from moving to New York," and that he was in discussions with shops like Fallon McElligott, the other agency in Minneapolis that Mr. McElligott helped to co-found.
McElligott Wright's end would write an abrupt and disappointing finish to a tale that began with ambitious expectations in September 1990, when the executives, who had worked at agencies like Fallon McElligott, Chiat/Day/Mojo and Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, opened their own shop.
"By all standards, it's been successful in new business," Mr. Weyl said, though he added that perhaps "the big, quality, choice clients you daydream about didn't come knocking," like American Isuzu Motors or Mercedes-Benz. (Guy Day, who was named vice chairman of McElligott Wright a year ago, as the agency competed with four other finalists to land the Isuzu account, left after the car maker selected Goodby, Berlin.)
Lee Lynch, chairman and chief executive of Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis, said that although the McElligott Wright partners "had worked together, they had never been in business with each other before."
He added, "Partnerships generally show the most stress in the first two years."
Mr. Weyl also cited the current economic climate as "really a tough time" to start an agency, a task that is challenging enough during a flush economy. He said, "When you think of all the success a guy like McElligott has had -- he's won more awards than many large agencies -- it's probably pretty damn hard to do over again."
It was while Mr. McElligott was away from the office last month, serving as a judge at the International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes, that he was the subject of what he called a "palace coup." The next three weeks brought charges and countercharges that confused and dismayed industry executives.
"I hate to see something unravel like that in public," said Patrick R. Fallon, chairman of Fallon McElligott, who co-founded that agency with Mr. McElligott and a third partner, Nancy Rice, in 1981. "It's not good for the business."

HEADLINE: Pepsico Profit Climbs 20.4%

 BODY:
Led by a strong performance at a revitalized Frito-Lay, Pepsico Inc.'s second-quarter profits jumped 20.4 percent, the company said yesterday. The beverage and restaurant businesses also had solid gains.
Profit for the quarter was $383 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with $318.3 million, or 39 cents a share, for the corresponding quarter last year. Sale rose 11.6 percent, to $5.21 billion, compared with $4.68 billion. 
 Operating profits for snack foods jumped 23 percent, and the beverage and restaurant operations each had profit gains of 15 percent.
Earnings were at the high end of analysts' expectations, and Pepsico's share price gained $1.125 to close at $36.75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
"The key to the quarter was Frito-Lay," said Martin Romm, an analyst at First Boston. "The momentum is back at Pepsi."
Analysts said Pepsi should return to its traditional 20 percent annual profit growth this year after an off year in 1991.
In a weak economy, the snack-food unit's shipments in the United States increased by 7 percent. Domestic beverage sales grew 11 percent, although the company said June volume fell below last year's levels.
Profits jumped 50 percent at Kentucky Fried Chicken. The gain was attributed to cost-cutting in the United States and improved volume.
Pizza Hut did not fare as well, with operating profits inching up 2 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Capital Cities Net Up 15.4% In Quarter

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Capital Cities/ABC Inc., the giant broadcasting and publishing company, said yesterday that its net income for the second quarter rose 15.4 percent, to $147.5 million, or $8.84 a share, compared with $127.8 million, or $7.60 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.
Revenues for the quarter increased 2.2 percent, to $1.39 billion, from $1.36 billion in the corresponding quarter of 1991. 
 Capital Cities said a number of one-time factors had affected earnings. The results for the latest quarter included a gain on the sale of the company's interests in Tele-5, a German television network. That was partly offset by losses for the disposal of real estate in New York City and the write-down of certain other nonoperating assets. The net result of these items was a pretax gain of $24.9 million. Without this gain, quarterly earnings per share would have been $8.16.
 
'A Difficult Environment'
 David Londoner, who follows the company for Wertheim & Company, said: "It is not a bad performance considering what a difficult environment it is. The stock is down slightly." The shares lost $5 each yesterday to close at $441 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Londoner added: "I think people are focusing on relatively flat unit prices to marginally up for advertising in the upfront season. There had been some expectation that prices would be up 2 percent to 3 percent." The up-front season is the period of advance sales of advertising for the coming fall television season.
The broadcasting operations continued to suffer from the recessionary environment, the company said.
Total operating income was $268.8 million, a gain of 8 percent from the 1991 period, with broadcasting increasing 3 percent. Earnings for the ABC television network showed a modest increase, largely because the comparable quarter last year had included a charge for staff reductions.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sears Posts 15.5% Gain In Earnings

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company yesterday reported a robust 15.5 percent increase in earnings in the second quarter, despite a 50 percent plunge in income from its retail operations.
Overall earnings climbed to $345.8 million, or 90 cents a share, from $299.4 million, or 87 cents a share, during the comparable quarter last year. Total sales rose slightly to $14.27 billion from $14.09 billion. 
 But the company's retail business has failed to regain its footing, in spite of strenuous cost-cutting efforts that have eliminated about 45,000 jobs and are expected to save $840 million this year and $940 million in 1993.
The company said earnings in the merchandising group were $78.5 million, compared with $156.9 million a year earlier. Sales for the group continued to slip, dropping 1.1 percent in the second quarter to $7.57 billion from $7.65 billion during the similar period last year.
"What is surprising about the merchandise group is that despite massive adjustments to its cost structure, and to its pricing structure, they appear to be losing market share and profitability as fast as ever," said Edward A. Weller, an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.
 
Insurance Unit Does Well
 Sears's Allstate Insurance group cushioned the impact of declining retail sales and earnings. Its earnings jumped 68.3 percent, to $235.3 million, from $139.8 million in the second quarter of last year, thanks to increased income from its property and casualty underwriting and growth in investment income.
While Sears's second-quarter performance was fairly close to analysts' estimates, many of them were surprised by the steep decline in retail income. They said the performance of Sears stores and catalogues must improve to give the company's stock a jolt.
Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman and chief executive, attributed the merchandise group's problems to the weak economy and increased competition that whittled away at profit margins. He also noted that the company had planned for a decrease in revenues from its catalogue. It spent $20.2 million to close counters in its stores where customers could pick up catalogue merchandise.
N. Richard Nelson Jr., an analyst at Duff & Phelps in Chicago, said he was keeping his estimate of Sears's 1992 earnings at $4.25 a share. "But my estimate might prove to be too high unless things get better in the merchandising group," he said.
Mr. Nelson and other analysts expect Sears's retail business to improve during the second half of this year, partly because its earnings last year during that period were so depressed.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Lower After Greenspan Comments

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, gave no indication that the Fed planned further moves to support the United States currency.
Gold fell to $357.60 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, down $1.50 from Monday's close. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $357.50, off $1.20 from Monday. 
 The dollar rose in cautious European dealings yesterday after the Fed and other central banks intervened on Monday to help support the sagging currency. The dollar even bounced a bit as Mr. Greenspan told a Congressional committee that a weak dollar would not help with the coming recovery from the recession.
Analysts said the market did not get the reassurance it wanted from Mr. Greenspan that the Fed would support the dollar.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony "didn't have a big impact on the market, actually," said Arnold Sherrer, chief trader for the Royal Bank of Canada in New York.
Analysts noted that the Fed and other central banks did not return to the market yesterday. Traders interpreted their absence as a sign that the dollar could be nudged lower.
By the close in New York, the dollar fell to 1.4870 against the German mark, down from 1.4935 at Monday's close. Earlier in Europe, the dollar rose to 1.4880 marks, up from 1.4825 late Monday.
The dollar closed in New York at 125.25 Japanese yen, down from 125.45 yen Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 125.12 yen, up 0.51 yen. In London, the dollar was quoted at a higher rate of 125.30 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.9095 in New York, up from Monday's $1.9065. In London, the pound fell to $1.9105 from $1.9183.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.3235 Swiss francs, up from 1.3230; 1,130.00 Italian lire, down from 1,135.00; 5.0245 French francs, down from 5.0500, and 1.19185 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19075.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.3235 Swiss francs, up from 1.3135; 5.0255 French francs, up from 5.0020; 1.6780 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6670; 1,130.50 Italian lire, up from 1,126.50, and 1.1925 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1890.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $357.85 a troy ounce, from $358.25 late Monday. In Zurich, it was unchanged at $357.90. In Hong Kong, gold fell $1.39 to close at $357.91.

HEADLINE: GTE Earnings Up by 13.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., July 21

 BODY:
The GTE Corporation today reported a 13.2 percent jump in second-quarter earnings on continued growth in its telephone operations and cellular-mobile phone businesses.
Income from continuing operations rose to a record $446 million, or 49 cents a share, compared with $394 million, or 44 cents a share, in the second quarter last year. Earnings per share rose 11 percent. 
 "GTE continues to perform very well despite a soft economy," said Charles R. Lee, GTE chairman. "The long-term strategic-positioning steps taken by GTE over the past several years are generating positive results, while at the same time improving our competitive position."
Consolidated revenues and sales rose 4 percent, to $5.06 billion in the quarter, compared with $4.85 billion in the second quarter last year.
For the first half of 1992, income was $873 million, or 96 cents a share, compared with $591 million, or 65 cents a share, in the first six months of last year.
The 1991 results included a one-time net charge of $204 million, or 23 cents a share, in connection with GTE's merger with Contel and gain on transfer of certain cellular properties. Excluding the one-time charge from last year's results, earnings per share from continuing operations for the first half of 1992 increased 9 percent over 1991.
Consolidated revenues and sales from continuing operations were $9.89 billion for the first half of the year, compared with $9.54 billion for the first half of 1991.

HEADLINE: Root Beer: A Flood Of Memories, A Sip of Foam

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
GIVEN root-beer drinkers' fierce attachment to their beverage, it's the unwise brew master who dares to tamper with a recipe.
But fortunately, some slight adjustments have been made to accommodate modern palates. 
 "In the early days of root beer, some unscrupulous manufacturers would add soap to the formula to give it a bigger head," said Jesse Meyers, the publisher of Beverage Digest, a newsletter that reports on the doings of soft-drink makers. (When the giant soap maker, the Procter & Gamble Company, acquired Hires root beer in 1980, Mr. Meyers's report on the transaction carried the headline "Another Tide Outlet.")
Absent the soap, old-time root beer is enjoying a bit of a comeback these days. While the $48 billion soft-drink business is dominated by two corporate behemoths, the Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico Inc., root beer has been left largely to the province of a handful of smaller companies.
In much the same way that micro-breweries have sprung up in the shadows of assembly-line-produced beer, small root-beer makers, like Triple XXX in Houston and Cable Car Beverage Corporation in Denver, have sprung up between the cracks of the cola giants. And while the big cola companies, with their seemingly bottomless advertising budgets, have battled on the grounds of catchier sayings and sunnier life styles, root-beer companies seem united in their intent to sell their beverage as a nostalgic reminder of simpler times and summers past. Some root beers now come in old-fashioned brown bottles, with slogans like "Tastes like root beer used to taste" or "Taste the legend."
"It's an icon of a naive and innocent time," said Jane Stern, who, with her husband, Michael, chronicles the eating habits of Americans. "It's from a charming time."
Root beer is the only soft drink that people still brew at home, she said, adding that some Amish families make and sell their own root beer from roadside stands. "You don't see anybody advertising homemade colas or homemade 7 Up," she said.
Hires, a division of Cadbury Schweppes, of London, which acquired the company from Procter & Gamble in 1989, contends it is the oldest "continuously marketed" soft drink in the United States. According to the public relations archives at Hires in Stamford, Conn., the drink made its debut in 1876, when Charles E. Hires, a Philadelphia pharmacist, showed off his drink at the same Philadelphia Centennial Exhibition that displayed Alexander Graham Bell's telephone, the typewriter and H. J. Heinz's ketchup.
Root beer originally was brewed from a combination of 16 different wild roots and berries, including juniper, wintergreen and pipsissewa. Nowadays, most root beer is made in laboratories by flavor technicians, using extracts of roots, bark and berries.
A sip of it often evokes a flood of reminiscences.
"It's an elixir of fond memories," said Kim Feil, the product director of Hires. She said that people are often at a loss to describe the taste of root beer, but when they are asked what it reminds them of, she said: "Out tumble very personal memories. It's sort of like a serum."
Last year, Olga Whaley, from Middleburgh Heights, Ohio, received a brown bottle of Stewart's Original root beer from her son for her 75th birthday. She said that, after taking a sip, "I closed my eyes, and it was just like I was a kid again at Euclid Beach," an amusement park in Cleveland, where she grew up. Root beer was served on tap for a nickel a glass at the amusement park, she said. Once or twice a summer, her father, who worked in a quarry for a brick factory, took her and her four siblings to the park for root beer. "We saved our nickels," she said. "Those big foamy glasses of root beer -- that was the biggest treat we ever got."
Lee Lydick, the president of the Triple XXX root-beer company, said: "The nostalgia appeal of root beer is very strong. It is one of the key marketing elements."
Drinks like Stewart's Original, made by Cable Car Beverage Corporation, have found a ready audience. Based on the growing popularity of its root beer, Cable Car Beverage is one of the fastest-growing small publicly traded companies in the country. In 1989, Cable Car Beverage licensed the name and recipe from Stewart's Restaurants, a 68-year-old chain of drive-in stands, based in New Jersey.
The popularity of old-fashioned root beers has not escaped the few big companies that make and sell root beer. Hires recently introduced an old-fashioned long-neck bottle, using the same root beer it uses in its cans. After less than a year on the market, Hires' long necks account for nearly a third of the company's sales in some cities.
While large corporations often copy ideas that have been made successful by smaller, nimbler concerns, some bottlers rue the trend toward packaging root beer the old-fashioned way. It takes longer and costs more to fill a bottle instead of a can. Also, although some people find a bottle pleasing to sip from, bottles are much harder to ship and stack than a pallet of cans.
That makes Steve Sourapas, a Hires bottler from Seattle, not very enthusiastic about new old-fashioned bottles. "It's not a high-volume package," he said. "After a while, the economics get to you."
Such sentiments are a delight to Samuel Simpson, the president of Cable Car Beverage. "It's very difficult for the big guys to get root beer in the brown bottle," he said.
The nation's largest root-beer maker, A & W Brands Inc. of White Plains, tried and decided it was not worth the trouble. M. L. Lowenkron, who as the chairman of A & W is qualified to refer to himself as a root-beer maven, called the old-fashioned bottles "a clever marketing approach." A & W accounts for about a third of all the root beer sold in the country, Mr. Lowenkron said. Over all, he said, old-fashioned-style root beers make up an insignificant portion of the root-beer market.
And not all of the quaintly bottled concoctions are made in backyard breweries. I.B.C., which comes in bottles that look as if they were culled from antique stores, is made by a division of the Dr Pepper / Seven-Up Companies of Dallas.
Putting root beer in brown bottles dates back to Prohibition, when many brewers converted their idle plants to root-beer factories, using their inventories of brown beer bottles.
Pepsi has its toe in the root-beer waters with its Mug Old-Fashioned brand. Coke has all but ignored the market; its Ramblin' brand is sold in only a handful of cities.
People in the middle of the country drink far more root beer than people in the rest it, market researchers for Hires said. Pittsburgh is the root-beer-guzzling capital of the world, said Mr. Lowenkron, adding that he did not know why.
But colas still dominate the nation's taste, accounting for nearly 70 percent of all soft drinks consumed, according to figures compiled by John C. Maxwell Jr., a stock analyst with Wheat First Securities in Richmond. Lemon-lime drinks and drinks like Dr Pepper are next in popularity, with root beer beating out orange for fourth place.
Even though root-beer consumption is growing slowly and steadily, people these days often seem more interested in clear, sparkling fruity drinks.
Frank Armstrong, the chairman of the Monarch Company in Atlanta, which makes Dad's Root Beer, thinks he knows why. "It's not a yuppie drink," he said.


GRAPHIC: Eleven brands of root beer were tasted blind by Bryan Miller and Florence Fabricant. No diet root beers were included. In general, the tasters were looking for the satisfyingly rich, earthy, slightly resinous quality associated with old-fashioned root beer. Most were too sweet. HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
A RESTAURANT with a couple thousand bottles of wine in its cellar is a serious restaurant. One with 20,000 or 30,000 is in the big leagues, oenologically speaking.
What does that make a place with about eight million bottles? It makes it Air France. 
 From the lordly Concorde en route to New York to a 747 over the Himalayas to a 737 on a quick hop to Geneva, wine is as much a part of Air France service as the fuel that gets the planes aloft. The airline is one of the largest purchasers of French wines. And only French wines; Napa Valley is not spoken here.
All airlines carry wine these days and most of what they serve, particularly in business and first classes, is good. But some of the stuff doled out in the back of the bus can be awful. The Air France list, however, really has no clunkers.
Of course, even with Air France, if you're shoehorned into economy and trying not to spill your pocket-size wine bottle into your blanquette de veau, you might debate that value. But that's the fun of flying.
Actually, eight million is pushing it a bit. Most of the bottles are quarter-bottles, sometimes called splits. They hold 18.75 centiliters, a fourth of what's in a standard 75-centiliter bottle. This year, Air France is buying 6.2 million of these splits.
The most popular wine with Air France passengers? Champagne. The airline is buying 360,000 full bottles and 1.7 million quarter bottles of Champagne this year.
About 135,000 bottles of premium reds and whites are stocked for first class and Concorde passengers; Le Club -- business class -- passengers are served 25-centiliter bottles, of which the airline buys about one million a year. And then there are 4.5 million of those little quarter bottles of red and white wines, all of them destined for economy passengers.
What you drink very much depends on where you sit. If you're on the Concorde or in first class elsewhere, you will be offered one or more of five different Champagnes: Dom Perignon 1985, Cuvee Louise Pommery 1987, Laurent-Perrier Cuvee Grand Siecle 1985, Krug Grande Cuvee and Mumm de Cramant. (These and other wines are sometimes subject to change, depending on availability.)
When it comes to Champagne, the Concorde is a glorious exercise in wretched -- but Gallic -- excess. Concorde-class passengers arriving at Charles de Gaulle Airport here for the regular 11 A.M. dash to New York are greeted by a sumptuous breakfast buffet, with red and white wine, Bloody Marys and two or three varieties of Champagne to wash it down.
On board, the Champagne resumes, now competing with iced vodka -- to go with the caviar, naturally.
There is no fooling around on the Concorde: no "discoveries," no wines from trendy new regions, none from unpronounceable grapes. Air France appears to believe that folks paying $1,000 an hour for the ride want to deal only with proved successes -- like themselves, presumably.
Among the four white Burgundies served on the Concorde are Chassagne-Montrachet premier cru "Les Vergers" 1989, and Chablis grand cru "Les Clos" 1990. Among the four red Burgundies: Corton grand cru 1986 and Echezeaux grand cru 1985. Red Bordeaux -- there are six -- include Chateau Grand-Puy-Ducasse 1982, Chateau Lascombes 1985 and Chateau Cantenac-Brown 1988. There are two Sauternes: Chateau Rieussec 1981 and 1982. Air France will buy 19,200 bottles of these quality wines this year just for its Concorde clients.
Not all wines are carried on every flight, and it's probably a good thing. The point of taking the Concorde from here to New York -- it lands at 8:45 A.M. -- is to get there in time for a full day's work. One shudders to think of a solid French businessman arriving at breakfast time, already befuddled by Corton-Charlemagne.
Passengers in first and business class on other Air France flights will be welcomed with one of half a dozen Champagnes, including Pol Roger Brut and Pommery Brut rose. First-class clients, like those on the Concorde, are exposed only to Burgundy and Bordeaux, but wines with a little less breed, perhaps, and an occasional minor vintage. For example, there is a Chablis premier cru "Vaillon" 1989 among the white Burgundies, but there are also a Puligny-Montrachet 1989 and a Meursault "Clos du Cromin" 1989.
The clarets illustrate this same thinking: Cantenac-Brown 1988 and Chateau Batailley 1986, and Lynch-Bages 1987, a lesser year. Air France is buying 115,000 bottles of these wines this year. Le Club's white Burgundy is actually from Macon, and its two reds from Morgon, in Beaujolais, and Mercurey from the Cote Chalonnais. The clarets are young and less well known. Among them: Chateaux Belgrave 1990 and Tour du Moulin 1986.
With Le Club the airline's buyers ventured afield, picking up a riesling from Alsace and reds from the southwest, a Cahors and a Bergerac.
There are around 14 different wines for economy passengers with, usually, two reds, two whites and a Champagne to choose among on any flight. The Champagne, in a screw-top quarter bottle, can be Pommery Brut Royale, Charles Heidsieck Brut Reserve or Veuve Clicquot Brut. The whites could be a Macon Villages and a simple Bordeaux blanc; the reds a Duboeuf Morgon from Beaujolais and a light Bordeaux rouge like a Chateau Beau-Mayne 1988. Wines from Cahors, Bergerac, Alsace and the Var may also appear.
With their wines, Air France passengers each year eat more than 20 tons of caviar, 20 tons of foie gras, 55 tons of smoked salmon, 100 tons of fresh salmon, 250 tons of butter and 130 tons of cheese. And these items just for the kitchens at DeGaulle and Orly, the two main Paris airports.
There is of course, no accounting for taste. For dieters, teetotalers and of course for gourmands who have partaken of a bit too much, there is mineral water -- Vittel, Volvic, Evian, Perrier and others.
Any old airline can serve good wine. Who but the French, though, would boast of serving 1.5 million gallons of bottled water every year?
 
TASTINGS
Rully 1989, Louis Jadot, Burgundy; about $15.
There are three well-known appellations in the Cotes Chalonnaise, a wine region at the southern end of the more famous Cote d'Or, the source of Burgundy's best wines. The three are Rully, Mercurey and Givry. The best known of the three is Mercurey, and indeed its wines are the best. For a long time, Rully was allowed to sell its red wines as Mercurey. When the Government stopped that, the growers turned to making sparkling Burgundy. After the passing of the vogue for sparkling Burgundy, most of it sweet, the growers concentrated on white wines. There are some good red Rullys around, however, and this is one of them. It's lighter than a Cote d'Or wine, of course, but it can hold its own with all but a few of the best Mercureys. The wine has body and true Burgundy flavor and the color is excellent. Good Burgundy at a good price is always a rare find. Not much of this wine is made; if you see it, don't pass it up.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Travel Books That Nourish a Vision

BYLINE: HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
It is generally more rewarding to read about someone else's travels than to hear about them (especially when there's a slide show). Vita Sackville-West had it right: "There is no greater bore than the travel bore. We do not in the least want to hear what he has seen in Hong Kong." But even seasoned travelers carry visions in their mental luggage: romantic encounters, unspoiled locales, recaptured youths, imagined historic times, and a good book can nourish the pursuit of those visions.
Here is a decidedly mixed handful of readable books that take the reader not only across but above the United States, as well as to the towns of Europe and the islands of Oceania. 
 AMERICAN PLACES: A Writer's Pilgrimage to 15 of This Country's Most Visited and Cherished Sites, by William Zinsser. (200 pages, HarperCollins. $20.) This inspiring guide includes places everyone means to go to some day, all described with the usual clarity of the author of "On Writing Well." A reader ticks off the well-known destinations: Mount Rushmore, Lexington and Concord, Niagara Falls, Yellowstone Park, the Alamo, Appomattox, Mount Vernon, Kitty Hawk, Disneyland, Rockefeller Center, Pearl Harbor. Then some unusual places: Mark Twain's Hannibal, Mo.; the Civil Rights Memorial in Montgomery, Ala.; Dwight D. Eisenhower's hometown, Abilene, Kan.; the lecture and adult educational center in Chautauqua, N.Y.
Mr. Zinsser personalizes each place, giving its history and adding his own keen observations. In Montgomery, he interviews Maya Lin, who designed both the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington and the Civil Rights Memorial; their conversation turns to the people who were killed during the civil rights movement. After speaking to park rangers, librarians and curators, Mr. Zinsser says, "The eloquence of the so-called ordinary man or woman is the most extraordinary resource waiting for any writer who goes looking for America."
THE CANNIBAL QUEEN: An Aerial Odyssey Across America, by Stephen Coonts. (Illustrated. 344 pages. Pocket Books. $22.) The novelist describes a flight with his 14-year-old son in a 1942 open-cockpit biplane across the United States. The plane, named "Cannibal Queen," was built as a trainer for the Royal Canadian Air Force, declared surplus, used for crop dusting, then bought by the author. He discovers that you can fly an airworthy plane anywhere in the country without a flight plan or anyone's permission.
From the perspective of his biplane looking down on Mount Rushmore, Mr. Coonts decides that his candidates for additional faces carved on the cliff are Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., "the two greatest Americans of this century."
AMERICA EATS, by Nelson Algren. (Illustrated. 123 pages. University of Iowa Press. $22.95) Anything by Nelson Algren deserves notice. This book, a rarity, was written in the late 1930's when the novelist worked with such writers as Saul Bellow and Richard Wright for the Illinois Writers Project, a branch of the New Deal Works Progress Administration. While researching the book, Algren traveled around the Midwest, wrote about what farmers were growing, cooks cooking, restaurants serving. It's a portrait of ethnic America, with recipes for Russian pancakes, Spanish eggplant, English scones, Hungarian goulash, Flemish booya ("30 pounds of ox tails, 10 pounds beef soup bones, 4 fat hens") and other hearty, cholesterol-packed eats.
Like his prose poem, "Chicago: City on the Make," this gustatory travel junket is pure Algren: "These are the blue plate specials, the streamlined steaks and the laborer's lunch pail, passed down an endless boarding-house table from a brave in buckskin to a blue-turbaned voyageur, from a coonskin Yankee to a drawling steamboatman, from a Negro fish-vendor to an Irish section hand."
ASTONISHING WORLD: Essays, by Barbara Grizzuti Harrison. (285 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $22.95.) This collection of essays includes sojourns in Tuscany, Sicily, Dubrovnik in Yugoslavia and Morocco, not to mention lively interviews with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in Albany and Gore Vidal in Rome. Ms. Harrison, who never forgets that her roots are in the old Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn, is unafraid to allow her emotions to show through her observations.
"Shopping in Morocco has become for me a transaction almost as personal as sex," she writes. "The Astonishing World" continues the autobiographical style of her keen "Italian Days" and "The Islands of Italy."
THE HAPPY ISLES OF OCEANIA: Paddling the Pacific, by Paul Theroux. (528 pages. Putnam. $24.95.) The novelist and travel writer goes from Australia and New Zealand to Hawaii by way of Melanesia (the Solomon islands, Vanuatu, Fiji) and Polynesia (Tonga, Samoa, Tahiti, the Cook Islands, Easter Island). Because of an unexplained domestic crisis and a possible illness, he decides to get away from it all. So he packs a collapsible kayak, paddles around the islands, camps on an aboriginal reserve, hikes mountain trails and encounters natives and tourists in civilized Oceania.
He can be the toughest of travel writers: "When France has succeeded in destroying a few more atolls, when they have managed to make the islands glow with so much radioactivity that night is turned into day, when they have sold the rest of the fishing rights and depleted it of fish (already Tahiti and the surrounding islands have been overfished), when it has all been thoroughly plundered, the French will plan a great ceremony and grandly offer these unemployed and deracinated citizens in T-shirts and flip-flops their independence."
Mr. Theroux's sharp eye and tongue make his "Happy Isles of Oceania" a strong if not always cheerful reading adventure.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Helping Guests With the Answers

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Pop sociology rides again. Barbara Walters is in the saddle tonight, whipping along eight attractive young men and women who have been selected to personify the 40 million or so Americans who were born in the 1970's.
Ms. Walters concedes at the start of "Twentysomething: What Happened to the American Dream?" that eight people can't speak for all those now in their 20's, but she adds that they can tell of "growing up, romance, sex, their hopes and fears and what the American dream means to them." All right. But she or her producers are evidently unwilling to settle for human interest; they want human interest with a social-science face. Despite her disavowal, Ms. Walters indulges in generational generalizing: "This is a generation that pursues the quality of life. They want time for family, friends, themselves. They want to enjoy life on their own terms." Unlike all other generations? 
 The show works this way: Ms. Walters tosses out a statistical snippet, and a guest confirms it. By age 20, the typical American has spent 23,000 hours in front of a television set; a woman admits cheerfully to being a television addict and there she is at home watching the tube. Recent graduates have been particularly hard hit by the recession; meet a woman who is looking for a job. Millions of women in their 20's are on welfare; see the unmarried mother caring for her baby.
So it goes. Ms. Walters spurs her guests with leading questions: "Don't you think you are kind of serious as a group?" And perhaps flattered or awed at being in the presence of so famous a personality or just courteous or trying to perform as expected on national television, someone always comes through: "I think we're terribly serious for 20." Noting that divorce became more common in the 1970's and 80's, Ms. Walters prods, "It may make you more afraid when you grow up in a family where you see divorce." "Right." Ms. Walters informs them, "You are pretty turned off with politicians." "Absolutely."
Disappointments keep popping up. Several of the young people, responding to hints from their hostess, ooze envy at past generations. For example, the fear of AIDS has taken some of the kick out of the famous sexual revolution. (That invites a discussion about the use of condoms, a sure-fire talk-show subject.) And there are references to lowered economic expectations.
Ms. Walters calls the twentysomething set, somewhat unoriginally, a lost generation. And the group is encouraged to advertise its moral superiority over what she dismisses as the me decade. She announces that this generation is more interested in "personal and fulfilling rewards" than in big salaries and big jobs, and, believe it or not, nobody proudly declares they are out mainly for the buck. A man who makes television commercials clucks that in the 80's "money became the end instead of the means to the end."
The only safe generalizations from this exercise are that most groups are inclined to feel put upon and if given an opportunity will let the world in on their discontents. The one married man present tells of the burden of paying back big school loans and meeting all the other bills of a growing family. A black bank executive says he has to work harder than whites to win respect. The welfare mother tells of the difficulties of working her way off welfare.
Any of these conditions might make for an illuminating hour. But Ms. Walters, like a schoolteacher determined to obtain the answers set down in her curriculum guide, elicits uplifting cliches. She asks what her sample would most like viewers to know about their generation. An A to the man who answers: "We are responsible and we are willing to take the torch."
Given the amount of television these people admit to having watched, they ought by now to be wary of shows that pander to the latest consuming generation. "Twentysomething" is upscale Oprah. Categorizing eight men and women, if it is to be at all enlightening, takes a more sophisticated touch than is applied tonight. So it would be unfair, as you might be inclined to do at moments in this exasperating hour, to write 40 million people off as the kvetch generation.

ABC, tonight.
