HEADLINE: Snack Hierarchy: Small Is Good, Tiny Is Better

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
AMERICANS are getting bigger and heavier, the Government says, but you would never know it from what they eat: food is getting smaller and smaller.
Every aisle of the supermarket now holds miniature versions of familiar brands: shrunken Oreos, tiny Dove Bars, and Ritz crackers the size of a thumbnail. 
 There are plenty of reasons to eat itty-bitty foods. They're cute, like puppies and kittens. And a little version of anything familiar creates warm feelings. Small is neater, too. When everything disappears in one bite, there are no crumbs.
More important, delusions are easier to sustain with tiny foods. For adults who try to control what they eat, smaller foods feed the fantasy that they're eating less. For children, it may be easier to persuade parents to buy a package of tiny cookies.
Some of the charm of the small is novelty. Go to any extreme, and attention follows. That's why some food marketers and restaurateurs are taking the opposite approach: selling gigantic muffins or serving restaurant portions so big that doggie bags are mandatory.
But for the moment, miniaturization seems more prevalent than gigantism. Smaller-than-usual foods are among the fastest-growing items in the supermarket.
"Everyone is looking at their portfolios and thinking, 'What can we shrink next?' " said Tony Adams, vice president of market research at the Campbell Soup Company. "It's sort of hard to shrink soup," he conceded, but that hasn't stopped the company from trying. "We are shrinking some of the ingredients," he said, mentioning little noodles shaped like dinosaurs and teddy bears.
One reason for the trend stands out: companies like Campbell are trying to make food more fun. "This is a countervailing balance to the seriousness about food," Mr. Adams said. "Miniaturization reminds us that food is there to enjoy."
Researchers who talk to people about their feelings about life say respondents report a general loss of pleasure. The Trends Journal, published by the Socioeconomic Research Institute, a future forecasting company in Rhinebeck, N.Y., suggests that stress levels are higher than they have been since the late 1940's. Americans, the journal says, are "anxious and tense and losing their sense of humor."
Blame the recession, maybe, but also blame the grim attitude people have acquired toward food. Food has always been an important source of pleasure, but now it is increasingly a source of worry. More often, it is regarded as medicine, and medicine is not fun.
For adults, small foods can produce pleasure by leading to a greater sense of freedom: you can seem to eat more, but with less guilt, because you're not really eating more. (In calories and weight, eight mini Oreos equal two regular Oreos.)
Millions of Americans struggle with weight. The mean weight of men grew by six pounds between 1960 and 1980, and their mean height increased by almost an inch; the mean weight of women grew by four pounds in that time and the mean height by half an inch, according to the National Center for Health Statistics, which is determining whether weights and heights changed in the last decade.
It's hard, fortunately, to keep count. "You think you're eating less, but you're probably eating more," said Frances Colorio, a receptionist at an advertising agency in New York who buys Ritz Bits every few weeks.
Children and teen-agers like small foods for different reasons. Vera Barkas, a 13-year-old who was shopping for groceries last week at a supermarket on the Upper West Side with her mother and brother, said she liked the cheese-filled Ritz Bits.
"You can get a whole bunch, and you don't have to keep reaching in the box," she said. "It's fun to pack them in your mouth." When really hungry, she figures she can fit five in her mouth at one time.
She also likes the tiny Oreos because she can pop them right into her mouth. That's not possible with the standard Oreo. "It takes too much time to eat the big ones," she said, because she feels compelled to take them apart and scrape off the white filling with her tongue. With the little ones, that onerous task is unnecessary.
People are starting to eat cookies and crackers the way they eat chips. In the industry, the lingo is "hand to mouth." That's very different from the way cookies used to be eaten: at the table, as a dessert. Carefully. Slowly. Not in a stream.
"Minis are very snackable; you just put them in your mouth, one after another, like chips," said Barbara S. Thomas, the senior vice president of marketing for the Nabisco Biscuit Company, which has shrunk 10 of its brands in the last five years, including Ritz, Oreo, Chips Ahoy! and Lifesavers.
Small foods suit an ever-more-rigorous definition of convenience. "People are eating on the run," said Stuart Greenblatt, a spokesman for the Keebler Company. "They want things that are easy to consume." In the last year, Keebler has introduced small versions of some of its better-known products, like Rainbow Chips Deluxe and Pecan Sandies.
Among the fastest-growing foods in the supermarket, according to Nielsen Marketing Research in Northbrook, Ill., are four new mini products: Bagel Bites, Milky Way Miniatures, Mini Chips Ahoy! and Snickers Miniatures. But miniaturization is not without its hazards, and success can be fleeting. Some mini products that have been around for a while are losing sales, and others have been taken off the market: Nabisco Honey Maid Graham Bites and Nabisco Triscuit Bits lasted less than two years.
Impulse, of course, plays a part in buying snacks. Monica Desai, 3, sat in her mother's shopping cart recently, explaining why she likes Mini Chips Ahoy! but not regular Chips Ahoy! "I like these because they have these nice little cookies," she said.
But then she noticed a bag of fudge-covered Oreos and insisted on having them. To her, the color of the fudge on the package looked pink, and she likes pink.
Shoppers didn't always have vast choices in food size. Candy bars were available in only one size until the late 1950's, said Hans Fiuczynski, a spokesman for M & M/Mars. "They were like the Model T: you could have it in any size you wanted as long as it was the standard size," he said. Then, in the late 1950's, Mars introduced its "fun" size bar, which took two bites to eat. In the last year, it has introduced one-bite miniatures.
Maybe the most extreme miniaturization is the Lifesaver Hole. "There's a play value to the product," said Bruce Wood, president of the Planter's and Lifesavers divisions of Nabisco, which introduced the Holes last year. "People eat them in little bunches."
Indeed, it would be easy to have a feast of mini food, to obtain real-life versions of the tiny plastic foods set out in dollhouses. Some are old, like the miniature bottles of liquor served on airplanes; some are new, like snack-sized yogurt; some are processed, like doughnuts, coffeecakes and Shredded Wheat, and some are natural, like finger-size bananas and baby vegetables.
The little foods, not surprisingly, can be seen as part of larger shifts in society. Peter Landry, shopping for food last week on the Upper West Side, said he found the little foods "kind of silly." They simply try to give the illusion that there is more, when there isn't, he said.
"It's almost political," he said. "We've been through an era of excess. Now it's the reverse: if it's smaller, it must be more hip, it must be better."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Yugoslavia May Snub Invitation To the Games

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain, July 21

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council informed the Spanish Government tonight that athletes from Yugoslavia would be welcome to compete in the Barcelona Olympics in individual events without national identification, but not in team sports.
But Yugoslav Olympic officials suggested they might withdraw from the Games rather than comply. 
 The decision was made to allow Spain to comply with sanctions, which prevent members of the United Nations from allowing athletes who represent Yugoslavia to participate in international sports events. The United Nations has identified Yugoslavia as the aggressor in the current civil war.
In the ruling, from the sanctions committee of the Security Council in New York, individual athletes can compete in the Games, provided they do not participate as a group, gather for any group appearances or march in any ceremonies with the Yugoslav flag or anthem.
Any violation of those terms, said Matthew Nerzig, a United Nations spokesman, would become "grounds for expulsion of the athletes from the Games."
It was not immediately clear, however, whether those conditions would satisfy the Yugoslavia Olympic Committee, whose secretary general tonight left open the possibility that Yugoslavia, now just the two republics of Serbia and Montenegro, would send no athletes, rather than a fractured team. The prohibition of team competitions would eliminate more than half the 118 athletes Yugoslavia was prepared to send.
"We will study this matter tomorrow, and our president will make a decision," Caslav Veljic, the secretary general, said from Belgrade. "It is my opinion, that we say, 'Thank you very much for the invitation, but rather than be present with no name, no country, no flag, we will not come.' If everybody is against Yugoslavia, we can live without them. Goodbye. It is very stupid to ask that we divide our team."
Meanwhile, one of the two members of the International Olympic Committee from Yugoslavia, Slobodan Filipovic, said tonight that he would ask the I.O.C. to request an extraordinary session of the Security Council in an attempt to change the decision of the sanctions committee.
 
Bound to Obey
 "This is a really difficult decision for the Yugoslavian Olympic Committee," Filipovic said. "It is good for any athlete to compete in the Olympics Games. But it is also important to think about solidarity."
As a member of the United Nations, Spain is bound to observe the sanctions, but the I.O.C. has obliged itself to maximize Olympic participation for as many athletes as possible.
In addressing concerns of the sanctions committee raised earlier, the I.O.C. proposed that all Yugoslavs could compete under the banner of the Independent Team, a nonpolitical designation, and march into the opening and closing ceremonies by the white Olympic flag with five rings.
That solution satisfied the sanctions committee only so far as individuals were concerned. Some committee members still had serious reservations about team events -- Yugoslavia qualified for men's and women's handball, men's water polo and women's basketball -- and it was on the basis of those concerns that the split decision was rendered.
The I.O.C. delayed any response tonight, pending its own discussion during a regularly scheduled meeting Wednesday morning.
In essence, the I.O.C. members have more of a philosophical question to debate, rather than a practical one, in that Spain must follow the United Nations mandate.
 
Which Way to Go
 "The debate is whether we get Yugoslavia to the Games in some form," said Kevan Gosper of Australia, an I.O.C. vice president, "or do we protest the discriminatory decision of having individuals, not teams. Do we take the whole team, or do we say some are better than none? That's the dilemma."
The I.O.C., he said, also must factor the notion that, as sponsor of the Olympics, it makes no distinction between individual athletes and those who compete as part of a team. Just as an individual athlete receives a gold medal, so does each member of a victorious team.
Whatever decisions are reached here and in Belgrade, they are not likely to affect teams from two former Yugoslav repubics, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Macedonia. Their athletes are waiting to learn from the I.O.C. under what conditions they will be allowed to compete, either as separate teams or as one and under what name and flag.

HEADLINE: Mr. Perot's Chance for Courage

 BODY:
Just before Ross Perot quit the Presidential race, his campaign staff put together a courageous plan for rebuilding the nation's economy. Would that Mr. Perot had been as courageous. He has yet to release the plan or endorse it. Still, judging by published reports, the program is full of excellent ideas that challenge both Bill Clinton and George Bush, as well as the electorate.
Jimmy Carter's budget director, Charles Schultze, calls it "the best plan I've seen in a long time" for balancing the budget and moving the country forward. The plan draws freely from independent economists, liberal and conservative. It seeks, in ways both clever and fair, to distribute pain and reward. 
 The plan calls for higher income taxes on the wealthy. It would sharply increase gasoline taxes, a move that would raise costs for most Americans but also provide important budgetary and environmental benefits.
The plan does not propose the same level of public investment Mr. Clinton asks for, but seeks in various ways to encourage private investment. It would also limit deductions for mortgage interest and curb runaway entitlement programs like Social Security. These are sacred cows that few politicians have been willing to challenge, even for a greater good.
Unfortunately, sensible economic ideas are often political suicide. Walter Mondale damaged himself by proposing higher taxes in 1984; news accounts suggest that Mr. Perot blanched when he saw what his advisers were asking him to do. According to his media director, James Squires, "Mr. Perot was more comfortable showing this plan to the country as a non-candidate than he could possibly be as a candidate. "
The plan is certainly far more threatening to special interest groups than Mr. Perot's earlier and generally painless ideas for reducing the deficit. Mr. Perot once said that if elected, he and Congress would waltz together "like Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire." With this new plan, what he was looking at was four years of slam-dancing.
Like many who yearn for serious discourse and truth-telling in the 1992 campaign, the economist Isabel Sawhill of the Urban Institute hopes that Mr. Perot will endorse the plan. "If Ross Perot can help get such proposals on the table," said Ms. Sawhill, "that would be a big contribution."
Mr. Perot's jilted advisers, it appears, have given him one more chance at courage.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rebound a Bit, With Dow Up 5.41

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Buyers made a tentative return to Wall Street yesterday after two days of steep losses, but bargain hunting was inhibited by continued worries about the health of the nation's economy.
Congressional testimony on the economic scene by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, failed to provide the market with much fresh insight. Investors chose instead to focus on earnings reports. 
 Bank stocks were among the most active issues after a spate of second-quarter results in that sector.
The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 5.41 points at 3,308.41. Gainers outpaced decliners by 901 to 844 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume rose to 173.8 million shares, from 165.8 million on Monday.
The Fed chairman said it was not likely that the United States economy would return to recession in the foreseeable future.
 
Gross Domestic Product
 Mr. Greenspan expects the nation's gross domestic product growth to have grown some 2 percent during the second quarter. He also said he believed new revisions in payroll data would show less weakness in the labor market.
"He doesn't seem to have had any effect" on the markets, John Blair, County NatWest's head trader, said.
Shares in London, Tokyo and Frankfurt all staged partial recoveries from the sharp selloff that gripped world stock markets Monday.
"There were no new bombs in earnings," said A. C. Moore, a market analyst at Argus Investment Management, explaining one positive factor on Wall Street. When I.B.M. reported on Friday that its earnings had increased fivefold -- which was less than analysts expected -- it set off two days of losses in the market.
"The stability in the currency has also been helpful," the analyst said. The dollar has recovered some ground after hitting historic lows against the German mark following a German rate increase.
Mr. Blair said: "The bank stocks were fairly active, with a lot of earnings out on those. That was probably the real issue today."
Among the banks, Wells Fargo slumped 2 1/2, to 70 3/4, despite a sharp earnings gain. Citicorp, which reported a surge in profits to $171 million, added 1/4, to 20 1/4. Mellon Bank fell 1/4, to 40 1/2, and Chemical Banking lost 1, to 35 7/8.
Among individual shares, Syntex dropped 1 7/8, to 32 5/8. Smith Barney removed the stock from its investment policy committee's recommended list.
STAC Electronics shares tumbled 3, to 5 1/2, after releasing third-quarter results. Alex. Brown cut estimates, citing a slowdown in sales at the company's retail outlets.
Shares of Ford Motor slipped 1 1/4, to 44, and General Motors fell 3/8, to 39 7/8.
I.B.M. recouped some ground, rising 7/8, to 93 3/4.
Shares of United Technologies added 2 1/4, to 53 1/2 after reporting second-quarter results late Monday. Bear, Stearns repeated a buy.
Intelligent Electronics added 1 5/8, to 9 1/8, after it said it was exploring options to increase shareholder value.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks ended 0.01 point higher at 413.76. The American Stock Exchange index rose 0.30, to 384.82.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks eased 0.04 point, to 227.47. The average share price was unchanged. The Nasdaq index was up 4.35 points at 568.63.

An article on Wednesday about shares of stock sold short and not covered by mid-July included an erroneous figure supplied by the American Stock Exchange. The number of shares sold short on that exchange for the period ended July 15 was 69.5 million shares, up 5.6 percent from the 65.8 million shares reported in mid-June.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bush on the Attack
But Charges Against Clinton and Gore Could Raise His Own Negative Image

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
President Bush has wasted no time attacking the Democratic nominee, accusing Gov. Bill Clinton this week of peddling birth control pills to teen-agers without their parents' consent and encouraging children to "haul their parents into court."
Today, Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, accused Senator Al Gore, Mr. Clinton's running mate, of selling out the economy to environmentalists and making America look bad before the world. 
 Mr. Bush's own attack on his rival is generally couched in vague references to "they," rather than to Mr. Clinton personally. The Bush campaign said the President was talking about "people in general" who advocate the policies he was criticizing.
But the campaign acknowledged that Mr. Clinton fell into that group, and it was evident that Mr. Bush had the Arkansas Governor in mind in his remarks. Some of what the President said had some basis in fact or amounted to a political argument that could not be proved one way or another. Other accusations seem misleading.
 
Wife's Writings Cited
 In one case Mr. Bush appears to be trying to use old legal writings by Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary, about the rights of minors to give voters the impression that Mr. Clinton would encourage children to sue their parents.
Mr. Fitzwater said he attacked Mr. Gore's environmental record because the Democrats were the first to "go negative." But Republicans have been attacking the Democrats all year. And their strategists are counting on such attacks -- which spring from voluminous research by the Bush team, just as Mr. Clinton's team has been researching Mr. Bush's past -- to drag down the Democrat's approval ratings.
Political history shows that this approach can be effective and that campaign attacks need not be entirely true to hurt an opponent. Indeed, in 1988 much of Mr. Bush's strategy against Michael S. Dukakis, then the Democratic nominee, was based on accusations of varying accuracy that were intended to chip away at public trust in his character and patriotism.
 
Bigger Risk This Time
 But politicians from both parties suggest that Mr. Bush is taking a much bigger risk this time by focusing his campaign on attacks against Mr. Clinton, since polls show that the President's own negative image with voters is very strong.
"Bush is in trouble because people don't think he's committed to changing anything," said Representative Vin Weber, Republican of Minnesota. "He can't fix that just with a negative campaign. It's not enough."
Some of the things the candidates are saying about each other simply cannot be assessed easily for some black-and-white truth.
Mr. Fitzwater, for example, sharply criticized Senator Gore today for going to the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro last month and condemning Mr. Bush's refusal to sign a new treaty on endangered animals.
"Gore here is Mr. Sellout America," Mr. Fitzwater said, adding: "Now he wants to be Vice President. Now he tries to talk about economic growth when he spent a week in Rio saying, 'The heck with the economy; sell it out to the environment.' "
 
Business vs. Environment
 The Senator did not say that exactly. Moreover, both candidates say they favor both environmental protection and economic growth. But the White House says Mr. Gore would bankrupt businesses by imposing costly regulations, while the Clinton camp says Mr. Bush favors businesses at the expense of the environment.
"The Administration is so blinded by its big contributors that it can't see that simple truth," said George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director.
Other charges are more specific.
In a speech Tuesday at the Three Saints Russian Orthodox Church in Garfield, N.J., Mr. Bush said the 1992 Presidential election was a choice between himself and "the advocates of the liberal agenda."
"They want public schools to hand out birth control pills and devices to teen-aged kids, and they believe it's no business of the parents and that it's strictly a matter between our children and the Government," Mr. Bush said.
 
Clinics at Public Schools
 The President appeared to be referring to clinics at public schools in Arkansas that receive Federal and state money. Under the program, which Mr. Clinton supports, local school districts can dispense condoms, birth control pills and spermicidal foam at the clinics.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said children must have parental consent to use the clinics. Mr. Clinton supports the distribution of condoms, he said, "to prevent AIDS and to help prevent unwanted teen pregnancies."
In the same speech, Mr. Bush asserted: "They even encourage kids to hire lawyers and haul their parents into court. And I believe kids need mothers and fathers, not 'big brother' bureaucracy,' and the bond between the parent and the child is sacred and it is fundamental."
Responding to that comment today, Mr. Stephanopoulos said: "That's spurious and specious, because it has nothing to do with Clinton's record or his plans. It's a legal analysis, and it's Hillary's legal analysis."
Mrs. Clinton, who has served as co-chairwoman of the Children's Defense Fund, said in articles written for legal journals starting in the 1970's that children should be allowed in some circumstances to bring legal action against their parents. She said the longstanding legal principle that adults are presumed "competent" in the eyes of a court and that children are not should be re-examined.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said this was not intended to "encourage" children to sue their parents but to give courts some recourse in cases of abuse or neglect. He provided this citation from an article by Mrs. Clinton, entitled "Children's Rights, a Legal Perspective," published by Columbia University's Teacher's College in 1979:
"Even among persons in the children's rights movement there is a concern that extending rights to children against their parents is too difficult to control, and in all but the most extreme cases such questions should be resolved by the families, not the courts."

HEADLINE: U.S. Aides Split Over Whether to Attack Iraq for Defying U.N.

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Senior Administration officials are divided over whether to mount a military strike against Baghdad and, if an attack seems necessary, whether it could be done effectively enough to avoid backfiring in the midst of President Bush's re-election campaign, officials said today.
Publicly, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today that Iraq "must be held accountable for its defiance of the U.N. resolutions and for the safety of all U.N. personnel in Iraq, as well as other international personnel providing assistance to the Iraqi people." He added, "We are not ruling out any option, including the use of military force." 
 But privately, fears that President Saddam Hussein could emerge from any allied military action unfazed politically and emboldened in his defiance of Washington have sent State Department lawyers and Pentagon planners scrambling to devise a military solution that would meet a specific military objective and would be perceived as having changed Mr. Hussein's behavior and improved his compliance with the cease-fire resolution that ended the Persian Gulf war 17 months ago.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was said by Administration officials to have joined Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in questioning the use of military force at this time, but a clear consensus has yet to emerge. It seemed certain that with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d traveling in the Middle East, Mr. Bush had not gathered the small group of top aides to review his final array of options, as was his pattern during the gulf war.
 
Position Papers Circulate
 A high-level White House meeting of Administration "deputies" was canceled Tuesday as additional position papers circulated raising new questions about the use of force, Administration officials said.
Mr. Baker was scheduled to meet with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia on Thursday to discuss anti-Iraq planning as well as the Middle East peace process. Saudi officials appeared confident that Mr. Hussein had miscalculated both Mr. Bush's political situation at home and the strength of the international resolve to force Iraq's compliance with the terms that ended the war. The Saudis have granted permission for American and allied air forces to use Saudi bases to stage any United Nations-sanctioned mission against Iraq, Administration officials said.
At the Pentagon, however, one paper drafted this week by Carl W. Ford Jr., the principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for International Security Affairs, articulated what one official described as a convincing case that military action was fraught with risks if it was not properly focused, proportional and effective.
One Administration official signaled the acute White House concern over the prospect of military impotence by saying: "There is no political motivation to talking about military action. If anything, the pull is the other way."
Administration officials said the longstanding conventional wisdom that a well-timed military strike against Baghdad might reclaim for Mr. Bush some of the political luster he garnered from the gulf war operation has now been eroded by the fear of taking action that does not produce results.
Still, Mr. Bush has projected an aura of studied determination this week. Boarding his Presidential helicopter Tuesday, he said, "We want Iraq to comply with the United Nations resolutions, and we are insisting that they comply with the U.N. resolutions."
The Iraqi leadership appeared to be calculating that Mr. Bush's political vulnerability in a Presidential contest against the just-struck Democratic ticket of Bill Clinton and Al Gore has instilled a new sense of caution about a potentially risky military venture that, whatever it achieves, will probably leave Mr. Hussein in power.
Iraq's Ambassador to the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Enbari, recently returned from Baghdad, bluntly told reporters in New York "throwing a bomb or two, whether on Baghdad or here or there, is not going to change" matters. To the contrary, he said, such limited strikes show that the United Nations Security Council, "cannot do much" without "the cooperation of the Iraqi Government."
Nevertheless, there is a deep, underlying sense in the Administration that Mr. Hussein has just survived the most significant attempted revolt from his army since the war's end, and that although he brutally and efficiently detected and pre-empted the coup plot late last month, it signified the overall weakness of his position.
Mr. Hussein's new aggressiveness toward the United Nations presence in Iraq could thus reflect a more desperate need to break the international blockade that has been inexorably strangling Iraq's economy by denying Mr. Hussein any source of national income.
One major predicament for Administration planners was devising a punitive military strike that is "proportional" to Mr. Hussein's defiance in refusing to allow United Nations inspectors to enter Iraq's Agriculture Ministry, where an archive of documents on Iraq's ballistic missile program is suspected of being hidden.
A plan to bomb the ministry has in effect been ruled out, officials said. Such a strike would destroy the very evidence the United Nations is seeking and would not be likely to change Mr. Hussein's behavior, officials fear. It would also reduce to rubble a civilian building whose leaders oversee food and crop production in Iraq.
Plans to bomb other military and industrial targets in Iraq may not meet the legal test that has been asserted by some Administration legal experts. These experts argue that United Nations authority for allied military action may be limited to targets that are related to Iraq's violations.
Other officials, however, argue that the target list has been expanded as the United Nations Security Council has cited Iraq for more and more numerous violations of the terms of the cease-fire and its follow-on resolutions related to the sale of oil, the Iraq-Kuwait border dispute and human rights abuses against the Kurdish minority in northern Iraq and the Shiite Muslim majority that predominates in southern Iraq.
Administration officials emphasized that there was broad consensus in the Government and among the allies to take some action, but Mr. Hussein's provocation, narrowly defined as his refusal to open his Agriculture Ministry, has thrown military contingency planning into a quandary.

HEADLINE: Dow Off Again, Losing 30.80; Japanese Stocks Rebound

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The stock market fell sharply again yesterday, resuming a slide prompted by heavy overseas losses, disappointing earnings and a weak dollar.
But in trading in Tokyo today, Japanese stocks recovered from a steep selloff yesterday. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 30.80 points yesterday to close at 3,277.61. It was the the third big loss in four sessions, broken only by Tuesday's modest 5.41-point rise. Declining issues beat advancers 1,092 to 643. New York Stock Exchange volume edged up to 191.8 million shares, from 173.8 million Tuesday.
Stocks fell worldwide yesterday. Tokyo stocks hit a six-year low before recovering today. Meanwhile, the leading London stock average lost 1.15 percent and the main German index fell 1.9 percent.
 
Nikkei Wipes Out Losses
 Still, Japanese stocks bounced back today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 497.99 points, or 3.20 percent, to close at 16,039.94. Much of today's gain came in the last half-hour of trading and it wiped out yesterday's lose of 460.46 points, or 2.88 percent.
Japanese brokers said traders bought back shares today that they had sold yesterday in hopes that the Government would take some action to prop up the market. But they also said investor sentiment was wary.
Yesterday, the American stock market was also unsettled by speculation about whether the United States would lead an attack on Iraq. And it showed little response to Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.
Some analysts said that the market's reaction could have been worse yesterday. Hersh Cohen, president of Shearson Asset Management, said he believes the market's decline has been fairly contained.
"For two out of the last three days, it looked like it was going to get killed, but it can't seem to gather steam on the downside," he said. "The market is being aided by this low interest rate structure."
With yields on bonds and bank accounts at levels not seen in years, some traders say the stock market remains the only game in town.
The over-the-counter market was dotted with stocks posting sizable declines after disappointing results. Among the weaker stocks were Advanced Technology Labs, down 8 3/4, to 16 5/8, and Symantec, off 7, to 20 3/4.
Among individual issues, Computer Associates topped the Big Board volume list, up 2 1/8, to 13 3/4, after releasing results. Dean Witter upgraded it to buy from hold and raised estimates.
On the losing side, Cray Research tumbled 4 5/8, to 23 7/8, after releasing lower earnings, and Symbol Technologies dropped 3 1/2, to 14 1/2, following its unexpectedly weaker profits.
First Community Bancorp jumped 8 1/4, to 26 3/4. It will be acquired by Banc One in a stock swap.
Upjohn rose 1 7/8, to 34 1/4, after the company's scientists said they had synthesized an AIDS compound that was more potent than similar drugs.
Amgen rose 3, to 65. Analysts upgraded their ratings or repeated buy opinions after the company reported strong second-quarter results.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 2.83, to 410.93. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.34 points, to 226.13. The American Stock Exchange index fell 1.65, to 383.17. And the Nasdaq index dropped 4.75, to 563.88.

HEADLINE: COMMITTEE DEFINES U.S. GOAL IN WORLD

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Saying the Administration and Congress are failing to meet the complex challenges of the post-cold-war world, a high-level panel of foreign policy experts warned today that a slide into isolationism and protectionism would be disastrous for the American economy and the international prestige of the United States.
"The world is new, but what isn't new is how we are dealing with it," said Winston Lord, a former Ambassador to China and chairman of the 23-member panel assembled by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, which issued its report at a news conference today. 
 "We see no coherent vision at home or abroad to guide us into the next century," Mr. Lord said.
The report, "Changing Our Ways: America and the New World," reflects six months of discussion among academics, former senior Government officials and heads of international organizations. The panel hopes to use its study, which surveys the world broadly and also makes specific policy recommendations on trade, the environment and population, to touch off a debate on foreign policy.
 
Why Is There No Confetti?
 Focusing on what it sees as a nearly inexplicable malaise gripping American institutions and policy makers just as the United States could be celebrating the collapse of Communism, the reports says, "Ours is a paradoxical victory."
"There has been no Victory-over-Communism Day," the panel wrote. "No confetti, no strangers kissing in the street. Indeed, it is a long time since America has been so uneasy about itself and so uncertain of where to go next."
Speaking at the news conference today, David R. Gergen, former White House communications director, said the United States was entering the third great policy watershed of the century.
In the first, after World War I, Americans displayed a "lack of wisdom" that contributed to future conflicts. After World War II, he said, the United States made "some of the smartest, shrewdest foreign policy moves in our history."
Now, he said, Americans risked repeating the folly of the 1920's. "Too little attention is being paid to what kind of world we want," he said.
 
What They Propose
 These are among the report's recommendations:
*United States foreign policy must be built on renewed domestic strength. Rebuilding the United States economy should be the highest priority, but not through protectionism or purely regional trade organizations at the expense of international free trade and competition.
*United States world leadership must continue, but with a new emphasis on collective action in support of peace, democracy and open trade.
*NATO should be associated with the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, thus abandoning a "NATO or nothing" approach.
*Germany and Japan should become permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, acknowledging their pre-eminent roles in economic and political affairs while also having them pay a larger share of international operations.
*The United States should raise energy taxes for economic, environmental and security reasons.
*The fight against narcotics should focus on reducing demand at home rather than attack overseas suppliers.
*The United States should withdraw all forces deployed abroad while strengthening the peacekeeping functions of the United Nations.
The report is available for $9.95 from the Brookings Institution, 1775 Massachusetts Ave. NW, Washington D.C. 29936. Telephone: (202) 797-6258 or (800) 275-1447.

HEADLINE: Fed Chairman Tries a Balancing Act

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, returning to Congress for a second day to testify about the economy's uncertain future, walked a tightrope again today between pressures from his White House friends in an election year and pressures from within to preserve the Fed's independence.
Economists said Mr. Greenspan did not step into the domain of the brazenly political in giving his guardedly optimistic forecast. But in their view he offered a few nuggets that might help the White House, notably his predictions that the economy would gain momentum soon and that the unemployment rate would fall substantially in the next 18 months. 
 Fed chairmen usually put a positive spin on their forecasts. Mr. Greenspan followed this tradition, some economists said, not because he wanted to help the White House but because he, like his predecessors, knew that painting a gloomy picture could cause markets to plunge and companies to lay off workers.
 
'Benefit of the Doubt'
 "His economic forecast was perhaps somewhat on the optimistic side," said David M. Jones, the author of a book on the Fed under Mr. Greenspan and the chief economist for Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York securities firm. "One could perceive it as giving the benefit of the doubt to a stronger economy, which colors things more favorably for President Bush."
But while the chairman's forecast of a stronger economy could give President Bush some ammunition to contend that conditions will soon improve, political experts say voters act less on promises and forecasts than on what is happening on Main Street.
"How the economy acts from March to June is the most sensitive period in affecting how people vote in November," said Michael S. Lewis-Beck, a University of Iowa professor who has studied how the economy affects election results. "The President can do very little right now in the short run to change the course of the economy."
To be sure, if Mr. Greenspan's new forecast proves too rosy, it would not be the first time. He made overly optimistic forecasts last July and in January, and many economists say that the optimism in his newest forecast stems not from politics but from his conviction that low interest rates should spur growth soon.
Joseph R. Coyne, a Fed spokesman, rejected suggestions that Mr. Greenspan was seeking to help President Bush, whose poll ratings have plunged because of the economy. Mr. Coyne argued that Mr. Greenspan was calling it the way he saw it.
 
An Ex-Official's View
 Scott E. Pardee, a former senior Fed official who is chairman of Yamaichi International (America), a New York securities house, said of Mr. Greenspan, "His integrity as the chairman of the Fed is probably more important than anything he can do for the Republican Party."
In Mr. Greenspan's testimony today before the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy, he said as he did on Tuesday that there would soon be an economic pickup, but he added that it would not be vigorous because many households and businesses are still weighed down by heavy debts.
He said the economy would grow by 2.25 to 2.75 percent this year, and 2.75 to 3 percent next year. He forecast that unemployment, now at 7.8 percent, the highest in eight years, would fall to between 7.25 and 7.5 percent by year-end and to between 6.5 and 7 percent by the end of 1993.
Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, who was Under Secretary of Economic Affairs in the Reagan Commerce Department, said the forecast that the economy would gain momentum soon "was a fair statement," adding that "if it helps the White House, so be it."
But Mr. Dederick quarreled with the employment forecast. "The only bone he tossed to the Administration was his comment that the unemployment rate would come down significantly," he said. "I don't see where they are going to get a sharp drop in the unemployment rate from the rate of growth they're predicting."
All in all, Mr. Greenspan seemed far less preoccupied with politics than with defending the Fed against criticisms that its actions have been too little and too late.
With long-term interest rates already high, he said, more aggressive action on short-term rates "more than likely would have been interpreted by market participants as risking a resurgence of inflation."
 
Confounding the Experts
 Mr. Greenspan said there was general surprise among experts that the Fed's repeated interest rate cuts had still not produced a vibrant recovery.
Mr. Greenspan took credit for helping avoid a depression, saying easier credit had helped keep the drop in asset values from snowballing.
Mr. Jones, the economist, said Mr. Greenspan's optimism made excellent strategic sense. "It's a good tack to take," he said, "when Congress is berating you for not doing enough, when the White House is concerned about the election and when it's consistent with your view that lower interest rates are someday supposed to produce stronger growth."

HEADLINE: House Ethics Panel Sees No Evidence Of Violations in Post Office Scandal

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
A Congressional panel investigating the House post office said today that it had found no evidence that any members of Congress violated ethics rules. But it described a postal operation plagued by accounting failures, patronage problems and the gross inflation of mail volume to justify more jobs and a larger budget.
The House voted unanimously to turn over all the material from the five-month investigation to both the House ethics committee and Justice Department investigators, who are conducting a parallel inquiry. As a practical matter, the report appeared to bring an end to the House's scrutiny of itself in the post office affair. 
 The resolution adopted 414 to 0 by the House gave the ethics committee no mandate for further action, and Democrats said that they did not expect action to be taken against any members.
In other action, the House on Tuesday night removed one hurdle to anuclear waste repository that has been the subject of much debate in New Mexico by approving a transfer of the land above the site to the Department of Energy. But opponents added several requirements to the measure that could delay the opening of the repository for years.
 
Partisan Split
 Republicans on the panel investigating the House post office issued their own report, shattering any illusions that the group, half Democrats and half Republicans, had maintained the cordial bipartisan air that had earlier been proudly proclaimed. And they named the members, mostly Democrats, who had used the post office for political or personal reasons. Still, they stopped short of finding any violations.
The Republicans asked the ethics committee to review the entire record, while the Democrats asked that the ethics committee look only into the conduct of four post office employees.
The House bank and post office cases have already claimed the jobs of Robert V. Rota, the postmaster, and Jack Russ, the sergeant-at-arms, who resigned in March and recently returned to the Congressional payroll as a $100-a-month part-time adviser to Representative Mervyn M. Dymally, Democrat of California. Some low-level employees have also pleaded guilty to embezzlement and drug dealing at the post office.
All of the members of the special group looking into the post office contended today that the investigation had been severely hampered by senior employees in the office like Mr. Rota who had asserted their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination, and by the United States Attorney's office in Washington, which counseled some witnesses not to cooperate with Congress.
Prosecutors have privately questioned whether the group could competently conduct an investigation because it includes lawmakers who oversaw the post office and provided patronage jobs for relatives and political allies.
The panel did not substantiate accusations by one employee, James C. Smith, that he had made cash payments from postal funds to Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, and two other House Democrats, Austin J. Murphy and Joe Kolter, both of Pennsylvania. The office expenses of the three have been subpoenaed in the criminal inquiry and they have said they would be cleared.
The Republicans said as many as 25 current and former lawmakers had used House post office employees to deliver campaign donations to the Capitol from post office boxes elsewhere in Washington. But their report identified only current members: Nicholas Mavroules of Massachusetts, Dennis M. Hertel of Michigan, Mary Rose Oakar of Ohio, Jim Moody of Wisconsin, Edward F. Feighan of Ohio and Mr. Rostenkowski, all Democrats and Jan Meyers, Republican of Kansas.
The Republican report also said that Mr. Rota had overestimated the mail volume handled by the office by as much as 350 percent, which the Democrats did not dispute, in an effort to get a larger budget and more employees.
 
New Hurdles to Repository
 In action on Tuesday night concerning the nuclear waste repository, the House voted 382 to 10 to approve a proposal to transfer 10,240 acres of Federal land in New Mexico that lies above the project from the Department of the Interior to the Department of Energy. Three court decisions said such a transfer must be authorized by Congress before the repository, called the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant, can accept radioactive wastes.
But even as the House voted to approve the transfer, opponents of the project managed to include new barriers that could indefinitely prevent the $1.3 billion repository from opening.
Among the new provisions is one that requires the Environmental Protection Agency to establish new standards for disposing of radioactive wastes before any can be put in the repository. Five years ago, a Federal Appellate Court in Boston struck down the existing standards, saying they were lax.
Today, an E.P.A. spokesman said the agency may propose new standards in the fall, but final rules would not be ready until months later. Other provisions in the House measure, like one that requires public comment and E.P.A. review of certain operations, could delay the repository for years.
The Government wants to proceed with this project quickly because tens of thousands of tons of waste contaminated with plutonium are stored in boxes and barrels across the nation, much of it in unstable conditions.
The Bush Administration opposes the House measure but supports a related bill passed by the Senate late last year that does not include any of the barriers in the House version. A conference committee has not yet been named to resolve differences in the two proposals.
The House legislation is another marker along the punishing path the Energy Department has taken to get the repository opened. The repository was finished in 1988 after nearly a decade of construction in salt beds deep beneath the desert near Carlsbad, N.M. It is intended to entomb nearly one million barrels of waste contaminated with plutonium from nuclear weapons plants and laboratories.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua's Government Astir as Police and Ex-Troops Trade Fire

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 22

 BODY:
The police came under a military-like assault from demobilized soldiers on Tuesday night near key public buildings as the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro struggled to defend itself against critics and opponents.
The 20-minute exchange of fire near presidential offices and the National Assembly, in which 14 police officers were wounded, pitted two elements controlled by the opposition Sandinista Front against each other. 
 That seemed to reflect differences over how to function as a democratic movement that have rent the former guerrilla force since it lost power in elections in February 1990.
But that confusing episode -- the culmination of two days of violent strikes and demonstrations by bus drivers, university students and former soldiers -- contributed only one part to the growing sense that the Government is under siege.
Mrs. Chamorro also faces demands from the coalition that put her in office that she break her alliance with the Sandinista Front and remove the minister on whom she is dependent to run the Government -- her son-in-law Antonio Lacayo -- because of corruption allegations.
The Government is further pressed by the Congressional blockage of $104 million in previously authorized American aid. Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, requested the cutoff until, among other things, the Chamorro Government breaks with the Sandinistas and speeds up the return to legal owners of properties confiscated in the Sandinista era.
As she left earlier this week for the Ibero-American summit meeting in Spain, Mrs. Chamorro brushed aside questions about whether Mr. Lacayo would resign, saying that, if Mr. Lacayo goes, "Violeta leaves, too."
The two Ortega brothers -- Gen. Humberto Ortega, the army commander and the Sandinista whom Mrs. Chamorro took into her inner circle, and Daniel, the defeated former President -- seem to be following contradictory lines on the use of violence.
Daniel Ortega Saavedra, in recent days, has seemed to encourage disgruntled Sandinistas to take up arms to back economic and social demands, while General Ortega has sharply condemned such actions.

HEADLINE: Senate Nears an Accord On a Coal-Benefits Issue

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Breaking a logjam that had been holding up an ambitious energy bill, Senate Republicans and Democrats negotiated the broad outlines of a compromise on an amendment forcing coal companies to provide medical benefits to 100,000 retired coal workers.
The coal-company provision has attracted strong opposition from the Administration and has threatened to lead to a crippling filibuster. But by this evening, senior aides of senators on both sides of the issue said that except for a few details, negotiators had reached agreement, essentially guaranteeing a demand by Senator Jay Rockefeller, Democrat of West Virginia, that retired miners and their families not be stripped of benefits they had been promised. 
 In return, Mr. Rockefeller dropped a provision in his amendment calling for a tax on coal companies.
 
A Potpourri of Issues
 Both the Senate and House have passed similar versions of the energy bill by overwhelming margins, but final enactment has been delayed the last two months by legislative maneuvering involving a number of tax provisions. Because the bill deals with a potpourri of complex and economically sensitive areas, from deregulation of electric utilities to possible storage of spent nuclear materials in Nevada, final passage of the most important energy legislation in more than a decade could still be weeks or months away.
The latest in a seemingly endless series of controversies occurred when Mr. Rockefeller persuaded the Finance Committee last month to attach to the energy bill a measure to bail out an insolvent health care fund that President Truman and the United Mine Workers set up in 1946 with a tax on coal companies.
Mr. Rockefeller's measure drew heated criticism from the Administration and Senate Republicans, who contended that nonunionized coal companies should not be held liable for health costs they did not agree to meet in negotiations. Republican leaders promised that President Bush would veto the energy bill if Mr. Rockefeller's amendment was not scratched or at least modified.
 
Threats and Compromise
 Such threats led to several weeks of negotiations between Senator Rockefeller and Senators Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, and Wendell Ford, Democrat of Kentucky, which several aides thought would culminate in a compromise within hours. An eventual compromise should insure a successful cloture vote to close off debate on the energy legislation on Thursday, all but guaranteeing that the bill would proceed to a House-Senate conference committee for final compromises on a separate array of issues.
Having achieved the objectives in the energy bill of streamlining licensing procedures for new nuclear power plants and deregulating the natural gas and utility industries, the Administration did not want to forfeit them over the Rockefeller measure.
In recent days, Labor Department negotiators told Rockefeller aides they were willing to accept a substitute for the Senator's coal tax provision that was based on a measure proposed a few years ago by the West Virginia Democrat. That proposal imposed health care responsibility for retired miners and their families on companies that had bought out or taken over the properties of the defunct firms that had once employed the workers. Administration officials said such a solution would reduce the bureaucratic waste that would accompany a tax.
The Administration offer formed the basis for the emerging compromise.
 
'A Huge Victory'
 "We consider this a huge victory," said a senior Rockefeller aide. The aide added that Mr. Rockefeller still wants to insure that the guarantees of health benefits are permanent, and that will require "an additional small amount of funds" beyond what the Republicans have agreed to.
A Republican aide agreed that the two sides were narrowing their differences, adding, "We'll be working most of the night" to reach a final settlement.
Another hurdle was overcome earlier today when Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, the Democratic chairman of the Energy Committee, dropped his support for a controversial nuclear-waste-disposal provision. To smooth final passage, he said he would insure that a House measure to allow the Energy Department to override Nevada laws to determine if the Yucca Mountain storage site in Nevada is suitable for the disposal of high-grade nuclear waste would not survive a House-Senate conference committee.
Nevada's two Democratic Senators, Richard H. Bryan and Harry M. Reid, had threatened to block final passage of the energy legislation with a filibuster if the House provision was included in the final draft of the bill.

HEADLINE: Asian Nations Hope to Settle Dispute Over Islands Peacefully

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, July 22

 BODY:
Foreign ministers from across Southeast Asia, reflecting a growing fear of China's military intentions in the region, called today for a peaceful resolution of disputes over a chain of tiny islands in the South China Sea coveted by Beijing and thought to be rich in oil.
Earlier this year China claimed sovereignty over the entire chain of the Spratly Islands, which it calls Nansha, and in June Beijing announced it had contracted with the Crestone Energy Corporation, of Denver, to explore for oil and gas in the area. 
 The Chinese move angered and alarmed the other five nations that claim all or part of the Spratlys: Vietnam, Taiwan, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei.
 
Call for Restraint
 In a joint declaration issued here today at the annual meeting of foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the officials urged that the dispute be resolved "by peaceful means, without resort to force." The association's members are the Philippines, Malaysia, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand.
The message was clearly meant for China, which has been willing to battle over the Spratlys in the past: In 1988 its forces sank two Vietnamese warships in the Spratlys, killing more than 70 Vietnamese, and Chinese soldiers were stationed on several of the islands.
The unspoken fear is that China, capitalizing on Washington's pullout from its military bases in the Philippines, will use the Spratlys to assert military supremacy in the region.
 
An Added Sense of Urgency
 The Philippine President, Fidel V. Ramos, warned during the conference that a diplomatic failure could lead to "perilous developments."
The Spratlys, tiny uninhabited islands and reefs spread across several hundred square miles of the South China Sea, are the subject of an old dispute. But China's recent moves have added a sense of urgency, and they threaten to undo the recent detente between China and its traditional adversary in Hanoi.
Vietnam, which resumed normal relations with China last year after years of tension, has said that Beijing's oil-exploration plans in the Spratlys are threatening the stability of the region. Vietnam also claims sovereignty over all the islands and once awarded oil-exporation rights there.

HEADLINE: Prof. F. S. C. Northrop, 98, Dies; Saw Conflict Resolution in Science

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
F. S. C. Northrop, a protean scholar at Yale University who used the scientific method as his philosopher's stone and influenced politics, culture and the cold war, died yesterday at a nursing home in Exeter, N.H., where he had lived for many years. He was 98 years old.
Professor Northrop died in his sleep, said his son Stuart J. Northrop. 
 An expert in the fields of philosophy, science, anthropology and law, Professor Northrop studied the major scientific advancements of the early 20th century, especially Einstein's theory of relativity, and related them to the cultural conflicts emerging from the two world wars.
"Do the advent of the atomic bomb and the possibility of biological warfare make the physicist and biologist, rather than the scientist and humanist, the wisest guiders of policy?" he asked in his book, "Ideological Differences and World Order" (Elliot's Books, Northford, Conn., 1949). "Have psychology, anthropology and history demonstrated that irrational emotions, environmental stimuli, biological heredity, or inevitable historical trends determine what will happen? Or do ideas really matter?"
He argued at the outbreak of the cold war that it was not ideological, political or economic issues but rather science that offered the basis for improving relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. In the early years after the United Nations was formed, he grew skeptical that brokering for peace on a political basis could prevent a third world war.
At a conference to plan for an Emergency World People's Congress in 1947, he said it appeared "that the United Nations has failed quicker than the League," referring to the doomed League of Nations begun after World War I.
 
A Native of Wisconsin
 Filmer Stuart Cuckow Northrop, who used only the initials of his first three names, was born in Janesville, Wis., in 1893, a descendant of Joseph Northrop, who arrived in New Haven in 1638. He graduated from Beloit College in 1915 and began his graduate work at Yale in 1917. He served in the Army tank corps during World War I, then worked in China for two years before returning to Yale to complete his master's degree.
He received his doctorate from Harvard in 1924 and later studied in Germany and England. He became an instructor in philosophy at Yale in 1923 and remained on the faculty for nearly four decades. He was chairman of the Department of Philosophy from 1938 to 1940 and was the first master of Silliman College, one of 12 residential colleges at Yale, from 1940 to 1947.
He had the rare distinction of being appointed to a Sterling endowed professorship, the highest scholarly honor at Yale, in both philosophy and law. He was one of the few nonlawyers to teach at Yale's law school.
 
Prolific Author and Scholar
 In 1927, Professor Northrop spent a year in Germany and Switzerland, where he began in earnest his 20-year study of Einstein's theory of relativity and the nature of the scientific method.
He was the author or editor of 12 books, the most influential of which was "The Meeting of East and West," a critique of the world's principal philosophical traditions in their cultural settings, published in 1946. In a front-page review in The New York Times Book Review, Howard Mumford Jones called the book "great, difficult and important," and said it was the "most important intellectual event in the United States thus far in 1946."
Professor Northrop theorized that the East, embracing Confucius and Lao-tze, used "concept by intuition," while the West, in the tradition of Aristotle and Plato, valued most highly "concepts by postulation." This placed the two cultures in conflict with each other, the solution to which, he theorized, rested on a synthesis of values.
"The Meeting of East and West"has been reprinted 10 times, most recently in 1979 by Ox Bow Press of Woodbridge, Conn., and translated into three languages.
Through the course of his studies, Professor Northrop became an expert on the writings and theories of Einstein and the philosopher Alfred North Whitehead. He once described both as "men of genius who are as sensitive in spirit as they are brilliant in mind."
Professor Northrop served on several international organizations involved in resolving international ideological conflict. He was a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and a member of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.
He is survived by his sons Stuart, of New London, N.H., and Johnston F., of Lakeville, Conn.

HEADLINE: Fed to Cut Money-Supply Goal

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the Fed was planning to reduce its target for monetary growth below current levels to reduce inflation.
But in his testimony before the House Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy, the Fed chairman said the central bank was holding off for the moment because it was still trying to analyze the erratic behavior of M-2, the most closely watched gauge of money. 
 The measure includes cash, savings and checking accounts, money market funds and short-term certificates of deposit.
"We were generally in agreement that we have to bring the ranges down another notch to conform to our long-term goal of price stability," he said.
He said the Fed had provisionally adopted a target range for growth in the money supply for 1993 that is identical to this year's. The Fed's goal is growth of 2.5 to 6.5 percent for M-2 and of 4.5 to 8.5 percent for debt.
He noted that growth in M-2 had been far below the Fed's targets in recent months. He added, however, that the historic, fairly consistent relationship between the growth of M-2 and growth in the overall economy seemed to be breaking down.
He explained, for instance, that many people were moving their savings from six-month certificates of deposit, which are considered part of M-2, into mutual funds, which are not considered part of M-2. He said the Fed's chief policy-setting committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, would reconsider its targets for money growth no later than its meeting next February.
"The reason we forestalled in moving this time was primarily because of the fact that the problems involved in relating M-2 specifically to gross domestic product have gone so far off track," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Russia Uranium Talks Seen

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
The United States will hold secret talks with Russia and four other former Soviet republics to settle a dispute over whether the republics have been selling low-grade uranium to American utilities at illegally low prices, Administration officials said today.
At stake is whether the Energy Department will be able to buy weapons-grade uranium from Russian nuclear warheads for peaceful uses, as Russia has offered. The American uranium industry, in a longstanding lawsuit, is trying to make all uranium from the republics subject to the prohibitive duties that the Commerce Department imposed May 29 on low-grade imports from the republics. 
 The decision to open negotiations follows an active effort by Russia to turn the trade dispute into a diplomatic issue.
 
Taking Their Case to the Top
 "They've raised it at the highest levels," Robert Strauss, the United States Ambassador to Russia, said in an interview today. "They've raised it with me; they've also raised it with President Bush."
In the last two months, the Bush Administration has almost completely reversed its position in the highly political case, a case study in effective lobbying and in the sensitivity of Federal agencies to the mood of the capital -- in this case, to a desire not to throw roadblocks in the way of economic growth in the former Soviet Union.
Not only does the case involve Mr. Strauss, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, but also Frank Fahrenkopf Jr., who was chairman of the Republican National Committee during most of the Reagan Administration.
Until mid-May, the Energy Department enthusiastically supported the uranium industry in its suit for steep punitive duties on all imports of uranium from the republics. Then, startling and angering the domestic uranium producers, the Energy Department asked that weapons-grade uranium be excluded from the case because it was unsuitable for commercial use, Government documents show.
Weapons-grade is the type of uranium that the department and several American companies are now talking about buying from Russia. The material would have to be diluted before it could be used in reactors.
Mr. Fahrenkopf, who represents the Russian exporter of the uranium, said the Energy Department had been discussing the possible purchase "for some period of time."
Meanwhile, the Commerce Department has decided to open negotiations under a never-used provision of American trade law that would allow the department to impose a settlement on the domestic industry without its consent, said a department official who insisted on anonymity. The section only applies to trade cases filed against countries with nonmarket economies and was enacted in 1988.
The settlement would impose a tonnage limit on uranium shipments but not a duty.
 
Industry Is Angered
 The initial decision to exclude highly enriched uranium, followed by the possibility that the uranium may now be used for civilian purposes, angered the American industry, which contends that political interference took place.
"The preliminary decision to exclude appeared to be cooked to us," said Valerie A. Slater, who represents the American uranium industry."It was done within tight time constraints, without any time for us to respond." .
A Commerce Department official said that nobody from outside the department's office for trade cases had made any effort to interfere.
Ms. Slater works for Akin, Gump, Hauer & Feld, a Texas law firm formerly known as Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld. Mr. Strauss, one of the firm's founders, left when President Bush named him Ambassador to Moscow last year.
Mr. Strauss said today that because of the conflict of interest, he had not become personally involved in efforts to settle the case and had tried to avoid acquiring information about the case. "I don't have any, don't want any and haven't accepted any," he said.
 
Playing Down the Politics
 For his part, Mr. Fahrenkopf played down his political connections. "I'm acting as a lawyer in this context," he said, acknowledging, "I have written to the President."
"I have written to everyone I can write to," he said, "because I just feel this is so outrageous."
Uranium accounted for an eighth of the entire Soviet Union's exports to the United States last year, as sales soared to $110.4 million from just $2 million in 1986.
In its preliminary ruling on May 29, the Commerce Department imposed a duty of 115.82 percent on all types of uranium except the highly enriched uranium. The decision is subject to confirmation by the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission before it becomes official, and the American uranium producers have filed legal briefs in the case asking that highly enriched uranium be included once more.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
NBC Still Aims for the Gold in Its Olympic Sales

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
If selling spots for the 1992 Summer Olympics were an Olympic event like a footrace, NBC would find the finish line to be tantalizingly close. But whether its performance was of gold-medal caliber would still be up to the judges.
The network has sold 96 to 97 percent of the $500 million worth of commercial time it has intended to make available during its 161 hours of Olympic coverage, which begins with the opening ceremonies on Saturday and continues through Aug. 9. That translates into upward of $480 million, a notable achievement in a daunting, recessionary climate plagued with slackened demand from advertisers to sponsor sports programming. 
 "I think they did a whale of a job in a tough economy," Paul Schulman, president of the Paul Schulman Company, a media-buying service in New York, said yesterday.
Andy Donchin, director of national broadcast at Media Buying Services International in New York, agreed. "It's impressive," he said. "I'm surprised they made it this close."
 
'Battered and Bruised'
 Yet close is, of course, still shy of a sellout -- an accomplishment that network sales departments seek with as much intensity and determination as athletes strive for Olympic medals. For instance, CBS, when it presented the Winter Olympics, managed to sell out all its commercial time just before those Games began in February.
"We're battered and bruised, but every time the bell rings, I answer it," said Larry Hoffner, executive vice president of sales at NBC in New York.
"We're not at our goal," he added, "but if we miss, we can't miss by much."
Mr. Hoffner said his challenge had been intensified by a fundamental shift in marketers' spending patterns. In contrast to previous years, when companies budgeted additional money for special events like the Olympics, he said, "now, the majority of funding is coming, not from corporate funds, but from brand budgets."
 
Less Earmarked Money
 Bert Fett, director of sports sales at John Blair & Company, the television sales-representative firm in New York, agreed. "There aren't a lot of advertisers who have earmarked funds specifically for the Olympics," he wrote in the current issue of the Blair Outlook newsletter.
Media buyers said that NBC's results were impressive, despite coming up short, because of the network's decision to avoid deeply discounting prices, which run around $335,000 for each 30-second prime-time Olympic spot.
"My staff and I are doing everything to get to that number," Mr. Hoffner said, referring to the 100 percent level, "but we don't want to do bad deals to get there."
The NBC sales efforts will continue through the Olympics, he added, as they did in 1988, when the network broadcast the summer games from Seoul, South Korea.
One potential advertiser yet to be heard from is Bush-Quayle '92. There has been widespread speculation that the national ad efforts from the President's re-election campaign might be inaugurated with a series of spots during the Olympics; it is a logical venue, given the patriotic feelings that the Games often inspire, especially if the United States is winning plenty of gold medals.
"We are looking at a number of different options," said Jack Irving, executive vice president and director of media operations at Saatchi & Saatchi Media Advantage in New York, "but we've not been given approval to buy anything at this point." His firm is sharing the campaign's media-buying duties with National Media Inc. in Alexandria, Va.
Though advertising and media executives are curious as to how NBC fares in selling commercial time for the Games, they are perhaps even more fascinated by the fate of the Olympics Triplecast. The pay-per-view presentation, being marketed by NBC and the Cablevision Systems Corporation, is a highly unusual experiment, offering 15 days of Olympics coverage on three cable channels for $125.
Most executives have insisted that few, if any, subscribers in local cable markets around the country will sign up, resulting in losses for the project as high as $100 million to $150 million. Some, though, looking to previous pay-per-view events, have suggested that a flood of last-minute subscribers is possible.
Mr. Schulman, the media buyer, said he disliked the Triplecast because the extensive commercial time that NBC devoted to promoting it "could have been used to get the country familiar with the U.S. Olympic team and to promote the Olympics," thus possibly raising NBC's broadcast ratings and delivering larger audiences to advertisers.
Television Digest, an industry newsletter, reported in this week's issue that even though the Triplecast "is generating significantly less customer interest" than NBC projected, the network's overall Olympic losses might run as low as $20 million to $50 million.
NBC "actually could break even," the report added, based on calculations that include additional revenues like the $75 million in new business the Olympics is expected to generate at NBC's six owned-and-operated stations.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Taxable Yields Fall Again; Tax-Exempts Rebound a Bit

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Yields on taxable funds slipped a bit further in the latest week, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report. The cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve three weeks ago is apparently still exerting downward pressure on taxable yields.
Yields on tax-exempt funds, however, rebounded slightly after a sharp slide. Investors have been withdrawing their money to invest in higher-yielding stocks and bonds. In addition, investors who had temporarily parked their income from a spate of municipal bond redemptions are also shifting those funds elsewhere. The outflow has given yields a small lift. 
 The seven-day compounded average yield for tax-exempt funds rose 12 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 2.21 percent. The simple yield rose by the same amount, to 2.06 percent. The 30-day compounded and simple yields each dipped 5 basis points, to 2.29 percent and 2.26 percent, respectively.
 
Long Maturities
 Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, said the assets of tax-exempt funds shrank a modest $581 million, to $96 billion. The average number of days left to maturity of tax-exempt securities held in fund portfolios slipped a day, to 62 days.
Mr. Frank noted that the long maturity suggested that investors were not especially concerned that interest rates would head higher.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with $100 million or more in assets, IBC/Donaghue's reported that the New York fund with the highest yield was the Boston Company New York Tax Free Money Fund, with a seven-day compounded yield of 2.54 percent. The top Connecticut fund was Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with a yield of 2.69 percent. And the leading New Jersey fund was the Vanguard New Jersey Tax Free Money Market Fund, with a yield of 2.53 percent.
Yields on taxable funds continued to slip as assets rose by $7.7 billion, to $501 billion. Institutional investors accounted for most of the increase in assets, which probably reflected the rocky stock market as well as the Fed's latest easing.
Money market yields typically descend more slowly than open market yields, so investors historically put money into funds for several months after the Fed cuts rates.
The average seven-day compounded yield for taxable funds was 3.24 percent, down 5 basis points. The simple yield also declined 5 basis points, to 3.19 percent. In the meantime, the 30-day compounded yield was down 5 basis points as well, to 3.31 percent.
The average days to maturity of the securities decreased a statistically insignificant one day, to 62 days.
This week's leader among taxable funds was the Olde Premium Plus Money Market series, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.01 percent, down 11 basis points from the previous week.
