HEADLINE: Beer Dispute Flares Up Between U.S. and Ontario

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, July 22

 BODY:
Ontario brewers are preparing for a new beer battle with the United States after learning that the Bush Administration's interagency Trade Policy Review Group has recommended a 50 percent import duty on Ontario beer.
The action is subject to approval by the Cabinet, and Canadians say they will retaliate in kind. 
 Kathy Lydon, the assistant United States trade representative for public affairs, said no final decision had been reached but said the trade representative's office was preparing to make an announcement on Friday.
The dispute over beer, after a peace accord "in principle" was reached in April, underscores the unusually high political sensitivity over trade issues that both Governments are wrestling with, as they combat economic sluggishness, prepare for elections and try to reach a free trade agreement with Mexico.
 
One of Many Disputes
 Beer is just one of a number of trade sectors, including steel, magnesium, lumber and pork, where the United States and Canada have clashed in recent months.
Both Canada and the United States have complained that the other was applying protectionist policies to maintain domestic beer production and employment and hinder cross-border shipments. Trade arbiters in Geneva under the General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade have upheld the respective cases.
Canada agreed to steps to open its market in April, but as the two Governments sought to put the final details in place, the provincial government of Ontario, which has a fair amount of autonomy, introduced a 10-cent-a-can levy on beer cans, which enraged exporters from the United States, most of whose beer enters Canada in cans. Canadian brewers sell mostly in bottles.
In addition, the Liquor Control Board of Ontario has set a $2.53-a-case warehouse charge, which Canadian brewers do not pay. Ontario is Canada's largest province, where about 40 percent of all Canadians live.
Leading the fight for retaliation in the United States are the G. Heileman Brewing Company and the Stroh Brewery Company. The three largest American brewers -- the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the Coors Brewing Company and the Miller Brewing subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies -- have longstanding licensing arrangements with the Canadian brewers under which their major brands are produced in Canada.
The projected new American levy, which would amount to about $3 on a case of 24 bottles, would hit Molson Breweries of Canada Ltd., the Labatt Brewing Company, Sleeman Brewing and Upper Canada Breweries.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Greenspan Comments Help Prices

BYLINE: BY KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates declined yesterday, as credit market participants were encouraged by comments from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, that suggested the Fed remained vigilant in the fight against inflation.
In response to a question during his appearance before a subcommittee of the House Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan suggested that in coming years the Fed might lower its money supply growth targets. 
 Answering a question about money supply from Stephen L. Neal, a Democratic Congressman from North Carolina, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed's Open Market Committee was "generally in agreement that we have to bring the ranges down another notch to conform to our long-term goal of price stability."
 
'Anti-Inflation Bias'
 Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America, said Mr. Greenspan's comments "suggest to me there is still a very strong anti-inflation bias at the Fed."
"Even though Mr. Greenspan has admitted there is a breakdown between money growth and economic activity," he added, "there still seems to be enough of a connection between money and inflation to keep going."
In addition to Mr. Greenspan's comments, prices of Treasury securities also benefited from a further decline in stock prices abroad and in the United States, as well as from rumors that the Fed was selling short- to intermediate-term issues and buying bonds for a customer. Traders said the purchaser was rumored to be the German central bank.
"I don't know who is doing it, but someone is giving the long end a nice bid," a government-securities trader said. "And with the yield spread between two-year notes and bonds at 3.40 percentage points, there is a good reason to buy bonds."
In his testimony yesterday, Mr. Greenspan said that "long rates have a good way to go down if inflation expectations could be purged from the system."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 104 1/2, up 18/32, to yield 7.61 percent, compared with 7.65 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues outstanding, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 23/32, up 10/32, to yield 6.83 percent. And the 5 7/8 percent three-year notes were offered at 10 33/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 4.68 percent.
Yesterday afternoon the Treasury announced it would sell $15 billion of new two-year notes on Tuesday and $10.5 billion at an auction on Wednesday. The size of the auctions is unchanged from June.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the new two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 4.30 percent, while the new five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.78 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell, as the further decline in stock prices persuaded some investors to seek haven in safe short-term debt instruments.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.15 percent, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.22 percent.
New-issue activity accelerated in the corporate bond market.
Among the issuers was Ralph's Grocery Company, which priced $300 million of 10-year high-yield securities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 10 1/4 percent notes, which are noncallable for five years, were priced at $100, or par.
The issue is rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Merrill Lynch acted as lead manager for an offering of $300 million worth of 30-year debentures for the Province of Nova Scotia.
 
Tax-Exempt Rally
 The 8 1/4 percent noncallable debentures were priced at $98.20, to yield 8.415 percent, 77 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's.
The rally in the Treasury market spilled over into the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds.
Traders said that prices of most widely quoted securities improved by 3/8 point in fairly active trading.
"The market is in very good shape," a municipal securities trader said. "At the moment there are not enough bonds around, and there is too much money."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mixed Trading for Dollar, While Gold Moves Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday in sluggish trading, with money traders apparently worried that the central banks might take concerted action again to support the United States currency.
Gold prices rose to $358.90, up $1.30 from Tuesday's close. A late bid at the Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $357.50, up $1.50. 
 Kevin Logan, chief economist in the New York branch of the Swiss Bank Corporation, said comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a Congressional committee on Tuesday that the dollar should not fall much further "just reminded everybody the central bank is out there."
On Monday, the Fed and several other central banks intervened in the currency markets in a coordinated swoop, supporting the sagging dollar by purchasing large amounts of the currency and selling German marks. The mark had been rising because of an increase in German interest rates last week.
The dollar fell yesterday against the German mark in New York trading to 1.4850, compared with 1.4870 late Tuesday.
The dollar closed in New York at 126.63 yen, up from 125.25 yen Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 125.42 yen, up 0.30 yen from Tuesday's close. In London, the dollar was quoted at 126.95 yen.
The British pound fell to $1.9065 in New York, from $1.9095 Tuesday. In London, the pound fell to $1.9025, from $1.9105 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.3150 Swiss francs, down from 1.3235; 1,127 Italian lire, down from 1,130.00; 5.0145 French francs, down from 5.0245, and 1.1882 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19185.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.4885 German marks, up from 1.4880; 1.3215 Swiss francs, down from 1.3235; 5.0235 French francs, down from 5.0255; 1.6785 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6780; 1,128.50 Italian lire, down from 1,130.50, and 1.1903 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1925.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $359.38 an ounce, from $357.85 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $358.85, from a $357.90 bid late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Will George Bush Read Their Lips?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
A STIFF tax on gasoline . . . higher income taxes on the rich . . . caps on Social Security . . . tax incentives for business research and investment . . . more money for education and infrastructure . . .
To many analysts, Ross Perot's aborted call for shared sacrifice was the impossible dream that was, indeed, impossible -- tough common sense from a nonpolitician who in the end did not have the stomach to challenge a decade of national self-delusion. "I might have written it myself," said Benjamin Friedman, a Harvard economist who has been tirelessly proselytizing for deficit reduction since Ronald Reagan inaugurated the decade of what-me-worry economics. 
 But unlike Ross Perot's bid for White House gold, the plan may not be dead. For while one of the remaining candidates has offered a clear sense of how he would energize the economy, polls suggest that the other man is deeply in need of the vision thing.
"The Perot plan was the plan for the consummate outsider with nothing to lose," said Jeffrey Garten, an investment banker with the Blackstone Group and author of the new book "A Cold Peace." "But it might still become the plan for the consummate insider with nothing left to lose: George Bush."
Two scenarios, both admittedly longshots, are intriguing:
The Agent of Change. Count the reasons why candidate Bush would never embrace the Perot economic agenda. "The stickiest issue is taxes," said David Hale, an economist with the Kemper Financial Group. Tax proposals would offend key supporters -- everyone from hard-line supply-siders, who view higher levies on income as the devil's work, to suburban commuters who already resent paying $1.19 a gallon for unleaded regular. Indeed, Mr. Bush has made no secret that he regrets the day he broke his no-tax pledge.
Then there is the matter of momentum: Any radical policy shift would face opposition from the White House-Treasury coalition that crafted Mr. Bush's 1993 budget proposal. "I bristle at the dismissal of our effort to cut spending on entitlements," said John Taylor, who recently returned to Stanford University after a tour of duty on the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
If enacted, Mr. Taylor argues, the Administration's proposals would allow the economy to grow its way out of big deficits. And while the Congressional Budget Office politely demurs -- it forecasts a rising deficit after 1996 under Bush policies -- there is certainly an impulse to justify the last few months' politically punishing effort to stay the course.
But 20-point-plus debits in the opinion polls have a way of focusing politicians' minds. So do economic forecasts, echoed this week by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, that unemployment is certain to remain stuck above 7 percent through the election. And surely one lesson of the career of the man who coined the phrase "voodoo economics" is that Mr. Bush is capable of changing his mind -- indeed, his political persona -- when the votes of millions of would-be Perotists are on the line.
Were the President to abandon budget business as usual, he would probably not have to look far for moral support. While supply-siders, the anti-tax ideologues in the Republican Party, wield influence beyond their numbers in Congress, most Administration tacticians believe in fighting deficits the old-fashioned way.
Mr. Bush's budget director, Richard Darman, reportedly toyed with proposing a gasoline tax before the invasion of Kuwait blew the lid off energy prices. And he has certainly never hidden his frustration with the Administration's failure to tame the great engines of escalating Federal spending, Social Security and Medicare.
The January Surprise. One reason for discounting the prospects of a pre-election conversion is that Mr. Bush's campaign advisers can still make a plausible case for toughing it out. The President can win, the argument goes, if he can hang onto Republican redoubts in the South and West, and then pick off a few Rust Belt states.
But suppose Mr. Bush does manage to squeak back into office, there to face a hostile Democratic majority in Congress. Would he hunker down to what seems likely to be four more years of tepid growth, political fingerpointing and policy gridlock?
Mr. Hale thinks not. "This would be President Bush's last term," he noted, "the time to do the dirty work." If he struck early and hard, he might regain the respect he has frittered away since the gulf war. And if he is at all inclined to take the chance, he might well be quietly egged on by Republican Presidential hopefuls -- everyone from Dan Quayle to James Baker -- who would be eager to remove the deficit albatross before they faced the voters in 1996.
A war on the deficit would be hard to win, of course, because the enemy is almost all of us. "But even if he went down with the program," argued Mr. Garten, "it would be a better way to lose."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
New Lines Hold Hope For Chrysler

BYLINE: By Doron P. Levin

 BODY:
FEW new products from Detroit in recent years have provoked as much curiosity on Wall Street as the Chrysler Corporation's midsized models, code-named L/H and set to be sold as the Dodge Intrepid, Eagle Vision and Chrysler Concorde.
Accordingly, several financial analysts took the unusual step this week of attending the L/H debut in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., held principally for automotive journalists. 
 The debut, held in three sessions to accommodate everyone, consisted of technical briefings by Chrysler executives and test drives of Intrepids, Visions and Concordes over several hundred miles through horse country and the 112-degree heat of Borrego Springs, Calif.
Cars made by competitors were available, too. So analysts and reviewers could drive a $19,000 Intrepid for a while, and then switch to a $30,000 Acura Legend to see how they compared.
Too often in the past, Chrysler cars compared poorly.
Hobbled by rock-bottom credit ratings and unfinanced pension liabilities of some $4 billion, Chrysler now needs a "home run" car to restore financial stability and confidence. The Ford Motor Company -- and its common stock -- received just such a lift in the mid-80's when its Taurus and Sable midsized models became smash hits.
Analysts were optimistic when they saw hand-built L/H prototypes last year. But they were eager to assess how L/H's built on production tooling compared with cars like the Taurus, Toyota Camry and the Legend, which are competitive on either size or price. They were also keen to hear professional judgments of automotive reviewers, because their recommendations often shape consumers' early buying patterns.
"Certainly some cars the reviewers love don't sell well," said Jerry G. Paul, automotive analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, which owns about 20 million Chrysler shares. "But it's a lot easier for a car to sell well if they love it than if they don't."
The reaction of Kathy Hamilton, senior editor of Automobile magazine, seemed to exemplify what most automotive writers were saying: "The consensus was that this is an exceptional automobile. It definitely was major league, in my opinion, and the first American car I've seen in a long time that you could call state of the art."
Reviews of the L/H cars will begin appearing next week; the cars will trickle into dealerships during August and September and become more readily available later in the fall.
Chrysler executives say the L/H proves they have been able to restructure their development process from a hierarchical system to a team system, in the manner of the best of their Japanese competitors.
Most of the 22 automotive analysts tracked by Zaks Investment Research in Chicago are already recommending either a full-fledged buy or a buy-hold on Chrysler stock. The main reason for the buy signal is that the economy is in an early phase of recovery, which usually spells price appreciation for the cyclical automotive stocks. But if the L/H succeeds "it could give the stock an especially strong tailwind," Mr. Paul said.
Analysts warn that Chrysler must still prove it can maintain the quality of the L/Hs's when the assembly line cranks up to speed. And the economy must grow robustly enough to provide buyers. Given those caveats, the L/H could once more turn Chrysler stock into a great turnaround story.
Harvey Heinbach, Merrill Lynch's automotive analyst, said that driving the L/H and listening to reviewers extol its virtues reinforced his confidence in the No. 3 auto maker. If Chrysler sells 225,000 L/H's annually, pretax profit could top $1.1 billion, he estimated, representing a gross profit of $5,000 a car -- about what Chrysler earned during its best years from its highly profitable mini-van.
The depressed price of Chrysler stock during the last two years reflects the auto maker's recent earnings performance: break-even in 1990 followed by a $795 million loss last year. But unlike Ford and the General Motors Corporation, Chrysler's balance sheet remains scarred by its near-bankruptcy in the early 1980's. The auto maker can no longer borrow money in public credit markets.
In December, when Chrysler was forced to raise $350 million of new equity, its common stock was selling for roughly $10 a share. That compared with a peak of $48 a share just before the market crash of 1987. Yesterday, shares closed at $18.50, down 62.5 cents.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Mirror Net Up 54%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 22

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company said today that its second-quarter profits rose nearly 54 percent despite charges arising from job cuts at Newsday and weak newspaper advertising revenues.
The company, which also publishes The Los Angeles Times, said it had earned $47.2 million, or 37 cents a share, on revenues of $911.4 million in the quarter. That compared with profits of $30.7 million, or 24 cents a share, on revenues of $900.9 million a year earlier. 
 Operating profits rose by 16.5 percent in the company's book and magazine publishing group, by 10.6 percent in cable television and by 27.3 percent in broadcast television operations.
The charges related to Newsday totaled 10 cents a share, Times Mirror said. Upon completion of the Newsday buyout program, which covers about 300 employees, staff levels will be down 8 percent from a year earlier.
The company said newspaper advertising revenues continued to be hurt by weakness in the Southern California and New York regional economies.
Newspaper publishing revenue fell 1.8 percent and operating profit was off 23.4 percent from the comparable quarter of 1991, the company said.
Times Mirror also publishes New York Newsday, The Baltimore Sun and The Hartford Courant.
The company's shares dropped 25 cents today, to $34, on the New York Stock Exchange.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1312 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
FACING PRESSURE, BUSH IS ADAMANT ON KEEPING QUAYLE

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
With pressures mounting within his own party for further measures to revitalize his re-election campaign, President Bush denied today that he was even considering the possibility of replacing Vice President Dan Quayle.
Deeply concerned about the President's dismal standing in the polls, two groups of Republican Senators, in separate meetings, held what Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the minority whip, described as "spirited discussions of what should be done" to get the flagging campaign moving again. 
 One participant in the meeting of the Wednesday Club, to which mostly moderate Republicans belong, said at least half the 15 or so Senators there either explicitly or implicitly said Mr. Quayle should be dropped from the ticket.
 
Opinion Sharply Divided
 The replacement of the Vice President was also Topic A today among Republican campaign workers, state party officials and strategists, with opinion sharply divided as to whether a change would help to reverse the precipitious slide in popularity that has imperiled Mr. Bush's re-election.
The President appeared to leave open not the slightest possibility of a change in the ticket. Asked at a White House photo session whether the Vice President's status was shaky, Mr. Bush replied, "No, it's very certain." He dismissed the talk about replacing Mr. Quayle as "a lot of crazy rumors."
David Beckwith, Mr. Quayle's spokesman, said the Vice President would not step down voluntarily, adding: "If he seriously thought it would help the President, he would do it. But he doesn't think that, and neither does the President."
 
'Goes With the Territory'
 "I'd just soon not have the stories but it goes with the territory," Mr. Quayle said in an hourlong appearance tonight on CNN's "Larry King Live.""Believe me if I thought that I was hurting the ticket, I'd be gone. I want George Bush re-elected, so my decision is predicated on what is best for the President."
The statements of denial did little to quiet the fever of speculation in Washington. Instead, in the often perverse logic of the capital, they fed the storm, with political professionals sensing that something must be afoot.
There were also widespread calls on Capitol Hill for the dismissal of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the budget director, Richard G. Darman, said participants in the meetings of the Wednesday Club and the Steering Committee, the other Republican Senators' group. Some nervous incumbents said that as things now stood the Republicans might lose four to six Senate seats.
One indication of the disarray in the party, said Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, was that most Republican Senators had little interest in attending the party's convention next month, preferring to keep their distance.
An Associated Press poll indicated that 4 in 10 Republicans nationwide thought Mr. Quayle should be dropped from the ticket. Few Republican Senators suggested that he deserved, on the merits of the case, to be replaced; indeed, most said he had done a good job.
Yet some, like Senator Lugar, said Mr. Bush needed to "send a signal that by its very drama tells people that this is a whole new ball game, a new campaign with a new game plan and a new vigor." He said he thought that "a dramatic statement about growth and jobs" would produce the best results, but conceded that other lawmakers, "stunned by what they have heard at home in their states the last two weeks," thought Mr. Quayle should go.
 
Concern Over Bush's Health
 Others, like Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, said many voters were concerned about Mr. Bush's health, "whether there's any ground for it or not," and that made them worry about Mr. Quayle, whom many would not trust with the Presidency. It was not fair, Mr. Rudman added, "but it exists, and people have gone to the President to tell him about this."
The discussion about a new Vice-Presidential candidate centered on Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who is believed to be as acceptable to conservatives as Mr. Quayle. Most Republican politicians believe that Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, another popular conservative, would find it hard to work closely with Mr. Bush.
Until the Los Angeles riots in late April and early May, Mr. Kemp was all but ostracized by the White House, and his often innovative ideas were usually given short shrift.
But Mr. Cheney might present problems, too. He has had a history of heart problems and has undergone bypass surgery, although he appears to be in robust health now.
Even the chance that Mr. Quayle, a former colleague, might be sacrificed clearly pained most of the Republican Senators. Mr. Rudman, for example, said, "He's a lot better than most people seem to think, and he's a very good friend of most of us, but the public perception is just not very good."
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York also mentioned concerns about the President's health as an element hurting Mr. Quayle, and said the White House "is going to have to come to grips with this, sooner or later."
The President and his physician have both denied that he has any serious health problems.
"There is no Bush campaign now," Mr. D'Amato said. "We have to make changes, get rid of Darman and Brady, and get bold, decisive leadership."
Many Republican insiders have come to believe in the days since the Democratic convention that Mr. Bush would be obliged to consider dropping Mr. Quayle by the very perilousness of his situation. But most, like Senator John McCain of Arizona, said they thought the President would refuse to do so because of his strong belief in loyalty to subordinates and because of political reality.
"He should have fired Brady and Darman a long time ago, but that isn't his way," Mr. McCain said. "The only way Quayle will go is if he concludes that this battering is bad for him and the party, which is certainly possible."
By replacing Mr. Quayle, Mr. Bush would be tacitly admitting that he had erred in choosing Mr. Quayle in the first place, and he would be breaking his repeated pledges to keep him on the ticket. And it might not solve the problem. As the Vice President's aides and backers argued feverishly today, Mr. Bush has had both good ratings and bad with Mr. Quayle at his side.
 
'Bush Has a Bush Problem'
 "Bush doesn't have a Quayle problem," said Richard A. Viguerie, a conservative consultant, in a comment typical of Quayle supporters. "Bush has a Bush problem. Dan Quayle musn't be scapegoated in the President's re-election strategy. President Bush's troubles are a direct result of his failed economic policies."
The pending switch of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d from diplomacy to campaign management appeared to be one factor feeding the speculation. A senior Republican who rode the Bush campaign plane four years ago commented, "I saw how bitterly Jim Baker resented the selection of Quayle then, and I have to believe he will try to move him out as soon as he takes control."
That is expected to take place in mid-August, before the Republican convention opens in Houston. Asked about a news article in The New York Times this morning reporting the change, Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said that "it's all speculation," but did not deny it.
Traveling in the Middle East, Mr. Baker also avoided a denial, but he said, "Until you hear it from the President of the United States and the Secretary of State of the United States, I wouldn't make book on it."
But most Republican politicians and campaign strategists took it as a done deal, and said they wished Mr. Baker was available tomorrow.
"I'm delighted that Jim Baker's coming back," said Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, the Southern chairman of the Bush effort. Asked if he was sure the switch was definite, the Governor answered firmly, "Baker will be back."

Mr. Bush greeted pupils yesterday at an elementary school in Arlington, Va., where he joined a discussion about a community anti-drug program. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A10)

PUB-DATE: July 23, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1277 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Bus Trip Leaves Bandwagon Air For Time Being

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, July 22

 BODY:
More than 25,000 office workers, labor unionists and curious onlookers jammed the streets for blocks around the city's main public library today to give the Democratic ticket of Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore an ecstatic salute at the final stop of their six-day bus tour.
The 1,240-mile trip, which took the campaign through eight states with rallies along superhighways and two-lane rural roads, at times eclipsed its planners' efforts to make it exciting. While the results were occasionally chaotic, they provided the Democrats with continuing coverage after the intensity of the New York convention.
 
Promises a Rescue
 
 Stripped to his shirtsleeves and drenched in sweat at a humid lunchtime rally, Mr. Clinton gave an old-fashioned tub thumper of a speech as he promised to rescue the American people from a Government that he says cares and does too little for average people.
"If you're sick and tired of the way it's been going," he said, "if you want the American people in control again, if you believe your country is still the greatest country in the world, if you think we can compete and win again, if you're tired of being heartbroken when you go home at night and you want a spring in your step and a song in your heart, you give Al Gore and I a chance to bring America back."
"We'll lift the country up," he said, as the sound of applause rolled down the streets and bounced off office buildings. "It's time for them to go. It's time for us to rescue America."
Recognizing that pictures often leave a more lasting impression than words, the Clinton-Gore ticket tried this week to take from the Bush Administration its claim to represent family values. Standing on platforms with their wives, Hillary Clinton and Tipper Gore, the candidates waved, applauded and whipped up the crowd into chants as hired crews filmed the events for campaign commercials.
Frank Greer, one of the campaign's media strategists, said the Democrats do not plan to televise commercials before next month's Republican National Convention unless they are attacked first.
"It would be icing on the cake," Mr. Greer said. "I don't think we need to waste money on commercial advertising right now."
In Vandalia, Ill., thousands of people waited for hours Tuesday to see the Democratic ticket, lit candles after they spoke and waited more than an hour afterward for a closer glimpse or an opportunity to touch the Clintons and Gores.
In dozens of interviews, people in the crowds Tuesday and today spoke most often about the need to elect a candidate whose views they share on jobs, health care, abortion and crime prevention. They mentioned family values only when specifically asked.
"He may be trying to put a wholesome family image across now because of his past problems," said Sue Albrecht, a clerk from St. Louis who heard Mr. Clinton speak today. "He won't get my vote on that issue. No one will. I think there are too many other important issues." She said she was "on the fence" about Mr. Clinton because he favors abortion rights.
 
Mutual Admiration
 The image the campaign has cultivated on the tour, that of two devoted young families, has been obvious. On Sunday, Mrs. Clinton rubbed her husband's back as they sat side by side on hay bales. On Tuesday, the Gores held hands as they walked down the street. And each day, Mrs. Gore and Mrs. Clinton -- arms linked around each other's waists -- waved at crowds and then stepped into the background to gaze adoringly while their husbands spoke.
Initial plans to have the Gores drop off the bus in Louisville, Ky., on Monday to return to Tennessee were scrapped after strategists realized that the Clintons and Gores together were causing some of the reaction.
"We hoped it would just send a signal that we were going to run a serious, people-oriented campaign," said George Stephanopoulos, the campaign's communications director. "Instead, we got a signal back from the American people."
Aides to the Clinton campaign said more joint campaigning is planned. They are also scouting out new motorcade routes for future bus tours.
The apparent success of the bus tour together with recent polls showing Mr. Clinton with a significant lead over the President, seem to have stung the Republicans. President Bush has dispatched surrogate speakers to at least three stops along the way. Vice President Dan Quayle, Labor Secretary Lynn Martin and a domestic policy adviser, Clayton K. Yeutter, made separate taped or live appearances in Pittsburgh, Louisville and St. Louis.
"Governor Clinton does not have one-tenth the stature the President has all over the world," Mr. Yeutter said. "The American people are going to wake up and realize this."
And in Washington, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, called Mr. Gore "Mr. Sellout America" for supporting stronger environmental planks than the President did at the recent world environmental summit in Rio de Janeiro.
"Now he tries to talk about economic growth when he spent a week in Rio saying 'the heck with the economy, sell it out to the environment,' " Mr. Fitzwater said.
Both Democrats dismissed the White House criticism today. Mr. Clinton said that Senator Gore "tried to help America lead the world again" during his participation in the environmental summit. The Republicans, he said, "are going to attack us for their failures."
Mr. Gore said that by recruiting Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to rescue its flagging fortunes, the Bush-Quayle campaign was "getting desperate."
"I think you're seeing with the decision to pull Secretary of State Jim Baker -- the best they've got -- out of the Middle East peace talks at a critical moment to concentrate on politics is a sign of panic in the White House," Mr. Gore said.
The Clinton forces seem supremely confident as they watch at least some of Mr. Clinton's message take hold. The caravan's path through small towns often took on the feeling of a Fourth of July parade.
At the end of the rally today, dozens of people lined up to autograph the Gore-Clinton banners that were attached to the buses.
Mr. Clinton's route through the Middle West steered away from inner city neighborhoods, and there was little evidence that an effort had been made to attract the traditional Democratic constituencies of minorities and organized-interest groups.
An aide to Mr. Clinton said such forays would be made in the future. But for the first week, he said, the Democratic ticket wanted to make its presence felt in battleground states.
"The thing that kills a country is when people get up every day and they don't think tomorrow is going to be better," Mr. Clinton said. "We want to restore to this country a genuine sense of community and caring, to say we're all in this together. We're going up or down together without regard to race or region or income. This is America. Let's start acting like it again."

Clinton Is Welcomed Home

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 22 (Special to The New York Times) -- Governor Clinton was greeted by a cheerful crowd of several hundred campaign workers and supporters when he returned home this evening for a welcome rally outside his national headquarters.
"We have just a little over 100 days in this campaign," Mr. Clinton said, before signing dozens of autographs and greeting his hometown well-wishers.
"One hundred days of struggle and effort; 100 days of spirit and hope. I want you to know that no matter how tough it gets and how long the days get, we're going to stay to the end, and we're going to win this campaign because of people like you."

HEADLINE: In Free Trade, Mexico Sees An Economy in U.S. Image

SERIES: A New North America -- Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico

 BODY:
When Mexico dreams of itself as a free-trading country, it imagines Monterrey.
Driving through this rugged city in a Mexican-made Ford or a Mexican Chevrolet, the vision comes into focus against the jagged spine of the Sierra Madre. Past the freshly painted houses of factory workers and the apartment buildings sprouting satellite dishes, the elegant quarters of big industrial companies stare out from a hillside. Beside the rusted carcass of what was the largest foundry in Latin America, 250,000 square feet of new convention center glow in rainbow colors.
 
New Commercial Landscape
 
 Past a Blockbuster Video outlet, the Burger King and the Sirloin Stockade, a sign in Spanish reads, National Lumberyard. But the structure from which it rises isn't that at all. As a joint venture would have it, the store is Mexican but the shelves are stocked by True Value Hardware; even the nails come from the United States.
After half a century of devout economic nationalism, Mexico's embrace of a proposed North American Free Trade Agreement has crystalized changes in everything from the way the country does business to the way that it looks.
To an extent that is difficult to fathom in the United States or Canada, where the treaty would mean far less economic or social change, the idea of a union with two big, rich neighbors has come to dominate the Mexican imagination.
In the future that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has proffered to his countrymen, free trade has become a guarantee of their deliverance from underdevelopment. The rapid Americanization that has already taken place in Mexico's consumer culture whispers that the economy, too, might be transformed in America's image.
But the expectations of a new prosperity are at best unevenly shared. In some industries, the pain of adjusting to foreign competition is just starting to be felt. Ancient factories, decrepit infrastructure and poor, uneducated workers challenge the idea of competing at all. At the other end of Mexico from Monterrey, the fear of being left behind is palpable.
In the steam heat of Tuxtepec, a river town set a few dozen miles inland from the Gulf of Mexico in the southern state of Oaxaca. Andrea Solis Ramon, 23 years old, said she believed free trade had changed some things already. But as she stood across railroad tracks from a dilapidated sugar mill and scolded the tiny children running shoeless through her garbage and mango peels, she did not include herself among them.
"There are imported products in the stores, but who can buy them?" asked Miss Solis, who has neither a husband nor a job. "We only buy rice, sugar, beans, soap and bleach." She counted the items slowly on her fingers.
"For the peasants, for us, it is nothing," she went on. "It is only for the big businesses. There is no work here, and that is not going to change with this free trade."
Trade officials from Mexico, the United States and Canada are expected to reach an agreement within weeks. The accord must then be ratified by the legislative bodies of all three countries, a process that will likely take until next year.
 
The Meaning
Investment, Jobs, Political Change
 While trade barriers have been falling in Mexico since 1987, the agreement has come to represent infinitely more than new rules of commerce. Even in the hierarchy of economic benefits, it is less important as a means to open foreign markets than as a magnet for foreign capital.
As the flow of foreign investment quickens, there are to be better wages, stronger industries, and cheaper, more efficient services. According to a study by the Institute of International Economics in Washington, Mexico would gain 600,000 jobs by 1995. Subsequent governments will be bound by treaty to continue the economic opening, Mr. Salinas has argued, and the development of the economy will beget democratic political change.
"I don't want Mexicans leaving the country anymore," he said last year, "only our products."
But nothing quite like the merger that the 43-year-old Harvard-educated President is proposing for his country has ever been tried before.
The Mexican economy is one-twentieth the size of America's. It is full of bottlenecks, inefficiencies and failing companies that still hang on. Under the expected terms of the treaty, Mr. Salinas's third-world nation will have to integrate with its first-world neighbors more quickly (though less fully) than Spain or Greece did in joining the European Community. And it will receive nothing like the regional-development funds that the European club gave its new members.
In its sales pitches abroad, the Salinas administration tends to concentrate on its market of 85 million consumers, the tariffs it has brought down to an average of 11 percent and the looser investment regulations that are to follow a trade agreement.
For many foreign companies, however, the essential attraction is still cheap labor. Mexicans' per capita annual income is $3,458; that of Americans, $22,690, and Canadians, $21,245. Even in big industrial companies in Monterrey, assembly-line workers are paid as little as $5 a day.
By its de facto control over most of the Mexican media, the Salinas Government has projected a more consistently positive image of the accord than either of its North American counterparts could hope to do. The Government's success in ending nearly a decade of economic crisis has also inspired many Mexicans, even among the nearly 40 million who live in poverty, to grasp its vision without reserve.
 
The Fears
New Competition Will Be Tough
 Yet while opinion polls show that Mexicans support a trade agreement by a large majority, interviews with scores of laborers, businessmen and farmers suggest a country nearly as skewed in its allocations of confidence as it is in the distribution of its wealth.
Corn farmers who survive on a crop for which the Government now pays them twice the world price have drawn only some reassurance from officials' promises that the price supports will continue for more than a decade. Small-business owners worry that they might face extinction, though they cannot foresee how or when. In industries like chemicals and textiles, plastics and automotive parts, the mortality rate for companies has already shot upward.
Despite Mr. Salinas's call for a new, more confident nationalism, there is also widespread unease about partnership with a country that has stood larger in Mexican history as an adversary than as an ally.
"There are going to be dead and wounded," said Adrian Gonzalez, a manufacturer of steel shapes who heads the Monterrey Chamber of Commerce. "This is going to be like those winters in the United States and Canada. The snow will come and kill all the pests."
In the last three years, about 3,000 of Mr. Gonzalez's 22,000 affiliated businesses have shut down. Some 2,000 new enterprises have joined. Elsewhere as well, Mexican companies accustomed to much more government protection have begun to fail at a rate more like that of the United States, economists say.
 
The Promise
Better Standard Of Living for All
 Boiled down, the promise for Mexico is that by fixing investment rules, magnifying its manufacturing and assembly advantages, and opening paths into both its own market and those of its bigger, richer neighbors, the treaty will draw new business from North America, Europe and Asia.
That capital, officials say, will raise people's living standards as it slowly narrows the gap between Mexican wages and those paid across the border. In raising annual economic growth by 1 or 2 percent, it will also provide the Government a cushion to continue structural changes in the economy.
Aides to Mr. Salinas argue that the sharpest pains of Mexico's adjustment have already been felt, and some independent economists agree.
During the foreign debt crisis that exploded here in 1982, they note, companies were forced to slash work forces and increase efficiency to an extent that domestic competition never required. A withering internal market also prompted some that had never thought about exporting to look abroad. No longer satisfied with the savings of cheap labor, large industrial concerns now routinely scrutinize their production costs against foreign benchmarks.
"There has been a very important change in productivity," said Jesus Reyes Heroles, an economist who heads the Mexico City consulting firm GEA.
The end of import permits and the fall of tariffs has helped bring down the double- and triple-digit inflation that eroded lower incomes severely for a decade; Mexican manufacturers have had to lower their prices in the face of new foreign competition.
Moreover, the increase in American products and franchises has not always hurt local business. Mexicans often own, staff and supply the new businesses, distribute the new goods and provide the new services.
But the modernization taking place from textile mills to supermarkets is one that took a generation or much more in developed countries. The free-trade agreement will give Mexico only a few years.
"We've been in the free-trade mode ever since we started coming to Mexico in 1990," Thomas O. Mudd, the managing director of Blockbuster Mexico, said, sounding as though he were harking back to another time. "We felt that Mexico was becoming hot, and now look at it -- it's the hottest country in the world!"
In a market cluttered with the same sort of mom-and-pop rental stores that it took on in the United States, Blockbuster opened its first Mexican store in September. Within less than nine months, it had 15 scattered around the country. Plans are for 300 by the end of 1996.
 
The Revolution
Retailing Sector In an Upheaval
 If change is spreading everywhere across the Mexican economy, then retailing is in the throes of a revolution.
Even a few years ago, discount stores were almost unheard of in Mexico. Markdowns and sales, when they occurred, were a product of bankruptcy or economic crisis, and a handful of big supermarket and department-store chains could comfortably extract profits of 30 percent or more.
But driving north along the smog-laced highway that circles Mexico City, in the plastic, strip-mall world that is Ciudad Satelite, or Satellite City, one now finds el Price Club and Club Aurrera.
The two steel and concrete warehouses sell mostly to Mexican businesses, offering the large quantities at low prices typical of hypermarkets. The first of what are to be at least a dozen Price Clubs within five years is a 50-50 joint venture of the San Diego-based company and Commercial Mexicana S.A., a Mexican grocer. Opened on Feb. 29, it already has 65,000 members, a subscription rate that its chief executive, Jaime Gonzalez, says is "unheard of" in the United States.
In the cavernous Club Aurrera, part of a $20 million joint venture of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. of Bentonville, Ark., and the Mexican retailing giant Cifra S.A., the phenomenon is explained by Jesus Real, a 43-year-old dry goods merchant in the city of Queretaro, 93 miles away.
As he is interviewed, Mr. Real moves through the store slowly, hauling a pallet stacked with a ton and a half of sacked beans, instant coffee and boxes of Kellogg cereal. His bill comes to nearly $10,000, but Mr. Real describes this as a bargain. By no longer shopping at Mexico City's teeming Central Market like other grocers, he says, he has saved not only $2.25 on each sack of beans but bribe money for the police, tips to the self-appointed parking attendants and the small rocks usually mixed with his beans.
Like Wal-Mart and the Price Company, many American and Canadian investors have sought Mexican help to interpret consumers, circumnavigate Government rules, and set up distribution networks. With few exceptions, big Mexican food companies have either joined forces with, sold out to, or been overrun by foreign counterparts in the last two years.
"I've yet to find a company of medium or large size that is oblivious to what's happening," said Carlos Lukac, a vice president in Mexico City of the consulting firm Booz, Allen & Hamilton. But being aware of competition does not necessarily seem to mean being prepared for it.
 
The Advantages
Mexicans Know Their Markets
 Constantino Lacayo, a vice president of Offset Multicolor, conceded that his printing company, which did $30 million in sales last year, was vulnerable to American and Canadian rivals. But he said: "We think we can give our clients a quality of service that only one Mexican can give another. It is going to take them a long time to understand the market."
In Glasgow, Ky., however, the American printer R.R. Donnelley has already added 10 Mexican publications to a client list that rang up $3.9 billion in sales last year. Two years ago, Donnelley opened a plant in Reynosa, on the Texas border, and it recently bought a large printing company in central Mexico.
"We have considerable respect for the local parties," said James M. Ratcliffe, Donnelley's vice president for corporate relations. "But having said that, we wouldn't have moved into Mexico if we didn't think we could compete successfully."
 
The Contrasts
Two Regions, Worlds Apart
 In larger industries especially, the drop in Mexican tariffs has fostered a whole new series of private-sector demands on the Government. Steelmakers complain of higher electricity costs. Cattle ranchers say they pay too much more for their feed. The deregulation of areas like trucking and the reduction of corruption and labor union control at key ports and border crossings allow goods to move more smoothly but Mexican exporters say they can still be crippled by the added costs of inflation and faulty services.
The prospect that these difficulties will be temporary seems clearest in Monterrey. Of the 18 banks auctioned in the Government's recently concluded selloff, nearly half were bought by local industrialists. The city boasts the best-educated people in Mexico, the highest wages, the greatest concentration of satellite dishes. It is home to both of the country's two major multinational companies, the glass maker Vitro S.A., and the cement manufacturer Cementos Mexicanos S.A., which is known as Cemex.
The state Governor, Socrates Rizzo, said in an interview, "We are moving toward the integration of Texas and northeastern Mexico in a single region." And there is much to support the claim. Within months, a new highway will cut the driving time to San Antonio from six hours to four and a half, speeding the imports of Borden milk that is already on grocery shelves. General Motors has a big automotive plant nearby, and scores of other American and Canadian businesses have set up shop over the last three years.
But for every Monterrey, there seem to be at least a few Tuxtepecs.
By its own definition, the city of about 150,000 people would qualify as a pole of development for the destitute state of Oaxaca. There is a "Tuxtepec Industrial Park," although it is thigh-deep in grass and its only three structures -- an ice factory, a sawmill and a metal workshop -- have all closed. Yet as cows graze peacefully, the mood is so far from that of Monterrey as to belong to another country. In the afternoon, the air seems thick enough to have pulled the mangoes down from their trees; no one picks them up, and they perfume the squalid landscape as they rot.
Outside the town, Gaudencio Medina slumps in the thin shadow of his hedge and tells the history of the paper factory where he has worked for 32 of his 48 years. It began in 1958, he says, when the the President came to lay the cornerstone. Everything was fine until a couple of years ago.
"Now they tell us our paper is no good, that it's not like the paper in the United States," he says. "One of the machines is shut down and 420 workers who depended on that factory one way or another are already out. We don't know why they have abandoned us like this."

HEADLINE: Big and Little Reunions For Black Americans

BYLINE: By ENID NEMY

 BODY:
THEY stood in the doorways of the Stop 1 Supermarket, the Red Hook Chinese Kitchen, Freddy's Fast Cleaners and other small businesses, smiling, waving and looking delighted and puzzled as the 28-piece marching band strutted and danced along Van Brunt Street in Brooklyn at noon on Saturday.
They waved, too, at the matriarch sitting in the horse-drawn carriage that followed, who acknowledged their greetings with a gracious nod and a flutter of a hand reminiscent of Britain's Queen Mother. Most of the crowd had no idea what the woman, the people marching behind the carriage or the black and gold uniformed band from the Jackie Robinson Center in Brooklyn were doing on their street. But before the entourage had reached the entrance to Coffey Park, word had spread among the curious. The procession was a prelude to what was believed to be the biggest African-American family reunion ever held in Red Hook. 
 It was, too, a tribute to the head of that family, a 77-year-old woman named Grace (Mudgie) Stevens who with her husband, Thomas, left St. George, S.C., in 1937 and ended up in Brooklyn some 30 years ago. The reunion, with its white and purple T-shirts printed with family names and the rubric "When you know where you come from, It's easy to see where you're going," was similar in format to many others being held across the country this summer.
Although black family reunions have been going on for generations, they proliferated after the publication of Alex Haley's "Roots" in 1976 and the television mini-series the following year. And the last seven years have seen a phenomenal increase in the number of participants. For example, more than six million people have attended the black family weekend reunions that the National Council of Negro Women began in 1986. While many participate in small family reunions at these weekend gatherings, many more come to festival activities as part of a symbolic extended family. In addition, the amount of money participants spend is significant to businesses in the host cities.
The council's original program in Washington, a weekend festival combined with family reunions, has expanded to seven cities -- Washington, Philadelphia Chicago, Los Angeles, Cincinnati, Memphis and Atlanta. Los Angeles, which attracted 150,000 people to Exposition Park for its first weekend celebration, expects a total of some 600,000 at its Aug. 7 weekend this year. Cincinnati had a total of 200,000 at Sawyers Point in 1990. More than 50,000 people turned up for the first day of Chicago's reunion weekend in Grant Park earlier this month.
Queen L. Gladden, national director of the celebrations, noted that "the whole idea is the restoration and strengthening of black families and emphasizing traditional values."
"It's a broad picture," she said, "an extended family reunion as well as reunions of immediate family and friends. People usually come and bring their families and meet other family members. You'll see family groups with T-shirts, but you'll also see just two members of a family, a mother and daughter, or just a person alone."
The weekend festivals are coordinated by the National Council of Negro Women. There are commercial sponsors of pavilions and activities.
Dr. Dorothy I. Height, president of the council, said: "We've had some six million in attendance in the last six years and not a single police incident. We started these weekends in response to the negative projection of the vanishing black family, and we plan the family reunions within the festivals."
The format for most of the reunion weekends begins with an invitation-only leadership forum, reception and prayer breakfast. The remainder of the weekend, open to everyone, is concentrated around picnics, pavilions dealing with family values, health, drugs, education, the arts and, Dr. Height said, "our African heritage and contribution to this country, showing we are not a problem people but people with a problem." There are, as well, African-American marketplaces and vendors.
The Stevens-Shuler festivities in Brooklyn (Shuler was Mrs. Stevens's maiden name) began with a blessing offered by Nellie Stevenson, a family member who is an evangelist, and continued through the afternoon with entertainment and with presentations by members of the Emergency Medical Service and of the Police and Fire departments. There was also an information poster on subjects ranging from the environment to AIDS.
With the exception of several dozen friends and neighbors, white and black, the more than 500 people honoring Mrs. Stevens were family members, among them her eight children, most of her 64 grandchildren and numerous great-grandchildren whom, she allowed, she hadn't yet counted. Not all of them stayed for all 15 hours of picnics, programs and dancing that tapered off only at 3 A.M., although Mrs. Stevens was on hand until well after midnight.
The entire event was orchestrated by Annette Renaud, a granddaughter, as a way of honoring both her grandmother and her family. (As a peripheral activity -- a celebration within the park celebration -- Ms. Renaud also organized a bridal shower for Cheryl Crawford, a friend.)
"My grandmother did housework for many years, in private homes during the day and hotels at night, to help raise her family," Ms. Renaud said. (Mr. Stevens, who died 20 years ago, was a plumber.) Her grandmother still sends $100 every two months to the Shady Grove United Methodist Church in St. George, S.C., she continued, adding: "She's also helped raise at least one child of each of her daughters. I thought it was time to do something to honor her."
Ms. Renaud, one of 11 daughters (all of them college graduates) of Mrs. Stevens's daughter Willie Stevens Renaud, arranged the Afrocentric-theme program with her aunt Barbara Reno. A popular entertainer was Clyde Wilder of Message From Our Ancestors and his stilts dance.
Ms. Renaud also paid most of the costs, other than those for the individual family picnics, photographs and T-shirts. "It was just easier that way," she said. The day also included a disk jockey and music, a petting zoo and pony, a cotton candy and ice cream truck, and an ice sculpture of the family crest. There were portable bathrooms, a refrigerator truck and scores of other incidentals.
As in many family reunions, this one had most participants staying with relatives and comparatively few in hotels. Nonetheless, particularly in the case of the gigantic weekend reunions, comparatively few can add up to a considerable number.
"I've no idea of the percentage of our business done with family reunions, but it's important," said Marc Michaelson, a spokesman for Motel 6, with 700 motels in 48 states. "For the last two summers 20 percent of our advertising budget has been targeted at family reunions."
Pamela Gilbert, director of sales at a Holiday Inn in Orlando, Fla., speaking of black reunions, said: "It's a growing market. We expect 2,000 to 3,000 room nights this summer, which, at about $60 a night, would come to $150,000." Jeff Ericson, the Holiday Inn regional field marketing manager in Atlanta, said the chain of 1,400 hotels was seeing "more and more family reunions, with black reunions in the forefront of them."
"It's meaningful business," said Gordon Lambourne, public relations director of some 200 Marriott hotels in this country.
Even more meaningful is the overall economic impact of family reunions. The Cincinnati Convention and Visitors Bureau estimated that the 200,000 at the 1990 black family reunion in that city spent an average of $93 each, bringing some $18.6 million to the area. The office of Kenneth Hahn, the Los Angeles supervisor whose district includes Exposition Park, used $10 million as a conservative figure for the reunion weekend's impact on local business last year.
But in Red Hook, business was the last thing on anyone's mind. Mrs. Stevens could only repeat, "This is really something," with an occasional nod of the head and "oh, my" thrown in. She was kept wondering for weeks, she continued, adding, "They wouldn't tell me anything." But once the day began, she rather enjoyed the surprises and "the blessing of so many of the family and so many nice neighbors, white and black."
"This is just a little bit of us," said Barbara Reno, Mrs. Stevens's youngest daughter, who is noted for her own parties and fish fries.
"We've all been here all our lives," said Debbie Graham, a friend of Ms. Renaud. Mrs. Graham came to the reunion with her husband, John, a loading dock worker at a chemical plant, her young son, Jason, and her mother and father, Hazel and Emerson Melton. "Annette and I went to school together and it was always the kind of thing where if one of us was bad, either mother could handle it."
Jeanette Dozier, who came with her four children and identified her mother as a cousin of Mrs. Stevens's husband, summed it all up: "You have to thank God when you're blessed with this kind of family."

HEADLINE: Quayle Insists Abortion Remarks Don't Signal Change in His View

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 23

 BODY:
Under increasing pressure to prove that he is a political asset, Vice President Dan Quayle found himself on the defensive once again today, this time on abortion, an issue that is central to his appeal to his conservative base.
Mr. Quayle intended to use today's trip to Indiana and Kentucky to shift blame for the country's economic troubles to the Democratic majority in Congress. But much of that message was obscured by the political storm surrounding his comments on Wednesday night that he would support his daughter "on whatever decision she made" if she decided to have an abortion. 
 Mr. Quayle, his wife and his aides all maintained today that the comment did not represent a softening of the Vice President's stance against abortion rights. Mr. Quayle said he had been talking only about a hypothetical situation involving a grown daughter.
Mr. Quayle and his wife, Marilyn, both said today that if their daughter, Corinne, who is 13 years old, became pregnant now, they would insist that she carry the pregnancy to term.
"Under the current situation, she would have the child," Mr. Quayle said at a news conference in Evansville, Ind., the first of two campaign stops. "We are pro-life and we are opposed to abortion."
He said he would support her decision "were she an adult."
"I would counsel her and encourage her not to have an abortion, but I would support my daughter," Mr. Quayle said.
 
Fresh Ammunition
 Mrs. Quayle, interviewed on a radio show in Des Moines today, said that if her daughter became pregnant now "she'll take the child to term." Asked if she would make that decision for her daughter, Mrs. Quayle said, "We will make it with her."
Mr. Quayle's remark about his daughter appeared to provide fresh ammunition for Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and his supporters at a time when the Bush-Quayle campaign is trying to move onto the offensive.
"Sounds like choice to me," said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, a Washington Democrat.
The trouble began during Mr. Quayle's appearance on CNN's "Larry King Live" program on Wednesday night, when Mr. King asked the Vice President how he would react if his daughter was pregnant.
"Well, it is a hypothetical situation and I hope that I never do have to deal with it," Mr. Quayle responded. "I would counsel her and talk to her and support her on whatever decision she made."
Mr. King asked whether he would support her if she decided to have an abortion.
"I'd support my daughter," Mr. Quayle said. "I would hope that she wouldn't make that decision."
Mr. Quayle defended his statement under questioning at both campaign stops today. By the time he landed at the airport in Lexington this afternoon, the abortion issue had become grist for a homemade anti-Quayle campaign poster. "Choice -- Is it only for the families of the powerful and the wealthy?" asked the sign, which was held by a woman in the crowd of several hundred people who greeted Mr. Quayle on the tarmac here.
 
Losing Opportunities
 William Kristol, Mr. Quayle's chief of staff, said, "The only thing that strikes me is the cynicism of the pro-abortion groups in trying to exploit a sincere and personal comment of the Vice President."
Mr. Clinton, speaking to reporters on the way to the Governor's office in Little Rock, Ark., said he did not think he should comment on Mr. Quayle's statement about his daughter. But he added, "I think it reinforces my position that these matters should not be turned back into crimes."
Later, Mr. Clinton said: "My impression is he was asked a question that he was not prepared for, prepped for. He answered it as a father, not a Vice President."
Asked what he would do if his 12-year-old daughter, Chelsea, were pregnant, Mr. Clinton said, "I wouldn't talk to the press about it."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York told reporters today in Albany that Mr. Quayle's remarks on Wednesday night constituted a "classic pro-choice position" because "you can't make a distinction between your own blood and everybody else's daughter."
For Mr. Quayle, the abortion controversy meant yet another suspension of political momentum. He faced a similar problem last month when his offensive on family values stalled after he misspelled the word potato in a New Jersey classroom.
This time, the trouble came at a juncture when Republican leaders, including some members of Congress, have been talking among themselves about whether President Bush should remove Mr. Quayle from the ticket to stop the Republicans' decline in public opinion polls.
 
Support From Abortion Foes
 Mr. Bush said on Wednesday that Mr. Quayle's place on the ticket was "very certain." But the discomfort caused by the polls is likely to focus attention on Mr. Quayle until the Republican National Convention begins in Houston on Aug. 17.
The Republican Party platform, which should be adopted at next month's convention, calls for a constitutional amendment to ban most abortions. Mr. Quayle has long opposed abortion except in cases of rape, incest or when the life of the mother is in danger.
Opponents of legal abortion consider him a more dependable ally than Mr. Bush, whose position on abortion has shifted over time. Aware that Mr. Quayle was in some political trouble, they rallied to his side today.
Mr. Quayle's statements were "consistent with his pro-life views, his role as a parent, and the reality that abortion is legal," said Wanda Franz, the president of the National Right To Life Committee.
Mr. Quayle's trip to his home state of Indiana and then to Kentucky was planned around tours of new subdivisions under construction. He said he wanted to "promote a little good news" by stressing that the weak economy makes it a good time to buy a house.
In a breakfast speech to the Chamber of Commerce in Evansville today Mr. Quayle demonstrated that he could make a joke at his own expense.
Referring to the now-infamous potato incident, Mr. Quayle said he knew how to spell liberal: C-L-I-N-T-O-N.
And in a bit of gallows humor, he joked about his use of the television character Murphy Brown to make the case for family values. "Actually," Mr. Quayle said, "I'm a little envious of Murphy Brown. At least she's guaranteed of coming back this fall."

HEADLINE: REPORT IS CRITICAL OF ESTATE SYSTEM IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
More than four years after a state report found widespread mismanagement and theft in the handling of certain estates in New York City, a follow-up investigation has found that the problems remain largely unabated and in some cases have worsened.
The estates at issue are those in which there was either no will or a will whose terms could not be executed. Thus, they fell under the supervision of public administrators, appointed officials assigned by the Surrogate's Court in each of the city's five boroughs. 
 The new investigation by the State Attorney General and the State Comptroller found problems ranging from long, unnecessary delays in the handling of such estates to public administrators intentionally misinforming the court, to the use of estate funds to pay office and personal expenses, including computers, staff bonuses and automobile insurance. In one case, a draft version of the report said, staff members who had been accused of stealing property from the apartments of people they believed to be dead were allowed to continue work.
 
Unnecessary Fees
 One of those staff members, inspecting a Brooklyn estate valued at more than $1 million, reported finding property worth only $130. The report said that public administrators' investigators suspiciously reported recovering "little or no property from estates of high value."
The report portrayed a kind of feeding frenzy on the estates. In Queens and the Bronx, the report said, an unnecessary 3 percent fee was levied on estates when real estate was sold at public auction to pay brokers who accompany prospective buyers. In Queens and Brooklyn, lawyers who already receive 6 percent commissions on real-estate sales received extra fees.
The report said all five public administrators purchased services on behalf of estates without competitive bidding to assure the lowest price.
As in the past, the findings are expected to be made available to the criminal-justice authorities. Some criminal charges grew out of the last report.
In 1990, the city's five administrators controlled $135.8 million in estates, with Manhattan accounting for the largest share, $81 million.
 
'Little Has Changed'
 "We found that little has changed," the report concluded. "As a result estate assets continue to be at risk."
The draft version of the latest report by the State Attorney General and the State Comptroller concluded that few changes suggested by the last investigation had been adopted.
It also said that, as before, the deficiencies in Manhattan, where the bulk of the big estates were concentrated, "were particularly alarming."
There, the report found, the administrator was "improperly" holding more than $4 million in estate funds in special office accounts under her control. As before, the inquiry found that many cash accounts were so poorly maintained that the office could not say where the money came from or to whom it belonged.
 
Call for Legislation
 The two statewide officials, Attorney General Robert Abrams and Comptroller Edward V. Regan -- a Democrat and a Republican -- renewed their 1987 appeal for legislative changes, including a removal of the public administrators from the sway of the patronage-ridden Surrogate's Court, to which the administrators owe their appointments and before which they practice.
The latest critical report comes as Federal investigators are pressing a separate investigation into operations of the Surrogate's Court, including the public administrators' offices. Yesterday, a politically connected Manhattan lawyer, Melvyn Altman, was indicted on Federal racketeering, mail fraud and money-laundering charges in what the United States Attorney in Manhattan, Otto G. Obermaier, called a continuing investigation that identified the Surrogate's Court as a "racketeering enterprise" used by the defendant.
Many of the sharpest criticisms in the report were directed at the Manhattan Public Administrator, Ethel J. Griffin, who was appointed in 1988 when her predecessor resigned in the wake of the previous revelations.
The report said that by officially reporting to the court "under oath" that the fees had been paid she "misrepresents the actual status of legal-fee payments on sworn court submissions."
Ms. Griffin, in an interview, denied any wrongdoing and said her actions were with the knowledge and approval of the two Surrogates, Eve Preminger and Renee R. Roth.
The draft report did not include responses from the public administrators who received copies months ago. But several of the administrators, reached yesterday by telephone, challenged the findings.
According to the report, legal fees to the lawyers total more than $3 million a year, an amount it termed "excessive." Several hundred thousand dollars go to a few private accountants. All the money comes out of the estates. The report said the same services could be provided more economically by salaried lawyers and accountants.
The report also criticized the administrators for how they invested cash receipts, contending that the administrators deposited the principal and accrued interest from estate accounts into office accounts to pay for things like computer equipment, staff bonuses and personal car insurance.
But one administrator, Samuel Plotkin, from Brooklyn, said in an interview that because he assumed all his other automobile expenses, he was permitted by his surrogate to pay his $1,378 annual car insurance premium out of estate funds.
In some cases, the report said, conditions have worsened since the last review. In 1985, it said, the Manhattan administrator had $1.2 million in "house accounts" for payment of office expenses. By 1990, this had grown to almost $4.2 million.
This practice, it said, had cost estates hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost interest.
In 1989 and 1990, the report said, the deputy public administrator in Manhattan had improperly drawn checks of $750 and $1,200, payable to himself from estate accounts, for staff bonuses.
And it said of its review in Manhattan that it again found that the public administrator "still holds many passbooks belonging to closed estates, does not always attempt to locate beneficiaries and does not submit passbooks to banks with court papers, as required to close accounts."
 
'Questionable Disbursements'
 In Brooklyn, the report said, the office made "a number of questionable disbursements" to an investigator who was later convicted of stealing property from a dead person's residence.
Even after that staff member and another investigator were charged with such thefts, the office did not dismiss, suspend or reassign them, the report said. Instead, the public administrator "allowed them to continue searching residences for one and a half years after their arrests," it said.
Mr. Plotkin, the Brooklyn Administrator, challenged that finding in the interview, saying they were let go. Charges against one were later dropped, he said, and the other had his conviction overturned by an appellate court.
The Bronx Public Administrator, Robert S. Black, criticized the report for unfairly lumping the Bronx, with what he said were fewer shortcomings, with the other boroughs.
The Staten Island Administrator, John D. Kearney, who handled relatively few cases, said he had made some of the changes sought by the state officials.
The Queens Administrator, Mindy Trepel, did not respond to a message left with her office.
 
'No Valid Reasons'
 In Manhattan, the report found some large estates that had languished for decades "with no valid reasons."
It raised particular questions about some of Ms. Griffin's actions in Manhattan, particularly her withholding of 40 percent of the fees of a counsel whose work she was disputing.
The lawyer, John J. Connolly, who is suing the Administrator for what he says is at least $317,000 in fees due, has produced court documents showing that Ms. Griffin put more than $100,000 withheld from him in an account marked "Estate of John J. Connolly" in the Union Chelsea National Bank "although I am alive."
He said he never knew about the account at the time and had never authorized deposits into it. Nor, he said in a sworn deposition, did he ever authorize any payments out of it, as were made to other accounts.
Ms. Griffin said yesterday that "I don't know if he knew or not," but called it an "escrow" account until Mr. Connolly completed his work. She said that she did not know who endorsed the checks to other accounts but that she did not do it.
The Surrogate's Court -- one elected judge in each of the boroughs, except Manhattan, which has two -- appoints guardians for minors and the mentally incapacitated, probates wills and appoints executors in cases where wills are absent or deficient. By its ability to award lucrative appointments, the court has traditionally wielded enormous influence and power.
The surrogate judges also appoint the public administrators, who hire lawyers to oversee the estates under the court's jurisdiction. The lawyers arrange funerals, collect and inventory the decedents' assets and distribute the proceeds to heirs they track down.
For this, the lawyers may charge fees equal to 6 percent of the value of each estate over $10,000 and lesser fees for smaller estates. The administrators also take a sliding scale of commissions for their office expenses from each estate administered.
In the 1990 fiscal year, the latest year studied, the administrators' offices received a total of $1.5 million from the estates.
