HEADLINE: ISRAELIS CALL OFF FUTURE DWELLINGS IN OCCUPIED LANDS

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 23

 BODY:
Israel's new Government stopped all planned construction for Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today, but said thousands of apartments and houses already started would be completed.
The decision means that more than 8,700 new housing units in progress will be built in the territories while nearly 6,700 that were on the drawing boards will be frozen. Those include many for which construction contracts were signed but real work not begun. 
 It was the most politically sensitive action taken thus far by the young Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, and obviously it fell well short of Arab demands for a complete building freeze.
 
West Bank Roads Halted
 In principle it also flies in the face of the Bush Administration's opposition to Israel's settlement activity as a major obstacle to peace. Although the Americans have spoken approvingly of Mr. Rabin for moving in the desired direction, it is not clear how they will react to the large numbers of new houses that will be finished
In addition to freezing future housing plans, Israel also halted work on several West Bank highways defined by senior officials as "political roads," designed by the former Government to help settlers avoid routes along which they risked attacks by Palestinians.
The 8,700 units given the go-ahead are now in various stages of construction, from little more than a hole in the ground to, far more commonly, near-completion. Senior officials say a large majority are either in the final stages or well beyond merely a framework.
 
Shamir Assails 'a Nightmare'
 The Government also did not touch 1,000 new apartments planned for areas around Jerusalem that Mr. Rabin, like his predecessor, Yitzhak Shamir, considers an integral part of Israel and not negotiable.
The action today left Israelis unhappy on the political left and right.
Mr. Shamir said the announced freeze was "a nightmare," and Benny Katzover, head of a settlers' group called the Samaria Regional Council, denounced it as "a grave anti-Zionist act."
There were calls for protests and unspecified forms of resistance from some of the 110,000 Jews estimated to be living in 140 West Bank and Gaza communities.
On the left, Peace Now, a prominent anti-settlements organization, said that by allowing thousands of apartments to be completed, the Government would increase the settlers' population by about 50,000, in the process "adding an obstacle to talks toward an agreement with the Palestinians."
It was not feasible to stop existing work in its tracks at this stage, Israeli officials said, asserting that the important point was that they had begun to shift national direction on the issue.
In separate interviews, the new Finance Minister and Housing Minister said that their goal was a sharp and swift scaling back of future settlement-building, and that that would be reflected in their 1993 budget proposal.
"I would say the investment will be negligible in proportion to what was before," Finance Minister Avraham Shohat said.
It is now up to the United States to decide whether the Israeli actions amount to the glass being half full or half empty if Washington intends to give Israel $10 billion in loan guarantees that have been suspended for months because of friction over the settlements.
Housing Minister Binyamin Ben-Eliezer said Mr. Rabin had told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d about the planned housing restrictions when the Secretary visited Israel early this week at the start of his latest swing through the Middle East.
In Cairo on Wednesday, Mr. Baker pronounced himself "really very satisfied with the philosophy and the orientation" of the Rabin Government on settlements, and he predicted "a severe and substantial reduction" in construction.
Earlier, in Amman, Jordan, he said that he did not accept Mr. Rabin's distinctions between "political settlements," which the Israeli promises to end, and "security settlements," which he says must continue. But the Americans have strongly suggested that they are interested in bolstering Mr. Rabin's 10-day-old Government, and may be ready to turn a blind eye to a certain level of construction.
"We see an entirely new situation," Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said today on the NBC program "Today." Mr. Peres also expressed confidence that a loan-guarantees agreement will be reached, saying, "We feel the air is very favorable."
In the last few days, Palestinian peace negotiators from the territories have also begun to adjust their settlements position. They still want a freeze, they say, but they have also expressed willingness to accept some construction as long as there are assurances that no American aid ends up financing such activity.
Although Jewish neighborhoods in the territories are routinely referred to as "settlements," the word can be misleading. For many people it conjures up visions of tent cities and messianic pioneers. In fact, many -- perhaps most -- are indistinguishable from red-roofed suburbs in Israel.
And the settlers, far from having gleams in their eye, are often families and young couples initially lured to the territories by the lower prices and favorable mortgages to be found there.
Mr. Rabin and his ministers insist that they are not kowtowing to the Americans but rather are shifting national priorities on their own away from settlements and toward other social and economic needs.
In addition, Mr. Ben-Eliezer said, the intense construction championed by the former Likud-led Government amounted to an "undeclared annexation" of the territories that in his opinion endangered the peace talks.
The new settlements policy has emerged in stages over the last week, relying in part on gestures like a Cabinet order last weekend to review previous Government decisions to approve about a dozen new communities in the territories. On paper, it looked like a new freeze. In fact, the order lacked immediate significance because even Likud had not found the wherewithal to start those settlements.

HEADLINE: 2d Big Bank Sets I.O.U. Deadline For California

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23

 BODY:
California's budget crisis deepened today when the Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank and the biggest in the state, said that on Aug. 5 it would stop accepting the i.o.u.'s the state has been issuing employees and other creditors while Gov. Pete Wilson and legislators fight over the $11 billion deficit.
Later, Wells Fargo Bank, the state's second-largest bank, reiterated its position that it would stop accepting the i.o.u.'s, or "registered warrants," dated after July 31. 
 After the two announcements, a smaller bank, the Union Bank of San Francisco, said that it would also stop acceping i.o.u.'s dated after July 31.
Several of the state's smaller banks have said that they would either not accept the i.o.u.'s or limit the amount they would honor.
"It is very unfortunate for the entire State of California that this situation developed at all," Richard M. Rosenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of America, said in a prepared statement. "In essence, the banks are funding the crisis -- serving as a shock absorber for the budget process."
Bank officials said the Bank of America had accepted about $220 million of the $892.4 million worth of i.o.u.'s that California has issued. State officials said California had paid about $10 million in interest since the beginning of July.
Bankers have become increasingly unhappy with their role in the budget crisis in recent weeks and have quietly been applying more pressure for a quick end to it.
 
Facing $10 Billion Deficit
 California ran out of cash on July 1, as the fiscal year ended, and State Controller Gray Davis sent out the first of 12,000 i.o.u.'s after the Democratic-controlled Assembly failed to reach agreement with the Republican Governor on how to erase a $10.7 billion deficit in the new state budget.
Although the i.o.u.'s pay 5 percent annual interest to banks that accept them, bankers have grumbled that they are not profitable because they present an administrative nightmare and require extra hours for processing.
Officials at First Interstate Bank said that they would continue to honor the i.o.u.'s from their customers but that they would monitor the crisis day by day.
Mr. Davis proposed a short term plan to pay back $922 million in i.o.u.'s on Wednesday, saying his office would begin redeeming them on Aug. 3 with money that the state had saved from payments it is not making during the budget crisis.
But banking industry officials said the Controller's action would only delay a resolution of the budget impasse. "This may just prolong the whole crisis," said Nancy Badely, a spokeswoman for the California Bankers Association. "The banks are being put in a tough position."
At the Bank of Walnut Creek, in a suburb east of San Francisco, officials said that they had placed a $10,000 limit on i.o.u.'s its bank would accept and that they are reviewing higher amounts case by case. "I don't want to turn down the poor clerk who works at the Department of Motor Vehicles," said Leland Wines, the bank's chief financial officer. "That person depends on the warrants to pay their mortgage or their groceries."
Since the state began issuing i.o.u.'s -- for the first time since the Depression -- the crisis has had a variety of adverse effects. Standard & Poor's Corporation stunned the municipal bond market last week by lowering its ratings on debt securities issued by the State of California by two notches, to A+ from AA.
State officials said they were concerned that more delay in agreeing on a budget would further damage the state's credit rating and cause serious harm to the California economy.
"This will have a domino effect on the economic health of businesses and individuals in California," said State Treasurer Kathleen Brown. "The consequences aren't like an earthquake; they are much more subtle and long term."
Ms. Brown said her office had already been forced to hire nine staff members to help process the i.o.u.'s and had logged 3,800 hours of overtime since July 1.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Delta Air Lines lost $180.2 million for its fourth quarter, and said it would reduce its work force of 80,000 by 5 percent. The loss followed poor performances by other domestic airlines. [Page D1.]
Digital Equipment lost $1.85 billion, including a $1.5 billion charge to cover further reductions in personnel and operations. The loss was one of the largest in computer industry history. [D3.] 
 Exxon's profits fell 15.1 percent, while Texaco's slipped 8.9 percent, Occidental's plunged 49 percent and Ashland Oil's tumbled 52.2 percent. [D2.]
Salomon earnings climbed 18.5 percent to $211 million in the second quarter, underscoring the firm's renewed vigor almost a year after the Treasury market scandal. [D3.]
McDonald's earnings rose 9.5 percent to $254.1 million, reflecting cost cuts, marketing efforts and strong sales overseas. [D3.]
Euro Disney said it would lose money this year, retreating from the rosy optimism of its opening on April 12. [D3.]
LTV said Loral intended to buy its missile business, in a joint move with Thomson-CSF of France. [D3.]
Warren E. Buffett has 14.9 percent of General Dynamics' 4.35 million shares, as a result of Berkshire Hathaway purchases. [D3.]
Mattel named Jill Elikann Barad president and chief operating officer. She had headed the girls and activity-toys division. [D2.]
The Times of London named Peter Stothard as editor, succeeding Simon Jenkins, who will return to writing. [D4.]
 
International
Prime Minister Miyazawa of Japan summoned leaders to an emergency meeting to try to halt the stock market skid. [D1.]
Boris N. Yeltsin has only a layman's knowledge of economics, as did Franklin D. Roosevelt. Yet like F.D.R. he is presiding over a historic economic reorganization. [D1.]
 
The Economy
The House passed a bill to re-regulate cable TV prices, setting the stage for a confrontation with President Bush. [D4.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Deficit Politics;
White House Prods Congress on Deficit

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
In a midyear recalculation apparently motivated by election-year as much as economic considerations, the White House asserted today that President Bush's economic program could eliminate the Federal deficit by 1998 if Congress were to pass it.
The revision comes only six months after President Bush sent Congress a budget projecting the deficit's being reduced to $200 billion a year in five years' time. In Mr. Bush's tenure, the deficit has doubled, to about $350 billion a year, from $155 billion in 1988; in the month that he took office, the Administration forecast that the deficit would be just $32 billion this fiscal year. 
 The new projection is based on Congress's approving a cap on Medicare and other entitlement programs and passing Mr. Bush's economic proposals. The White House said the cap on entitlements would bring 1998 spending down by $169 billion, while the economic package, including a long-sought cut in the capital gains tax, could spur growth enough to reduce the deficit by another $104 billion in 1998.
The budget document said the cap would limit spending increases on mandatory programs to the inflation rate and population growth plus 2 percent in the first year. In the second year it would be inflation, population growth plus 1 percent, and in subsequent years it would limit spending increases to inflation and population growth.
 
Harsh Words for Congress
 As he presented the new figures, Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, castigated Congress for not acting yet. In a seeming effort to shift the blame for the stumbling economy, which has badly hurt Mr. Bush's re-election prospects, he declared, "Over all, Congressional inaction has made the deficit very much worse than it would have been had the President's program been enacted.
In the document itself, the Administration revised its growth forecast for this year to 2.7 percent, up from 2.2 percent in January, right after the fourth quarter when growth had virtually stopped. Today's forecast, which projects growth of 3 percent in the second half of the year, is in line with that of most economists, as the January forecast had been.
The Administration predicted that the unemployment rate would fall from its current 7.8 percent to 6.9 percent in the fourth quarter. The forecast is more optimistic than that of many economists, but Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said the projection was made before June's sharp jump in unemployment. Mr. Boskin said that if he were making the calculation today, he would estimate a jobless figure of 7.1 percent at year's end.
"We've been in a slow recovery for some time," said Mr. Boskin. "We do expect that to pick up some. And the probability that it will pick up some and the pace that it will pick up some would be enhanced substantially by passage of the President's short-term stimulus program."
The White House also revised its 1992 deficit projection, to $333.5 billion, down $66.2 billion from the January estimate of $399.7 billion.
The main reason, Mr. Darman said, is the refusal of Congress to pass an anticipated $69 billion to bail out failed savings-and-loan institutions. Economists say such spending will merely be pushed into future years, and that the delay could increase the cost of the savings-and-loan problem.
"Congress has failed to act in a timely and responsible manner," Mr. Darman said.
Alice Rivlin, an economist at the Brookings Institution who was director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1975 to 1983, said that while the White House program over all sounds simple and straightforward, "it doesn't tell you anything about how you do it."
"One thing it has to mean is drastic cuts in Medicare and Medicaid, because those are the programs where spending is growing the fastest," she said.
 
'An Act of Faith'
 Mr. Darman also asserted that passage of the President's growth package would help push up growth. His report added that annual growth of 4 percent would be needed for several years to balance the budget in 1998.
Ms. Rivlin countered: "It would be nice to have 4 percent growth, but the connection between anything in the growth package and 4 percent growth is an act of faith.
The Mid-Sesson Review, as the document released today is known, was 421 pages long. Last year's review was a more traditional 55 pages. This year's version contained hundreds of pages of proposals from the budget the President sent Congress in January, including ones to beef up research and development and improve education.
Democrats expect the Administration to use today's report to argue that it has a more comprehensive economic program than the 22-page program Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas issued last month. "The mid-year economic report is more of the samae trickle-down economics from the White House," Governor Clinton, the Democratic nominee, said in a statement. "Instead of a serious and constructive plan for economic change, the President has recycled his old and meager tax package and sought once again to blame Congress for his failed leadership."
Administration officials say that over the next few weeks they will press Congress to enact the President's economic proposals, which include a tax credit for first-time home buyers and the capital gains tax cut.
President Bush outlined a seven-point economic program in his State of the Union Message in January, calling on Congress to pass those proposals by March 20. Congress ceremoniously met the deadline, but the economic package, while including several of the President's proposals, also included tax increases, and he vetoed it.
Democrats reacted angrily today to Mr. Darman's attacks. "Under 12 years of Republican rule, we have the largest deficits, the worst growth record, the longest recessions and biggest declines in middle-class incomes in the post-World War II era," Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, declared.
Meanwhile, Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, introduced a bill that would obligate the President and Congress to eliminate the deficit within five years. If a balanced budget is not approved, tax increases and across-the-board spending cuts, including Social Security, would automatically take effect.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael J. Boskin, left, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, during the presentation of the Administration's midyear budget review. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Clinton's Policy Test;
On Accord With Mexico, He Can Be Free-Trader or Critic of the President

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
The trade agreement the Bush Administration is about to conclude with Mexico will present Gov. Bill Clinton with one of his first important policy decisions of the general election campaign.
If he endorses the agreement, he will alienate labor unions, some environmentalists and other legs of his political base. But he will be praised by most academic experts and business interests and will burnish his argument that economic growth is the most important issue in the campaign. 
 Mr. Clinton must decide, in short, whether it is to his advantage to close off an area of debate with President Bush and paint himself as an enlightened free-trader, or whether it would be better for him to seize the opportunity to attack the President's competence and say, "I could negotiate a better deal."
 
Clinton Able to Buy Time
 Until now, Mr. Clinton has been able to buy time, saying he believes in free trade in principle while withholding judgment on the pact with Mexico until he sees the details -- particularly the ones involving labor standards and environmental protection.
Few people doubt that in the long run an effective trade agreement would promote economic growth, jobs and wealth throughout the continent, allow consumers to buy a greater variety of goods at lower prices and help solve the problem of illegal immigration into the United States from Mexico.
But there is also little question that some communities and some people would be hurt at first. Some American businesses will surely move their operations and jobs to Mexico to take advantage of cheap labor and lax pollution rules.
What is being discussed is an agreement and not a treaty. That means it must be approved by a simple majority of both houses of Congress rather than a two-thirds majority of the Senate.
The negotiations are likely to be concluded this fall, if not before, but Congress will not vote until next year. Many of Mr. Clinton's advisers say that allows him to continue to straddle the issue. But others say it is too important a matter for him to dodge.
The top trade negotiators from the United States, Mexico and Canada will resume talks in Mexico City this weekend.
Many of Mr. Bush's political advisers say it is important that the trade negotiations, which have been under way for more than a year, are completed before the Republican National Convention begins on Aug. 17.
"One of the points we are trying to drive home is that there are domestic benefits to Bush's skills in foreign affairs, and this would be exhibit No. 1," an adviser said.
The Bush campaign also relishes the issue because it puts Mr. Clinton on the spot. If Mr. Clinton sides with the Administration, the Republicans can accuse him of me-tooism. If he opposes the agreement, the Bush camp will paint the Democrat as a tool of the labor unions -- a lobby the Republicans believe is politically unpopular in most places of the country.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, the California Democrat who sits on the trade subcommittee and favors the North American Free Trade Agreement, said he thought Mr. Clinton "in good conscience could say, 'I want to reserve judgment because I may want to reopen the negotiations once I become President.' "
But one of the Democratic candidate's chief economic advisers said he thought Mr. Clinton would have to take a firm stand because he could not afford to have the Republicans accuse him of dodging an issue involving economic growth.
 
Clue to Clinton's Thoughts
 A clue to Mr. Clinton's thoughts may lie in a speech to be delivered on Monday by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader and an important Democratic voice on labor issues. Until now, Mr. Gephardt's public position has been the same as Mr. Clinton's -- that he was withholding a commitment until he saw how labor and environmental standards were handled.
Unlike Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gephardt has had official access to details of the agreement that have already been settled. He has told associates that he will say in his speech that the drafts he has seen do not meet his criteria for supporting the agreement.
Mr. Gephardt campaigned in St. Louis with Mr. Clinton on Wednesday. The prevailing view among Democrats is that Mr. Gephardt would not take such a public stance on the trade agreement unless he had cleared it first with Mr. Clinton. But some Democrats say they believe Mr. Gephardt might be trying to make the point that he is an independent power who will not be hidden by Mr. Clinton's shadow.
Political positions on trade matters tend to break along regional lines rather than partisan ones.
 
Strongest Supporters
 The strongest supporters are in the states along the Mexican border. A free-trade pact would allow businesses there to offer more goods and services to the Mexican market. And growth in the Mexican economy would mean that fewer immigrants would try to cross the border illegally. When the House of Representatives voted last year to allow Mr. Bush to negotiate with Mexico, 23 of Texas's 27 House members supported the President.
So Mr. Bush would probably be helped in California and Texas by a dispute with Mr. Clinton over trade with Mexico.
But he might be hurt in the Midwest, where the fear of lost jobs is greatest. During the Democratic primaries, support for former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California surged in Michigan and Wisconsin because of his opposition to the trade pact. The official position of Mr. Clinton's campaign is that he will decide how to respond once he sees the details of the final agreement.
Asked if he expected a response from Mr. Clinton soon, a Democratic Senator said: "Right in the middle of a Presidential campaign? Sure."

HEADLINE: Kidnapping and 'Taxes' Transform Guerrilla Inc.

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, July 23

 BODY:
Hunched over computers confiscated from a guerrilla group here, detectives recently discovered a surprising electronic file: a list of 239 Peruvian businessmen forced to contribute "war taxes" and a directory of 2,500 additional candidates for extortion or kidnapping.
With the collapse of the Soviet Union and the near-bankruptcy of Cuba, South America's orphaned guerrilla groups survive by honing their skills at local fund-raising. Several groups in Peru and Colombia might rightfully be named "Guerrilla Inc." And the sophistication of their intelligence-gathering apparatus testifies to the seriousness of their pursuits, with some keeping detailed files on the finances, personal lives and movements of local executives. 
 "The guerrillas lose their ideological coloring and become a bureaucracy," said Gene Mastroangelo, manager of risk information service at Pinkerton's Security and Investigation Services in Van Nuys, Calif., which tracks politically inspired incidents around the world and advises companies on such risks. "They take on a corporate structure and have to finance it."
In Colombia, guerrillas are considered responsible for a third of the 375 kidnappings that took place in the first three months of 1992. In the last year, multinational companies paid guerrilla ransoms for the release of one American geologist, two Japanese engineers and three American oil engineers. Natco, an oil services company in Tulsa, is reported to have paid $1 million for the release of the three engineers.
The guerrillas' refusal to release 300 kidnapping victims -- largely ranchers and rural businessmen -- was a big reason that peace talks with Colombia's Government broke down in June.
Originally supplied by Cuba, Colombia's two main guerrilla groups, the National Liberation Army and the Revolutionary Armed Forces, have been fighting the state for more than 25 years. Today, to keep their fighters fed, clothed and armed, the groups extort "war taxes" from rural businesses and provide armed guards for cocaine laboratories and plots of opium poppies.
In Chile, police officers investigating the arrest this week of two central committee members of the Lautaro Youth Movement, a leftist guerrilla group, announced that the pair received salaries five times Chile's minimum monthly salary of $100, a level that allowed the urban guerrilla leaders' families to maintain middle-class life-styles.
 
Double Drag on Peru's Economy
 In Peru, guerrilla activity by the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement and by the more radical Shining Path cost Peru's economy about $500 million in the first half of 1992, according to Senator Enrique Bernales, who tracks the human and financial cost of the violence. In a second drag on the economy, guerrilla violence is frightening foreign investors away from an ambitious Government plan to privatize most of Peru's state enterprises, from telephone companies to copper mines.
A recent series of police raids against the Tupac Amaru here laid bare the modern financing techniques of this largely middle class, pro-Cuban guerrilla group.
Cellular telephones, facsimile and photocopying machines, American and South Korean computers, and a basement "people's jail" in a comfortable neighborhood were all part of a smoothly efficient Tupac Amaru kidnapping and extortion operation uncovered by the police.
"They had files on most Peruvian businessmen, where they lived, where they worked, where their children studied," said Julio Favre Carranza, a leader here of business resistance to extortion demands. According to Mr. Favre's group, the Confederation of Peruvian Industries, companies here spend more than $150 million a year on security protection against terrorists.
Working on a tip from a Lima businessman forced to pay Tupac Amaru "war taxes," the police on April 15 arrested Peter Cardenas Schulte. Described as operations director for the guerrillas, Mr. Cardenas had $237,500 in United States currency in his apartment at the time of his arrest.
In June, the police arrested the group's top leader, Victor Polay Campos, while he was dining in a restaurant in an upper-middle-class neighborhood here. The police have issued an international warrant for the arrest of the group's financial director, Maria Luisa Benza Pflucker, who may have fled to the Netherlands, her mother's native land.
 Studying documents and more than 50 computer diskettes seized at Optimisa S.R.L., a front company run by Miss Benza, detectives pieced together details of a well-organized kidnapping and extortion ring.
"We found information relating to economic and financial movements, company directories, addresses and telephone numbers of different public and private businesses -- all designed to be used for extortion and blackmail for subversive activity," said a spokesman for Peru's National Anti-Terrorism Police Directorate.
The police said that bank clerks either sold or supplied free of charge financial and personal information about bank executives and holders of large accounts. Police officials found photo albums filled with newspaper clippings and snapshots of potential kidnapping victims. A small library of private school yearbooks provided more photos and residential addresses of potential victims.
Studying computer printouts, anti-terrorist police officers said that the 239 companies that regularly paid "war taxes" included mining companies, pharmaceutical makers, soft drink bottlers and printers. To prevent double billing by common criminals, Peru's guerrilla extortionists gave printed receipts, which they call "war bonds."
The police speculate that the Tupac Amaru hid millions of dollars in overseas accounts. But when a judge in late June asked Mr. Polay to list his assets, the guerrilla leader responded defiantly, "All I own in the world are the clothes on my back."
 
 
Grenades and Phony Passports
 At one news conference here, the police displayed materials purchased with extortion money: falsified passports and passes for official cars, immigration stamps, infrared binoculars for night vision, sophisticated radios, pistols, grenades, antitank weapons and ammunition for automatic weapons. The police said they also found plans to dynamite the Camino Real, Lima's largest shopping center and the site of several multinational companies' local offices.
Peru's more radical guerrilla group, the Shining Path, is thought to finance its activities through the collection of as much as $40 million a year in "war taxes" from Peruvian coca leaf growers and Colombian cocaine traffickers.
In early July, the anti-terrorist police released a document that they said was seized during a recent raid on a Shining Path cell in Lima. According to this document, the Shining Path committee in Peru's principal coca leaf-growing area, the Upper Huallaga Valley, promised to turn over to the party half of the protection money raised from coca leaf growers and laboratory operators.
Addressing landing fees collected from planes arriving from Colombia, the documents' signers promised to devote 5 percent to the maintenance of airstrips and to deliver the rest to the central committee of the Shining Path, formally known as the Communist Party of Peru.
 
 
Big Profits From Drugs
 Analyzing this and other documents, Caretas magazine, Peru's largest-selling news weekly, estimated this month that the Shining Path earned $250 million from the drug trade over the last six years. The magazine speculated that most of the money had been spent on domestic operations or had been deposited in overseas accounts.
Recognizing that continued terrorism is preventing Peru's economic revival, President Alberto K. Fujimori issued an emergency decree in May that establishes life sentences for most major terrorist crimes.
But with guerrillas firmly established as extortionists in the public mind, businessmen are now plagued by freelancers trying to piggyback on the guerrillas' fearsome reputation.
In Peru's second-largest city, Arequipa, the police in late June freed a kidnapped textile executive, breaking up a gang that had extorted "war taxes" from local businesses since 1985. These "guerrillas" turned out to include one active-duty policeman and two retired police officers. Their leader, Carlos Corso Portocarrero, was a well-known businessman who frequented the city's most exclusive club, Club Arequipa, apparently to select his victims.

(Daniel Cox)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Newspapers Start To Rebuild Profits

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
SECOND-QUARTER earnings reports from newspaper companies paint a picture that seems so rosy as to be hot pink.
For instance, the Gannett Company's earnings per share increased 13 percent; net income at The Washington Post Company was up 35 percent; Knight-Ridder Inc. reported an 11 percent increase in earnings; net income at The New York Times Company jumped to $15.2 million from $5.4 million, and Dow Jones & Company said net income for the quarter rose 25 percent. 
 But while such solid increases may suggest a return to the fat and happy newspaper profits of the mid-1980's, they actually reflect a toughened industry able to wring profits out of a business environment that is still flat.
In most cases, the profit increases come from significantly reduced newsprint costs, bare-bones cost controls and advertising rate increases.
For many newspaper companies, advertising volume -- the key indicator of the industry's fiscal health -- actually decreased for the quarter compared with a year earlier.
And the quarter's profit gains, though certainly welcome, represent only a first step in recovering ground lost during the last several years.
"The best way to show strong earnings growth is to climb out of a deep hole," said John Morton, a newspaper industry analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington. "We're trying to get back to 1990's earnings levels, for God's sake, and 1990 wasn't a great year."
Indeed, in advertising linage, many papers would be pleased to get back to 1991's weak level. Advertising at The Washington Post fell 3.8 percent for the quarter, compared with a year earlier. Advertising for The New York Times declined 2.4 percent, and total linage for the Gannett chain declined 1 percent, though USA Today's linage increased 3 percent.
Analysts said display advertising, like that from department stores, continued to be depressed, reflecting the slow economic recovery.
In most areas, help-wanted classified advertising has also showed little improvement, because hiring usually lags behind any recovery, as companies generally prefer to pay overtime until they are certain a recovery is under way.
Among the few bright spots has been automotive advertising, because the American passion for new cars is usually one of the first cravings to be satisfied when consumers have money to spend. In some areas, a second passion -- home buying -- has led to more vigorous real estate advertising, particularly in the Midwest and South.
But in general, newspapers have raised advertising revenues through rate increases, a move that probably demonstrates the essential strength of the industry better than anything else.
For two decades, most newspapers raised their advertising rates every year, generally by a percentage higher than the rate of inflation, and advertisers were willing to pay the price because newspapers were regarded as the best way to reach a community's consumers.
In the last couple of years, newspapers have become more timid about raising rates for fear that advertisers would defect to other media, like direct mail and cable television, or significantly reduce the newspaper advertising they would buy.
This year, newspapers have generally gone back to raising their rates somewhat more than the inflation rate. And though this has hurt advertising volume, overall advertising revenues are generally higher.
Kevin R. Gruneich, an analyst of newspaper stocks at the First Boston Corporation, said newspapers generally increased rates by 4 to 5 percent this year. He noted that the inflation rate was expected to be about 3 percent.
"Newspapers are still dominant as to local print media, and there is still no better place to put help-wanted ads or an ad for a sale at a big retailer," Mr. Gruneich said.
Should the economy improve, increased advertising volume would probably follow, and the new advertising would be purchased at the higher rate.
But such a potential windfall would be offset somewhat by higher newsprint costs, as more paper would be needed to print the ads and as increased demand would undoubtedly prompt newsprint companies to increase their very depressed prices.
Mr. Gruneich estimates that newsprint is selling at a discount of about 40 percent from the list price of $685 per metric ton.
Newsprint companies had announced that they would raise rates Aug. 1 by about $35 a ton, but such an increase now seems unlikely.
Labor negotiations this summer at the newsprint mills in British Columbia had been expected to reduce the oversupply of newsprint, creating a chance for newsprint companies in the United States to make a price increase stick. But the negotiations were concluded earlier this month and the prospects of a shortfall have declined.
This means that any increase in newsprint costs will probably be driven by increased demand, which in turn will be prompted by more advertising. And if advertising increases, newspapers will be delighted to pay for the added newsprint.
Newspaper stock prices, which moved sharply higher earlier this year, have since leveled off. Yesterday, Gannett was up 12.5 cents, to $46.25; The Washington Post Company was up $1, to $220.50; Knight-Ridder was unchanged at $60.875; The New York Times Company was up 37.5 cents, to $28, and Dow Jones was up 50 cents, to $33.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Weak Economic Data Lift Treasuries

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Another jolt from more pessimistic economic data gave the bond market a strong lift yesterday, pushing the price of the 30-year bond up almost a point and bringing long-term yields down toward the levels of January.
The rally also provided some needed support for a difficult issue of notes from the Tennessee Valley Authority and may provide a good background for a first-of-its-kind issue by the American Express Company that will be priced today. 
 The impetus for the rally, which sharply raised the value of notes and bonds with maturities of five years and longer, was the unexpected report that initial unemployment claims jumped by 19,000 in the week ended July 11. The surge in claims was the largest since December and higher than most forecasts, some of which assumed a decline.
 
More Sluggish Signals
 The claims data and incomplete numbers on weekly auto sales added to a recent string of data showing that the recovery, if it is there at all, is very slow. This means there is no threat of rising inflation and, possibly, still another reduction in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
"This is confirmation that we are in an atypical recovery that will be weak for some time," said Joseph Liro, senior vice president at S. G. Warburg & Company in New York. "This is not the kind of growth that will put any pressure on inflation."
James S. Fralick, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said, "The July data are still on the soft side, and it won't be until August that we may see any activity."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds were offered at a price of 105 15/32, up 31/32, to yield 7.53 percent.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 6 3/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 10 17/32, up 27/32, to yield 6.15 percent. The 7.5 percent 10-year note was offered at 105 22/32, up 31/32, to yield 6.69 percent.
Three- and six-month Treasury bills were unchanged, while the one-year bill declined slightly. In the auction for one-year bills, the average discount rates was 3.37 percent, down sharply from the 3.93 percent at the last auction on June 25. The drop reflects the impact of the cut the Federal Reserve made in both its discount rate and the Federal Funds rate at the beginning of July.
 
Bolster T.V.A. Issue
 The sudden rally on Wednesday and yesterday apparently gave a nice lift to the underwriters of $1.25 billion in Tennessee Valley Authority notes that were issued Tuesday and were not selling briskly.
The 7- and 10-year notes were priced at relatively narrow spreads over the comparable Treasury securities, making the deal very attractive to the T.V.A. but apparently not that attractive to investors.
Several underwriters involved in the deal said the issue did not move well on Tuesday.
But the rally in the market meant that the difference between the interest rate offered on the T.V.A. notes and comparable Treasury securities widened sharply in the last two days, making them much more attractive.
"It would have gone well despite the rally," said a trader at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the lead underwriter. "It is a matter of timing, but with a rally like this the bonds sell faster."
In late trading yesterday, both issues were selling at 98.875. When they were issued, the price was 98.47 for the 7-year note and 98.585 for the 10-year note. The 7-year note yielded 6.45 percent, about 29 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than the comparable Treasury security. The 10-year note yielded 7.03 percent, about 24 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury. When issued, the 7-year note yielded 15 basis points over Treasuries, and the 10-year notes were 19 basis points over Treasuries.
 
American Express Offering
 The rally could also help the reception for the $1 billion in five- and seven-year notes that American Express is offering. And it will lessen American Express's cost. The notes, which are expected to be priced today, are the first ever issued that are backed by the payments of charge card bills. In the past, such asset-backed offerings were backed by credit card receipts -- cards that charged interest on outstanding balances.
One key in the design of this security was compensating for the fact that the American Express green, gold and platinum charge cards do not have finance charges. In a security backed by a credit card, the revenue from the finance charge provides a cushion for investors against larger-than-expected defaults or nonpayment by card users.
In this new issue, in which the lead underwriter is American Express's own Lehman Brothers unit, the fund to back the securities is designed so that 3 percent of every dollar is set aside in a way that makes it similar to the flow of money from a finance charge.
Based on talk in the market yesterday, the negotiated deal for the five- year note should be priced about 42 to 44 basis points more than the five-year Treasury note, which was yielding 5.58 percent in late trading in the secondary market yesterday. The seven-year note was expected to be priced at 45 to 47 basis points more than the seven-year Treasury, which yielded 6.15 percent late yesterday.
As the rally in the Treasury market continued yesterday afternoon, the Bush Administration, as part of its midyear economic review, released an estimate for the budget deficit for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. The revision cut the estimate by $65.5 billion, to $333 billion.
While traders said the market showed little reaction, the decline in Government borrowing should be positive for bonds because it would decrease the supply.
The Federal Reserve money supply figures released near the close of trading also seemed to have little impact. The $3.6 billion decline in M-1 and the $2.5 billion drop in M-2, after sharp increases in the previous week, were a little disappointing, Mr. Fralick said, because they did not fall more.

HEADLINE: Stocks Up; Dow Gains 12.43 Points

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed moderately higher yesterday in listless trading as investors combed through earnings reports looking for fresh direction.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 12.43 points at 3,290.04 after hitting a low of 3,267 and a high of 3,291. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange slipped to 180.1 million shares, from 190.1 million on Wednesday. Issues that advanced outnumbered those that declined by 962 to 758.
The stock market's performance stood in sharp contrast to bonds, which surged on a higher-than-expected weekly jobless claims report. Claims posted a rise to 422,000, from a revised 403,000 the previous week.
The Treasury's benchmark long-bond rose 31/32 to 105.13, pushing its yield to a seven-month low of 7.54 percent, from 7.62 percent on Wednesday.
The weak jobless report, suggesting the economy is still crippled, stirred hope of lower interest rates, which would make bonds a more attractive investment.
But over all, the stock market's interest was muted, said Jon Groveman, president of Ladenburg Thalmann.
 
Investors Seek Direction
 "People don't know whether to react to the strength in bonds or the potential weakness in the economy," he said.
Politics were also playing havoc with the market, analysts said.
Gerald Simmons, manager of institutional trading at Interstate/Johnson Lane, said investors were worried about earnings, the election and the possibility of war with Iraq.
"I think portfolio managers are really looking for direction: Is it growth or cyclicals or will we continue this slide?" he said.
Strength in oil stocks, including Exxon and Texaco, gave blue chips a leg up after the energy giants reported earnings that were roughly in line with Wall Street projections, analysts said.
Exxon closed up 1, to 63. The nation's biggest oil company said earnings slipped because of lower profits on refined petroleum products.
Texaco, the No. 3 oil company, said it too had lower profits than a year ago. Texaco rose 1, to 63 1/2.
Jack Solomon, a Bear Stearns technical analyst, said the stock market was showing signs of trying to stabilize. He also noted the broader market had been improving.
"Within a week or so, we should see the bottom," he said. "Then we should start the summer rally."
 He said it was encouraging that the Dow industrials did not match the performance of the Dow transportation index, which fell 1.15 points, to 1,269.74.
Among other stocks, shares of Immunex added 1 3/4, to 34 3/4. The company settled suits with the Hoechst A.G. affiliates Behringwerke A.G. and Hoechst-Roussel.
Monsanto lost 1 1/2, to 54 1/2, after reporting second-quarter results.
The stock of General Dynamics rose 1 3/4, to 75 5/8. Berkshire Hathaway acquired 15 percent of the company.
Shares of a new issue, Pyxis, topped the Nasdaq volume list. It ended at 18 1/8 after being priced at 14.
Surgical Care Affiliates slumped 2, to 28, after releasing second-quarter results.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.15, to 412.08. The American Stock Exchange index fell 0.67, to 382.50.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.53, to 226.66.
The average share rose 8 cents.
The Nasdaq index rose 1.36, to 565.24. The Wilshire Associates Equity Index, the market value of Big Board, American Exchange and Nasdaq issues, was 3,969.783, up 8.909, or 0.22 percent.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Benefit Claims Rose Sharply in Early July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose sharply in early July, the Government said today. The increase will make anything more than a minimal improvement in the unemployment rate unlikely this month.
The Labor Department said initial jobless claims for the week that ended July 11 hit 422,000, up from 403,000 the week before. 
 It was the largest rise since late February and the level of claims was at its highest since the week that ended on May 2.
Economists had been expecting a smaller increase but cautioned against reading a great deal into weekly fluctuations in the claims number. Still, they said, it suggested there was little prospect of an immediate improvement in the nation's unemployment rate, which last month hit an eight-year high of 7.8 percent.
"The evidence is we are just holding our own in the labor market," said Robert G. Dederick, economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. He said the unemployment rate might edge down a tenth of a percentage point or two because of statistical adjustments for seasonal job patterns. "But fundamentally we have an economic growth rate that isn't going to bring any meaningful decline in unemployment," he said.
A four-week average of claims, considered a more reliable indicator of the labor market than the weekly number, rose as well. It hit 415,250 for the four weeks ended July 11, up 250 from the period ended a week earlier.
In the first three months of this year claims averaged around 450,000, then fell to around 410,000 in April and May. But since then they have edged higher.
Mr. Dederick said part of the latest increase probably occurred because unemployment offices closed a day during the week before for Independence Day, causing some unemployed people to delay filing their claims until the next week.
Economists at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the New York securities firm, predicted that claims will head even higher later in the month because the General Motors Corporation began a two-week companywide shutdown on July 17.

HEADLINE: Trade Center Overcharge Found Again

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
A second cleaning company has overcharged the Port Authority thousands of dollars for work at the World Trade Center, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday. The overcharges, which have not been fully calculated, represent the third instance of overbilling on Port Authority contracts disclosed by the agency this week.
The firm, Prompt Maintenance Services, holds a $3.5 million contract to clean Buildings 4 and 5, two nine-story structures adjoining the twin towers of the World Trade Center, which is owned and operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. 
 Agency officials disclosed earlier this week that another cleaning service, the Ogden Allied Services Corporation, overcharged tenants at the World Trade Center by almost $1 million over the last year, and that the Port Authority may also have overpaid as much as $500,000 over the last two years to a company that provides security at the center.
Allen Morrison, a spokesman for the Port Authority, described the overpayments to Prompt Maintenance Services as a "relatively minor matter" that is being resolved between the agency and the contractor.
 
'Inadequate Supervision'
 But Mr. Morrison said that taken together, the three incidents reflect a pattern of "inadequate supervision of contracts" that has emerged recently in a series of audits. As a result of the findings, two top agency officials were reassigned this week. They are Frank Garcia, who oversaw World Trade Center business operations from May 1990 until January, when he was named director of economic development, and August K. Preschle, who oversaw the Trade Center's maintenance and daily operations. Both were reassigned after the first cleaning overcharges were disclosed.
The center's construction manager was demoted in January after an internal audit turned up inadequacies in contract oversight, officials said. But they have refused to release that audit or discuss its specific findings.
Prompt Maintenance Services, which has its headquarters in Rockland County, is cooperating with agency auditors and has agreed to "do everything possible to make restitution," Mr. Morrison said.
A telephone message left at the company's office in Rockland County was not returned yesterday. Noel Roman, the company's maintenance supervisor at the World Trade Center, said he knew nothing about the overbilling.
 
Withholding Part of Payments
 Under the terms of its two-year contract, granted in January 1991, Prompt Maintenance was supposed to bill the Port Authority each month for the amount of square footage its workers cleaned, Mr. Morrison said. Instead, the company submitted bills each month for one twenty-fourth of the contract limit of $3.5 million, regardless of the actual work done, he said.
Auditors are now reviewing the records of the last 18 months to determine the amounts that should have been paid, Mr. Morrison said. Until the matter is resolved, the Port Authority will withhold 15 percent of the company's future monthly payments, he said.
Prompt Maintenance is one of two smaller companies granted cleaning contracts by the World Trade Center in 1990 as part of an effort to open contracts to smaller businesses. An audit of a $4.3 million two-year contract awarded to the other small company, Maintenance Services Inc. of Yonkers, showed no irregularities, Mr. Morrison said. The cleaning contract held by Ogden Allied is worth $24 million a year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Exxon, Texaco and Occidental Earnings Fall in Quarter

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 23

 BODY:
The Exxon Corporation, Texaco Inc. and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation today reported lower earnings for the second quarter, reflecting troubles in refining and chemical operations that suffered from weak demand in sluggish global economies.
Exxon, the world's largest oil company, said profits fell 15.1 percent in the quarter. Income at Texaco declined 8.9 percent and Occidental's earnings plunged 49 percent. A large independent refiner, Ashland Oil reported a 52.2 percent drop in earnings. 
 The results were no surprise. George F. Friesen, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Capital Group, said most major oil companies would post moderately lower profits for the second quarter, down an average of 15 percent.
The exception will be companies like ARCO and Unocal, which sell much of their gasoline in California, where retail prices and refining profit margins were higher than a year ago, he said. Unocal reported a twelvefold increase in profits last week. ARCO will report earnings on Monday.
"The third quarer will not be too different," Mr. Friesen said. Crude oil prices will be higher, but profit margins in refining and chemicals will continue to be squeezed by weak demand in the United States and Europe, he said. "In the aggregate, profits will be about flat with last year," he added.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Exxon
Net income declined to $955 million, or 76 cents a share, from $1.125 billion, or 90 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. The total for the recent quarter included a one-time charge of $75 million for cutbacks in domestic oil and gas operations.
Revenues for company, based in Irving, Tex., rose 1.8 percent, to $27.8 billion from $27.3 billion.
Earnings from refining and marketing in the United States plunged to $47 million, from $113 million in the period a year ago, and to $133 million, from $419 million, in foreign refining and marketing operations.
The refining units had higher costs to buy inventories of raw crude oil, but could not raise prices at the same rate because of tepid demand, the company said. Profit margins in the period a year ago were unusually high because crude costs were low.
Profits in global chemical operations fell to $66 million from $79 million in the United States, but increased in foreign markets, to $51 million, from $31 million in the corresponding period last year.
Earnings from exploration and production activities rose slightly in the United States, to $181 million from $179 million, while the international exploration unit earned $544 million, compared with $463 million a year ago.
Exxon's share price rose $1.125, to $63.125, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Texaco
 The nation's fourth-largest oil company said net income declined to $245 million, or 85 cents a share, compared with $269 million, or 94 cents, a year ago. Revenues rose by 4.4 percent, to $9.4 billion from $9.0 billion.
But Texaco's share price rose $1, to $63.50, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
James W. Kinnear, president and chief executive, said Texaco had reduced spending programs and other expenses because of "generally weak industry conditions," and expected to reduce 1992 budgets from original levels to conserve $700 million by the end of the year.
"As of midyear, our progress towards meeting these goals is on target," he said.
The company, based in White Plains, said earnings from oil and gas exploration and production in the United States rose to $113 million from $111 million and increased to $94 million from $78 million in foreign operations.
Crude prices in the United States rose to an average of $16.70 a barrel in the quarter, from $16.48 in the corresponding period a year ago. Natural gas prices rose to $1.51 for 1,000 cubic feet, from $1.48 in the quarter a year ago.
Profits in domestic refining improved to $80 million, from $65 million in the quarter a year ago, mainly because of higher profit margins in California gasoline sales, lower refinery costs and higher gasoline output. For Texaco refineries and service stations along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, profits declined. Refining profits outside the United States fell to $94 million, from $129 million in the corresponding quarter last year.
 
Occidental
 Net income plunged to $75 million, or 25 cents a share, from $147 million, or 49 cents a share. Sales for the Los Angeles-based company declined 8.3 percent, to $2.2 billion from $2.4 billion.
Weak chemical prices overwhelmed improvements in oil and gas production and natural gas pipeline operations that came mainly from favorable results in tax and legal issues. Profits in chemicals dropped to $35 million, from $127 million in the period a year ago. Ray R. Irani, chairman and chief executive, said chemical sales had risen recently.
Profits in oil and gas exploration and production, mainly outside the United States, rose to $82 million from $54 million. Results for the quarter ended June 30 included a $35 million gain from a legal settlement.
A favorable ruling that reversed a previous legal judgment resulted in a pretax gain of $75 million for the pipeline unit, including the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America and United Texas Transmission Company. The 1991 results included a one-time gain of $26 million from a rate case refund.
Occidental's share price fell 25 cents, to $19.50, in trading on the Big Board.
 
Ashland Oil
 Net income fell to $32 million, or 54 cents a share, from $67 million, or $1.19 a share, in the second quarter last year. Revenues rose slightly, to $2.6 billion from $2.4 billion.
The refining unit, based in Ashland, Ky., earned slightly less than $1 million, compared with a profit of $79.5 million in the quarter a year ago. Profits also fell in gasoline marketing, chemicals and exploration. The Valvoline motor oil unit earned $17.1 million, a 10.3 percent gain from $15.5 million in the period last year.
Ashland Oil's share price rose 87.5 cents, to $24.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Sales Up by Ford and Japanese 'Transplants'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 23

 BODY:
Sales of vehicles built in North America by the Ford Motor Company and the Japanese "transplant" auto makers rose 9.4 percent in mid-July, but analysts said the figures showed that consumers remained cautious.
Ford and the seven Japanese manufacturers with American assembly plants said they sold cars and light trucks at a daily rate of 14,365 from July 11 to 20, compared with a daily rate of 13,127 in the similar period last year. There were eight selling days in the 1992 period, compared with nine in 1991. 
 The General Motors Corporation, which is in the midst of a two-week vacation shutdown, did not report mid-July sales, and Ward's Automotive Reports said the lack of data from G.M. had prevented it from providing estimates for the Chrysler Corporation, which reports only monthly.
 
Rental Fleet Sales
 Based on about 44 percent of the market reporting, domestic cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of about six million units. Analysts said that figure was likely to change when G.M. and Chrysler sales were added, but they said the rate indicated a cautious level of consumer demand.
In the early July period, cars sold at a 6.5 million rate, and in late June they sold at a 7.5 million rate.
"The higher sales of the last few periods were boosted completely by the rent-a-car business," said Michael Luckey, an analyst with the Luckey Consulting Group. "It's not surprising that we fell back down to a six million level, with the dip in consumer confidence we've experienced."
He said recent increases in unemployment data were having a negative effect on consumers.
Sales of the Ford and American-built Japanese cars rose 3.5 percent over last year's levels, to 8,950 a day. But sales of light trucks rose 20.8 percent, to 5,414 a day.
Over all, Ford sold 40,826 cars, up 4.9 percent on a daily basis. In the July 1-10 period, Ford sold 49,188 cars domestically, an increase of 16 percent on a daily basis.
Ford has attributed the early July surge to advance orders from rental businesses.
In early July, Ford's light-truck sales, hurt by the July 4 holiday, were up only 1.3 percent over a year earlier, to 32,394. But in mid-July, they rebounded to 37,071, an 18.8 percent daily increase.
"Ford seems to be outperforming the major Japanese nameplates," David Garrity, an analyst for McDonald & Company, said. "That's representative of the pricing advantage they now enjoy.
Sales of domestically built Japanese nameplate cars and light trucks fell 10.5 percent on a daily basis, to a total of 31,336.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
MCI Earnings Climb 9.3% On Higher Calling Volume

 BODY:
The MCI Communications Corporation, citing business from newly won residential and business customers, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 9.3 percent, to $141 million, as revenue rose 10.6 percent.
Despite the favorable news, the stock market bid MCI's stock price down slightly. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, MCI closed at $32.50 a share, down 37.5 cents. 
 Analysts said the profit, up from $129 million in last year's second quarter, was in line with expectations, and they expressed surprise that MCI's stock had declined. "Maybe people were focusing on expenses, which were higher than my model predicted," said Charles W. Schelke, a telecommunications analyst at Smith Barney.
Sales, administrative and general expenses rose 9.7 percent, to $687 million.
Revenues were $2.6 billion, up from $2.35 billion in the comparable period last year.
MCI's earnings per share rose to 53 cents, from 50 cents a year earlier. In the 1992 second quarter, MCI had 266 million shares outstanding, up 6 million from a year earlier because of a newly formed employee stock ownership program.
Like its major competitors in the long-distance market -- the top-ranked A.T.& T. and the third-place Sprint Corporation -- MCI, No. 2, has had to cope with a sluggish economy in which residential customers have tried to reduce their calling and corporations have laid off thousands of office workers, who account for the great majority of calling during daylight hours.
MCI said the number of minutes of customer use had grown 14.6 percent, but was not more specific. Earlier this month A.T.& T. reported traffic growth of about 6 percent, and the Sprint Corporation reported 3.3 percent growth. But minutes of use, while generally more reflective of the actual level of business growth than revenue, is sometimes calculated differently by each company, making comparisons difficult.
MCI has pursued large corporate accounts with extensive services and low prices, while offering a popular residential counterpart in its Friends and Family program. The company has won major contracts with Citicorp, Holiday Inn, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and the Minnesota state government.
Under the residential program, customers get a 20 percent discount for their calls by encouraging up to 20 other people in a "calling circle" to join MCI.

HEADLINE: David Wojnarowicz, 37, Artist in Many Media

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
David Wojnarowicz, one of the most individual artists of the 1980's, whose impassioned and outspoken work about AIDS thrust him into the center of the recent debates involving the National Endowment for the Arts, died on Wednesday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 37 years old.
He died of AIDS, said his companion, Tom Rauffenbart. 
 Mr. Wojnarowicz (pronounced voy-nah-ROH-vitch) worked in many media, often mixing them together, to produce an art that was distinguished by its rage and its spirit of personal longing. His paintings, photographs, installations, performances and writings railed against the status quo as they also mourned death. He dealt not only with AIDS but with many other issues, both public and private. His art could be simplistic and preachy. Yet it could also be unnerving, wry and very moving.
Like the artist himself, his art never pulled punches. Mr. Wojnarowicz gained the national spotlight in 1989, when the National Endowment for the Arts decided to rescind money for a catalogue to an exhibition about AIDS because of an essay in which he attacked various public figures. The endowment reversed itself. It also supported a 10-year retrospective of his work that was organized at the University Galleries of Illinois State University in Normal, Ill., which included a catalogue that reproduced the essay.
Mr. Wojnarowicz was in the news again after the American Family Association of Tupelo, Miss., an antipornography lobbying group, and its leader, the Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, issued a pamphlet criticizing the endowment. The pamphlet included photographs cropped from works by Mr. Wojnarowicz that included sexual images. The artist sued the organization for misrepresenting him and damaging his reputation. In 1990, a Federal District Court judge in New York ruled in his favor and ordered that the organization publish and distribute a correction. Mr. Wojnarowicz was the only artist to challenge Mr. Wildmon in court.
 
The East Village Scene
 An abused child and a teen-age street hustler, Mr. Wojnarowicz made much of his personal history in the social margins in his art and writings. He was born in Red Bank, N.J., ran away from home, lived on the streets, and eventually graduated from the High School of Music and Art in Manhattan. One of many artists of his generation to achieve recognition in the boom-and-bust East Village art scene of the early 80's, Mr. Wojnarowicz was first known for stenciling images of burning houses and falling figures onto the sides of buildings. He typified the approach of artists from the East Village who felt free to explore various media, to mix high and low art.
In his writings, which moved from the shrill to the elegiac, he often recounted the goings-on of those on the sexual and economic periphery. In 1990 he published "Close to the Knives" (Random House). Another book, "Memories That Smell Like Gasoline" is to be published by Artspace Books in San Francisco.
In his paintings and photographs, which sometimes incorporated texts, he borrowed from popular culture and created images that could be darkly surreal. One concocted photographic image, of buffaloes toppling over a cliff, became the cover of an album by the band U2. The death from AIDS of his friend Peter Hujar, the photographer, in 1987, and the diagnosis in 1988 of his own illness, prompted Mr. Wojnarowicz to bear witness in his art to the disease and its social and psychological impact.
He is survived by his mother, Dolores Voyna of Manhattan; two sisters, Pat Bernier of Paris and Linda Zaccaria of East Brunswick, N.J.; and two brothers, Peter, of Englishtown, N.J., and Steven, of East Windsor, N.J.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

Next Season at Second Stage
Carole Rothman, the artistic director of the Second Stage, has announced her new season. First up is "A . . . My Name Is Still Alice," the topical musical revue that recently played six weeks at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego. The show was conceived and directed by Joan Micklin Silver and Julianne Boyd, who created the original "A . . . My Name is Alice" in 1984. Among the numbers in the new version, Ms. Rothman says, are "The Clarence Thomas Home for Unwed Mothers" and "It Ain't Over," about sex and the older woman. Contributors to the revue include Steve Tesich, David Zippel, Carol Hall, Amanda McBroom, Lucy Simon and Susan Birkenhead. 
 Next up will be a new, still untitled play by Tina Howe, about two couples and a third man, and the difficulties of fidelity in marriage; Ms. Rothman is to direct. Then, Gary Sinise is to direct "Sticks and Bones," by David Rabe, starring Peter Weller and Ethan Hawke. These plans may sound familiar because they were announced for last season but fell through. A fourth play is still to be announced. Subscriptions: (212) 787-8302.
 
Casting 'My Favorite Year'
 Don't look for Victor Garber to star in "My Favorite Year," the musical-comedy version of the 1982 film about an aging matinee idol and a young television writer. Although word was favorable from the recently completed workshop in which Mr. Garber played the actor, Bernard Gersten, the executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater, says Mr. Garber withdrew for economic reasons. "None of the theaters can compete financially with movies or television," Mr. Gersten says. "We're sorry to lose him. But he is shooting Nora Ephron's new movie in August, and he has a recurring role on a Canadian television series." Mr. Gersten says Andre Bishop, the artistic director of the theater, is in London auditioning actors. (Peter O'Toole played the role in the film.) Mr. Gersten adds that the casting office at the Royal National Theater is helping with the search. Evan Pappas is to play the writer.
 
The Public's Library
 Among the seven pink slips recently issued at the New York Shakespeare Festival were a few for the Archives Department, which has documented the history of the theater since Joseph Papp founded it in 1954. Serge Mogilat, its director, has been given a year to find a new home for the staggering amount of material that has been collected, everything from ticket stubs to videotapes, of which there are 900. They contain interviews given by Papp and television reviews, which feature clips that in most cases are the only record of a show.
"The collection will logically end with Mr. Papp's death," Mr. Mogilat says. "Right now, we are considering two options. The Library of Congress approached us first to start a Joseph Papp wing in its manuscript division, which documents the lives of famous American personalities in different fields. And the performing-arts library at Lincoln Center approached me about putting in a bid to keep the material in New York City. We have already given them our news clippings on microfilm, dating from 1954. But our problem is that one library might not be able to take everything, and we don't want to decimate the collection."
Besides copies of all of Papp's speeches, memos and correspondence, the collection includes everything from the scripts for plays he optioned but never produced to production books, which are working versions of a script with complete sets of cues for new productions. There are also numerous versions of scripts from their initial submission, when Papp first showed interest in them, through to their final performances, documenting the entire play development process. Complete music files contain the original score of every show Papp produced, including "A Chorus Line"; full sets of blueprints for original set designs; audio tapes of radio interviews and commercials, and one-of-a-kind photographs. And, Mr. Mogilat adds, that's not even half of it.
 
Autumn Openings
 The first wave of theatrical activity for the new season is starting, including the announcement of a bona fide Broadway opening. "The Woman in Black," a thriller that has been playing in London since 1989, is to open at the Music Box Theater on Oct. 29, at a cost of $1.3 million. The play was adapted by Stephen Mallatratt from Susan Hill's horror novel about an aging lawyer, haunted by the memory of a woman in black, who hires a young actor to help him exorcise his past. Robin Herford, a former artistic director of Alan Ayckbourn's theater in Scarborough, England, will direct.
Off Broadway, you can expect to see "Remembrance," the well-reviewed drama that had an extended run at the Irish Arts Center two seasons ago. The love story, set in Belfast, Northern Ireland, is to open at the John Houseman Theater on Sept. 24 starring Milo O'Shea, Frances Sternhagen and Mia Dillon.
And on Sept. 8, just in time for the campaign season, a tour of -- you guessed it -- "Camelot," starring Robert Goulet, begins in Detroit.
 
Two for Summer
 The John Drew Theater at Guild Hall of East Hampton, L.I., is offering two theatrical events to watch for this summer. Spalding Gray will perform his work in progress, "Gray's Anatomy," a monologue about his search for a cure for a vision problem, next Thursday and Friday. And in case you missed Roger Rosenblatt's well-received one-man show at the American Place Theater last season, he will perform "Free Speech in America" on Aug. 14. Information: (516) 324-4050.
 
In Print and on Disk
 Also in the summer pleasures category, Applause Books has just published "13 by Shanley," a collection of plays by John Patrick Shanley, who also wrote the Oscar-winning screenplay for "Moonstruck." . . . "You're the Top: Cole Porter in the 30's" is a collection of three compact disks that you can find in most stores or order from the Indiana Historical Society. The set, which commemorates the centenary of Porter's birth in Peru, Ind., includes recordings by Fred Astaire, Ella Fitzgerald, Ethel Merman and Porter himself. The album also has a biography of the composer by Robert Kimball, the music theater historian. Information: (317) 232-1882.

Ron Rifkin, above, won an Obie Award for his critically acclaimed performance as a Holocaust survivor who founds a publishing company. He is also to play the part in the film version for Columbia Pictures. Mr. Baitz is to write the screenplay.
