HEADLINE: Review/Architecture;
Steel and Backbone in Hard Times

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
LEAVE it to the Municipal Art Society to mount a tasteful political protest. Last week, when the Democrats were in town, the members of this century-old organization of civic do-gooders didn't surround Madison Square Garden with bullhorns or scrawled posters. Instead they occupied the decorous Urban Center Galleries and opened a dignified rally of a show. Its theme is New York's tradition of great public works; its purpose is to stimulate ideas for reviving that tradition.
"Steel, Stone and Backbone," which runs through Sept. 19, is a protest against recessionary thinking. It's a strike against the idea that in hard economic times people should lower their expectations about what kind of city they want to live in. In fact, the point of the show is to offer historical proof to the contrary. When the going gets tough, the tough get ambitious about architecture. Much of the New York that is most admired -- its water and transportation systems, housing, cultural institutions -- emerged from periods of economic crisis. 
 The show, put together by Laura Rosen, an archivist with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, offers a look at six of these periods and the public works they produced. Many viewers will already be familiar with one of them: the Great Depression and its astounding record in projects for housing, recreation and transportation. With segments devoted to such projects as La Guardia Airport, Orchard Beach in the Bronx and the Queens-Midtown Tunnel (with a video presentation on the "sand hogs" who built it), the 1930's takes up most of the exhibition space.
But the real news of the show is that the building boom of the 30's wasn't the exception. It was the rule. Such booms have frequently coincided with financial busts, or as they were termed in the 19th century, "panics." The Panic of 1837 saw the building of the Croton Water System, including the monumental Egyptian Revival reservoir that used to stand on the current site of the New York Public Library. After the Panics of 1873 and 1893, work began on the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the American Museum of Natural History and the New York Zoological Society, later known as the Bronx Zoo. What a panic.
"Steel, Stone and Backbone" deals more with economics, politics and labor than with architectural esthetics. Still, the works on view convey the power of buildings to create strong images of public service. When Government officials are holding fire sales on urban properties, it's instructive to review the monuments left by periods when serving the public was a noble end that called for noble forms. The design of the Orchard Beach bathhouse, for example, equals the Rainbow Room in Art Deco elegance.
These examples of urban bootstrapping are inspiring, but it would be helpful to have something more than inspiration. What is the key to these success stories? Does history offer a pattern we can follow today?
Sorry. There is no key. The motives behind these works are as varied as the projects themselves. Disastrous fires and a cholera epidemic prompted the building of the Croton Water System. Social ambition -- the oblige of would-be noblesse -- spurred wealthy collectors to erect the Metropolitan Museum to "educate and better the lot of the working classes." And the record of the 30's would be a good deal skimpier if it hadn't been for Robert Moses' rabid lust for power. Since history doesn't hand us a key, however, the implicit message of this show is that we will have to invent one for ourselves. And perhaps invention is the key we're looking for.
This political speech of a show has visual as well as polemic appeal. Among the curiosities on view are two panels prepared by Calvert Vaux and Frederick Law Olmsted for the 1857 competition to design Central Park. Combining cartography, photography and painting, each panel features a map of the park site and "before" and "after" images showing how Olmsted and Vaux proposed to transform different portions of the landscape. These forward-looking mixed-media works (photography was a recent invention) should jolt us out of the habit of equating Olmsted with the sweetly picturesque. If he were alive today, this pioneering artist would be dazzling us with holograms.
Ms. Rosen offers some smart image mixes of her own. Pictures of the Bronx Zoo, for instance, are set beside William Holbrook Beard's 1879 painting of vicious bears and bulls rampaging on Wall Street. The juxtaposition brings to mind the financial predators of a more recent day who have done time behind bars.
"Steel, Stone and Backbone" goes soft at the end, with strained attempts to declare the present a time of maintaining the "basic infrastructure" of a "mature cityscape." It would be great indeed if the kind of energy that went into building these projects could be applied to maintaining them. But clearly the Municipal Art Society has its sights set on bigger things than rustproofing. And there's an ulterior motive here as well: a bid by the society to refurbish its public image. Just as the Democrats are seeking more mainstream appeal, the Municipal Art Society wants to cast off its image of upscale gentility. That's why, instead of potted palms, they've adorned the galleries with such tough-guy paraphernalia as hard hats and rubber pylons.
Actually, this organization outgrew its tea-party image long ago. In recent years it has shown its well-developed political muscle in major projects all over town. Sometimes it flexes its biceps publicly, as when it brought suit to halt a development proposal for Columbus Circle. More often its members have worked behind the scenes, political equivalents of the sand hogs toiling beneath the East River. "Steel, Stone and Backbone" is one of several events that will honor the society's centennial. What better way to ward off recessionary blues than to toast the vigor of this venerable group?

 	 	 		. . .	 	"Steel, Stone and Backbone: New York Builds in Hard Times" remains at the Urban Center Galleries, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street, through Sept. 19. Tomorrow afternoon at 1, John Kriskiewicz, the architectural historian, will lead a four-hour bus tour of major New York City public works. Tickets are $22 for Municipal Art Society members; $30 for nonmembers. Reservations: (212) 935-3960.

HEADLINE: Democracy Denied in Algeria

 BODY:
When Algeria's army staged a coup in January, heading off an anticipated Islamic electoral triumph, Washington, like other Western governments, winked.
Apologists for the coup warned of frightening consequences if Algeria's Islamic Salvation Front had been allowed to compete. Though the Front's official leadership had promised conciliation and economic reform, apologists argued that radicals would soon have swept aside these moderates. Further elections would have been banned, foreign policy radicalized, market reforms diluted, human rights of non-believers abused. 
 It is of course impossible to know what would have happened had democracy been permitted to run its course. Given the record of Islamic rule in Iran and the Sudan, such fears can scarcely be dismissed.
But there is no need to speculate about what's happened since Algeria's coup. Elections remain suspended; elected local councils have been disbanded. Human rights have been trampled; thousands of Islamic militants spent weeks in desert prison camps. The army's strong-arm tactics have embarrassed, even discredited, Islamic moderates. And the Salvation Front has been radicalized.
Last month Algeria's provisional President was assassinated, perhaps by Islamic militants, perhaps by army dissidents. His successor has just installed a Socialist economic planner to run the Government. The new Prime Minister is known for his vocal criticism of free-market economics and of the International Monetary Fund.
In sum, the coup has accomplished almost everything the West did not want to see happen. Yet Western democracies remain silent. The new Algerian regime still welcomes foreign investment. The Islamic militants it persecutes are unlikely to seek refuge in Europe, as the Westernized elements might have under Islamic rule.
The West's attitude is remarkably shortsighted. Algeria's Islamic majority won't go away, nor will it become more democracy-minded when its electoral majorities are treated with contempt. Meanwhile, political instability is increasing.
The surest way out is an early return to the ballot box, with all parties free to compete. America's Algeria policy needs to be revisited.

HEADLINE: Time to Punish Hussein -- Again

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein continues to flout the authority of the United Nations, most recently by interfering with its arms inspectors. The U.N. Security Council cannot allow his repeated and flagrant violations of international law to go unpunished.
Devising appropriate and effective punishment won't be easy. But the U.N. cannot rule out military action -- including air strikes.
That action has a clear objective: to disarm Iraq in a way that bolsters the U.N.'s authority and undermines President Hussein's. Unilateral action by the U.S. won't do that.
U.N. implementation of the cease-fire resolution has been chipping away at Saddam Hussein's authority. He has reacted with calculated desperation, defying the U.N. wherever he can. He has just turned away U.N. arms inspectors from Iraq's Ministry of Agriculture, where Iraq was believed to have filed records of its arms purchases. These records could document Iraq's continuing non-compliance with the disarmament provisions of the cease-fire resolution.
That's not all. He has bullied U.N. personnel, even threatened them with hand grenades and car bombs. He has barred participation in U.N. efforts to draw Iraq's frontier with Kuwait. He has refused to renew the memorandum of understanding by which international humanitarian agencies have been conducting relief efforts in Iraq. And he continues to wage war on Shiite refugees near Basra. These provocations put President Bush under pressure to take military action. But acting unilaterally, or blindly bombing Baghdad, won't shore up the U.N. Even a punitive raid on the Agriculture Ministry building would simply scatter, if not destroy, evidence of illegal Iraqi arms.
Mr. Bush would be wiser to encourage the U.N. to take a number of steps that, together, would bring home to Iraq the costs of Mr. Hussein's continued defiance.
The Iraqi Air Force has breached the cease-fire accord by resuming flights of fixed-wing aircraft. Its air bases and planes can be put out of action. Selective attacks on military targets would show Iraq's armed forces that keeping this dictator in power is suicidal.
Mr. Hussein is trying to intimidate U.N. humanitarian workers and guards and force them out of Iraq. One has already been slain. The U.N. needs to protect its people in Iraq and punish those responsible for the slaying.
And Iraq continues to circumvent the economic embargo by way of Jordan. If Jordan cannot enforce the embargo, it can admit armed U.N. monitors to patrol its border. If it is unwilling to do so, it too could be liable to sanctions.
Saddam Hussein cannot defy the world with impunity. Stern punishment is required if the U.N. is not to emerge weaker, and a desperate dictator stronger, from the present confrontation.

HEADLINE: Break the Political Stranglehold

BYLINE: By John B. Anderson; John B. Anderson is visiting professor at Nova University Law School.

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
When Ross Perot suddenly quit the Presidential race, he left millions of supporters without a candidate. Frustrated with a two-party duopoly, many feel they are without real choices or real voices; they wonder what to do next. It doesn't have to be this way. We could easily make it simpler for new candidates like Ross Perot to run and allow supporters of these new candidates to vote their true beliefs.
In 1980, I ran for President as an independent. I had my name put on the ballot in all 50 states and for a time my standing in the polls was over 20 percent, showing that millions of Americans supported my platform. Yet in the end I only received about 7 percent of the vote. It wasn't because all those voters stopped supporting me. It was because many calculated that I couldn't win and that a vote for me would be wasted. 
 A system called majority preferential voting could eliminate the chilling effects of this "wasted vote" syndrome. Used in Australia since the 1920's, preferential voting both insures that a winner has majority support and sensibly allows voters for losers to have a second chance.
Here's how it works. Rather than simply vote for one candidate, voters rank candidates in order of preference, putting a 1 next to their first choice, a 2 next to their second choice and so on until they no longer want to support any remaining candidate.
After voting is completed, first choices are counted. If a candidate receives more than 50 percent, he or she wins. But if no candidate has a majority, the candidate with fewest first-choice votes is eliminated, and the ballots of voters who indicated that candidate as their first choice are redistributed to their second choices. This process continues until a candidate gains over 50 percent.
As with runoff elections, majority preferential voting insures that the winner has majority support but has several additional advantages over runoffs.
It is cheaper, as no second election is required.
It increases the likelihood of having a high voter turnout in the determining election; in runoff elections, supporters of eliminated candidates often do not vote.
It promotes positive campaigning: Because candidates may need votes transferred from eliminated candidates, they will not want to alienate other candidates' supporters.
Would preferential voting have changed the 1980 result? Probably not. However, I might have received 20 percent of the vote, as my candidacy would have been treated more seriously, and more people might have voted. Ronald Reagan likely would have been forced to explain his economic program more thoroughly with me as a serious contender. His mandate as President also would have been clearer if his victory had depended on a significant number of transfer votes from my supporters -- people who wanted change, but not Reaganomics.
Most important, the two-party duopoly's stranglehold on political discourse would have been broken. More candidate voices and voter choices would improve our political process, just as a free market in economics results in products more suited to consumers' tastes. We would have a revolution if people were forced to choose between two cars; why should we be forced to choose between only two parties?
Watching the distraught Ross Perot volunteers react to his withdrawal, I was struck by the tragedy that so many Americans want to be involved, want to make a difference, yet keep being disillusioned by broken promises and Teflon bureaucracies. Don't we owe them the right to have as much of a voice as possible? Don't we owe them consideration of a simple, sensible reform like preferential voting? I believe we do. A vote is a terrible thing to waste.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Getting Saddam Hussein

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL; Anthony Lewis is on vacation.

 BODY:
By God, we have to teach that Saddam Hussein a lesson. Bomb Iraq.
Great idea, sir. The only thing is, then what? Do we go on bombing him until he resigns or something? 
 Well, no, that has not seemed to work before. But maybe he will back down after all. Maybe then he will be good, and disclose all his nuclear secrets to U.N. inspectors.
So we give him another chance?
No, that hasn't worked either. Let's pray hard that one of our bombs sends him to hell.
That would be nice. But then, his family and his top command would take over. Himmler-Goring leading the post-Hitler reform movement; doesn't seem right, somehow . . .
Well, of course -- none of these great ideas will work. The debate in the U.S. Government about what to do about Saddam is largely puerile and evasive because it does not confront the basic truth.
By keeping Saddam in power after he lost the gulf war, the U.S. made a historic error from which there is no one-track way out short of another all-out war.
But unless he is insane enough to make his own second historic error -- another direct act of aggression -- the coalition cannot be recreated nor public support mustered to support another Desert Storm.
So some of our bureaucrats and commentators are pushing an entirely different Grand Strategy. Do nothing! That would really catch him off guard! We could then just let sanctions squeeze him into exhaustion!
Relying on sanctions alone would extend the smuggling license for Saddam's ally, everybody's pal, the King of Jordan. Then, how many years before Saddam Hussein rebuilds his nuclear base -- five, six?
And if anybody cares, there is the additional point that without fear of reprisal he will wipe out tens of thousands more Kurds and other Iraqi rebels.
But, if we face reality, it is in those very people that the answer lies.
Both the basis and the base for the strategy against Saddam exist already, inside Iraq. A Kurdish government is in place in northern Iraq, chosen by election, not imposed by tyranny, and should be recognized by the U.S. No law or self-interest ties us to continued recognition of Saddam and his killer regime -- the contrary.
With U.S. help, all anti-Saddam Iraqi exiles could convene in Northern Iraq to form a new resistance government including Kurds, and Sunni and Shiite Muslims, and a unified army of liberation. '
But let's face it plain: To survive against the tanks and weapons we so kindly left with Saddam, the resistance forces would need economic assistance -- plus antiaircraft and antitank batteries. Also needed would be air support -- a euphemism for bombing, for specific military purpose, not political show.
And there'll be times when feuds among resistance groups will make American officials wish they had never heard of any of them. But the Kurds and the others say they can come together for the fight against Saddam. They need the chance, as the U.S. needs them to rid itself of Saddam's perpetual threat to Mideast peace.
To bring it off, the U.S. will also need the support of Turkey. Washington must free itself of the ludicrous thought that it must preserve the "territorial integrity" of Iraq.
The country was carved from the Turkish empire by the British in the 20's -- with a fine eye for British oil interests. Now there are new struggles, new values, new interests important in the area -- including those of friends of the U.S. like the Kurds and the Turks.
And it is naive to believe that the present Bush Government could do it -- that all those experts who gave us the appeasement of Iraq, the strange loans and the decision to desert the Kurds would be able to think straight, clean and strong enough. If Mr. Bush is re-elected, he will have to be tough-minded enough to bring in people with fresh minds, tough enough to do some rethinking himself, or Saddam will remain in power.
Governor Clinton says he will back U.N. action against Saddam -- and that is as far as he will go now.
But he should demand full intelligence briefings right away. And if his advisers are as good as they should be, they will tell him that the removal of the Saddam gang is essential but will be hard and complex to work out. That's the price of the U.S. retreat from victory after Desert Storm, and no use pretending it isn't.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Time for U.S. to Rediscover Philippines

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Corazon Aquino's triumph over Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines six years ago, with its inspiring slogan of People Power, was headline news in the United States, avidly followed by millions of Americans. In sharp contrast, Fidel Ramos's recent assumption of the Philippine presidency received very little attention, in Washington or on Main Street.
Undoubtedly, this is partly a reflection of this country's general fatigue with international affairs -- given our domestic economic malaise and this being an election year. But I suspect it also has to do with the specific unhappiness of Washington over having been booted out of our military bases in the Philippines, plus considerable official disappointment over what Mrs. Aquino's once-promising people power failed to achieve. 
 The Philippines clearly remains the sick man of East Asia -- left in the dust by Korea and Taiwan in the 1960's and 70's, and by Thailand and Malaysia in the 80's -- and it has one of the worst poverty profiles in the third world.
As a consequence, the much-proclaimed special relationship with our former colony now finds itself on a not-so-special back burner. Interest in the multilateral aid initiative, for example, which was originally championed by the United States, is clearly flagging, with the White House scarcely lifting a finger to resist additional Congressional cuts in our own contribution.
The irony of all this is that we are threatening to pull away at the very moment in history when the opportunity for real change in the Philippines is probably greater than at any time in the past.
You saw hints of hope in Manila in a June 1 editorial, and President Ramos's initial pronouncements since having taken over indicate a realization that the hour is late and an intention to shake his Government loose from the amiable passivity of the Aquino years. Moreover, the potential for United States influence on the quality of Philippine policies remains large, despite our own budgetary limitations.
Indeed, the absence of an agreement on Philippine bases and the related end of an aid program widely interpreted as rent payment provide a more favorable setting for an objective discourse on policy, accompanied by arm's length, if lower level, financial flows.
Linking substantive reforms to hard-nosed generosity is never easy, but, as illustrated by the East Asian experience of the 1960's, it is the only way. President Ramos is not a member of the traditional elite that has consistently ruled the Philippines. The country's entrepreneurs, its working people and its technocrats remain unusually strong. Its powerful vested interest groups are temporarily on the defensive.
This is likely to be just the time when renewed United States engagement with the Philippines and a reinvigorated multilateral aid initiative are likely to have the best chances for success.
 
GUSTAV RANIS
Frank Altschul Professor of
Intl. Economics, Yale University
New Haven, July 7, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
Yeltsin Walks Path That F.D.R. Once Trod

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin, as did Franklin D. Roosevelt, has only a layman's knowledge of economics. Yet like F.D.R. he is presiding over a historic economic reorganization. And like Roosevelt, Mr. Yeltsin is groping for the right mix of free markets and government intervention to make Russia's economy function and prosper.
Yevgeny Yasin, director of the Russian League of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs, sees considerable similarities between the leaders. "Where the two men converge is on the question of how much government help any market-oriented, capitalist economy must have," he said. 
 Mr. Yeltsin would recognize in Roosevelt's experiences in Depression America similarities to his own efforts to steer the Russian economy through hard times.
They come at the problem from opposite directions. When Roosevelt became President in 1933, the United States economy was mostly a free-market system. But the marketplace had broken down. Roosevelt's challenge was to enlist the state in reviving consumer demand. He eventually did this through deficit spending, in effect printing money and putting it into people's hands to spend.
Roosevelt acted reluctantly, inveighing frequently against unbalanced budgets. He always felt more at home promoting a second, safety-net role for government; to protect Americans from the ravages of the Depression, he created programs like Social Security, Federal bank-deposit insurance and workers' compensation.
 Mr. Yeltsin's task is the opposite -- creating free markets, and cutting back governmental systems. While pursuing his task, the burly, white-haired Russian President is using the same tool, deficit spending, that so preoccupied the smiling and debonair Roosevelt. Should the Yeltsin Administration continue to print money to subsidize big state companies, keeping them afloat while they try to make the transition to private corporations in the new marketplace?
Like Roosevelt, Mr. Yeltsin inveighs publicly against deficit spending, but is giving in. And like Roosevelt, he seems more comfortable in a different sort of government role, also creating safety net features like unemployment insurance for a nation certain in the future to have major layoffs or new regulations for the new commercial banks.
As Roosevelt did initially -- even upon hearing the advice of John Maynard Keynes, the great British economist -- Mr. Yeltsin has resisted the notion of deficit spending to stimulate the economy. But not recently. Last week, with Mr. Yeltsin's acquiescence, Parliament raised the ceiling for 1992 deficit spending, mostly for subsidies to state-owned enterprises, to help them preserve jobs.
Sergei Ignatyev, a vice chairman of the Russian central bank, has also considered the Yeltsin-Roosevelt comparison and its implications for Russian policy. One form of deficit spending in Russia is done through the central bank, which can create new credit.
"The American Depression was brought about by the Federal Reserve, which allowed the money supply to shrink," Mr. Ignatyev said, alluding to the tight-money policies of Herbert Hoover and, at first, Roosevelt. "We are not making that mistake. We are increasing the money supply by 10 percent every month -- very fast."
 
No Lack of Demand
 Unlike in Depression-era America, with consumer spending so moribund it had to be revived with public works spending, Russians are eager to buy right now. There is no lack of consumer demand. Instead, there is a lack of supply from the state companies that the Yeltsin Government persists in subsidizing, in the process feeding money into workers' pockets. The concern is that with so much money and so few goods, inflation, now nearly 20 percent a month, will skyrocket.
As a lesser evil, some of Mr. Yeltsin's advisers argue to cut off deficit spending and let enterprises fail. The millions of unemployed Russians will in time find work, these advisers say, as new private companies emerge to satisfy the desire for goods. Roosevelt got similar advice to let market forces take their course, and he generally heeded it, until 1937. After all, the economy was recovering slowly, and unemployment had fallen to 14 percent from 25 percent in 1933.
Then the bottom fell out again. Unemployment jumped back to 19 percent and Roosevelt turned to deficit spending.
In Russia, with unemployment just beginning to rise, and the state enterprises clamoring for help to survive the transition, Mr. Yeltsin might be throwing in the towel faster than Roosevelt.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 24, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on July 24 drawing parallels between Russia under Boris N. Yeltsin and the United States under Franklin D. Roosevelt referred incorrectly to the origin of workers' compensation. It began early in this century; it was not created by Roosevelt.

HEADLINE: White-Black Disparity in Income Narrowed in 80's, Census Shows

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
The long-standing income gap between black and white households in the United States remained wide in the 1980's, narrowing only slightly. But data from the 1990 Census released today show there were also sharp regional disparities.
The new data provide the most comprehensive state-by-state picture of the range of incomes among racial and ethnic groups. In the Northeast and on the West Coast, where many households did well, black households generally fared better than others. In New York State, for example, among whites the median household income, adjusted for inflation, increased 19 percent to $35,811; among blacks it increased 29 percent to $24,089. 
 But the slumping economy of the Midwest hit blacks harder than any other racial group. Income disparities between blacks and whites widened sharply along a belt of states from Ohio to Minnesota, as the automobile-manufacturing and metal-bending industries, which attracted thousands of rural Southern blacks to urban jobs two generations ago, closed their doors on the migrants' children and grandchildren.
Indiana's numbers tell the story: median household income for whites dropped 1 percent; for blacks it dropped 16 percent.
 
Gap Is Slightly Smaller
 The 1990 Census asked people how much income they had during the previous year. Since then, the nation's economy has been set back by a recession that has been particularly severe in the Northeast and West. Nevertheless, economists and demographers say that the detail offered in these Census numbers will be crucial to the continuing debate over how fairly income is distributed in the United States.
Nationally, the 1989 median household income was $31,435 for whites and $19,758 for blacks. Put another way, a black household typically brought in 63 cents for every $1 that went to a white household. In 1979, it was 62 cents for every $1.
These were among a wealth of new data measuring, by racial group, educational attainment, income, labor-force status and poverty in states and the District of Columbia. The Census Bureau had released overall figures in these categories this year but without racial breakdowns.
Among other things, the data revealed that New Jersey and Maryland were areas of relative prosperity for all racial groups in the 1980's and that Asians in New Jersey had a median household income of $52,846, the highest level for any group in any state.
The lowest was for American Indians in South Dakota: $11,017.
Among blacks in Maryland, the median household income was $30,746, higher than any other state with a black population of more than 200,000. People who identified themselves as Hispanic, who can be of any race, make up only 2.6 percent of Maryland's population, but they fared better there than in any other state, with a median household income of $37,300.
 
Asians Are Prospering
 The data provided new evidence that Asians, the nation's smallest and fastest-growing racial minority, generally had higher household incomes than the population as a whole. Overall, the nation's median household income was $30,056. For Asians, who represent 2.9 percent of the population, the figure was $36,784. For Hispanic households, which now represent 9.0 percent of the population, the figure was $24,156.
The data also confirmed earlier surveys showing that Asians were the nation's best educated racial group. Among all people ages 25 and older, 75.2 percent are high school graduates, and 20.3 percent have college degrees; among Asians, 77.5 percent are high-school graduates, and 36.6 percent have college degrees.
 
'The Door Has Been Shut'
 With the exception of Wisconsin, the states where blacks lost the most ground were those with high out-migration of both blacks and whites. The states that showed the greatest income gains among blacks, like Maryland and Washington, were also states where the black population increased far more than the national rate of 13.2 percent. Maryland's black population rose 24 percent; Washington's rose 42 percent.
"In the past, for the blacks to get good incomes, they had to move from the rural South to the North," said William Frey, a researcher in the University of Michigan's Population Studies Center, which did a preliminary computer analysis of the data for The New York Times. "Now we're seeing the areas blacks are moving from are not only in the rural South but also in the urban North."
In much of the South, where income disparities between blacks and whites have traditionally been highest, the gaps widened. But the continuation of this trend was less surprising to demographers than the extent to which the impact of Midwestern industrial decay had fallen disproportionately on black households.
"The Midwest has taken its hits in general, but the economy took a particular hit at the black population because these were entry-level, labor-intensive kinds of work," Professor Frey said. "They were important ways to get in the door to the middle class. Now the door has been shut."
Illinois was the exception as black households lost economic ground to white households in Ohio, West Virginia, Indiana, Michigan, Wisconsin, Missouri and Minnesota. A decade earlier, most of these states had been national leaders in closing the gap between black and white incomes.
In 25 states, including New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Maryland, California and Washington, the income gains of black households outpaced those of whites.
 
Focus on Ethnic Groups
 Other Government surveys permit some regional comparisons on income, poverty and employment among blacks and whites, but the new Census data provide a sharper focus on less-numerous racial groups, like Asians and Indians, and smaller regions.
For instance, they reveal that Asians in Rhode Island have been left out of the general trend of Asian prosperity; they have high rates of unemployment and low household incomes. Nearly 28 percent of 18,000 Asians in Rhode Island had incomes below the poverty level, and nearly 13 percent of Asian men were unemployed in 1990.
The data that tracked employment status and poverty, which are the focus of several other surveys, revealed no new trends, but they did offer stark evidence of the degree of economic disparity between blacks and whites. Forty-four percent of all black children under age 5 lived in poverty in 1989; for whites the figure was 13.8 percent.
In the industrial Midwest and in the western half of the Old Confederacy, the poverty and employment data offered different views of the same bleak economic story for blacks. While the percentage of black children under age 5 living in poverty topped 60 percent in Louisiana, Wisconsin and Michigan, the number of black women working or seeking work fell below the national average in these states and many others in the central region of the country.
Across the Midwest and in states that bordered the Mississippi River from Minnesota south to New Orleans, the unemployment rates among black women were higher than the national average of 12.2 percent. The unemployment rates for black women in Louisiana (18.7 percent), Michigan (18.4 percent) and Wisconsin (17.3 percent) were the highest in the nation.
The same states also had the highest unemployment among black men: Michigan led with 22.1 percent, followed by Louisiana with 19.1 percent and Wisconsin with 18.8 percent.
Seven of the 10 states in which the disparity in household incomes between blacks and whites grew fastest were in the Midwest: Wisconsin, Indiana, Iowa, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio and Missouri. In the South, where the gap between the races was already widest, it generally widened even more. In both 1989 and 1979, six of the 10 states with the largest gaps were Southern: Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Arkansas, South Carolina and Georgia. In Georgia, the gap decreased somewhat during the decade; in the other states it widened.
The figures for Wisconsin are likely to revive a contentious debate over whether the state's generous welfare programs serve to attract poor blacks from nearby Chicago. From 1980 to 1990, the percentage of blacks in poverty rose from 27.8 percent to 40.8 percent. While white income was stagnant, black household income tumbled faster than anywhere in the country, dropping 21.8 percent in constant dollars from $20,711 to $16,189.
Yet while black population growth was anemic in other economically hard-hit Midwestern states, Wisconsin's black population increased by more than one-third, far faster than the national average of 13.2 percent.
In Arkansas, the home state of Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, white median household income rose by about 2 percent during the decade, while for blacks it fell by about 2.5 percent. In 1979, 41.4 percent of blacks were in poverty; in 1989, the figure was 40.9 percent. The total black population (374,000) and the number in poverty (154,000) remained virtually the same.
A Census survey released last year showed that when such payments are factored in and tax payments are factored out, blacks do relatively better and the income gap between blacks and whites narrows.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Black Voters;
In 2 Diverse Neighborhoods, Blacks Are Drawn to Clinton

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITHONIA, Ga., July 24

 BODY:
It is 23 miles in distance and a few light years in ambience from the ragged cottages of Atlanta's inner-city Fourth Ward to the $275,000 homes in the all-black Hunters Pace subdivision in this densely wooded suburb at the edge of metropolitan Atlanta.
But when it comes to Presidential politics these days, there is no difference at all. From McGruder Street in Atlanta, where the only sign of prosperity is the new Cadillacs driven by young crack dealers, to the swimming and tennis club here, black voters seem to be solidly in the Democratic fold. 
 In a topsy-turvy year, there is no guarantee that their feelings will not change if, as expected, Gov. Bill Clinton comes down from his current jolt of favorable publicity after the Democratic convention in New York. And there is certainly no guarantee that the views from the Fourth Ward and Hunters Pace mirror those of black America.
But interviews with blacks in these two entirely different neighborhoods indicated an enthusiasm for the Democratic ticket that seemed potentially in peril in recent months as Mr. Clinton feuded with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and risked offending the Democrats' most loyal constituency.
"A few months ago, I would have said my vote was more a vote against Bush," said Karen Walker, who is building a home here and wrote in Jesse Jackson's name in 1988 rather than vote for George Bush or Michael S. Dukakis. "Now I'd say it's more a vote for Clinton. I've seen a lot of him in the last month, and I like what he has to say."
Back in Atlanta, where Marvin Reed was inspecting his parents' sagging home in an area full of abandoned buildings only a few blocks from where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. grew up, the sentiment was about the same.
"I like Bill Clinton," Mr. Reed said, sipping on a Budweiser in the mid-day heat. "He wasn't born with a silver spoon in his mouth. He was raised without a father and stayed with his grandparents while his mother learned to be a nurse, and he came all the way up. I think that gives him an understanding Bush will never have."
In a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted July 8-11, 75 percent of blacks supported Mr. Clinton, 13 percent President Bush when the two were matched one-on-one. No polls with a broad enough sample to isolate black voters have been taken since the Democratic convention, but poll takers say it is certain that the surge of support in the overall electorate was reflected among blacks.
Motivating black voters has been a concern because of their relatively low turnout in Democratic primaries. In 1988, when Mr. Jackson was a candidate, blacks made up 21 percent of Democratic primary voters. This year, without him in the race, blacks made up 14 percent of the Democratic primary vote. In the 1988 general election, 86 percent of black votes went to Mr. Dukakis.
As in the electorate as a whole, many black voters interviewed voiced skepticism about politics and politicians, Mr. Clinton included.
"Not a one of them's worth three cents more than any other," said Mary Mattox, a housekeeper who was sitting on her porch, smoking a Winston and drinking coffee, across the street from Mr. Reed's parents' house.
But in the next breath she said she always voted and knew she was not going to vote for President Bush.
"The Democrats are for poor people and the Republicans are for the rich," she said. "Now Bush is even hurting the rich. Even the rich people are crying."
To some, the Democrats' post-convention hoopla has not obscured what they see as a failure of anyone to address the nation's most fundamental problems, particularly the Federal deficit, realistically.
"They're all a bunch of spineless wimps, from the President on down to Congress," said Marion Fye, a 46-year-old accountant who lives at Hunters Pace. "No one has the guts to say what it will take to get the budget under control. I want someone to tell me the truth, and no one's doing it."
But Mr. Fye, who said he usually votes Democratic in national campaigns but could not bring himself to vote for either Mr. Dukakis or Mr. Bush four years ago, plans to vote for Mr. Clinton.
It is clear that in addition to whatever short-term benefits the Democrats have gained, at least two more substantial long-term factors explain the positive responses here.
The first is the ailing economy. If change is this year's inescapable buzzword, no one wants it more than black voters who figure they will get the sourest portion of a sour economy.
 
Democrats to Get First Vote
 Allen Jones, a disabled 42-year-old former marine, and Robert Shorter, a 32-year-old with AIDS, sat on Mr. Jones's porch in Atlanta, as if in a grim snapshot of America's urban problems. Mr. Jones was animated and Mr. Shorter mostly silent as he sucked on cherry-flavored crushed ice, but both said they were sure to vote.
"I've never voted before," Mr. Jones said, "but I'm going to vote Democratic this time. You got all these kids that want to make something of themselves, and now they don't have a chance. I think Clinton wants to change things."
In Hunters Pace, where the world of Mr. Jones and Mr. Shorter seems far away, Beverly Perry sees it the same way. "Bush can't be the only one who can do this job," she said. "We need some fresh blood."
The other is that many blacks, both rich and poor, seem receptive to the more moderate message Mr. Clinton is voicing.
Ms. Mattox, the housekeeper, turned from the candidates to a lengthy criticism of welfare. She said she was not familiar with Mr. Clinton's views on the subject, but it was clear his call for welfare reform that would force recipients to work and limit eligibility would not trouble her.
"I work," she said. "I'm not on welfare, and I'm not on food stamps. You've got to cut some of these people off, so they don't think they can stay on welfare forever, and find a way to get benefits to people who really need it."
Similarly, Brent Wilson, a lawyer who lives in Hunters Pace, said the Democrats need a winner more than they need a candidate wedded to traditional liberal positions.
"I think traditionally the Democrats have had what has been considered a 'liberal agenda' and as a result, they haven't been in the White House," he said. "The values of the people who vote are leaning toward the middle, fiscally conservative but socially responsible. My leanings are that way, and I think the majority of black people who vote are leaning toward those kind of middle-America values."
Of 25 people interviewed, none brought up Mr. Clinton's squabbles with Mr. Jackson or Mr. Clinton's criticism of the rap performer Sister Souljah. None saw much significance on either count.
"I respect Jesse Jackson, but I try to form my own opinions," said Jackie Thurman, 39, who was supervising children at the Hunters Pace swimming pool. "I respect his opinion, but I don't think Jesse is 100 percent on the same wavelength as anyone."
Of those interviewed, only one, Alexander Jones, a 35-year-old butcher at a neighborhood market in the Fourth Ward, said he planned to vote for Mr. Bush.
"Clinton's a showboat," he said. "He's running around offering a chicken in every pot. When a man makes a lot of promises, you've got to watch him."

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Leaders Back Beaten Woman

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
Police officials in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, met with more than two dozen angry and concerned community leaders yesterday, a day after a member of the 81st Precinct's Community Council accused several officers and a sergeant of beating her and her three grown children.
The officials called the meeting to address community outrage and defended the officers, saying they were simply responding to a fight between two sons of the council member, Ann B. Dodds. They added that all of the officers were injured in the dispute and that one had a broken shoulder. 
 Their account came as the two men whose fight led to the incident offered a sharply different account from the police version after they were released from jail last night.
Mrs. Dodds's sons, Harold Dodds and Tyrese Daniels, portrayed the events as Mrs. Dodds had, saying they were struck and arrested without provocation. And Mr. Dodds said the sergeant, Peter Viola, used a racial slur and said black families should handle their own problems.
"If you wouldn't call us out here, we wouldn't have to tame you like animals," he quoted Sergeant Viola as saying.
Mrs. Dodds's family is black. The officers and the sergeant are white.
Many of those who attended the meeting called by the police yesterday said they were satisfied with the officials' quick response and their pledge to investigate the dispute. But they said they were inclined to believe the account of Mrs. Dodds and her family.
"She speaks out," said Frances Hobson, president of the 81st Precinct Community Council, who was at the meeting. "She tells what's what. She tells the truth."
"Something bad happened," Mrs. Hobson said. "More than anything, this points to the need for better sensitivity training for white officers."
The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, has started a separate inquiry and had investigators in the neighborhood yesterday.
The meeting in the 81st Precinct station house at 30 Ralph Avenue was closed to reporters, but those who attended described what happened.
Police officials said they told the community leaders that many details were still unclear.
The commanding officer of Brooklyn Borough North, John J. Hill, an assistant chief, said that when officers first arrived, they saw Mr. Daniels holding a metal pipe and that he hit Mr. Dodds with it. Then, he said, as they tried to handcuff Mr. Dodds, they became involved in a struggle and that four officers, the sergeant and Mr. Dodds flipped over the fence. That is how, he said, one of the officers broke his shoulder.
 
Account Detailed
 City Councilwoman Annette Robinson, who was at the meeting, said Chief Hill was right in calling together religious and civic leaders, particularly, she said, after the recent disturbance in Washington Heights. But she said that her longtime relationship with Mrs. Dodds made her skeptical of the officials' story.
Mrs. Dodds, 57 years old, filed charges of excessive force on Thursday with the Civilian Complaint Review Board, as did several neighbors who said they saw the incident in front of Mrs. Dodds's home at 999A Lafayette Avenue. They said the officers repeatedly kicked and struck Mr. Dodds while he lay on the ground face down in handcuffs.
They also said that a sergeant became angry when Mrs. Dodds tried to read his badge number and when Mr. Daniels tried to take photographs. Mrs. Dodds said the sergeant pushed her, punched her in the head and threw the camera into the street. She and her daughter, Trina Daniels, 22, were treated for bruises at St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn.
Police officials said yesterday that Sergeant Viola sprained his neck and cut his mouth when he was "hit in the mouth with a camera." Of the officers involved, Jerome Bonser's left shoulder was broken, Kenny Paccio had a sprained back and Michael Sandano and Richard Ponzini had sprained wrists. All were treated at Wyckoff Heights Medical Center and released.
Mr. Dodds, 34, and Mr. Daniels, 29, complained of injuries but refused medical treatment, the police said. They were charged with resisting arrest and misdemeanor assault. Mr. Dodds was also charged with possession of marijuana.
Mr. Dodds said that he had been charged with resisting arrest before, but added that he had had no trouble with the police in the last five years. "I'm not a little angel -- nowhere near it," he said. But he added, "The way they were treating me and my family wasn't fair."
Mr. Daniels, an unemployed carpenter, said last night that he and his brother had worked out their disagreement with each other, but not with the police.
"I told the cops in the car, 'You all don't know what you just did. We aren't no average black family. They didn't believe me."
 
Community Support
 Mrs. Dodds is a member of the 81st Precinct Community Council and has lined the wall of a first-floor vestibule in her home with awards from the precinct honoring her work. She is the chairwoman of Community School Board 16 and a community planning board member.
Yesterday, community leaders offered support for Mrs. Dodds.
Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn said he had been friends with Mrs. Dodds for 20 years and that she had always worked to improve police relations.
"Now for her to be the victim of police brutality, it's disturbing," Mr. Towns said. "This is a clear signal that there's more brutality out there than one would realize."

HEADLINE: Montana Wilderness Battle: Apportioning Pristine Acres

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIG TIMBER, Mont.

 BODY:
Beneath a sky bruised by thunderstorms, the Crazy Mountains rise from the high plains of central Montana, a battleground without landmark status.
To the Crow Indians, who live on a reservation just southeast of here, the Crazy Mountains are a sacred place for feasting and spiritual journeys. To the Brand S Lumber Company, the largest employer in Livingston, 30 miles to the west, the Crazies hold valleys brimming with potential 2 by 4's. And to weekend warriors from places like Bozeman and Billings, these mountains are a backyard playground. 
 The fight these three groups are waging over the Crazies is but a skirmish in the grand struggle over Federal land in the Big Sky state. But it is typical of what is happening throughout Montana this summer as state residents and Congress try to settle one of the biggest and most drawn-out wilderness battles of the 20th century.
Nearly six million acres, most of it in the alpine heights of the Rockies, are at stake. The area, larger than Massachusetts, is not just the forest home of grizzly bears, wolves, elk and dozens of other big animals; it also represents the dreams of people who moved to this state believing it to be, as they say here, "the last best place."
 While copper used to fuel fortunes and political careers in Montana, these days scenery is the resource of consequence.
After a dozen years of furious argument over Montana's Federal lands, the state's senior senator, Max Baucus, a Democrat, introduced a bill last year that would designate 1.2 million acres as formal wilderness while freeing up four million acres for potential logging, mining, oil drilling and road building. Another 495,000 acres would be protected under special management, and 500,000 acres that were set aside in 1977 for study would remain pristine.
All six million acres are managed by the Forest Service, which has declared them off-limits to development pending the resolution of the wilderness debate.
In 1988, Congress passed a Montana wilderness bill involving much of the same land, but it was vetoed by President Reagan in one of his last acts in office. This year, the Senate passed its version of the bill by a 75-22 vote. It is now under consideration by several committees in the House.
The White House has deferred judgment on the new bill until a final version is ready. But recent polls suggest that the Bush Administration may have a tough time playing the Montana wilderness issue as a jobs-versus-environment debate -- the tack taken by the Administration in the fight over old-growth forests in the Pacific Northwest. In a poll conducted for the state's largest newspaper chain, Montanans approved of the wilderness bill by 55 to 29 percent, with 16 percent undecided.
 
A Political Football
 And when asked, "Should we protect the environment even if it means that people may lose their jobs," 57 percent of the state residents who were polled picked the environment, versus 36 percent who picked the economy and 7 percent who were unsure, The Billings Gazette reported.
The Crazy Mountains would not be protected under the bill -- one of many aspects of the measure that may keep it bottled up in the House this summer. But House leaders say the boundaries are likely to be redrawn to include such popular sites as Cowboys Heaven northwest of Yellowstone National Park and part of the Crazy Mountains. Critics say that under the Senate bill, too much of the land that would be protected is "rock and ice."
The Montana wilderness bill may be about fish and forests, but it is tied up in politics.
After Montana lost a congressional seat as a result of the 1990 Census, two of the state's enduring political figures, Representatives Pat Williams, a seven-term Democrat from the western side of the state, and Ron Marlenee, an eight-term Republican from the eastern prairies, ended up running against each other. The wilderness bill is a central issue in the race to determine who will represent the largest congressional district outside of Alaska.
Mr. Williams has backed the bill with some reservations. His support has alienated some of his conservationist allies who had urged him to fight to expand the boundaries of protected wilderness. Mr. Marlenee, who has ridiculed environmentalists as "prairie fairies" and "fern feelers," has decided not to fight the bill, but he has also threatened to request a Presidential veto if too much wilderness is included in the final measure.
 
'Vignette of Primitive America'
 Environmentalists, joined by a host of Hollywood celebrities who have recently made Montana into a sort of Malibu with mountains, are urging that the bill be killed unless more land is set aside. If no legislation is passed, they argue, the entire six million acres would remain pristine, protected by the cloud of indecision.
But the bill's backers contend that if Senator Baucus's bill dies in the House much of the land now under consideration for wilderness could eventually be opened to development.
Some of the environmental groups want to create a much larger wilderness area, covering several states -- an area sometimes called the American Serengeti for its abundance of wildlife.
"Much of this area is still a vignette of primitive America," said Lee Metzgar, chairman of the biology department at the University of Montana.
Backed by recent economic studies, Mr. Metzgar and others argue that only a handful of jobs would be lost by introducing a much more ambitious bill that would set aside as much as five million acres of new wilderness in Montana and Idaho.
"If we lose the wilderness, we've lost our economy," said Mike Bader, executive director of the Alliance for the Wild Rockies, based in Missoula, Mont. "The only way we can control our future is to hold on to our wild lands."
While acknowledging that timber, mining and oil jobs have been disappearing, those opposed to more wilderness say there is room enough in Montana to give everyone a piece of the Rocky Mountain pie.
"We want to end the civil war over wilderness," said Russ MacPherson, a forester with the Brand S Lumber Company in Livingston. Rather than wait and risk losing more land to wilderness, an alliance of industry leaders is pushing for passage of a scaled-down version of the Baucus bill, stripped to about 700,000 acres of wilderness.
The company gets an ever-increasing share of its timber from private lands, so a large new wilderness area would not kill its business but would make it harder to stay profitable, Mr. MacPherson said.
The Crow Indians also have a keen interest in how the wilderness lines are drawn. They want the Crazy Mountains to remain untouched.
"Those mountains are sacred to us," said Jerome White Hip, a cultural affairs leader with the Crows. "We use them for feasting and vision quests. We want to keep things as they are."
At the base of the Crazies, Big Timber, with 1,600 people, has the defeated look of a lumber town on a down-slide. Though there is not much big timber left around here, signs in small shops support the industry, proclaiming: "No wilderness, no wolves, no Williams."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Crazy Mountains in central Montana have become a battleground in a struggle between an Indian tribe, a lumber company and tourists over the future of six million acres of Federal land. Visitors posed for pictures above a waterfall on Big Timber Creek in the Crazies. (Larry Mayer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Orders for Durable Goods Rose 2.3% in a June Rebound

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Factory orders for cars, computers and other durable goods recovered in June from a late-spring slump -- just as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, predicted in testimony to Congress a few days ago.
Orders, which zig-zag from month to month, rebounded 2.3 percent, to $122.5 billion, after a 2.2 percent drop in May, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. The rise -- the fourth in the last six months -- suggests that the May decline in industrial production is not apt to continue. 
 "We're not going down," said Rosanne Cahn, an economist at First Boston. "This is more like a plateau than a triple dip."
But the backlog in order books continued to shrink, a sign both that executives remain cautious and that no significant revival in factory hiring is imminent.
"A new pickup will have to wait for housing and consumer spending to react to lower mortgage rates, probably in August or September," Ms. Cahn said. "Manufacturing will reflect that activity a month or two later."
Orders for all types of durables headed higher.
Military goods, a particularly volatile category that accounted for about one-third of the rise in durables orders, jumped 17.6 percent in June after a 27.6 percent slide in May.
More important, orders for capital goods -- an indication that business is determined to invest to raise efficiency -- increased nine-tenths of 1 percent in June after a 1.7 percent rise in May. The latest increases followed two back-to-back declines.
Apart from military goods, the largest leap was for industrial machinery, a top United States export, which increased 4.5 percent after a small decrease in May.
"Capital goods are on a bit of a rising trend," Ms. Cahn said. "It reflects some of the strength of the economy early this year plus the introduction of new computer mainframes."
Primary metals like steel, copper and aluminum shot up 2.8 percent after a small gain in May. Electrical equipment grew 2.4 percent after a small loss the prior month. Transportation orders -- including aircraft -- were up 1.9 percent, but they had plunged 6.6 percent the month before.

HEADLINE: Newspaper Theft Charged at Daily News

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
A two-year investigation of organized crime's penetration of New York newspaper deliveries has uncovered evidence of the theft of about 20,000 newspapers each day at The Daily News last year, state prosecutors said in Manhattan yesterday.
An Assistant District Attorney, Sean Dwyer, said the investigation showed that the theft was organized by members of the Colombo and Lucchese crime families and that it followed the pattern of similar thefts at The New York Post last year by a third Mafia crime family. 
 The District Attorney's office said last month that the Lucchese crime family had also stolen papers from The New York Times and the Metropolitan News Company, which has since been acquired by The Times.
In the News thefts, an affidavit filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by an investigator for Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, says the paper estimated that the thefts cost it more than $1 million a year at a time when it was in bankruptcy, losing money and seeking a buyer. Articles about the affidavit were published yesterday by The Daily News and by New York Newsday.
Virtually all of the stolen papers were taken from News delivery docks in Brooklyn.
The affidavit by Sgt. Daniel Wiese said, "Information provided by certain employees of The Daily News has shown that The News is the victim of wide-scale, highly coordinated theft, and that the perpetrators of the scheme are other high-ranking employees of The Daily News."
 
Elaborate Circulation Fraud
 Sergeant Wiese also said in the affidavit, submitted to the court in January, "The investigation thus far has also revealed that certain high-level members of The Daily News management are involved in a sophisticated fraud that involves the inflation of circulation figures in order to withhold millions of dollars in rebates from advertisers."
John Campi, a spokesman for The News, denied that the paper's circulation figures had ever been inflated.
"We are cooperating fully with the investigation," said Mr. Campi, adding that The News had previously taken steps to make sure that the stolen papers were not included in its circulation figures.
Officials in the District Attorney's office said they were investigating Donald Nizen, who resigned last week as circulation manager of The Daily News. The officials said they were investigating whether Mr. Nizen was involved in opening the door to the theft, which they said was similar to thefts at The Post when Mr. Nizen held a similar position there until early last year.
Investigators said the stolen newspapers, at both The News and The Post, were sold to distributors.
Reached by telephone at home, Mr. Nizen denied the allegations, threatened to sue those who made them and said he had promised to cooperate with the investigation.
The investigation also turned up evidence suggesting that Post officials had inflated circulation figures by 50,000 a day.

HEADLINE: Supercollider Regaining Its Support in Congress

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
Five weeks after the House voted to scrap the $8.25 billion Superconducting Supercollider, prospects for the Texas particle accelerator are sharply improving as it moves through the Senate.
The Senate Appropriations Committee on Thursday allocated $550 million for the project as part of the appropriations bill for energy and water development, setting the stage for a probable floor fight in the next several days. 
 That vote, coming at a time of mounting deficits and expanding domestic social needs, will offer another crucial test for a costly Federal science project. Another such vote, on the $30 billion space station, faces a floor fight in the House next week.
Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, promises to lead the fight to cut the Supercollider out of the appropriations bill. But today he expressed doubt that he could overcome a powerful coalition of Senators who back the project. That coalition is led by J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, the Democratic chairman of the Energy Committee, and the two Texas Senators, Lloyd Bentsen, a Democrat, and Phil Gramm, a Republican.
"This may be like one of those weapons systems that have nine lives," said Mr. Bumpers, who noted that Mr. Bentsen had just succeeded in persuading Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, to reverse his opposition.
Mr. Johnston predicted today that his side would win the Senate vote and would then reinstate the money in a House-Senate conference committee later this summer. "The feeding frenzy of the balanced-budget debate has faded into an afterglow," he said.
 
Some Support Is Shaky
 Mr. Bentsen's staff estimates that 50 Senators favor the Supercollider, but not all of them are solid supporters of the project, which would be built in Waxahachie, 25 miles south of Dallas.
President Bush invited five undecided Republican Senators to the White House on Thursday to lobby for their support, telling them the project was vital for future developments in cancer diagnosis and other technologies. In the past, many scientists have said that it is difficult to predict if practical applications will come out of the project.
"He tilted me from leaning no to the other direction," said Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, who also attended the meeting, said, "I think he made a pretty persuasive case and that's why I'm leaning in his direction."
With the concerted support of scientists in high-energy physics, the Administration and Senate proponents argue that the Supercollider holds out the hope of discovering the fundamental forces that make up the universe. Using 11,000 superconducting magnets, the Supercollider would make subatomic particles collide at close to the speed of light to reproduce the conditions that prevailed just after the birth of the universe.
The project is a boon for the state's faltering economy and could permanently employ 2,000 scientists by the year 2000.
 
Close Vote Is Expected
 Last year, Mr. Bumpers's efforts to scuttle the Supercollider failed by a 62-to-37 vote. But this year he will probably get more support, especially since an Energy Department audit released last week warned that inadequate oversight could mean more than $250 million in cost overruns for construction.
"My guess is this year the vote will be closer," said Senator James M. Jeffords, a Vermont Republican who opposes the project. "The dynamics of the deficit this year makes the expense of that kind of money hard to defend."
After a vociferous debate leading to the narrow defeat of the balanced-budget amendment, the House voted 232 to 181 last month to eliminate $484 million earmarked for the Supercollider.
Although much opposition came from concern about the budget deficit, several California Republicans opposed the project to punish Representative Dick Armey of Texas for challenging Representative Jerry Lewis of California for the post of chairman of the House Republican Conference.
The project's supporters hope that if an Appropriations conference committee reinstates the financing for the project, it will be next to impossible for House opponents to remove the particle accelerator from the total energy and water appropriations bill for a separate vote on the House floor. Lawmakers could then argue that they were not willing to cut off financing for dozens of other worthwhile projects by voting against the bill.
Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat who is a leading opponent of the project, acknowledged that the House opposition to the project was not firm.

HEADLINE: Dinkins, Respected by Foes, Seeks to Pacify Crucial Friends

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Slightly more than a year before the New York mayoral primary, Mayor David N. Dinkins finds himself at a critical, if unexpected, pass. He has appeased many of his enemies, but now he has to win back his friends.
Mr. Dinkins in recent months has won the sometimes grudging respect of many of his harshest critics, including business leaders and fiscal experts, for his handling of the city's financial problems. His political future, though, will depend on how well he can rebuild the coalition that elected him three years ago. 
 Many politicians and political analysts suspect that support for the Mayor is fragile among many of his core constituents -- black and Hispanic New Yorkers, gay voters, liberal whites and union leaders -- in part because the city's fiscal distress caused him to reduce programs and lay off city workers and made it impossible for him to satisfy his supporters' large expectations.
The Mayor, clearly concerned, has stepped up the effort to revitalize his base. He has pushed broad proposals, like his calls for 20 new community health centers and an all-civilian police review board, and myriad smaller acts, like appointing several Hispanic people to senior posts and achieving changes in the Democratic Party platform to promote economic development in Puerto Rico.
 
Reuniting Diverse Coalition
 But many political leaders say Mr. Dinkins faces a formidable challenge in reassembling the unusually diverse coalition that enabled him to defeat his Republican opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, by just 3 percentage points in 1989.
The Mayor himself acknowledged during the Democratic National Convention last week that as recently as six months ago many New Yorkers viewed him as politically dead, overwhelmed by the city's enormous fiscal problems. In a sense Mr. Dinkins has spent two years trying to overcome the image of disarray created in a single week in October 1990 when he agreed to a big raise for teachers and a large increase in the police force, and then said he may have to lay off 15,000 other city workers.
But Mr. Dinkins contended that a string of recent successes -- from his adept stewardship of the budget to his handling of the disturbances in Washington Heights to the Democratic Convention itself -- constituted a kind of political rebirth. He has benefited in part from somewhat more stable finances and better management.
Speaking at a luncheon last week honoring women in politics, the Mayor sought to encourage the Democratic candidate for Senate in Illinois, Carol Mosely Braun, who if elected would be the nation's first black female Senator. "They told me I wouldn't get re-elected, too," he said. "But you watch."
The next day, talking with reporters in City Hall, Mr. Dinkins noted that his approval ratings had gone up in two recent polls. He also said he was aware that many politicians and pundits still thought that he would be unable to rebuild his coalition.
"Well, I think they are dead wrong," the Mayor said. "I think that I will be able to -- not only that, I hope to broaden that coalition."
The elected officials and political analysts who doubt Mr. Dinkins point to two critical groups in which they think he is especially vulnerable -- Hispanic and gay New Yorkers.
"His great trouble is with the Hispanic community, and I don't know if he can repair that," said Richard C. Wade, a professor of urban history at the City University Graduate Center.
Mr. Dinkins's likely opponents -- Mr. Giuliani, a former United States Attorney, and City Council President Andrew J. Stein, who is expected to challenge Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic primary next year -- are already working hard to exploit these perceived vulnerabilities.
On Wednesday, for example, Mr. Stein and Mr. Giuliani joined the leaders of several Hispanic civic groups at a City Hall news conference in which they called on Hispanic political leaders to unite beyond a single candidate in a new Congressional district in Brooklyn and Queens. The district was fashioned to make it possible for a Hispanic candidate to be elected, but at least four have already emerged and Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn says he also will run in the district.
Many Hispanic elected officials and civic leaders say that Mr. Dinkins's standing among New Yorkers with roots in Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, Colombia and other Latin American nations has plummeted since 1989, when he won the votes of 65 percent of Hispanic voters in the general election, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll. He also captured 91 percent of the black vote and 27 percent of the white vote, according to the poll.
 
Rectifying a Perception
 Analysts offer many explanations for the perceived decline in support for the Mayor from Hispanic people. Mr. Dinkins himself said last month, while he was traveling in Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, that there was clearly a perception among Hispanic New Yorkers that he had not done enough for them.
The Mayor maintains that the perception is incorrect, but he has worked hard in the last two months to rectify it, in ways including the Carribbean trip.
He has begun meeting regularly with the eight Hispanic members of the City Council. He supported, as did Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Stein, a proposal for the creation of another Congressional district that would be favorable to Hispanic candidates, in addition to the two devised earlier this year. He visited twice last month with the companion of the Hispanic writer and editor, Manuel de Dios Unanue, who was killed in March by a masked gunman in a Queens restaurant.
And he seldom misses an opportunity to boast of the many Hispanic New Yorkers he has appointed to senior positions. When he mentions the most senior, Cesar Augusto Perales, who was named a deputy mayor last November, Mr. Dinkins almost always recites Mr. Perales's complete name and even attempts the proper Spanish intonation.
It is uncertain, of course, whether Mr. Dinkins's efforts have improved his standing among Hispanic New Yorkers, or even whether it had ever sagged at all.
 
'He Still Has a Year'
 "As I walk the streets, the Mayor is not doing very well," said Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th, a Democrat of East Harlem. "The administration just doesn't seem concerned about the feelings of the community. That's the bad news. The good news is that he still has a year."
Mr. Powell said the Mayor should place more emphasis on programs that help Hispanic communities. Some officials argued that the Mayor was in trouble with Hispanic New Yorkers because he had not hired enough of them for mid-level jobs.
"I'm a great believer in the patronage system, the qualified patronage system," said Councilman Israel Ruiz Jr., a Bronx Democrat. "The people who worked for you should be rewarded somehow. But Dave doesn't believe in that. Dave is a peculiar sort of fellow. He feels that everything has to be done on the merits."
Mr. Ruiz and some other Hispanic officials said they suspected that the Dinkins administration had hired blacks at the expense of Hispanic New Yorkers -- a charge that the Mayor denied.
 
Washington Hts. Leadership
 Several people said the leadership that Mr. Dinkins displayed in helping to quell the violence in Washington Heights two weeks ago may serve him well when Hispanic voters decide whom to support next year.
"I think the Washington Heights incident could become a turning point for the Dinkins administration," said Luis Miranda, the president of the Hispanic Federation of New York City, a coalition of 50 nonprofit social-service agencies.
"His presence, his involvement day to day -- people felt he cared," Mr. Miranda said. "Service to Latino constituents is ultimately what is going to make a difference. Do people feel they are better off today than they were four years ago?"
The same is true for many gay New Yorkers, in the view of political analysts. A litmus test for some is whether Mr. Dinkins will give gay municipal workers the same benefits -- including health insurance coverage for a domestic partner -- that heterosexual employees receive.
 
Hard Line With Unions
 "We believe he promised us that, and he has to get that accomplished this year," said Thomas K. Duane, a Manhattan Democrat who is the first openly gay Council member.
The Mayor's standing with union members will rest largely on contract negotiations that began last month. The city is taking a hard line, saying it will grant raises only in exchange for productivity gains, but labor leaders insist the city already has enough money for raises.
The Mayor said in an interview that the city's budget crisis had made it impossible to do many of the things he would have liked to have done. He also emphasized the huge expectations that accompanied his election as New York's first black mayor.
Basil A. Paterson, a former deputy mayor and Secretary of State and one of Mr. Dinkins's oldest friends, said that "more realistic goals have taken the place of what our idealistic expectations were."
Mr. Paterson said he was confident that despite the obvious difficulties, the Mayor would reassemble the coalition that put him in office. "I've got news for you," he said. "Don't bet against David Dinkins."
