HEADLINE: Lizzie Borden Took an Ax

BYLINE: By Mary Cantwell; Mary Cantwell is a member of The New York Times editorial board. Her small-town childhood in Rhode Island is the subject of a memoir, "American Girl," published last month by Random House.

 BODY:
TODAY THE narrow clapboard house is painted pale gray trimmed with deep green. A small print shop is shoved into one side of it, and a big air-conditioner pokes incongruously from a parlor window. I know it is a parlor window because, like a lot of people who grew up near Fall River, Mass., I am conversant with the floor plan of this house.
It is a house with no corridors and rooms that open awkwardly off one another. Because its former residents were much given to locking their bedroom doors, half the rooms on the second floor were once accessible only by the front staircase. The other half were accessible only by the back staircase. The maid slept in the attic; there were no bathtubs, and the water closet in the basement was seldom visited. It was easier to empty the morning slop pails in the backyard. 
 It was also easier, if one felt one's stomach coming up in one's throat, to vomit in the backyard. There was a lot of vomiting preceding the day that made this house famous, presumably because of the heat (though one resident mentioned poison) and the menu. Truly, this house's backyard does not bear thinking about.
On Aug. 4, 1892, the younger daughter of this house discovered a body sprawled on a settee in the sitting room. A short time later the maid and a neighbor found a second body face down on the floor of the guest room. Death in both cases came at the hands of a person, still officially unknown, wielding a small, sharp hatchet.
 ANDREW JACKSON BORDEN, WHOSE HOME this was from 1874 to 1892, was a tall, thin 70-year-old with hooded dark eyes and a long mean mouth. His relatives had lived in what is now southeastern Massachusetts since 1638 -- in 1714 two Borden brothers literally owned Fall River -- but they were not born equal. By 1892, some Bordens were high on the social ladder, some were Swamp Yankees, which is New England's word for rednecks, and most were in the middle. Andrew Borden, who began as an undertaker and ended as a bank president, was rich enough for a high perch but too stingy to claim it.
Andrew Borden's second wife, Abby Durfee Gray Borden, was short, fat and 63. She, too, had relatives in high places -- several Durfees, like several Bordens, had reaped fortunes from Fall River's cotton mills -- but her father had peddled tin from a pushcart.
There were two Borden "girls," Andrew Borden's daughters by his first wife. The elder, Emma, 41 years old, lived a long life without so much as occasioning an adjective; and in the only certain depiction of her, a drawing, she has covered her face with her left hand. Her younger sister, Lizzie, 32, was of a far more public disposition: active in the Christian Endeavor Society and the Ladies Fruit and Flower Mission, a Sunday school teacher and member of the Women's Christian Temperance Union. Several photographs of her exist, and a novelist named Victoria Lincoln, who lived up the street from her in childhood, left a vivid description. Lizzie Borden, she wrote, was "tall, stocky, jowly, dressy and unremarkable." Except, perhaps, for her eyes. "Photographs assure me that her eyes were as I remember them . . . huge and protruding, their irises an almost colorless ice-blue. . . . I have heard many people speak of them as dead eyes, but the eyes of the dead are dull; Lizzie's had the shine of beach pebbles."
On the very hot morning of Aug. 4, the Bordens' maid, Bridget Sullivan, whom the family called Maggie, and who, feeling ill, had just vomited in the backyard, was told to wash the windows. She did, pausing only to chat over the fence with a neighbor's maid. Everyone in the house -- but for Emma, who was out of town -- had been retching for days. Only Mrs. Borden consulted a doctor. On Aug. 3 she told Dr. Seabury W. Bowen she suspected poison. He suspected warmed-over fish (meals often made repeat appearances at the Borden table) and offered to take a look at the rest of the family. Mr. Borden, angry because his wife had been wasting money on a doctor, ordered him away from his door.
When Bridget started on the windows, Mrs. Borden was dusting. Mr. Borden had gone to the business district, as had John Vinnicum Morse, the brother of his long-dead first wife, who was visiting. Lizzie, who'd been drinking coffee, had left the kitchen.
Once she had finished washing the windows from the outside, Bridget came indoors to a seemingly empty house. Still scrubbing, this time from the inside, she heard Andrew Borden struggling with the locked front door. Bridget went to open it and, also struggling, uttered an impatient "Pshaw!" As she did, she heard Lizzie, who was at the top of the front-hall stairs, laugh. Given the house's peculiar geography, she could have been coming only from the guest room or her own bedroom.
Andrew Borden went into the sitting room to nap. Lizzie went into the dining room to iron handkerchiefs. First, though, she told Bridget about a sale on yard goods, and added that Mrs. Borden, summoned by a note, was out on a sick call. Bridget said she'd go to the sale later, but for now she was taking a nap. Then she climbed the back stairs to the attic. About 10 minutes later, Lizzie called out.
"Maggie, come down!"
"What is the matter?"
"Come down quick! Father's dead! Somebody's come in and killed him."
Bridget ran to Dr. Bowen's house and told his wife the news. She was then dispatched to get Alice Russell, a friend of the "girls." Meanwhile, Mrs. Churchill, a neighbor, noticing the alarums and excursions, came over to see what had happened. On finding out, she sent her handyman for help.
By now, Bridget was back from fetching Miss Russell, along with Dr. Bowen. On the chance that Mrs. Borden was at her sister's house, she asked, should she go there and tell her Mr. Borden was very sick?
"Maggie, I am almost positive I heard her coming in," Lizzie replied. "Won't you go upstairs to see."
Mrs. Churchill went with her. Before they got to the landing, they could see Mrs. Borden, partly hidden by the bed, lying on the floor of the guest room.
Mrs. Churchill rounded the bed to get a better look, then raced downstairs. Alice Russell said, "Is there another?"
"Yes, she is up there," Mrs. Churchill replied.
On Aug. 11, 1892, Lizzie Borden was arrested for the murders of her father and stepmother. Ten months later, she went on trial in New Bedford. The jury waited for what they perceived to be a decent interval, just over an hour, before freeing her. "It will be with a certain relief to every right-minded man or woman who has followed the case," crowed the editorial page of The New York Times, "that the jury at New Bedford has not only acquitted Miss Lizzie Borden of the atrocious crime with which she was charged, but has done so with a promptness that was very significant."
Those are the facts. The rest -- a notorious jingle ("Lizzie Borden took an ax. . . ."), countless books and magazine articles, plays, a ballet, a television drama and, from Aug. 3 to 5 in Fall River, the first Lizzie Borden Conference -- constitute a century of suppositions.
 IN 1892, FALL RIVER WAS A MILL TOWN -- no, more than that, a textile colossus -- and the mills are still the first buildings one sees on crossing the bridge from Somerset. Most are dinosaurs. The Depression came to Fall River five years before it arrived in the rest of the United States and never really left. The unemployment rate -- officially 13 percent -- is the highest in Massachusetts. "Fall River is a city of hills," Bernie Sullivan, the editor of The Fall River Herald News, says, "and we always seem to be going up them."
In 1892, the rich lived on the Hill, actually a steep drop from highland to the waterfront, and the poor lived below them, near the mills. Downtown, where the Bordens lived, must have had an interior logic, but it is gone now, lost to demolition, fires and the intrusion of Interstate 195. Even so, the city has a curious charm. What's left of the old breaks the monotony of the new; and once out of the business district, the streets are bosky. Because the vast majority of its citizens are of Portuguese descent, there's no better Portuguese food outside Lisbon. The Cambodians, the newest, fastest-growing immigrant group, have yet to make a culinary dent.
When the mills failed, the textile millionaires took their money and ran. Even in the good days, they'd never given much of it back to the city in which it had been made. But Lizzie Borden, descendant of Fall River's founding family, has. Tote bags and calendars printed with that famous face are hot items at the Fall River Historical Society's gift counter. And the Lizzie Borden Conference will surely attract tourists as well as scholars eager to debate, among other theses, "The Gertrude Stein/Lizzie Borden Connection" and "Lizzie Borden, Victim of Incest?"
Jules R. Ryckebusch, the conference chairman and an English and communications professor at Bristol Community College, where the conference is to be held, came to Fall River in 1966. A writing instructor, he assigned a paper on the Borden murders to his freshman class. "It was amazing! There was Bordenalia all over the place. One kid was able to get Lizzie's high-school record because her mother worked in the school office. Did you know Lizzie never graduated? And a kid whose father was on the police force got him to run off a complete set of the autopsy photographs, the ones that have never been published because they're so grisly. God, I wish I'd done an oral history! Because in those days there was still someone who knew someone who knew someone who knew something."
Professor Ryckebusch has his theories. So have legions of others. The Borden murders have been ascribed to Bridget, to a presumed illegitimate son of Andrew's and to passers-by unknown. Some amateurs of crime have kept a keen eye on Emma, despite her absence, and John Vinnicum Morse is thought by many to have been a very odd lot indeed. Jules Ryckebusch is sticking to Lizzie:
"It was money. The motive was money. But this wasn't planned. And Lizzie did hate her stepmother. My guess is she saw Lizzie doing something in her bedroom -- masturbating for all I know -- and Lizzie was enraged. There's an almost erotic association with that kind of violence. Nineteen or 20 ax blows! She got a kick out of continuing to slaughter her.
"Lizzie knew her father would know what happened, so she had to kill him. The killing released something, something like an orgasm. By the time the police arrived, she was fairly relaxed.
"Just for the hell (Continued on page 42)
of it, I sometimes mention Fall River -- and people say either 'Never heard of it' or 'Wasn't that where Lizzie Borden . . . ?' "
IF IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO divorce Lizzie Borden from this city, so it is impossible to separate this city from Lizzie Borden. "I'm just staying around long enough to tell people we had something in Fall River besides Lizzie Borden." The speaker is Florence Brigham, a former curator of the Fall River Historical Society, and she may as well forget about her mission in life. Not only do visitors make a beeline for the society's Borden memorabilia, but Mrs. Brigham is herself a splendid talker about these murders and their motive. The daughter-in-law of a character witness for Lizzie, she is, at 92, the last of the someones who knew someone who knew someone who knew something.
"I might have found out so much about this, and so could a lot of others, if only it hadn't been a closed subject," she says. "Why, Alice Russell was my sewing teacher at the Highland School! I could have asked her. When I think of it! I had so many ties to the story, and I never asked. Nobody did, out of respect to the name, out of respect to the other Bordens who still lived here. When my son was a little boy, he asked his grandmother if Lizzie did it. She said, 'Lizzie Borden was tried, and she was acquitted, and we don't talk about that anymore.' "
As she speaks, Mrs. Brigham, who is the size and speed of a cricket, is moving briskly about the kitchen of the Brayton mansion. The Brayton mansion houses the historical society, and its kitchen houses the contents of the hip bath.
The hip bath. Yes.
Once Lizzie's trial was ended, her lawyer, Andrew J. Jennings, dumped his notebooks, the minutes of Lizzie's inquest and assorted souvenirs into a hip bath, covered it with an awning and never spoke of the matter again. Seventy-five years later, his daughter gave the hip bath to the historical society. Barbara Ashton, then a reporter at The New Bedford Standard Times, was there when it arrived.
"I can remember sitting out in the office," she says, "opening the package and going 'Oooooooh.' "
Small wonder. The hip bath held not only the expected written material, but Abby Borden's dustcap and switch. The Marseilles spread and pillow shams with which she had been making up the guest room bed, each spotted with minute drops of blood. Locks of the victims' hair and two paper tags neatly labeled "Mr. Borden's stomach" and "Mrs. Borden's stomach." A handleless hatchet. The hatchet, probably, though yet another book is soon to proclaim its innocence.
Lizzie's lunch bucket, the bucket that was brought to her every day she was held in the Taunton jail, is on the side of the soapstone sink. The stool on which she sat to eat that lunch is near a window, and an ironing board, said to be hers, is beside it.
"Of course, it didn't have legs then, but don't you think that board is too heavy for a woman to lift?" Mrs. Brigham asks. "No," I answer, remembering the ease with which my short, stout grandmother, who was 15 years old in 1892, hefted her own legless ironing board. I am caught in the web. Two days in Fall River and I, too, am opining.
Leaving that ghastly kitchen (photographs of the Bordens' skulls hang above the sink), we speak of the dress Lizzie burned the morning after the murders, the dress some claim was bloodstained and that she claimed was soiled. "That family would never have burnt a dress just because it had paint on it," Mrs. Brigham says. "They would have torn it up for rags, or used it for quilt squares." And I, remembering my grandmother's ragbag, can only agree.
SOON AFTER HER acquittal Lizzie Borden and her sister, Andrew Borden's only heirs, left the purgatory that was that poky little house downtown and entered heaven. She bought a house on the Hill.
It was a big house with four bathrooms -- there would be no noisome backyard here -- and a world away from the spinning machines and the barefoot boys with old men's faces who worked them. This was the kind of house her friends at the Ladies Fruit and Flower Mission lived in. ("Why were there so many old maids among the group?" Mrs. Brigham asks rhetorically. "It was because they never married outside their own social set. The boys got out and fell in love with their college friends' sisters. But the girls were stuck here.")
They lived quietly, Lizzie and Emma, but not quietly enough for a society that would have liked Lizzie to perform some equivalent of suttee. A jewelry store in nearby Providence accused her of shoplifting; she had a crush on an actress named Nance O'Neil, and one night she gave a party for a theatrical troupe. Emma moved out soon after.
"My mother-in-law finally gave up on Lizzie," Mrs. Brigham says, "and I always thought it was those theater people. I can just imagine her and all those other Yankees saying: 'Now what does she want to do this for? Disgrace herself -- and us -- because we accepted her back.' "
Lizzie Borden died on June 1, 1927, and was buried after sunset in Oak Grove Cemetery. Only the undertaker's assistants were present for the interment.
"IF SHE'D BEEN CONVICTED, she'd have been hanged. And they didn't want to hang a woman." So says John C. Corrigan, Jr., a Fall River lawyer, who is in the Quequechan Club sipping a cold drink and munching hot peanuts. The Quequechan has a long porch and a dark mahogany bar and was established around 1894. Now it has both male and female members of varying professions and ethnicity, but then it was a hangout for well-off Yankee males.
John Corrigan says he thinks the jurors did the best they could with what they had. Lizzie's inquest testimony, which was a mass of contradictions, was excluded; so was the testimony of a pharmacist who swore that she had tried to buy prussic acid, a poison, from him the day before the murders, and the judge's charge to the jury was a virtual order to acquit. Even without all that, however, there would still have been that reluctance to execute a female.
Massachusetts hadn't executed a woman for centuries, Corrigan recalls, not since one Bathsheba Spooner was found after her death to be, as she'd protested, five months' pregnant. I recall a photograph of the hanging of Mary Surratt, who kept the boardinghouse in which Lincoln's assassination was planned. A guard's umbrella had shielded her from the summer sun, and before the trap was sprung someone had tied a rope around her skirts so no one could look up them as she dangled from the noose. Presumably Lizzie would have received similar courtesies.
Being chairman of the Legal and Forensics Panel at the Lizzie Borden Conference may well be fun for John Corrigan. He is, after all, a lawyer with an interest in the case. But he is ambivalent about the conference itself: "How the hell do you celebrate a gruesome ax murder?"
You don't, especially when you are standing in the Borden plot at Oak Grove Cemetery. A stele in the center is engraved:
 
Andrew Jackson Borden
 His wife
 Sarah Anthony Borden
 His wife
 Abby Durfee Borden
 Children of Andrew J. and Sarah A. Borden
 Alice Esther
 1856-1858
 Lizbeth Andrews
 1860-1927
 Emma Lenora
 1851-1927.
In truth, it isn't Lizbeth Andrews Borden who's buried here, because there never was such a person. Lizbeth Andrews was a figment of Lizzie Andrews's imagination: a woman with a lovely name and, if names confer magic upon their possessors, a lovely life.
A handful of friends, the books about Lizzie Borden say, attended a funeral service at the house on the Hill, during which a hymn was sung by the soloist from Central Congregational Church. Not exactly, Florence Brigham says.
"Mrs. Turner -- Vida Pearson to me -- was asked if she would sing 'My Ain Countree' at 306 French Street at a certain time. 'So I rang the bell,' she told me, 'and a gentleman said: "Follow me. You're to stand beside the fireplace." So I stood there and sang that song to an empty room. I never saw a soul but that one man.' "

SECTION: Section 2; Page 2; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2706 words

HEADLINE: CULTURAL VIEW;
You Can't Please All of the People . . .

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
Stung by three years of controversy, the National Endowment for the Arts recently produced a nine-minute video explaining its mission and achievements. Walter Cronkite, once the most trusted talking head on television, begins by noting that the endowment represents one of the smallest parts of the Federal budget; it is allocated just 68 cents annually for every American.
The rest of the video demonstrates how much that sum has bought. There are brief shots of orchestras, ballet companies, circuses, children's festivals, pottery making, the Vietnam Memorial, theater performances, museum galleries, folk dancing, an American Indian ritual -- images punctuated by Ray Charles singing "America." The video stresses two aspects of the endowment's labors: television (a "medium of collective experiences") and community (where the N.E.A. helped "make multiculturalism a reality long before it became a catchword"). 
 Missing from the video is any hint of the controversies that have raged since 1989, controversies so familiar they can be summarized by a list of names -- Mapplethorpe, Serrano, Frohnmayer, Helms -- and a list of words -- censorship, outrage, decency, quality. Publicly financed exhibitions of artworks that included images of a jar of urine, a bullwhip and various bodily parts were attacked and defended with principles far more important than the works themselves.
Somewhere between the video's celebratory vision and the recent debates, the underlying reason for the founding of the endowment seems to have been lost. "Art is a nation's most precious heritage," Lyndon Johnson said upon signing the law that created the National Endowment for the Arts in 1965, "for it is in our works of art that we reveal to ourselves, and to others, the inner vision which guides us as a nation."
But what is that inner vision today? Why, after 27 years and more than 90,000 grants, have the controversies increased? What conception of the arts does our country have? And what vision does the endowment serve? The answers tell us much about the status of contemporary culture and its discontents, and much, too, about our "inner vision" or, as I think, the lack of it.
A few years ago, a corporation used an advertising slogan at its sponsored cultural events: "It takes art to make a company great." The reason for founding the National Endowment for the Arts was similar; it began as one of Johnson's Great Society programs. But opponents of the legislation questioned whether the Government should be involved. The argument was that political interference in the arts is repugnant; the arts should be spared the typically deadening hand of the Federal bureaucracy.
The fear of political interference still haunts the debate today. An agency whose chairman is appointed by the President (with the advice and consent of the Senate) and whose managing body, the National Council on the Arts, is composed of 26 citizens, also selected by the President, is bound to be a political institution (the advisory panels of artists and other citizens who make grant recommendations, notwithstanding). And why not? Since the patron is the Government, perhaps the grants should be somewhat political, reflecting the country's view of itself and its arts.
The questions to ask then are, what sort of patron a Government can be, and what sort of patron our Government has become.
 
Expansionism
Culture Becomes A Growth Industry
 The endowment's philosophy is easy enough to discern from its recent publications. Among the most revealing about how the agency sees itself and its role and how it justifies itself politically to Congress and the public is a 106-page book entitled "Program Accomplishments." It was submitted to the House Appropriations Committee in April 1991 by the endowment's chairman, John E. Frohnmayer. President Bush dismissed Mr. Frohnmayer from his post last winter because he did not satisfy the most conservative critics of the endowment. Under his successor, Anne-Imelda Radice, who was appointed acting chairman in May, the fundamental philosophy appears unchanged.
The N.E.A. has consistently seemed to treat culture almost as if it were an economic system that had to display steady growth; every achievement is measured in terms of numbers and "expansion." There is the expansion of dollars given and dollars matched, of number of events and attendance. There is even an Expansion Arts Program, whose goal is to "expand programming" to assure, as the 1991 report puts it, that "the maximum number of Americans have access to excellent art." Expansion of access is admirable and important. But as American orchestras have learned, it can also be harmful, leading to out-of-scale expenses and a larger but less committed audience.
There are even times when the goal of expansion seems to become an obsession. The N.E.A. boasts, for example, that in 1989 the Cleveland Opera presented the premiere of "Holy Blood and Crescent Moon," the first opera by Stewart Copeland, a rock composer: "It outsold the company's productions of the A-B-C of opera, 'Aida,' 'La Boheme' and 'Carmen,' as well as its 1987 production of 'Porgy and Bess' by more than 61 percent." There was no word about the work's critical failure, only about attendance. There is actually no direct relationship between numbers and artistic achievement. Pop culture, which needs no patronage, will always draw the largest audience.
 
Drive for Diversity
An Artistic Soup Of 170 Varieties
 There is another, even more important aspect of the N.E.A.'s role as a Government agency: it is preoccupied almost as much with constituencies as with products. This means, in particular, racial and ethnic representation. The agency claims that it serves 170 ethnic minorities. It even has a Folk Arts Program that "helps insure that every American can find somewhere in the endowment a place where his own people's artistic voice can ring loud and clear." The N.E.A. has financially assisted: "Hmong needlework, coastal sea-grass basketry, southeast Alaska native dance, American Indian basketry and woodcraft, Pacific Island canoe building and Appalachian banjo playing."
Wonderful things come out of this diversity even though many grants amount to just a few thousand dollars. But the endowment effectively declines to let its own voice ring loud and clear. It argues that it "must not, under any circumstances, impose a single esthetic standard." It even states that "each traditional group has its own internal criteria for success." This means that each culture can be judged only by its own rules.
So the agency's priorities are established demographically. The N.E.A. seems to see its central mission as that of a democratic disburser of funds. Its independent judging panels are analyzed geographically to within a tenth of a percentage point. This year, 14 percent of panelists are from New York, 13.3 percent from the Central Plains.
Breakdowns are also racial. In 1991, 33.4 percent of the panelists were "minorities" -- American Indians, Asians, blacks or Hispanics -- and 48 percent were women.
The emphasis on diversity is increasing. In the 1987 fiscal year, 11.8 percent of the budget went to "multicultural" programming; last year, 15.2 percent did. In the 1991 fiscal year, 22.3 percent of all grants went to support arts associated with minority communities. Geographically, since 1989, the proportion of panelists from New York has declined by 36 percent (radically undervaluing the city as an arts center); California, the country's other major center for the arts, also was subject to rationing.
In all these cases, there are political arguments to be made for percentages: the arts must serve an entire country; there may have been neglected areas in past years. But the result is that a distribution curve becomes the determining factor, supplanting esthetic judgment.
Given this cultural policy, the Mapplethorpe case and its descendants, with their disputes over public sponsorship of material deemed offensive by some, take on a different character.
There have been incidents throughout the endowment's history when grants were objected to; in 1972, for example, Jesse Helms opposed the support given Erica Jong's novel "Fear of Flying." But now the stakes have been raised. There is more aggressive monitoring from political conservatives; objections have even increased since the end of Ronald Reagan's Presidency. This is partly out of conservative anxiety over the Bush Administration's less ideological stance. Simultaneously, some segments of the arts world have become more radical and explicitly political.
In addition, the endowment has aggravated tensions with its own apparent inconsistency. Generally, the agency has declined to establish universal criteria for judgment or to assert some idea of shared community; it has instead been preoccupied with just the opposite, with giving each subgroup and interest group an apportioned slice of the arts pie.
According to this view, the avant-garde arts lobby ought to be just another one of these groups. Performance artists like Karen Finley or Tim Miller, who have had grant applications rejected by the N.E.A., believe they speak for political or sexual minorities. Once the endowment has taken the position that no standard can be applied to all, that each minority group has its own culture and should be judged by its own criteria, how can the agency suddenly assert standards that transcend special interests? These artists intend to provoke; by their terms, they succeed.
Their rejection has been labeled "censorship," as if freedom of speech were being abolished simply because the Government declined to finance a particular project. This view exists because of the common belief that the Government is obligated to sponsor differing and provocative views. It is also precisely how the N.E.A. has acted -- as if all varieties of expression were entitled to equal time. The endowment has thus effectively abolished its own right to make judgments, while factions in the arts community lobby for their causes with increasing fervor.
 
Art and the Schools
Culture as Therapy, Not Enlightenment
 When it comes to arts education in the schools -- which is already in a bankrupt condition -- the problems multiply. In its 1991 report, the N.E.A. treats education as an extension of its general populist philosophy, implying that anybody can produce art, that no system of standards and values has more validity than any other.
But art involves a study of techniques, a mastery of a body of knowledge. What about meter and form in poetry, score reading and listening in music, brush strokes and perspective in painting? What about the discipline of art? The 1991 report bypasses all this. In March, the endowment announced a major initiative in arts education with the Department of Education; the question is whether their call for "world-class standards" will mean real change.
The critic Robert Hughes has argued that in the United States art is often treated as if it were therapeutic, as if it were meant to heal rather than enlighten. This may indeed be the key to the endowment's democratic esthetics. Here is how the N.E.A. describes a program designed to create an "in-depth arts-in-education program" for schoolchildren in Augusta, Ga. It is aimed at "improving general academic achievement, the general learning environment, student self-esteem, attendance, creative thinking and social equity among students." Everything for everybody, except world peace.
 
Government Patrons
Does a Democracy Allow for Elites?
 The great patrons of the past were usually individuals of enormous wealth and authority who asserted personal taste in granting commissions. This produced much that was meretricious but nearly all that was magnificent as well. The artworks commissioned by the Roman Catholic Church were really commissioned by individual popes like Julius II and Clement VII, who employed Michelangelo. In this country individual patronage has given us institutions ranging from the Boston Symphony Orchestra to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
Governmental patronage has a very different character. In countries with a clear consensus about culture, where traditions are deep and uniform, large quantities of money are available and often disbursed with great confidence. In France, culture high and low is a Cabinet-level concern. Public arts support in West Germany before unification traditionally amounted to more than a billion dollars a year; the 1992 N.E.A. budget was $176 million.
But problems still arise. In Italy, getting a job in an orchestra can be a matter of political party membership. In the Netherlands, there was, until recently, a program under which visual artists received higher benefits if they donated works to the state. By 1983, almost half a million works had been donated, most accumulating in warehouses. A policy revision involving stricter judgments of "quality" was finally introduced.
So confusion about taste, art and allocation is not American alone. But it is aggravated by aspects of our culture. There is a tension between the elite character of the fine arts and the American traditions of egalitarianism. In the 19th century, Alexis de Tocqueville predicted that American democracy would change the character of art itself. The emphasis, he said, would be away from the soul and toward the body; the arts would prefer motion and sensation to sentiment and thought. In a democracy, he wrote, "the productions of artists are more numerous, but the merit of each production is diminished."
The N.E.A. seems to be fulfilling this prophecy. Its promotional video focuses on the body, on motion, on sensation, on quantity. Moreover, the agency, even while supporting important projects in the fine arts, has followed the now regnant belief that notions of "high" and "fine" are matters of aristocratic snobbery. This is, of course, an extension of de Tocqueville's prediction: esthetics has become egalitarian and even irrelevant.
 
Redrawing the Portrait
What Should The Endowment Be?
 The N.E.A. has had its triumphs, but it continually stumbles over its own philosophy. The conservative critic and publisher of The New Criterion, Samuel Lipman, who has served on the National Council on the Arts, has argued that the endowment's policy of giving matching grants has stifled diversity in private patronage. In a series of provocative essays he has suggested that the agency's populism has distorted audience attentiveness and that Federal financing has created a "formidable bureaucratic class of administrators and advocates," many of whom may have less discernment than artists or donors. The result is an arts industry, intent on growth and self-preservation, supported by Government largesse.
What, then, should the endowment be? For the N.E.A. to be a more important patron it would have to become even more controversial. It would have to jettison its gerrymandering of funds according to geography, race, ethnicity, style and idea. It would have to argue that some things may be worth financial assistance that do not offer a social return on investment. It would have to be democratic in its inspiration but elite in its tastes. It would have to give priority to a national high culture that should provide a unifying frame for our rich multiplicity of folk and popular cultures. Finally, it would have to aggressively represent these positions in arguments for serious arts education.
Unfortunately, in our fractured culture, not much of this is possible. A majority of the public (and perhaps many readers) may agree with the endowment's approach to art; that is why the endowment boasts about it. Any N.E.A. that exercised strong contrary convictions would be cut to pieces for its elitism or narrow tastes. It may even be that the only National Endowment for the Arts we can have is the one that already exists. In its occasional triumphs and desultory character, it is a creature of the culture it supports. It is also, I fear, a portrait of ourselves, a disconcerting reflection, not of "inner vision" but of its absence.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Beyond Organic Architecture: The Office as Oasis

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
Recessions are hard times for architects, but they can be enriching times for architecture. In the early 1970's, a lull in real estate development offered a chance to absorb new ways of thinking about urban context. When building resumed toward the end of the decade, architects had largely abandoned the modernist view of the city as a messy slate to be rubbed clean. They had come to value the mess as history: a rich heritage of ideas.
Yesterday history, today biology. Now we've got a real mess on our hands: the environmental crisis that summoned the world's leaders to Rio last month. It's time architects were summoned to address this issue as well. Cars and factories aren't the only big polluters. Homes and office buildings consume energy, release toxic fumes, send mountains of garbage out into a world that is short on dumps -- or fast becoming one. How can design protect the environment from the impact of urban growth? There may be no more pressing question for architects to ponder. 
 Randolph Croxton and Kirsten Childs, partners in the Croxton Collaborative, a New York firm, are wizards at making something worthwhile out of a mess. They are taking a wreck of a building at Broadway and East Fourth Street and converting it into a $24 million showcase for ecologically sound design. The new building, which will be called Audubon House and will serve as headquarters for the National Audubon Society, has already aroused wide interest for its innovative techniques dealing with lighting, refuse treatment and climate control. Mr. Croxton and Ms. Childs aren't just renovating a building here. They're turning pollution control into an art form.
One of the beauties of Audubon House is the ease with which it joins the lessons of the 1970's to the solutions needed today. Lodged in a century-old Romanesque loft building designed by George B. Post, architect of the New York Stock Exchange, this is no space-age Biosphere. It is a tribute to the preservation movement that gave old buildings new life. And it is "recycling" on a giant scale.
Mr. Croxton, an architect, and Ms. Childs, an interior designer, tried out some of their ideas three years ago in another loft renovation, the New York offices of the Natural Resources Defense Center. The main goal there was to reduce energy consumption. Many of Mr. Croxton's energy-saving techniques rival in ingenuity those of the Gothic builders in their resourceful use of light. Clerestory windows admit natural light into private offices. Artificial lighting is shut off by motion detectors when offices are unoccupied. Pendant fixtures eliminate the loss of overhead light into ceiling recesses. Pale wood and painted surfaces magnify ambient light without creating glare. Files are placed near windows.
Two sets of judges have tested the results. Consolidated Edison, which awarded N.R.D.C. a grant to implement these methods, has monitored the offices for three years. Power consumption for lighting has been cut to less than a quarter of the level classified "energy efficient."
But the toughest judges are the people who work there. Not all of them looked forward to becoming Croxton guinea pigs. Some feared having to endure winter chills, summer heat, and eyestrain from peering over dimly lighted desks. They are breathing easier now in more ways than one. The air they inhale is free of formaldehyde and other chemicals that commonly pollute office interiors. And comfort has not been sacrificed to environmental correctness. With their neutral palette of off-white walls and soft green carpets, washed by the natural light that cascades from skylights down a central stairwell, these offices are an urban oasis.
Audubon House expands the oasis to the scale of a small green island. Although the National Audubon Society will occupy only the top five of the building's eight stories, it owns the entire property. This has allowed Mr. Croxton and Ms. Childs to overhaul the building from the ground up. Actually, from below the ground: a central recycling depot in the building's subbasement is the renovation's most imposing feature. With chutes running from the floors above, the system collects and separates four types of refuse, from organic matter (dispatched as compost to a rooftop garden) to paper (some 42 tons will be bundled for recycling each year).
Organic material and paper will also be used to insulate the building. Walls are injected with a thick pink foam based on whipped sea water. Floors are lined with cellulose made from recycled newsprint. It would take a small truckload of unrecycled newsprint to list the building's other features. Yet even a complete inventory could overlook the point of this design. What counts here is the design methodology -- how the parts fit together. This design is about connections: between the gas-fired heating and cooling system and the sun's transit overhead, between the thermal resistance of glass, the moisture content of air, and the height, placement and colors of office partitions.
The unity of this design surpasses the organic architecture of Frank Lloyd Wright because it unifies a far more complex set of parts. Most of those parts are invisible. They consist of information rather than tangible forms. What we will see at Audubon House is one stage in a comprehensive planning process that begins with research into each material used and continues as materials leave the building to be recycled. Mr. Croxton and Ms. Childs carry this kind of thinking to an extreme degree. They not only want to know what materials are made of, and how well they function, but they've also looked into the environmental standards of their suppliers' factories, their impact on local economies, even how they treat their workers.
It's tempting to ridicule an approach that differs so radically from conventional design. Is this architecture, or is it plumbing? Design or economics? Building or evangelism? Mr. Croxton's lighting may relieve headaches, but his puritanical philosophy can bring on a migraine. Who left the lights on? Save the tin foil! It's hard enough to separate the trash. Do we have to analyze it also?
Yet if this is an obsession, it is a magnificent one. And its benefits aren't limited to lower Con Ed bills, cleaner air and a more robust ozone layer. Audubon House also enlarges our conception of history. Some designers boast of the rare woods used in fancy marquetry. Ms. Childs boasts that her wood comes from "nonendangered" sources. Yet she turns humble wood into a precious material by reminding us of its rich history: the people, land, energy, ideas, and time it takes to grow a tree and fashion it into tables or pencils. History, in other words, isn't just a matter of landmark buildings and period styles. It is also a record of the ordinary objects that circulate through daily life.
Mr. Croxton takes the same approach with the building's exterior. The old brick-and-terra-cotta walls will retain the marks of age. Yes, Mr. Croxton is reluctant to commit the energy it would take to remove them -- but also to rub out the history those marks represent. If the walls look the worse for wear, fine. That will make the point that what he advocates is conservation, not restoration.
The result is that many people will walk past Audubon House without realizing that something revolutionary is going on inside. Indeed, if this project is any indication, there's a good chance that as the revolution spreads, few of us will even see it. But we will breathe it.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Spring's Air Deals Mean a Crush in Summer

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.; JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., based in the Washington bureau of The Times, covers aviation and transportation.

 BODY:
CLUTCHING their cut-rate tickets and dragging the kids, this summer's vacationers are descending on airports in record-breaking numbers, turning the hubs into hubbubs where an unprepared traveler might get a rude shock at the start of an intended trip to tranquillity.
The result of the half-price fares that the major airlines offered in late May and early June, the crowds are expected to last through mid-September with airlines carrying at least as many people each month as they did in June, when the low fares took effect. In June, air travel suddenly jumped 10 percent compared with last June, with nearly 39 million boardings, according to the Air Transport Association.
When Edward R. Book, president of the Travel Industry Association of America, recently passed through O'Hare Airport in Chicago on a flight from Washington to Phoenix, he found the nation's busiest airport was "wall to wall people." Airport executives say that O'Hare may well handle a record quarter of a million passengers on its busiest day this summer. But for bad weather and flight cancellations, that day probably would have been over the Fourth of July weekend. In the first 12 days of July, American Airlines, which started the summer fare wars and funnels many of its travelers through Chicago, recorded five of the busiest days in its history.
Although the airlines say they aren't making much money with their fire-sale prices, the rest of the travel industry is reaping a bonanza, Mr. Book said. But he and other travel experts cautioned that the traveling public had better be aware of the side effects of the crowding, which has meant spot shortages of rental cars, traffic jams in some national parks and a heightened risk of unpleasant surprises for those who don't leave extra time to catch their planes and make connections.
 
First-Time Fliers
 Adding to the confusion is the fact that many of the families packed cheek by jowl in the tourist cabins of jetliners are flying for the first time and may be unfamiliar with even the simplest airport procedures. Nancy Muller of American Express Travel Related Services said that one of the company's Atlanta offices had questioned every customer ordering plane tickets during the two weeks when the half-price specials were being offered. Thirty percent of them said they had never traveled by air before.
American, like other airlines, has posted extra service representatives around airports to search out the disoriented and speed them toward their departure gates. The airline, in a sign of how little some of its fledgling customers know, also published a sheet of a dozen tips for holiday travelers. "When asked to board the plane, do it!" urges Tip No. 11, pointing out that standby customers will be put into empty seats.
That's good advice, said Ed Perkins of Consumer Reports Travel Letter. "It isn't just get to the airport early," he said. "Make sure you get out to the gate early. And get on the plane when your row boards. Even having a boarding pass is no guarantee that someone else doesn't have the same seat assignment." (The airlines say that this is conceivable, but that in fact it almost never happens.)
Another tip: carry as little baggage on the plane as possible. On many days American's planes are averaging nearly 80 percent full, an extraordinarily high number that means many planes are completely full, with no room for carry-on bags in excess of the two-per-person limit.
And the most obvious tip, but perhaps the most commonly neglected, is to allow oneself plenty of time. Arriving at the airport an hour ahead for a domestic flight is cutting it close on a busy day. With parking lots full and traffic heavy, that hour can vanish quickly, especially for those who must pick up tickets at the airport. It's smarter to get tickets ahead of time, from a travel agent or ticket office, which allows passengers to check luggage at curbside and go directly to the gate.
And don't count on finding a car to rent at the other end. Travel agents and car rental agencies say that there are spot shortages of cars, and that prices may be unusually high for those who don't reserve vehicles long in advance.
"The industry probably is going to be sold out in July and August," said Brian Kennedy, executive vice president of Hertz. In almost every city in the country, rentals are up by double-digit percentages, and in some cities rentals are twice as high as usual, he said. More than a third of the Hertz fleet has been reserved for the rest of the summer, an extraordinarily high percentage given that so many cars are rented not by vacationers but by business travelers who do not reserve long in advance.
Mr. Kennedy said that because of the tight supply, travelers were likely to pay higher prices this summer.
Marilyn Kessler, manager of Belair Travel-Carlson Travel Network in Olney, Md., said that in Orlando, Fla., during the week of Aug. 9 the big rental companies were charging up to $150 a week for economy-size cars, while smaller companies off the airport premises would charge as little as $75. Florida's rates are lower than those in other states, she noted.
"If you are planning to rent a car, do it as soon as possible," she said.
Then brace yourself for a traffic jam, especially if your trip is taking you to one of the popular national parks, like Yosemite, Yellowstone or the Grand Canyon.
 
Logjams at National Parks
 The number of visitors to the Grand Canyon is up 35 percent over this time last summer, according to George Berklacy, a spokesman for the National Park Service. He expects the rate to continue, which would mean as many as 900,000 more visitors this summer than last. At the more popular parks, it is too late to reserve a campground or lodging within the park, though accommodations may still be available not far from the park's gates, he said.
Back-country campers won't have problems with crowds in the wide open spaces, of course. But the vast majority of visitors stay firmly on the beaten track -- the paved roads that wind through scenic vistas like those in the central valley of Yosemite, or the Skyline Drive in the Shenandoah.
"If you can time your arrival in the park to sunrise, you're in good shape," he said. "But if you get there after lunch, you are in serious trouble at Yosemite. It is like a commuter run into any large city, a virtual parking lot."
Mr. Berklacy said many visitors to the most famous parks were unaware of alternatives that lie a short distance from the logjams.
"At Mount Rushmore, over the years, we have had to close down the parking lots over 50 times in the summer months," he said. "Yet 10 miles north of Rushmore is the Wind Cave National Park. Outside of Yellowstone, this offers more abundant wildlife than any other national park.
"It is a magnificent, scenic park, with a very adventurous cave, yet we find that less than 10 percent of the people who go to Rushmore make that half-hour drive," he said.
Similarly, travelers interested in seeing the Grand Canyon might be best advised to visit the north rim rather than the hectic south rim.
As in any summer, it's too late now to get lodgings in the biggest national parks. But hotels are still available not far away. Indeed, the best news for travelers is that hotels are still not bursting at the seams. In fact, hotels are heavily promoting package deals to draw tourists who may have already bought plane tickets but not made room reservations.
Many travel agents were so busy during the airplane ticketing boom at the start of the summer that they did not make room reservations for their clients. In some cases, now that things are quieter, agents are calling their customers back to see if they need hotel rooms.
Randy Smith, whose Smith Travel Research tracks the hotel industry and publishes Lodging Outlook, said that demand for hotel rooms was up about 4 or 5 percent this summer, but not enough to wipe out the bargains, especially for travelers who made reservations.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Regional Planning;
A New Chief, With an Rx in the Wings

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
REGIONAL planners must think globally these days. H. Claude Shostal, the new president of the Regional Plan Association, is in the mold.
"For the first time people are beginning to question whether this region is going to manage competitively on a global scale," said Mr. Shostal, a 52-year-old alumnus of Nelson A. Rockefeller's gubernatorial administration who has worked on development issues in and out of government. "They are beginning to question whether we'll lose out to Paris or Tokyo or some other region." 
 Mr. Shostal who took over as president from Richard Anderson in June, comes to the Regional Plan Association as it reached the halfway point in the preparation of its third Regional Plan. The first was completed in 1929. The second came in 1968.
The influence of the global factor on the third plan was underscored just last week by Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, on his return from a trip with other urban professionals to Tokyo. He came back with a fresh appreciation of the regional transportation network that serves Tokyo. And that in turn called attention to a major component of the third plan, its call for an integrated regional transportation network for the metropolitan area.
The planners give it a name -- Regional Express Rail, or Rx -- and if it came to life as they propose, the course of office leasing and development and investment in the metropolitan area could be profoundly affected. As an example, the downtown Mahattan office market would get a considerable lift, because executives living in Westchester would be able to travel there directly by train, without changing trains.
Indeed, the success of the Regional Plan Association in nudging the great transportation bureaucracies and the state legislatures of the metropolitan area toward greater integration may the the test by which the plan's contribution is some day measured. The institutions are the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its operating components in New York State and Connecticut; the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and New Jersey Transit, the state agency that runs New Jersey's buses and trains.
"Berlin has a single regional transportation system," Mr. Yaro said. "Paris has a system, a joint venture with the French National Railways. Tokyo does a much better job than we do." Tokyo and surrounding areas have three closely integrated systems running buses, subways and regional rail lines.
As matters stand in the New York metropolitan area, said Mr. Yaro, it's too hard to get from Long Island to Westchester, from Connecticut to New Jersey, from Westchester and Long Island to lower Manhattan.
HE tempts the layman to hope, for example, that Harlem Line trains may be run on city subway tracks, connecting lower Manhattan directly with the Hudson Valley via the Hellgate Bridge and the Sunnyside Yards in Queens, with no change in train. And that Hudson Division cars may run into Penn Station on Amtrack tracks.
A commuter should be able to get on a Harlem Line train in Scarsdale, for example, and ride to Wall Street in about 45 minutes without changing trains. Another commuter should be able to board the Hudson Line in Tarrytown and make the same trip in about the same length of time.
The possibilities involve many interregional trips that have destinations outside Manhattan. The traveler should be able to board at Tarrytown and ride to Freeport, L.I. Or board at Stamford, Conn., and ride to Princeton, N.J.
These and other similar trips would mean that the trains of one metropolitan-area transportation agency would have to run on tracks controlled by another, which so far is done only in a limited way.
The central hub of this integrated system would be Penn Station in Manhattan. It would need a major improvement, or possibly an annex. Another important investment would be a link between the Sunnyside Yard and the never-opened upper level of the 63d Street subway tunnel, allowing commuter trains to find their way on to city subway tracks.
The association's senior transportation planner is Jeffrey Zupan, who left the Regional Plan Association in 1981 to become senior planner for New Jersey Transit. He returned to the association last year.
Senior planners from the association have already met with their planning counterparts at the M.T.A., the Port Authority and New Jersey Transit. Mr. Yaro describes them as "intrigued and interested" in the planners' ideas.
The problems in implementation are essentially governmental and political, according to Mr. Yaro. Financial investment is required. The M.T.A. already has a huge capital investment program under way, and is having trouble getting it implemented in the Legislature even new investment for the Regional Express Sysem.
Commuter transportation planning is only one element in the third plan. There will also be a section on bringing more immigrants and inner-city minorities into the workforce, for example, and on waste management and freight movement. There will be a proposal for a "highlands greenbelt" that would amount to a boundary for urban growth and protect the water supply.
A FAMILIAR theme in regional planning, sounded once more in the third regional plan, will be that development should be concentrated near mass transportation hubs. "We assume there will be decentralization but we want development around the transportation network," said Mr. Yaro.
Violations of the principle are not hard to find in the metropolitan region. In and around Princeton, N.J., development is occurring along Route 1 instead of along the rail corridor that parallels Route 1. West Windsor Township was mistaken, Mr. Yaro suggested, in using its zoning power to exclude office development in the vicinity of the Princeton Junction railroad station. Similarly, South Brunswick Township has been mistaken in resisting proposals for office development in the vicinity of a station that is to be built, he said.
On immigrants and inner-city minorities, the association sees its task as defining the dimension of the problem and seeking answers almost on a neighborhood by neighborhood basis. It should be possible to develop or expand institutions that link employers with the community groups that are close to immigrants and minority populations, Mr. Yaro said.
On waste management, the advice will be to go slow on big new resource recovery facilties and work instead to reduce the creation of waste.
OVER ALL, the approach of the third plan contrasts interestingly with those of the first and second, which were addressed to a younger region more concerned with implementing growth than protecting the region competitively.
The 1929 plan dealt mainly with growth. It spoke of long-range plans for highways, bridges, tunnels, parks and open space, and where to put them. It opted for a tunnel to Brooklyn from the tip of lower Manhattan rather than a bridge, and won the point.
The 1968 plan is remembered largely for its emphasis on the need to nurture the growth of employment subcenters throughout the region and to revitalize the central cities. The growth of corporate centers in Stamford, White Plains, New Brunswick and downtown Brooklyn are considered expressions of that idea.
In the 90's the emphasis is on the need to improve the basic structure of regional life, thereby helping it to compete both internationally and with other regions for economic growth. To Mr. Shostal, the new president, it is no disaster if Merrill Lynch moves some of its facilities from Manhattan to Jersey City, or Bankers Trust shifts some operations to Hoboken.
"We're all in this together," he said.

HEADLINE: Divorce Logjam Leads to Alternatives

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE increasing number of divorce cases filed in recent years has created a severe backlog in many of the state's family courts despite concerted efforts by court officials to ease the problem.
In some counties, divorce lawyers say, the wait for a trial in a contested divorce can last up to four years, resulting in personal and economic strains on the parties. Psychologists say that such protracted divorce proceedings often adversely affect the court's ability to make accurate decisions on the issues of child custody and visiting rights. 
 And while officials are attempting to address the backlog by assigning more judges to the family courts and by creating divorce mediation panels in every county, some lawyers say that more radical changes are necessary if the divorce caseload is to be reduced to manageable proportions.
As a result, an increasing number of lawyers seem to be taking matters into their own hands by asking other lawyers to serve as what one called "rent-a-judges" and act as arbiters of their pending cases.
 
'The System Has Stalled'
 "We are suffering from a crushing backlog in the matrimonial courts," said James P. Yudes, a Springfield divorce lawyer. "The system has stalled."
Alice Stockton, the assistant director of the Family Division of the Administrative Office of the Courts, said that from July 1987 to June 1991 the total number of divorce cases filed in the state's courts rose 41 percent -- to 49,226 from 34,938. And as the number of filings rose, Ms. Stockton said, so too has the backlog in the busier counties.
"There are probably a million reasons why some counties have backlogs," Ms. Stockton said. "Some might have a high volume of very complicated cases. Others simply don't have enough judges. Unfortunately, there are just too many people getting divorced."
Yet another reason for the backlog, Ms. Stockton said, is the fact that judges in the Family Part of the State Superior Court have jurisdiction over 13 different types of cases, including juvenile delinquency, termination of parental rights, child abuse and domestic violence.
 
Judges Must Divide Attention
 Consequently, the judges must divide their attention between the typical divorce cases and the more pressing cases in which someone's health or safety may be in danger.
During the 1991 court year, for example, there were 36,054 domestic violence cases filed statewide, a 35 percent increase over 1987. Such complaints are heard almost immediately in every county, resulting in backlogs of other types of cases, particularly divorce.
In some counties, the backlogs cause in huge delays between the times when the divorce complaints are filed and when they are finally scheduled for trial.
"Bergen County has a four-year wait," said Mr. Yudes, who has been practicing matrimonial law since 1975. Other counties with substantial backlogs include Essex, Middlesex, Morris, Passaic and Somerset.
Such delays, Mr. Yudes said, can contribute to increased frustration, anger and even violence between the parties.
"In abuse cases, part of the husband's violence is tied to the frustration with how long it takes to get through the system," Mr. Yudes said. Some women, he said, will settle for less than they might be entitled to just to get out of the marriage.
"They say, 'Cut me a cheap deal, give him what he wants, and let me get out of this before he kills me,' " Mr. Yudes said. As a result, he said, "the timing in the system becomes a bludgeoning tool."
 
Custodial Parent's Advantage
 Other effects of the backlog were described by Dr. Richard A. Gardner, an Englewood psychiatrist who is considered a national expert on child custody issues in divorce cases.
"Time is on the side of the custodial parent whether that parent has a justified position or not," said Dr. Gardner, who is also a clinical professor of child psychiatry at the Columbia University Medical School. The longer a custody battle goes on, he said, the more likely it is that the court will award custody to the parent with whom the child is living.
"Even if that parent is the less desirable one, the child will become more bonded and won't want to change," he said. As a result, he said, "the court will be less willing to order a change."
Protracted divorces can have other effects as well, he said. "The longer the case takes, the more money people spend on their lawyers," Dr. Gardner said. "It's an abomination and a legal form of exploitation of the public."
 
Mediation Panels Established
 Over the last few years, the State Supreme Court and court officials have attempted to address the backlog by assigning additional judges to the Family Part in some counties and by establishing divorce mediation panels in every county.
"We still have a lot of big backlogs, but we're starting to make inroads," said Judge Robert W. Page of the State Superior Court, who is presiding judge of the Family Part in Camden County.
The scope of the problem became evident, Judge Page said, with the issuance of a survey of the state's family courts in 1989. The report, known as the Pathfinders Report, was compiled by a State Supreme Court committee headed by Judge Page.
"It's been four years now, and we're seeing some improvement," Judge Page said.
Part of the improvement, he said, is attributable to the increased use of early settlement panels in each of the state's 21 counties. The panels, which are staffed by experienced, volunteer matrimonial lawyers, attempt to resolve disputed economic issues in contested divorce cases at no charge to the parties.
 
'Day in Court' Still Available
 "We look at it as a complement to the court system, not as an alternative," Judge Page said. "The parties will always have their day in court if they want it."
The early settlement panel program is administered by the New Jersey Bar Association, working in conjunction with officials in each county. In Hudson County, for instance, 16 volunteer lawyers meet in teams of two several times a month to mediate contested divorce cases.
"The way I look at it is if we settle one case, that's one less case that clogs the court docket," said Maureen P. Sogluizzo, a Rutherford matrimonial lawyer who serves on the Hudson County panel.
And while the majority of the cases that come before the early settlement panel ultimately end up back in court, most lawyers agree that the process is valuable because it helps define the issues and gives participants a sense of the reasonableness of their positions.
"It can be used as a barometer to give clients an idea of how a judge might rule," Ms. Sogluizzo said. "And if it doesn't prolong people's agony or make them incur any additional attorney fees, then we've done them a service."
Some lawyers, however, say that while the early settlement panels might be effective in some cases, they are not really useful in the hotly contested cases that are most responsible for the backlog.
"What's happening now," Mr. Yudes said, "is that matrimonial lawyers themselves are beginning to look for alternative ways to get their clients through the system more efficiently. What we're doing is using each other as blue-ribbon panelists to arbitrate our cases. Sometimes, we're even using each other as rent-a-judges to hear each other's cases."
 
Arbitration for Colleagues
 Typically, he said, fellow matrimonial lawyers will arbitrate a colleague's case free, knowing that they will be extended the same courtesy when the circumstances are reversed.
"It's good for the lawyers, and it's good for the clients," Mr. Yudes said.
In fact, the "rent-a-judge" concept seems so promising to several matrimonial lawyers that they have pooled their resources and formed a company to provide private divorce arbitration services for a fee.
"The feedback from attorneys has been tremendous," said William Laufer, a lawyer who is a principal of the New Jersey Divorce and Family Arbitration Institute, a Morristown-based company.
Mr. Laufer's company provides divorce lawyers with a list of 10 qualified matrimonial arbitrators to choose from, he said. The arbitrators are paid for by the parties at rates generally similar to what they pay their own lawyers.
The major advantage to such a system as opposed to the early settlement panels, Mr. Laufer said, is that while the panels simply mediate a dispute -- hoping to get the parties to agree -- an arbitrator makes a ruling that the parties stipulate beforehand will be binding.
In the long run, Mr. Laufer said, paying a private arbitrator would be less expensive than taking a case to trial because of the manner in which most divorce trials are now conducted.
 
'Calendar Calls'
 In most counties, he said, when a case is nearing trial there are "calendar calls" when both parties, their lawyers and their witnesses must be at the courthouse ready for trial. More often than not, however, the case is not reached on that day and everyone must return on another date. The lawyers and expert witnesses, however, still get paid for being in court.
Once a case actually gets to trial, Mr. Laufer said, the expenses continue to mount.
"You try the case for a day and then have to come back a month later for another day," he said, adding that at the subsequent hearing, issues dealt with at the previous hearing are typically revisited. "It can take you six months to try a simple divorce case," he said.
One of Mr. Laufer's clients offered firsthand testimony of such frustrations.
"I filed for divorce in December of 1989, and I'm still not divorced yet," said Christine Corigliano of Watchung.
"You want to get the divorce over with so you can start a new life," she said. "But you can't do anything during this time. It's unfair to everyone."
Ms. Corigliano said her divorce trial started in April of this year. "We had two days in April, three days in June, and now we have two days scheduled in August," she said. "It will probably take another year to finish this. And the only ones who win are the lawyers."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/July 19-24

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
A Fed Chairman in Search of His Economic Leviathan 

When Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, addressed the Senate Banking Committee last week, he sounded like an economic Ahab, searching for the recovery, his Moby Dick. The economy is still struggling against a "head wind," Mr. Greenspan said. "Today its speed is decidedly less, but still appreciable." He said the Fed, which has cut short-term rates to their lowest levels in 29 years, is contemplating easing the ratio of capital to assets that banks are required to meet as a way to spur lending. But robust economic growth continues to elude the chairman. Senators listening to his testimony turned testy: "I speak to people across the country, and you're about the most optimistic person I've talked to," said Donald W. Riegle, Democrat of Michigan. The Fed-watcher Allan Meltzer, professor of economics at Carnegie Mellon University, said, "For these head winds, monetary policy cannot do much."

Finally, Perot Gets Specific
 
Before dropping out of the Presidential race, Ross Perot was criticized for not releasing an economic plan. Now he's being criticized for having a plan but not being in the race. The 50-page plan, which surfaced last week, would have reduced the budget deficit by phasing in a 50-cents-a-gallon gasoline tax, slowing increases in Social Security benefits, raising taxes on the wealthy and cutting the military. The Perot plan proposed a bullish-on-business five-year moratorium on taxes for startup businesses and a permanent research and development tax credit. Economists praised it for pro-growth business savvy while politicians argued the plan had no political pull. "Each piece of this plan would probably be rejected by a large majority of the voters," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker.

A Recession in Triplicate?
 
Economists have been worrying lately that the nation could soon fall into a "triple dip" recession. Last week, the Commerce Department allayed those fears when it said sales of durable goods jumped 2.3 percent in June.

A Tax to Reflect Tuxedo Reality
 
Who says Congress is out of touch with the little people? Last week the House Ways and Means Committee took time to make 17 changes in the tax code. Those changes, which were sent on to the Senate, include a change in the depreciation law: Tuxedo rental stores will now be able to depreciate their fancy duds in three years instead of five. Why the alteration? A study by the Treasury Department showed that tuxedos don't last five years. Another measure nullifies the 11 percent tax hunters pay to have their cartridges reloaded. The measures would dispense $364 million in tax breaks to the little guy.

Caution From the White House
 
When it comes to the economy, President Bush has few fans: Only 18 percent of the people polled in the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll approve of the way he's handling the economy. That poor showing could have tempted the White House into making its mid-year economic forecast a little rosier. But no one accused Michael Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, of giving in to temptation. Last week he said the economy would perk up, growing at a 2.7 percent rate in the fourth quarter with unemployment falling to 6.9 percent. "The forecast seems reasonable," said Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities.

Congress Reregulates Cable
 
Back in the heyday of Reaganomics, the cable television industry was deregulated. But without competition, all that happened was that the nation's 11,000 cable systems raised their prices at triple the rate of inflation. Last week, the House overwhelmingly voted to re-regulate cable. The measure requires the Federal Communications Commission to establish a rate structure for basic cable service. It requires basic service to include the broadcast networks, Fox, PBS and any independent, over-the-air broadcast stations in the area as well as public, educational and government-access cable stations. The Bush Administration favored a less-stringent competing bill.

A Shadow Over Blue Cross
 
The nation's 73 Blue Cross and Blue Shield health plans insure 63 million people. But recently regulators have warned that some of the plans have been engaging in questionable business practices, like destroying unpaid claims. Last week, a Senate committee headed by Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, warned that at least 20 plans are in financial trouble. The National Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association acknowledged the problems. Fifteen plans "are being monitored because they don't meet our standards for financial reserves," said Bernard R. Tresnowski, the association's president.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Huffing Up the Dollar
 
To prevent the dollar from slipping further -- it hit an all-time low against the German mark on Monday -- at least 13 central banks bought greenbacks last week. The dollar dropped because of "weak U.S. economic data, widening interest rate spreads between the U.S. and Germany and tight monetary policy in Germany versus a loose policy here," said Richard Honeck, a currency trader at Chase Private Banking in New York. It strengthened at the end of the week, closing at 1.504 marks. Though the world's central banks huffed and puffed, they only managed to ante up about $300 million to buy dollars, hardly a dent in a market that can trade $800 billion a day. "The dollar strengthened partly due to the jump in durable goods orders," Mr. Honeck said, "and because market participants just decided to go with the dollar."
 
Kevin Maxwell's Maxi-Fines
 
Robert Maxwell, the British media baron who died at sea in November, left his sons, Ian and Kevin, a portfolio of bankrupt companies complete with looted pension funds and debts far exceeding their assets. Last week, a British court ordered Kevin Maxwell to pay more than $778 million in fines for breaching his fiduciary duties as a director of an investment management fund that was the trustee of the Maxwell companies' employee pension funds. Kevin Maxwell, who was not present in court, said in a statement: "Had I the resources, I would have strenuously denied all allegations of breach of duty."

USAir Going British
 
British Airways said it would invest $750 million for a 44 percent stake in the USAir Group. The deal will create the world's largest airline partnership. Although the Transportation Department has opposed large-scale foreign investment in domestic airlines in the past -- it blocked KLM's proposed $400 million investment in Northwest Airlines three years ago -- it is thought to be favorably disposed to this deal. "The world's airline industry is clearly moving in the direction of cross-border alliances," said Transportation Secretary Andrew H. Card Jr. More international linkups are expected.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
G.E. Pays the Price -- Again
 
The General Electric Company was punished twice for conspiring with an Israeli general to defraud the American Government out of $26.5 million. The first time was a slap on the wrist from the Defense Department: G.E. was forbidden to do business with the Pentagon for five days. But last week, at a hearing in the United States District Court in Cincinnati, G.E. was fined $9.5 million to settle criminal charges, and $59.5 million to settle civil charges. G.E. was accused by Chester L. Walsh, a former G.E. employee, of billing the Government for fictitious parts and testing equipment sent to Israel. Under the provisions of a Federal law, Mr. Walsh may be entitled to up to 25 percent of the money recovered from G.E.

Intel Can Afford to Be Late
 
The Intel Corporation, whose chips dominate the market, is known for nifty designs and a fiercely competitive spirit. But last week it announced it would have to delay the release of its latest chip, dubbed P-5, the powerful successor to Intel's 486. The P-5, which was to be released this fall, won't come out until 1993. But even with this sluggish start, analysts are not worried. The P5 "will be the dominant player shortly after it begins shipping," said Michael Slater, of Microprocessor Report, an industry newsletter.

The Payoff for Compaq
 
The 42.9 percent increase in earnings at the Compaq Computer Corporation certainly suggests its new strategy is paying off. For a year, Compaq has been cutting costs and chopping prices. It earned $29 million in the quarter ended June 30, up from $20.3 million the year before. Sales were $827 million for the quarter. "They were making a bet-the-company change in strategy when they went to these real low-end products," said Rick Martin, a computer analyst at the Chicago Corporation. "It really looks like it is working well."

Playing Catch-Up at Boeing
 
When United Airlines decided to lease 50 Airbus A-320's and take an option on leasing 50 more last month in a deal worth about $3 billion, it sent the Boeing Airplane Company back to the drawing board. Last week Boeing said it was doing research to see if its venerable 737 -- a short- to medium-range jetliner -- could be reconfigured to give it range and speed equal to the A-320's. If Boeing can do that, it "could blunt United's willingness to exercise the option on the other 50 Airbuses," said Bill Whitlow, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities in Seattle.

A Deal Proves Itself
 
Last year, the deal-making mavens at the BankAmerica Corporation promised big benefits from the acquisition of the Security Pacific Corporation. They said the $4 billion deal would produce major economies of scale and more marketing muscle. Last week they delivered the goods. BankAmerica earned $240 million. Without the non-recurring expenses stemming from the merger, it would have earned $421 million. "This is just a starting point, but it was a terrific quarter," said Ronald L. Mandel, a financial analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein in New York.

A Good Match for Spider Man
 
Even a child could understand the synergies of this merger. Last week, Marvel Entertainment Group Inc., publisher of soft-cover epics like the "Spider Man" and "Captain America" comic books -- said it planned to acquire the Fleer Corporation, which makes sports trading cards, in a deal valued at $265 million.
 
Another Challenge to Halcion
 
Earlier in the month, the Federal Food and Drug Administration said that the Upjohn Company's Halcion, the largest-selling prescription pill in the world, was safe to use. Last week, a consumer group, Public Citizen, challenged that decision in a petition to the F.D.A. The petition said Halcion was associated with dangerous side effects. Upjohn disputed those claims.
