HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Hong Kong, Star of 1992, Begins to Dim

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The world's major economic powers showed they could act together, for one day at least. And the world's stock markets showed they too could move in the same direction. They went down.
The carnage around the world last week was somewhat obscured in this country by the fact that Wall Street did relatively well. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 45.93 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,285.71. Intervention by the world's central banks to support the dollar seemed to ease concerns over American stocks, but did not help shares in the rest of the world, where fears of slow economies combined with a host of local factors, not to mention the possibility of bombs over Baghdad, to produce selloffs. 
 Even Hong Kong went down, with the Hang Seng index losing 5.8 percent, its worst week since the fall of 1990. But it still is up 34 percent in 1992, and remains this year's craze among foreign investors, who now own about half the shares available for trading.
The news in Hong Kong that has justified that kind of performance has been the pending takeover, in 1997, of Hong Kong by China. To hear Hong Kong bulls tell it, what really is going to happen is the reverse, as Hong Kong's economic system takes over China, producing a wave of prosperity and a boom in consumer spending. "The potential growth of just changing China from an inefficient economy to an efficient one is staggering," says Victoria Goodwin, a Hong Kong watcher for James Capel Inc., the British firm.
Just three years ago, the prospect of a takeover of Hong Kong by the regime that brought the world Tiananmen Square was viewed as a reason to panic. But now investors are confident that, however repressive the politics, the movement to economic reform is irreversible. And Hong Kong is seen as the way to play China.
So what can go wrong? A significant part of China's growth comes from its rising trade with this country. The American trade deficit with China, at $5.7 billion for the first five months of 1992, is now larger than with any other country except Japan. And while the Japanese figure is up 15 percent this year, China's has soared 60 percent.
President Bush has been China's best friend in Washington, staving off Congressional efforts to mess with most-favored-nation trade status, and the House vote to tie trade to human rights issues will not change the situation. But what about Bill Clinton? "It's an issue where Clinton could be protectionist and wear a white hat at the same time," said David Shulman, the chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers. "This could be a very big negative for the Hong Kong market," he said, adding that it also could hurt American companies that buy Chinese exports, ranging from Tyco and Toys "R" Us to Liz Claiborne and the Limited.
Occidentals have a way of applying straight-line forecasting to China, assuming that whatever trend is in place will continue forever. It won't, of course. Hong Kong stocks may have seen their highs for this year.

HEADLINE: A Coal-Burning Utility That's Trying to Paint Itself Green

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: CUMBERLAND, Ohio

 BODY:
Scimitar-horned oryxes browse amid the grass and wildflowers of the valley, as their ancestors have for millennia on the African savannah. But this is not Africa, it is eastern Ohio. And the oryxes are here not in their natural niche in the food chain -- eating foliage and falling prey to predators -- but in another role. They are helping to make coal look green.
The oryxes, a type of antelope, along with Hartmann's mountain zebras and other rare species graze on a reclaimed strip mine donated by the American Electric Power Company. They will soon be joined by elephants, rhinos and snow leopards, and the company proudly notes that at 9,200 acres the wild-animal preserve is the largest in North America. 
 More than perhaps any other North American utility, A.E.P. needs to show an environmental conscience. Of the one billion tons of coal that will be used in the United States this year, A.E.P. will use 45 million, more than anyone else, to serve seven million people in seven states from Virginia to Michigan. In this age of concern over acid rain and global warming, a coal-burning utility is a bit like a butcher shop in a village where the new religion is vegetarianism.
True, A.E.P. is refining a generation and transmission system that is already very modern and efficient, and plans to spend well over $1 billion to comply with the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990, primarily for control of emissions believed to cause acid rain. But it is looking ahead with dread to the debate over the greenhouse effect. Many scientists say carbon dioxide emissions, which are larger from coal than from other fuels, could bring catastrophic changes in weather.
Bruised by the Clean Air Act amendments, which imposed strict limits on sulfur dioxide emissions, and horrified at the idea of a tax on carbon dioxide emissions, like that proposed at the recent Earth Summit, A.E.P. is trying to demonstrate that it is an environmental good guy even if it does rely on coal for 89 percent of its fuel.
Not only is the Columbus-based company emphasizing to shareholders and customers a 40-year program of land reclamation and tree planting at old mines like the one here; it is also on the cutting edge of cleaner ways to burn coal, as evidenced by an experimental plant in Brilliant, Ohio, and better ways to use electricity, like an energy-efficient bulb.
Environmentalists praise many of these activities, but say A.E.P. has only dabbled in encouraging customers to use energy more efficiently through products like the bulb. While it has pilot programs for many kinds of efficiency improvements, utilities in New York, New England and California are spending heavily on large-scale efforts to promote efficient lighting, motors and refrigerators.
FOR years A.E.P. executives assumed that geology was destiny. With its service area astride the heart of the continent's coal fields, the company has become so attached to coal that it not only burns it but also mines and transports it. Its rates are low, about 6 cents a kilowatt-hour, and the supply is reliable.
But concerns about the greenhouse effect make the company wonder about its future. "Clearly, coal is following nuclear as being unacceptable to the public," said Dale E. Heydlauff, the vice president for environmental affairs, a post created by A.E.P.'s board last year. "It scares me as someone fairly young in the management of this company, trying to figure out what will be environmentally acceptable in the next decade."
The question faces the whole industry, because the United States has about 30 percent of the world's coal. And coal comprises the vast majority of the country's fossil fuel resources, and about 60 percent of utilities' fuel.
It is not clear what fuel A.E.P. could use instead. Nine percent of its power is from a nuclear plant, and it recently named E. Linn Draper Jr., who has a Ph.D. in nuclear engineering, as its president. But he said in a company newsletter, "Let me assure you that I do not have a set of reactor designs in my back pocket."
Two percent of A.E.P.'s supply is hydroelectricity, for which expansion prospects are limited. Executives say solar power is simply not feasible here. There is not enough wind to make much of a dent. Burning corncobs would work, one executive calculated, if A.E.P. planted land equivalent to three-quarters of Ohio in corn. Natural gas is a possibility, but like most of the industry, A.E.P. is reluctant to bet on the future price.
Meanwhile, A.E.P. has only a toe in the water in the most widely used strategy, increasing efficiency.
If not conservation or other fuel sources, how else can A.E.P. show its environmental commitment?
Enter the oryx and other image-enhancing programs, a kind of corporate verdification. The company recently won a patent on a mixture of water and coal ash (currently sent to landfills) that can be pumped like a liquid into street excavations, and hardens in a few hours.
THE reclaimed strip mine that is the oryxes' new home was donated by the utility in 1986, to a group called the International Center for the Preservation of Wild Animals. There are successes already: while fewer than 400 Cuvier's gazelles exist wild in their native north Africa, two were born here in early July.
Other reclaimed land has been set aside by the company as campgrounds and for fishing and boating.
The heart of the company's effort, however, is in technological advances toward more efficient generation and consumption. The company recently gained wide attention for financing the development of an improved compact fluorescent light bulb, called the electronic lamp, that illuminates with one-fourth the electricity of a conventional bulb. Unlike existing compact fluorescents, the "e-lamp" comes on quickly and without flicker; it lasts 20,000 hours, compared with 10,000 for existing fluorescents and 750 to 1,000 for standard bulbs. Smaller than existing compact fluorescents, the bulb will fit in many more fixtures.
The progress in the lamp had been widely anticipated. But the sponsorship was a shock, because A.E.P. has always been regarded as an extremely conservative organization. Pierre Villere, who is commercializing the e-lamp, said hundreds of potential investors had turned him down.
FINANCING the bulb would have been adventuresome for most utilities, but was a real departure for A.E.P.; the company's critics say that for years its environmental attitudes were more than simply conservative. "Neanderthal," said Jan Beyea, senior scientist at the National Audubon Society, recalling A.E.P.'s powerful lobbying against the Clean Air Act. "It's wonderful that they're doing this," he said of the e-lamp. "The shift has blown everybody over."
The e-lamp investment, at $6.5 million, is a symbolic act for a company with a market capitalization of $10.5 billion, revenues last year of $5.046 billion and net income of $497.9 million. "It's going to be years before it has a bottom-line impact that I care about," said Sanford M. Cohen, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, with considerable understatement.
The lamp is a departure for another reason: it represents a philosophy to which the company does not fully subscribe. In New York and California, utilities subsidize high-efficiency bulbs because if customers use less power, the utilities will burn less fuel and cause less pollution.
But A.E.P.'s chairman and chief executive, Richard E. Disbrow, doubts that light bulbs, motors and air-conditioners that use less power are any substitute for new power plants. And besides, he said in an interview, "the leading advocates of demand-side management are companies that are short of generation." His company has a growing surplus of power, because its neighbors have built plants and its customers are suffering from recession, so additional kilowatt-hours cost very little.
Instead of demand-side management, Dr. Draper, the president, stressed the efficiency with which the company generates electricity. A.E.P. uses less fuel to produce a kilowatt-hour than any utility in the country but one, Commonwealth Edison, which serves the Chicago area, because its plants are well designed and well maintained. Its transmission system is also highly efficient. The amount of power lost in transmission generally declines as voltage rises, and A.E.P. was the first to introduce 765-kilovolt transmission lines, the highest-voltage lines now in use in this country. Realizing that moving electricity is often easier than moving coal, A.E.P. years ago began putting its plants near its mines.
As for pollution, Mr. Disbrow insisted that the greenhouse theory has not been demonstrated to the point where use of coal should be limited.
But there is no blueprint for convincing Washington of that. There is also no clear alternative. "What do you do if you're sitting on 250 years of coal?" said Mr. Heydlauff. "If you look at our options, they are extremely limited."
 
 
FINDING A CLEANER WAY TO BURN
BRILLIANT, Ohio
Most power plants burn coal by pulverizing it and blowing it into a boiler, where it is burned to generate steam.
But here on the banks of the Ohio River, engineers have ripped the guts out of a 46-year-old generating station to install an entirely different system, called pressurized fluidized bed combustion. The initial results show that the process is so clean and efficient that American Electric Power executives hope the technology will dominate the market for new coal plants.
The plant, called Tidd, was retired in 1976 because it could not meet rising environmental standards. Engineers disconnected the old boiler and grafted on a smaller one in which coal is burned in a bed of limestone and ash; the process is called "fluidized" because the mixture bubbles like a fluid. The limestone absorbs more than 90 percent of the sulfur during combustion, and the operating temperature of 1,500 degrees is too low to allow much nitrogen oxide to form.
Running through the bed are tubes filled with water. That water boils into steam, which is used to make electricity. Because the heat is transferred to the steam tubes by a solid, the fluidized bed, not a gas, heat transfer is enhanced and efficiency raised. Boiler exhaust drives another turbine to make more electricity.
A quantity of coal that would make less than 37 kilowatt-hours of electricity in a conventional scrubber-equipped pulverized-coal plant makes more than 40 kilowatt-hours here, and carbon dioxide emissions from the pressurized fluidized bed plant total 1.89 pounds instead of 2.12 pounds, per kilowatt-hour. With a refined design, engineers think they can get 10 percent more kilowatt-hours out of the coal, and cut another pound of carbon dioxide per kilowatt-hour. Even before considering the greenhouse effect, the reductions in fuel and sulfur dioxide would make the system attractive, especially because construction costs may be lower than for a conventional plant.
But the carbon dioxide output is still worse than that in oil- or natural gas-fired power production, making pressurized fluidized bed, like everything else in the coal world, contingent on the greenhouse debate.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Now Mr. Jenrette Can Get Some Sleep

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
When Richard H. Jenrette set out 19 months ago to take the Equitable Life Assurance Society public in the largest conversion ever of a mutual insurer, he knew a tough selling job awaited him. He had no idea how tough.
As the economy faltered, investors grew increasingly skittish about commercial real estate, a concern fueled by the widely publicized woes of Olympia & York. With much of Equitable's portfolio in real estate, Mr. Jenrette, the insurer's chairman since 1987, found himself waking many mornings at 3, churning over how to make the deal happen. 
 "I never doubted it would get done," he said last week. "But there were some sleepless nights."
He's resting easier now after investors turned out July 16 for the $9-a-share offering of 43.5 million shares. Demand for the stock sparked an additional offering of 6.5 million shares, and Equitable finalized on Wednesday its so-called de-mutualization, raising $450 million.
The 63-year-old Mr. Jenrette said he is also happy to have his voice back. He had lost it at the end of a five-week, 28-city road show throughout the United States and abroad, trying to convince institutions that the New York-based insurer had no exposure to the "daily recitation" of Olympia & York's troubles, and that the Equitable was in fact growing out of its own real estate problems.
To break the tension, Joseph J. Melone, Equitable's president, once pulled alongside Mr. Jenrette's limousine, rolled down the window of his own limousine and asked, "Can you pass the Grey Poupon?"
Many analysts considered Mr. Jenrette a key player in making the deal work. As a founding partner of the Wall Street firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette -- which the Equitable bought in 1985 -- he spoke investors' language, and was seen as someone who could scrape away the Equitable's baked-in troubles.
"He comes across as a very effective salesman and an outsider who was able to acknowledge that mistakes had been made," said James Ramenda of Northington Partners, a research and investment banking firm in Avon, Conn., that specializes in insurance.
For Mr. Jenrette, the Equitable conversion marks the second history-making deal he has helped shepherd. In 1970, DLJ became the first American securities firm to go public, a move that forced the New York Stock Exchange to end its prohibition against public ownership of member firms.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Taking Over at America West

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
"These things are never easy," said Michael J. Conway, talking of the resignation of Edward R. Beauvais, the chairman and co-founder of America West Airlines.
Mr. Conway, 47 years old, who is president and chief executive of the airline, has taken over the post vacated by Mr. Beauvais, 55, a little more than a week ago. The Phoenix-based carrier entered Chapter 11 proceedings 13 months ago and Mr. Beauvais said he was resigning "with the hope that it will improve the prospects for a successful emergence" of the company from the bankruptcy court. 
 Mr. Beauvais did not elaborate but he has gradually been relinquishing power; it was just last September that he turned over the chief executive post to Mr. Conway.
With Mr. Beauvais gone, Mr. Conway wasted little time. On Thursday, America West announced a round of cutbacks that it said was needed to obtain financing to keep flying and to get out of bankruptcy. The airline said it would cut 1,500 of its 12,000 jobs and drop 15 of its 102 planes by September. When it filed under Chapter 11, it had 15,000 employees.
Mr. Conway is no stranger to America West, having been a founder with Mr. Beauvais and others. The airline went into service in 1983. Mr. Conway was working for Continental Airlines in Los Angeles when he met Mr. Beauvais, who was doing consulting work for Continental.
Mr. Conway found his way to the airline industry through accounting. He is from the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and is a graduate of City College when it was known as C.C.N.Y. He worked for Price Waterhouse for 10 years, specializing in airlines, before joining Continental.
Mr. Conway is leading a company that quickly grew into a major airline with coast-to-coast service and annual revenues of more than $1 billion. Mr. Beauvais had even bigger expansion plans, but they ran afoul of the passenger dropoff during the Persian Gulf war and the recession, forcing America West into its current straits.
Now it will be Mr. Conway's job to get it out. "We will continue full speed ahead," he said in an interview last week. "We are looking forward to a speedy reorganization."

HEADLINE: Networking;
The Zip's in Communications

BYLINE: By STEPHEN C. MILLER

 BODY:
Now that local area networks have been installed just about everywhere, communications software is the new growth area. Communications applications include electronic mail (E-mail), sending and receiving facsimiles, and routing messages to and from other networks.
Forrester Research, a Cambridge, Mass., market research firm, predicts that the number of new network servers dedicated to communications will double this year to nearly 90,000, worth nearly $2.7 billion. The software for communications alone will generate about $148 million and that figure is expected to more than double by 1994. 
 Jim Manzi, president and chief executive of the Lotus Development Corporation, is trying to transform the company from a supplier of single-user software products to a supplier of global communications products.
"Communications is the key to the future of Lotus," he said during a recent interview. Lotus Notes is the cornerstone of that vision. Notes is a sort of super-organizer that, among other things, keeps track of incoming data, E-mail and faxes.
Compuserve Information Service, in Columbus, Ohio, is already in communications software, and Maurice A. Cox Jr., Compuserve's president and chief executive, sees more growth in what he calls "seamless communications." Compuserve has a new mail hub service that works with Novell's Message Handling Service to allow any Novell network to exchange E-mail not only with Novell sites but with Compuserve's 850,000 subscribers, A.T.&T.'s Mail and Easylink networks and other on-line services. Compuserve says that in less than a year it has signed up more than 500 corporate sites running Novell networks.
With the profit stakes so high, it is no wonder that a fight has erupted over what will be the new standard for transporting messages between systems. Three camps are vying to set the E-mail standard. For sending messages to other systems, Lotus prefers Vendor Independent Messaging, based on the way its CC:Mail and Notes handle messaging within networks that use Lotus software. Microsoft, with its Microsoft Mail, has a scheme called Message Application Programming Interface. Novell's Message Handling Service comprises the third standard, and with an estimated 64 percent share of the LAN market, Novell sets the de facto standard. Its M.H.S., with a "gateway" that routes E-mail from any system, is evolving into a standard for communications between all types of system and services, not just Novell networks.
"The Lotus and Microsoft products provide both the front-end and back-end solutions to messaging and that limits the market for third-party vendors," said Brett Warthen, president of Infinite Technologies in Owings Mills, Md., a supplier of network communications products. (Front-end systems interact with users; back-end systems handle the system-to-system connections.) Mr. Warthen said his company was is among 150 that provide front-end systems for MHS. "Actually, both Lotus and Microsoft support some form of MHS," he said. "If you wanted to connect a CC:Mail network with a Microsoft Mail network, they would talk via MHS," he added.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Keep the Work Place in Its Place

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
You know who you are, and you are not alone. You stay mentally Velcroed to the office long after you leave. You obsess and stew on the trip home and then replay the day minutia-by-minutia to your spouse or partner. "Sometimes, I put too many details in. I can see my husband's eyes glaze over," said Gretchen Park, the director of compensation and benefits at Residential Services Corporation, the holding company for the Prudential Home Mortgage. "I know he doesn't want to hear about the office for two hours."
Caught up in downsizing, streamlining and, in the case of Residential Services, the crush of work brought on by an expanding business, millions of Americans are working more, enjoying it less and experiencing firsthand the stern conclusion that Harvard economist Juliet Schor comes to in her recent book "The Overworked American." She wrote: "Excessive hours are unhealthy and antisocial, and ultimately erode the quality of life." 
 Because companies know that, stress reduction on the job has become a cottage industry with proliferating numbers of gurus du jour. But when Residential Services wanted advice, it chose Barbara Mackoff, a Seattle-based management psychologist who holds the contrarian view that employees suffer most not from stress at work but from an inability to detach themselves from work long enough to become refreshed and recharged. When she takes the stage in front of an audience of clients, she preaches a doctrine of renewal as a bottom-line, strategic skill.
"Companies are struggling to define what makes people productive," Ms. Mackoff said. "Some take the 'boiled-frog approach,' " in which managers turn up the productivity heat. "People get used to hotter and hotter water." But employees can only keep up for so long. One way or another, they will take time off, and it will cost the company as well as the employee. "Through mistakes, lack of creativity, illness, lack of follow-through with clients," Ms. Mackoff said. "You'll take time off, but not in a productive way."
Ms. Mackoff makes this observation on the basis of a decade of experience in organizations. A psychologist with training in anthropology, she does a cultural study of the company before she actually arrives for workshops or lectures. Once on site, her first job usually is to convince her audience that they will survive if they briefly turn off the treadmill. She may start with a simple story: Told that he is working with a dull saw, a workman replies that he is too busy to stop and sharpen the blade. "I get a lot of 'I'm too busy sawing to sharpen the saw,' " she said.
When when she begins to spin out her list of symptoms, she can see the looks of recognition -- and, often, relief -- on the faces in front of her.
* It's literally impossible to leave work. "You take your briefcase home and work," she said. "Or you take your briefcase home and don't touch it -- and feel guilty. You can't resist calling the office while you're on vacation."
* It's impossible to protect private time from work-related worries. "You can't fall asleep. You spend the whole night talking about work."
* Time away from work becomes an excuse for more work. "Every social occasion becomes a business-card occasion."
Managers may notice that employees come in on Monday looking more tired than they did on Friday. And they will surely notice a productivity decline.
One useful diagnostic is the first post-work encounter at home. "It takes about 40 seconds to ruin an entire evening," Ms. Mackoff said, just by continuing in the mode of the woes of the day. "Standing back from pressures of the day really is an accomplishment."
Like a good anthropologist, she advises developing some exit rituals to manage the work-to-home transition. One of her clients locks her appointment book in a drawer and backs out of her office shaking her finger, saying, "stay, stay." Another compliments one of his subordinates as he leaves each evening. Once home, she says, it is crucial to greet everyone before launching into a recitation of the day's horrors.
The trick over the long term is to use time away from work to get experience the job doesn't provide. Gretchen Park, who heard Ms. Mackoff's talk during a January sales meeting in Florida, said much of the message has stayed with her. Probably, she said a little ruefully, she should take up a hobby, but at least she tries to sit down and listen to music once a week. She really appreciated, she says, the message Residential Services delivered by bringing in Ms. Mackoff: "It was a recognition that this is a hard life we live."
 
 
HOW TO PUT LEISURE TO USE
 In her seminars and in a recent book, "The Art of Self-Renewal" (Lowell House), Barbara Mackoff suggests pursuing leisure activities that offer a sense of purpose, of self and of time completely different than anything available at work.
* Purpose: Stop thinking about having something to show for every activity. At the movies, don't think about how much the film grossed or how the popcorn stand is doing. Don't apply high strategic demands of jobs to the home -- e.g., lower your housework standards. Leave lists, and the inclination to make lists, at the office. Do nonprofessional reading. Don't think about any bottom line.
*Self: Participate in activities that express a dimension of personality or ability that doesn't come out on the job. It could be playing music, seeing friends or getting active in the community. . Stop using a work vocabulary to describe nonwork experience.
* Time: Resist the urge to overschedule and stop rushing. "One chief executive would take off his watch on Friday and put it back on Monday," Ms. Mackoff said. Do projects with a beginning, middle and end.

HEADLINE: Groan Heaven

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
HEY, it's the 90's: Sometimes you have to brace for the worst.
"Whooooo-a-a-a . . . aph." Over at the new World Gym near Lincoln Center, where the earth-tone locker rooms are still under construction and the steam room is but a stack of tiles and exposed piping, Billy Billitzer, a 28-year-old gemologist, was working out last week on exercise machinery that looked like so many helicopter parts. 
 "Unghhhh." Mr. Billitzer may never have to do more than run out some rainy Sunday morning for a carton of orange juice and an extra bag of bagels. But his lats, delts, traps and quads are ready for anything. Three or four days a week, he runs through a 90-minute lifting, hoisting, pulling, straining workout that has left him tuned and tough.
"Haaooouup." There are rewards, of course. "I eat about five meals a day," he said with a guiltless grin. "I feel like a newborn."
He looked as if he could tear through a steel door.
THE neighborhood gym -- reworked, repainted and repackaged -- is making a comeback. Glitz is gone, along with the attendant who bends to every whim. In its place there is only a chorus of grunts and a pared-down mission statement. The new gym is not a club where one has one's psyche scrubbed and back rubbed. It's a no-frills, no-fools room in which to break a sweat and sweat the details: the Ikea of the health-club culture.
Open 24 hours a day and practically abutting New York's cultural Ground Zero, the new million-dollar World Gym will bring to body building what Lincoln Center has long brought to the arts. It promises the best equipment that money can buy, and even a hint of stardom. Macbeth himself could strut across Broadway to do a couple turns on the abdominal crunch machine.
The Terminator is far more likely to appear. Arnold Schwarzenegger owns the World Gym franchise and is carrying on the principles of Gold's Gym, that mecca of body building in the mecca of health, Venice Beach, Calif. It was Joe Gold, the master muscle builder, who developed the modern gym. And it is now Mr. Schwarzenegger who is carrying the principle forward.
If fads followed the calendar, the fitness boom of the 1980's should have gone the way of junk bonds. The garden came back; so did the frumpy slipcover; even Jane Fonda started to look a little silly on her eternal quest for youth. Then the doctors weighed in and said all those aerobics and all that going for the burn might actually be bad for you.
The health-club culture crashed and burned. Like other bad investments of the 1980's, those born of hope and slipshod banking crumpled in a withered economy, leaving scores of people holding long-term memberships to nowhere.
It seemed reasonable that the nation would come down from its mesomorphic high and return to its shuffleboards, tennis courts and garage basketball hoops: to a time when exercise was something you hardly thought about, much less made into a religion.
Trouble was, it felt good to feel good, and a lot of people didn't want to give that up. Faced with the AIDS epidemic and the psychological vulnerability engendered by a tenacious recession, people of all ages and all backgrounds in the 1990's find themselves wanting to be tough enough to face any disaster, real or imagined.
Call it fantastic disaster preparedness. What if a house were to fall smack on your shoulders and you had to heave it off in a nice, clean, steady movement without ripping the muscles sheer off your shins? Or what if you had to lie upside down and hoist a car out of a ditch with one hand (no cheating), or pull a drifting ocean liner into its berth and rope it down against a steady 10-knot wind?
At the new World Gym, the props may be missing (there is no ocean and no ocean liner) but the movements are roughly the same. And the faithful and the flabby have already started to pour in. A maze of sparkling white-and-blue machines that didn't exist even in concept a decade ago stand ready to meet even the worst of the wimps.
The gym will not be complete until early September. But starting tomorrow, the silent Cybex exercise machines will beckon morning, noon and dark of night with the perennial enticement of the perfect biceps, sculptured sartorius and trim abdominal. For fees of $15 a day to $700 a year, the gym offers equipment that can test-drive every one of the body's more than 400 muscles and help them fire like so many well-oiled cylinders.
It all began as a whim. While vacationing in California during the health-crazed late 70's, Anthony Schettino had a vision. There, during a workout, he met Joe Gold, the master of the modern gym and a close friend of Mr. Schwarzenegger. The two started talking, and suddenly Mr. Schettino, a bulky but otherwise unassuming policeman from Brooklyn, saw his future flash before him. He saw a big gym using California themes to capture the rapture of the West.
By 1982, the doors opened to the World Gym in Queens, with touches truly new to the New York muscle culture. "Everything used to be these small, dark, little neighborhood places with guys who'd yell and scream," Mr. Schettino said. "I wanted my place to be big and full of wood and plants and with the whole feeling of that California scene."
While the Queens gym prospered, Mr. Schettino (pronounced ske-TEE-no) eased out of the police force and stuck a pin in his map of Manhattan. By 1988, Wall Street was reeling, but he was ready for his second venture, a 30,000-square-foot gym at Lafayette and Fourth streets with rubber floors, ceiling fans, wall-to-wall mirrors and the best equipment money could buy.
By then, his was an official franchise of Mr. Gold's gym empire, which was recently bought by Mr. Schwarzenegger.
From the start, the humblest taxi driver could some days be found heaving deltoid to deltoid with the likes of Ivan Boesky, Jodie Foster and Gregory Hines. Against a background din of barely audible rock-and-roll, clanking barbells and muffled grunts, the mighty and the meek still twist and strain against Abdominal Crunch Boards, Upper Body Ergometers, Leg Presses, Hack Squats and Rotary Torso machines in a space that looks more like a factory floor than a haven for good health. Even the clothing is low key. No tortured fashion statements here.
For some, the experience is transporting. Gregory Hines comes in "like he's going to church," Mr. Schettino said, adding: "He's here every day. He's devoted."
Jodie Foster waltzed in once, plopped down her $15, caused a minor sensation, jumped on a bike, pedaled with ferocious focus, then walked out again. She was, Mr. Schettino said, self-conscious. She has not been back.
Lauren Hutton ranks a casual "pretty good" from Mr. Schettino. But she hasn't been in for a while, so heaven only knows what is happening to her gluteus medius.
The biggest sensation was Ivan Boesky. He worked out on work release, "looking like a homeless guy," said Karen Wong, 23, the gym's manager, who said she feels like the gym police, making sure no one spits or fights or drips without using a towel. "He had the shabbiest clothes," Ms. Wong said. "And this huge beard. His workouts were really intense." So was the media coverage.
The expansion of the World Gym empire uptown was complicated by the need to elevate the no-frills concept to upper-crust standards. The ultimatum was to have a gym, not a playground; to keep that lean, mean, focused style without alienating uptowners who, truth to tell, expect at least a little glitz with their grunts.
Concessions were made.
"They want towels," Mr. Schettino said, shrugging. "So, I'm giving them towels." The gym, at Broadway and 64th Street, will also have a massage room, a baby-sitting service, a cafe and a pro shop. There is even a rug near the entrance.
With or without towels, there is a purpose to the pain, and a method. If one plans to use one's brachioradialis, for example, there is no good reason to ignore the latissimus dorsi or to discount the sublime importance of the infraspinatus. Total health is total health.
In the 80's, when everyone bashed around on tennis shoes stretching and yelping and smashing their knees, "people went with the flow," Ms. Wong said. Now they are waking up in pain. "Those high-impact aerobics," she added. "Oh! They didn't realize what it would do to their bodies in 10 years."
That stuff could totally crush you.
In good gym workouts the pain is fleeting, but real. Faces flush and contort and the occasional moan rises above Bonnie Raitt's musings about the anguish of being in love. New members tend to be histrionic about the agony. The experienced hardly notice. It is common, weekday mornings, to see a trim man on a stair machine walking up the equivalent of the Empire State Building, reading his paper.
The difference between the burn of old and the strain of the moment is that people are more realistic about their physiques, said Emily Wagner, 26, an aerobics instructor at the World Gym on Broadway. "They are serious," she continued. "Before, you had these, like, aerobics neurotics who are just suffering now. But these folks are serious. They've got AIDS to worry about. So they come to work, not to chitchat. They really think about their bodies."
The work itself is only part of a broader change. Mr. Billitzer, the gemologist, described his physical training as starting with his diet and ending on the Cybex machines. Kevin McGrath, a trainer at the Lafayette Street gym and a student of exercise physiology at Montclair State College in New Jersey, provides nutritional advice, lectures about getting enough sleep and even makes occasional wake-up calls to clients trying to get themselves together.
True devotees spend around $50 an hour for private supervision. But the final appeal is often the same for those who spend as much as $300 a week on private sessions and those who just pop in on their own.
"I want to keep what I've got from turning into mush," said Valerie Brown, a trim 36-year-old who works on computer systems at the New York Stock Exchange.
There are, of course, some professional body builders, "steroid heads" and far-gone muscle men for whom the gym is a culture in itself. Mr. Schettino tries to discourage them from feeling too at home.
"They don't like us here," said a professional body builder who uses only his first name, Pierre. Flicking his long, dark ponytail and shifting muscles so large that they seemed almost to impede normal movement, he complained that the World Gym, at least, was less than welcoming. "Look at me," he said without even pumping out his shaved chest. "I'm big. People our size, we are very intimidating."
Among the most devoted clients are those who find obsessive exercise a good substitute for other vices. "A lot of us are basically reformed drug addicts and alcoholics," said Karen Ciatyk, 37, who works out six days a week and looks as if she could stop a car with one hand. "Myself, I was very heavy at one time. And I drank a lot. But I gave it up mostly for the calories." The exercise is more that just a means of weight control, she continued, adding: "It's a challenge. It's a you-versus-the-machine type thing."
Some regulars find a home. Romances of all types flourish, founder and re-form in endless subtle circles. "If you sit on a bike for an hour you get to see a lot," Ms. Ciatyk said. "I mean, you really get an overview."
At the new World Gym, romance may come and go but the day will never end. And while the tuned and trim come down off some endorphin high, towels wrapped lightly about their necks and bodies flushed and glistening, they will inevitably turn to that most compelling of all subjects: how they look.
Mirror, mirror on these walls. Who has the fairest form of all?
The answer is not always pleasing. The best body Mr. Schettino says he ever saw was that of a woman who walked casually into the Lafayette Street gym one day. He asked her how she had gotten into such great shape. She looked straight at him without coyness and uttered the most depressing words he ever heard. "Roping cattle," she answered. And then, by golly, she shrugged.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
If Water Floods Basement, A Sump Pump May Help

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
WHEN a basement is flooded because of water rising from beneath the floor, one solution is to install a sump pump. Aside from requiring modest excavation, including breaking through the basement floor, the task is not difficult.
But before starting, call the building inspector to ask about the requirements for installing sumps. Find out whether the pump may discharge into a municipal storm sewer. In many localities that is strictly forbidden, because sewers can be overloaded during heavy rains. The inspector will probably say the pump has to discharge onto the ground on the property, where it can soak into the soil. Never connect a discharge line to an ordinary sewer or a septic tank. 
 Two styles of pumps are available, pedestal or upright pumps and submersible pumps. Pedestal pumps have an electric motor attached to a hollow shaft about three feet long. At the base of the shaft are the pump parts. The unit stands upright in a sump pit, a hole dug in the basement floor, with the motor above the water level.
Submersible pumps are sealed, so that water cannot enter the motor. The entire unit is placed on the floor of the sump pit. Submersible pumps are more expensive than pedestal pumps because of their waterproof casing, but they operate more quietly.
Unless there is a convenient 240-volt circuit, choose a pump that operates on standard 115-volt current. When shopping, compare pumping capacity, horsepower and the amount of electricity needed. Most houses need pumps having about one-third horsepower, capable of pumping 50 gallons a minute to a height of five feet. That information is usually on the pump or packaging.
To compare power use, determine the wattage from the label or by multiplying the motor voltage by its amperage. Then divide the wattage by the pumping capacity. The answer indicates how much electricity is used by the pump. The model whose specifications yield the lowest number when divided is the most economical to operate.
Because conventional pumps operate on household electricity they will not operate during a power failure. If that is a concern, buy a backup pump that runs on 12-volt batteries. Both pumps are usually installed in the same pit, with the secondary pump higher than the primary. That way, if the primary pump does not operate, the secondary will automatically start when the water rises higher than normal.
To install a pump, the first step is to dig the pit. That should be at the lowest part of the basement floor. A drain usually marks the spot. If there is none, find the lowest area by noticing where flood water collects or stretch strings between the walls at floor level and measure under them. Use a pencil or chalk attached to a string to mark a circle on the floor around the spot 18 inches in diameter or as specified in the pump instructions.
Break the floor to remove the concrete in the circle. One way to do that is to rent an electric hammer drill. Bore holes around the perimeter and in the center. Break up the concrete with a sledgehammer and remove it. A faster way is to use a rented jackhammer.
After breaking through the floor, dig the rest of the pit with a shovel to the depth recommended by the pump manufacturer, usually 24 inches. Cover the bottom of the pit with two or three inches of gravel, or as the pump instructions specify. Then insert a plastic, fiberglass or metal sleeve called a sump liner in the hole to prevent dirt from entering and fouling the pump. Liners are available where sump pumps are sold. Also buy a removable sump cover.
Fill around the outside of the liner with dirt and cap the area with concrete troweled smooth and sloped toward the pit. Fast-setting concrete like Sakrete Fast-Set High Strength Concrete hardens fully the same day it is poured.
Assemble a discharge line using plastic, PVC, plumbing pipe. The standard diameter for sump pumps is one and a quarter inches. The layout will vary according to the location of the pump and the dimensions of the basement, but a common design consists of a vertical pipe that is attached to the pump and rises out of the pit. If a secondary pump is installed, it also can be attached to that pipe. To the vertical pipe, attach a horizontal pipe running along the floor to the nearest window. The vertical or horizontal pipe has to have a check valve to prevent water discharged by the pump from flowing backward toward it.
Another vertical pipe is attached to the horizontal section. That pipe can lead to the window or to a hole drilled through the basement wall above ground level. Attach an elbow fitting to the end of the pipe. Connect a long length of flexible drain hose to the fitting. The hose should extend at least six feet away from the house, and the open end should rest on a splash block.
The glass can be removed from the window and replaced with plywood through which a hole is cut to accommodate the pipe. Apply caulking around to seal the hole.
Plug the cord for the motor into a basement receptacle protected by a ground-fault-circuit interrupter. Close the pit with the cover.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Awash in Imports, the Oil Business Dwindles

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Soviet Union's collapse is claiming yet another victim: the American oil industry. Like the defense industry, oil is no longer as strategic as it had been, and in a time of fiscal stringency, Washington is no longer as enthusiastic about preserving the domestic supply.
The signs appear everywhere in the last few weeks: the number of exploratory drilling rigs hit a record low a few weeks ago, at 596; the oil companies announced another round of layoffs, and domestic production briefly fell to below the level of imports. Yet these indicators caused hardly a blip on the national political horizon. 
 The evolution is striking. After the 1973-1974 Arab oil embargo, Richard M. Nixon launched Project Independence in an effort to reduce oil imports to zero. In 1977, with imports at 44 percent, Jimmy Carter set a target of holding them to 30 percent. Now the country imports nearly 50 percent, with no apparent qualms. "Our notion of where the goal posts lie has changed over the years," said James R. Schlesinger, a former Secretary of Defense and energy czar. "We are being a little casual about it -- more than a little casual."
Even the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a security blanket during the Persian Gulf war last year, no longer attracts much interest. And the National Energy Strategy, a bill that took a major step toward enactment last week, has no provision for filling the reserve. A House committee had approved a fee on oil imports that would have filled the reserve in a few years to its authorized level, a billion barrels, but the White House declared that the fee was a tax and opposed it, so the idea died.
Coincidentally, the Energy Department made a purchase early this month, its first since just before Iraq invaded Kuwait, almost two years ago. But the addition of a few hundred thousand barrels is overshadowed by another trend, growing imports. With about 570 million barrels now in hand, and imports running over 7 million barrels a day, the reserve is equal to about 80 days of imports, a figure that shrinks every time the level of imports rises.
 
Multi-Polar World
 The demise of the Soviet Union lies near the heart of oil's new obscurity. Under the old scheme, most of the world's surplus oil production capacity was in the Persian Gulf with the Soviet Air Force a few minutes' flying time away. Now, nearly all the surplus capacity is in the Gulf but with little outside threat.
"The only strategic consideration is that the Middle East remains unstable," said John H. Lichtblau, director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
In this new multi-polar world, producing oil counts for little among some of the fiercest economic competitors.
"Take a look at Japan," said Robert E. Lipsey, an economist and specialist in international competitiveness at the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private nonprofit organization in New York. "They seem to manage perfectly well. Look at all of the European countries." All are successful, he said, and only Norway and Britain have substantial oil.
Oil remains a commercial issue. America's net oil import bill last year approached $44 billion, an amount equal to two-thirds of the total national trade deficit. But another side to the commercial equation is less obvious. If, for example, the country resolved not to spend a cent on imported oil, the replacement cost would be far higher, comprising in part a mad rush to drill domestically and oil-saving measures like introducing more buses and trains and replacing oil-using equipment with more efficient models.
Another issue is domestic employment. Jobs in oil and gas extraction decreased by half, or 450,000, in the last 10 years. But here, too, the case is not clear cut, because technological change has reduced the number of rigs needed to find a field. Robert Z. Lawrence, professor of international trade and investment at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, said that even if there were a military or other non-economic reason to stabilize domestic production of oil at a certain level, "that's a different issue from how many workers we use to produce that; we should use as few as we can, as we should everywhere, to be as efficient as we can."
Another option for revitalizing the industry would be to put oil production ahead of environmental protection, by drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Reserve and the outer continental shelf areas from which rigs have been banned.
New technology could encourage production, too. Prof. William L. Fisher, head of the Bureau of Economic Geology at the University of Texas in Austin, estimated that 80 percent of the country's oil "is still out there waiting to be discovered," or is in the ground in known locations, but is not recoverable with existing technology. Much of it lies in fields too small for the major companies to bother with, Professor Fisher said. However, exploration activity by smaller companies will still depend on the price of oil.
Despite the relative cheapness of imports, some experts still argue that such dependence is unhealthy and in time of war possibly fatal. "You only have to go back 50 years to see that running out of oil had an adverse effect on the team that lost it," said Peter Beutel, an energy trader at Pegasus Econometric Associates, a consulting company in Hoboken, N. J., referring to Germany's defeat in World War II.
Others, like Mr. Lichtblau, disagree. Even at a vastly reduced level of production, the United States has enough oil to run a military machine, according to Mr. Lichtblau.
The American oil industry hasn't died; it has simply moved away. Companies still spend heavily on looking for oil, but mostly offshore. The United States, which once exported Texas crude oil, now exports Texas oilmen. Today they encounter British, French and Norwegian competitors.
As the oil industry's fortunes dwindle, its base of skills and equipment disappears. "We're in a fairly severe situation," Professor Fisher said. "We're taking an infrastructure down probably lower than we want to."
Geology students still enroll in his program. "They are as bright as ever," he said, adding, but "their interest is somewhere else. They don't see oil as a future."

HEADLINE: The Rich Get Richer. True or False?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Stung by the assertions that the super-rich did extraordinarily well in the 1980's, the Treasury Department struck back last week. But its initiative flopped and the exercise turned out to be an embarrassment.
Treasury was taking aim at a calculation -- made by the M.I.T. economist Paul R. Krugman and embraced by Bill Clinton -- that shows that the richest 1 percent reaped 70 percent of the rise in average family income between 1977 and 1989. 
 To shoot down the report, Treasury fired off its own statistic showing that the top 1 percent got a mere 11 percent of total income gains between 1979 and 1988. The very rich, the Treasury said, "fared somewhat better than average, but not very much better."
But experts instantly spotted that the Treasury statistic was calculated in a way that all but guaranteed that the gains of the rich would appear modest. To come up with its politically correct 11 percent figure, Treasury had arbitrarily defined the top 1 percent as those with very high incomes in 1979. But, as Will Rogers would have appreciated, people at the top at the beginning of the period had nowhere to go, if they moved at all, but down.
A less biased approach would have been to calculate the gains of those who fell into the top 1 percent based on their average income over the whole period.
This analysis the Treasury has declined to provide, but some enterprising academic will surely do it for them.

HEADLINE: Just Folks;
What's Meant and What's Mean In the 'Family Values' Battle

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Here is a pop quiz on the 1992 campaign. (TelePrompters are not allowed, but you may call your mother in Smalltown, U.S.A.) 
 Family Values are best exemplified by:
A. Vice President Dan Quayle extolling families with two parents, of different genders, who send their children to the drug-free school of their choice, where voluntary prayer is permitted.
B. Hillary Clinton rubbing Bill's back as they sit on a farm in their chinos and running shoes (plaid shirts added when appropriate) and Al and Tipper Gore beam approvingly from a nearby hay bale.
C. President Bush announcing in the Rose Garden that stopping drug abuse will "open more opportunity than ever for all Americans, preserving one nation under God."
D. Mr. Gore asking his wife, his four children, his father and his mother to join him on the platform at the Democratic National Convention, where he danced with Mrs. Gore and slapped five with his son.
Judging from how the Presidential contest has been going, the answer is: E. All of the above.
That the 1992 campaign has found its buzz phrase was abundantly evident last week as the two parties locked in a death grip over the "family values agenda."
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore toured truck stops in the Midwest to continue a pre-emptive strike on the family front, traditional Republican territory that the Democrats are now trying to seize. Mr. Quayle, who began the whole discussion by criticizing Murphy Brown, stumbled by saying he would reluctantly support his daughter if she chose to have an abortion as an adult.
And Mr. Bush talked about almost anything that would let him connect with voters and change the subject from the economy and whether Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will rescue his campaign. On Friday, he mentioned the death of his 3-year-old daughter from leukemia in 1953 to show hecklers at a conference of relatives of Americans lost in Southeast Asia that he too has suffered a family loss and was not insensitive to their problems.
But even with all this attention, it is not at all clear what the four candidates mean by family values. To what extent are they using the notion to point up what they perceive as their opponents' weaknesses -- Mr. Clinton's marital problems and appeals to gay and lesbian groups, Mr. Bush's air of detachment and poor record on the economy and racial issues?
Or perhaps the family talk is simply fodder for sound bites in a year when a politician feels safer with "Father Knows Best" than "Advise and Consent."
By Friday, even Regis Philbin and Kathy Lee Gifford, who have made a breakfast-television career out of being warm and fuzzy, had had just about enough. "Family values, family values, everybody's smothering themselves in family values," Mr. Philbin said. "I'm telling you, just before your eyes, Bill Clinton and Hillary became Ozzie and Harriet overnight."
Voters will know things are out of hand, Mr. Philbin suggested, when they "catch Clinton smoking a pipe."
Obviously, there are pressing issues evoked by "family values" -- child-raising, welfare, crime, drugs, faith and community, to name a few.
"The appeal of this vague phrase is that fundamentally it reminds people that good society depends not only, or even primarily, on their economic well-being, but also on this web of personal-social relationships that transcend the marketplace and transcend government," said Gary Orrin, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
Mr. Orrin said "family values" is a "protean grab bag" of issues that Republicans began using in 1968, when Richard M. Nixon campaigned on a law-and-order platform. But after years of ceding that ground to Republicans, the Democrats are now trying to recapture it.
"You can't campaign as the anti-family person," Mr. Orrin said. "The battle is to see which candidate or party is associated in the public mind as the party or candidate of family values, of peace, of honesty."
The President was trying to do just that on Friday, at a picnic in Brookville, Ohio. "The opposition would have you believe that family values is merely a slogan, and I don't look at it that way at all," he said.
But finding a widely accepted definition is hard.
Is it family values when Mr. Quayle says he would counsel his daughter against an abortion, but would support whatever decision she made? Or when his wife, Marilyn, alarmed that he might be seen as softening his stand on abortion, says that if the girl got pregnant now, at age 13, they would make her bear the child?
Is it family values when Mr. Clinton says he wouldn't talk about such an intimate question with the press? Or when he told millions of people how he bonded with his 12-year-old daughter Chelsea by having her join him to watch a "60 Minutes" broadcast on his alleged infidelity?
Is it family values when Mr. Clinton suggests his wife is smart enough to serve in a Cabinet, or when he backs off to appease stay-at-home mothers?
Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School of Communication at the University of Pennsylvania, said months of focus groups with 100 voters on that very subject offered no answer. "People," she said, "say everything from 'People ought to love each other, people ought to take care of their children, people ought to obey their parents,' to 'The government should treat families with respect and not tax them to death and does the government have the same values we have about money or are they spending it irresponsibly?' "
One thing was clear, Ms. Jamieson said: people are certain that their idea of family values is the only right one.
And both sides are trying to exploit that. Mr. Clinton does it by saying the Bush Administration does not value families because it refuses to mandate child-care and parental leave benefits at work. The Republicans do it by drawing a distinction between their view of society and the Democrats'.
"On the right, you tend to have people who say we've got to get kids to start abstaining again, get the divorce rate down, get families being faithful, children with some reliable sense of right and wrong," said Gary Bauer, head of the Family Research Council, an anti-abortion group. "I don't think I'm being unfair to say that the other side is more inclined to say families are evolving, that there are different lifestyles and government ought to accommodate the changes, rather than tell people there is a right or wrong way to live."
Republicans have been accused of using "values" to divide the electorate and to stir ugly emotions like racism or xenophobia.
In 1988, Mr. Bush was accused of using racism against Gov. Michael S. Dukakis by raising, in the name of law and order, the Willie Horton case. This year, Mr. Quayle has been accused of anti-Semitism for attacking Hollywood and of racism for arguing that poor urban blacks did not have the moral fiber to withstand the post-60's upheaval.
 
'Values' as a Code Word

 Mr. Bauer and Ms. Jamieson disputed the suggestion that "family values" is a specific code word for these sorts of things. "In conservative politics, long before Bill Clinton came on the radar screen, these were very important themes," Mr. Bauer said.
But the debate clearly touches sensitive issues. "Clinton has learned the lesson well," Mr. Bauer said. "That means the Administration is going to have to get into some specifics they are uncomfortable with, like gay rights, to show the difference between Democratic rhetoric and their platform."
Mr. Bush, who questioned Mr. Dukakis's patriotism, his religious beliefs and even his mental health, is clearly aware of the danger of being on the wrong side of the family values ramparts.
On Friday, during a political swing through the Midwest, he took every chance to drive home his devotion to the family. In Columbia, Mo., at the Show Me State Games, Mr. Bush said: "When you take the time to teach your son to shoot a bull's-eye, or teach your daughter to throw a strike, you're teaching more than a skill, you're teaching values. Values like perseverance, sportsmanship, motivation, effort."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Memo;
Pressure Builds on President As Anxiety Mounts in Party

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The soothing story line in Republican circles these days is that James A. Baker 3d is riding back to the rescue, just as he did in the summer of 1988, when George Bush was 17 points behind Michael S. Dukakis.
But even the prospect of Mr. Baker's return, which is still unannounced, can barely contain the Republican alarm. In a year of wild swings in the polls, almost nobody considers Gov. Bill Clinton's 27-point lead in a Time-CNN Poll conducted this week to be solid support. But almost no one expected the Democrat's post-convention bounce to be that big, or to be fueled by a cross-country bus tour that co-opted much of the Republicans' favorite Middle America, hay-bale-and-patriotic-sparkler imagery.
 
Deeper Problems
 Grim as the polls may be, the Republicans have deeper problems as they begin the buildup to their Aug. 17 convention in Houston. They are achingly aware of how hard it is to improve the image of an unpopular President during hard times. Jimmy Carter, once their favorite target, is now their worst nightmare. 
 The macropolitics of this year has some disturbing parallels to 1980. Few Republicans expected the economy and the national mood to be this dark this late in 1992. Moreover, for all of Mr. Clinton's vulnerable points, and Republicans find them especially comforting these days, many party strategists see him as a dangerous opponent -- much more dangerous than Mr. Dukakis.
In short, some Republicans suggest that the problems afflicting Mr. Bush this year make the great Republican comeback of 1988 look easy.
 
'Significantly More Difficult'
 "I'm firmly convinced that whatever margin we're down by now, it's significantly more difficult to overcome than the 17-point margin we were down by to Dukakis," said Neil Newhouse, a Republican poll taker handling numerous state and Congressional races this year, though he hastens to say that a comeback is "certainly possible."
Ed Goeas, another Republican poll taker, said: "I have felt all along that the campaign has to start on the part of the President, and it hasn't. You can't have the Democrats out there for a year being political and fall back on trying to be governmental." He added, "I believe that whether we win or lose, this race is going to be extremely close."
There are some analysts, notably the conservative Kevin Phillips, who argue that the zeitgeist is simply against George Bush this year. The old Republican coalition, bound together by anti-Communism, economic growth and social conservatism, does look decidedly strained, like a tripod teetering on one leg. "This is what you get in late stages of party coalitions," Mr. Phillips argues. "What knit them together is often 25 years old. You see Bush trying to recapture a lot of social issues that were critical in 1968 and 1972."
Mr. Phillips's thesis, which is revered by the Democrats, is that the country is headed for a backlash against the 1980's and a resurgence of economic populism, comparable to the periods after the Gilded Age and the 1920's. But even Republicans who dismiss his sense of sea change acknowledge that Mr. Bush faces a far chillier political climate today than he did four years ago.
In 1988, it might not have been the morning in America proclaimed by President Ronald Reagan, but it was still midday. The unemployment rate was 5.2 percent in June, a 14-year low, and only 5 in 10 Americans said the country was "on the wrong track," according to the Wirthlin Group, a polling company. This year, unemployment reached 7.8 percent in June, an eight-year high. And a key measure of the national mood shows an extraordinary level of pessimism as nearly 8 in 10 Americans say that the country is headed down the wrong track.
An incumbent President pays a price for that mood. Mr. Bush's approval rating, low most of the year, sank to 30 percent in the Time/CNN poll released today. The survey, based on telephone interviews with 855 registered voters, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Anxious Republicans
 These are the kinds of numbers that haunt Republicans on Capitol Hill, who sense their own political fortunes on the line. In recent days, there have been a wave of rumors and anxious pleas to do everything from replacing Vice President Dan Quayle to shaking up the Cabinet: calls, in other words, for big gestures to convince a skeptical public that the party in power has the energy to respond to the restless national mood.
"Some decisions in political life are very difficult; others aren't," said Representative Jim Leach, a veteran Iowa Republican. "The President needs to shift gears. He's going to have to do a little Cabinet reshuffling. And frankly, some early advertising -- substantial early advertising."
Mr. Leach added, "It's going to be extraordinarily difficult."
Stuart E. Eizenstat, who was domestic policy adviser under President Carter, agrees. "When you're embattled, as we were in 1980, everything you do is seen through the prism of politics and is perceived as simply a way of getting out of your current problems rather than a legitimate agenda for the future," he said. "We tried mightily to define a second- term agenda, but you can never break through the fog of criticism about your current record when things are going poorly."
 
Plenty of Advertising
 Eddie Mahe, a veteran Republican consultant, acknowledges the power of the fog. "The big thing that Bush, Baker and the campaign has to do, in my opinion, is jump the press, jump the interpreters, and remind the American people of what it is that this President has accomplished," he said. "I think they should put every dollar they've got on television, and I think they should not go off television until Nov. 3."
The Bush campaign is, in fact, planning television advertising before the convention, using money left over from the primaries. And the convention itself will obviously be an opportunity to highlight Mr. Bush's achievements and goals; he seized the moment four years ago, when he was widely thought to have given the speech of a lifetime at the convention in New Orleans.
But next month's convention could also highlight some of the tensions in the party, including the abortion issue. More broadly, Mr. Phillips asserted that Republicans ran the risk in the coming convention of seeming dominated by "two fringes, one cultural and one economic."
 
Missed Opportunities
 Many Republicans say they are haunted by a sense of missed opportunities for Mr. Bush, opportunities to convey his accomplishments on the world stage and pledge his commitment to a new domestic agenda. A prominent Southern Republican, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said: "They have to give people a reason to be for him. We've spent seven months now, and there are lot of reasons to be for him, but they haven't focused the public's attention on those reasons."
This is where Mr. Baker can help, many Republicans say: by focusing the message, making decisions and making them stick. Mr. Baker is also renowned as a man who can talk to the President, and get him to do what needs to be done.
But many Republicans agree that the Bush campaign also needs to focus much of its effort on making Mr. Clinton an unacceptable alternative. "The challenge now is, how do you move a President who's sitting at 35 percent approval rating up to 50 percent in the polls?" said Mr. Newhouse, the poll taker. "And part of the answer is, you have to get voters to vote for him who don't approve of the job he's doing, by making Clinton less palatable to some of your swing voters than George Bush is."
Mr. Eizenstat recalls that the Carter strategy in 1980 was also "to make Reagan seem too risky to be a legitimate agent of change." But the former White House official added that there is a risk of backlash with that approach, saying, "People can accept negative campaigns from opponents to a much greater degree than they can from an incumbent President, from whom they expect a more elevated campaign."
Still, many Republicans believe that Mr. Bush can only prosper by a head-to-head comparison with Mr. Clinton on trust and leadership traits. The Democratic nominee's surge in the polls, some noted, has followed a period of unusually positive news coverage that is unlikely to be sustained.
In the meantime, the Republicans keep a wary eye of the Democrats, and what they see as copyright infringement. Having watched the Reaganesque imagery and pretty pictures of the Democrats' bus tour, Don Sipple, a Republican consultant, said: "They've been sounding some themes that frankly in the past have been Republican themes, and that should be of concern to our party. They've been sounding hope and optimism, which in the last three elections were Republican themes."
