PUB-DATE: July 26, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 3579 words

HEADLINE: Solutions on Welfare: They All Cost Money

SERIES: Rethinking Welfare/Last of six articles.

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
The court official who supervises child support in Grand Rapids, Mich., described a 26-year-old local man who had fathered eight children with five mothers. "Before you condemn him for moral laxity," said the official, William D. Camden, "look what he did for these women."
"He gave each one of them a safety net," Mr. Camden said, referring to the welfare the women and children can receive. "They will have a steady income and full medical coverage until their kids are 18. 
 "The system seems designed to encourage this kind of dependency."
If there is one thing that nearly everyone agrees on, it is that the welfare system needs changing. Its rules can sap the spirit, recipients are the first to say, and it often discourages rather than fosters work and marriage. Yet its payments, if reliable, offer a bleak standard of living at best.
 
Going Beyond the System
 The criticism is hardly new, but in the last few years, as a result of local innovation and a national change in philosophy embodied in a 1988 law, a flurry of reforms has been tried, all intended to make welfare a bridge to self-reliance. Proposals for more radical change, like Gov. Bill Clinton's call to limit time on welfare to two years, are receiving unusual attention in the Presidential campaign.
But a consensus is growing among those who study welfare dependency, from Harvard liberals to Heritage Foundation conservatives, that major progress would require two costly innovations reaching far beyond the welfare system itself: health insurance for everyone and large income subsidies for the working poor -- in effect, a minimum guaranteed income for those who work.
In any case, the attack on welfare dependency must fight uphill against some profound social trends. One is a long-term decline in wages on the bottom end of the labor market, a trend that runs much deeper than the recession and has made it less advantageous than ever to leave welfare for work.
"It's harder to earn your way out of poverty now than it was 20 years ago," said Rebecca M. Blank, an economist at Northwestern University.
Another is a spectacular rise in out-of-wedlock births, swelling the population of prime candidates for long dependence on the dole.
The recent changes in welfare rules vary by state. They include new requirements for schooling, job training or community service work, financial carrots to encourage marriage, financial sticks to discourage irresponsible childbearing, and stronger efforts to collect money from absent fathers.
President Bush, who is also campaigning under a banner of welfare reform, has given several states, including New Jersey just last week, special exemptions from Federal law, allowing them to experiment with stronger incentives to change marital, work and childbearing behavior.
 
Dollars Lag Behind Words
 But the flow of dollars has not soared along with the lofty calls for sweeping reform. The country spent little more than $1 billion last year on education and job training specifically for welfare recipients. The modest expenditures are working as expected: they are helping small numbers of people reduce their need for public assistance.
With the new slogans have come wildly unrealistic expectations. Helping society's most downtrodden people change their lives will take more money, not less, in the near term. Yet in many states the "reforms" have been accompanied by cuts in benefits that seem mostly intended to save tax dollars. If experience is any guide, the new behavioral carrots and sticks will at best alter the actions of a small proportion of recipients.
The startling finding that one-fifth of the nation's children, including more than two-thirds of all black children, spend time on welfare by the age of 18 is less an indictment of the welfare system than a symptom of vast social calamity. Changes in the welfare system alone cannot transform communities caught in unemployment, crime, drug abuse and family disintegration.
"Simply isolating a problem like welfare, independent of the need to create jobs and educational opportunities, won't get you there," said William Julius Wilson, a poverty expert at the University of Chicago.
 
Incentives
Trying to Make Work Worth It
 If more families are to stand on their own, society has to "make work pay," said David T. Ellwood, a welfare expert at Harvard University and a liberal who proposes using tax credits and other measures to achieve that end.
Robert Rector of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group, also said that those shifting from welfare to work must be assured access to medical insurance, and have their incomes bolstered.
"If we want mothers to work their way off welfare, we should make sure their earnings when they get a job are as high as we can make them," said Mr. Rector, who agreed with Dr. Ellwood about little else. "I don't go as far as a guaranteed income, but I am proposing rather substantial tax relief and government assistance for those who are working."
Views are converging on this part of the answer, at least, at a time of great yearning for a full-scale attack on poverty. Unfortunately, it is also a time of record budget deficits.
Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main welfare program, now costs the Federal and state governments about $25 billion a year. Estimates of the extra cost of wage subsidies to help workers avoid poverty, combined in some proposals with new public jobs, range from $15 billion to more than $50 billion a year. Health insurance for the working poor would cost substantially more still.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, recalls the fierce debate within the Nixon Administration in 1969 and 1970 over his ill-fated proposals for a guaranteed annual income. "Cost was not a concern back then," Mr. Moynihan said in a recent interview. "The question was whether it was a good idea."
The paralysis induced by today's budget deficit will take a toll in wasted lives. "I'd love to come out with a $50 billion program," said Mr. Moynihan, who this year has been unable to get an extra $300 million beyond the $600 million in Federal money already spent on training of welfare recipients. "But it would be dishonest."
The concern is not for the half of the women who start on welfare, use it as a crutch and within two or three years get on with their lives. The concern is with the chronically dependent. One of every four women who goes on welfare stays on it for 10 or more years, according to an analysis by Dr. Ellwood of Harvard. These tend to enter the program as younger women, often teen-agers, with children born out of wedlock. They are often poorly educated, and a majority are black or Hispanic. These long-termers account for a majority of those on the rolls at any point and for most of the public expenses.
Marriage and childbirth patterns are producing a plentiful population of new candidates for dependency. In 1989, 27 percent of all births were to unmarried mothers, compared with 11 percent in 1970. Nineteen percent of white births in 1989, and 66 percent of black births, were to unmarried mothers.
The rate of births to unmarried teen-agers, who are most likely of all to need welfare and stay on it, is higher than ever and climbing. Two-thirds of all 1989 births to teen-agers (including 92 percent among blacks, 55 percent among whites) were out of wedlock, up from one-third in 1970, according to data analyzed by Kristin Moore of Child Trends Inc., a Washington research group.
 
Some Things Won't Change
 No matter how welfare is structured and no matter what the job market, an 18-year-old girl from a broken family with two babies, no high school degree, no work experience and no husband is going to have serious trouble supporting herself. It is naive, experts say, to think that six months or a year of remedial education and job training, and a threat to cut welfare checks, would be enough to set many such recipients on a trajectory out of poverty.
"Something has got to restore family structure," Mr. Moynihan said. "The illegitimacy rate is going up every year. If you expect a government program to change that, you know more about government programs than I do."
Something needs to change in the workplace, too. "Whatever your moral failings, if you are unskilled the world is a harder, rougher place for you today than it was for the equivalent person in the late 1960's," said Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution. "Your capacity to earn has declined."
The trend is worldwide, and involves more than the much-discussed decline in well-paying blue-collar jobs. Within most sectors, including the dominant service sector, pay for the less-skilled has fallen while incomes at the top have soared. Experts believe the trend may be linked to, among other things, global competition for jobs and technological changes that put a greater premium on advanced skills. Poorly educated younger men have lost the most ground, but women are still paid much less than men on average.
Though some experts disagree, Dr. Wilson of the University of Chicago argues that these two driving forces of dependency -- worsening wages and an increase in out-of-wedlock births -- are related. "The economic status of males is directly associated with the problem of marriage," he said.
In this disastrous synergy he sees a seed of hope. "I think that a sharp increase in employment opportunitites would certainly elevate the marriage rate," Dr. Wilson said.
But the rate of out-of-wedlock births climbed through the last decade's boom years, when unemployment was down, suggesting that more than work status is contributing to the decline in two-parent families.
 
Reforms
Huge Problems, Modest Gains
 Against this backdrop of poverty-spawning social and economic trends, Congress in 1988 made major changes in the welfare rules. The Family Support Act, written by Senator Moynihan and others, promoted by Mr. Clinton on behalf of the country's governors and signed by President Ronald Reagan, laid out more clearly than before the principle of mutual obligation: society would help the poor, but they had to strive for independence.
The actual targets were modest, if realistic: by 1995, states should push 20 percent of recipients into education or job training, with many recipients, like women with children under age 3, excluded. The law also required states to guarantee child care for women who needed it to work, and it strengthened enforcement of child support from absent parents.
If the ideas were sound, the timing was bad. In 1991, states used only $600 million of the $1 billion in Federal money available to them for education and training under this law because so many did not appropriate the required matching money.
The results so far suggest both the promise and the limits of this kind of change. An April evaluation of how the new law is working in California, by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a not-for-profit group in New York, showed results that experts said were encouraging. In the first year, single parents entering the education and job training program earned an average of $1,902 a year, compared with $1,631 for a similar group that did not receive the services.
That modest difference masks greater individual successes; some recipients earned a lot more, and the gains are likely to be greater in subsequent years. Researchers estimate that California is spending up to about $1,500 per recipient in training.
Judith M. Gueron, President of Manpower Demonstration Research, said that giving comparable training and assistance to all eligible welfare recipients would take some $4.5 billion a year, compared with little more than $1 billion spent now. What results could be expected?
"If we could run the programs as effectively as some earlier demonstrations, we would save three times that much for taxpayers over time," she said. "It might reduce the welfare rolls by 10 percent. That would be an ambitious goal."
Mr. Moynihan cautions against impatience. "Anybody who thinks you can change something so huge in less than a generation is not telling the truth," he said.
 
States Experiment
 Several states have experimented with bigger changes, with some success. New York's Child Assistance Program, one of the most far-reaching, involved 1,650 families in seven upstate counties in its first year. Those who volunteered received lower monthly grants but could keep a much larger share of earnings than under traditional welfare -- 90 cents of every dollar until their incomes reach the poverty line. In contrast, welfare is often reduced dollar for dollar.
To receive any benefits, participants had to obtain a child-support order against the absent parent. In turn, the state paid benefits for each child whether or not the fathers actually paid.
As New York officials enthusiastically announced in June, between grants and earnings, participants in the experiment had total incomes well above the poverty line and well above those of traditional welfare recipients.
But the participants were a self-selected, better-off group to start with. The program is structured to be financially advantageous only for those who can earn at least $350 a month and secure child-support orders. These requirements "are likely to limit the program to a small part of the A.F.D.C. population," said the one-year evaluation report by Abt Associates.
In fact, only 6 percent of those who were given the option chose to participate. The evaluators said it was too early to determine whether the program would reduce the extent of welfare dependency.
Beginning in 1983, many counties in Ohio experimented with a "workfare" program far more stringent than most of the job-search or training programs carried out in the name of welfare reform. Many adults on welfare were required to work in community service jobs, for an average of about 25 hours a week, in return for benefits. The jobs were with public or not-for-profit agencies.
The results were intriguing. Over five years the welfare rolls in counties with workfare shrank compared with those in other counties, though not drastically. Among single-parent families, caseloads in the workfare counties stayed level while elsewhere they rose 11 percent to 14 percent. Among the smaller category of families with both parents present, and who received much stronger pressure to work, the divergence was more than 30 percent.
Researchers could not determine whether people left the rolls because they had gained useful contacts and experience or because they had simply found the work requirement too onerous. "We don't know why they left, or if they were better or worse off," said Bradley R. Schiller of American University, who studied the program and thinks it showed promise. "We just know their welfare behavior changed." The program ended in 1988 under opposition from labor unions and a shift in state priorities toward education and training.
 
Outlook
No Shortage Of Suggestions
 Even as they applaud the new efforts to foster independence, many welfare experts have concluded that the system needs more radical changes.
The solutions offered vary greatly in detail but have some crucial points in common -- above all, calls for assured health coverage and for large subsidies for the working poor. Concern about the design and especially the cost of these broader measures may make adoption of sweeping changes unlikely in the near future.
Dr. Ellwood's solution, parts of which resemble proposals of Governor Clinton, the Democratic Presidential candidate, has three main elements. First, he would subsidize the working poor by increasing refundable tax credits and raising the minimum wage, providing day care and insuring that all families have medical protection.
Second, he would combine much stronger enforcement of child support with an assured minimum support payment to single mothers of perhaps $2,000 a year for each of the first two children and less for additional ones.
And third, welfare benefits would be explicitly short-term, provided for two or three years to help people through a difficult time. No one could renew them by having another baby or claiming that work was unavailable.
With all these elements in place, he said, "single parents could realistically support themselves at the poverty line if they were willing to work half time, even at a job paying little more than the minimum wage." The Government would be an employer of last resort for what he predicts would be a small number who could find no private jobs.
"If we can make sure that when you go to work you are better off, then I think we can say that we don't have to provide welfare forever," Dr. Ellwood said. But he warned against putting time limits on welfare in the absence of the income and child-support elements. "We would put single parents in an impossible position," he said. He estimated that the tax credits, child support, child care and job training in his plan would cost an extra $15 billion to $20 billion a year. Health insurance for the working poor and the costs to business of a higher minimum wage would be additional.
 
Another Point of View
 Mr. Rector of the Heritage Foundation attacked Dr. Ellwood's plan as a disguised way of creating "a whole new welfare system," pointing to the assured child-support benefits in particular. Instead, arguing that the current combination of grants, food stamps, housing subsidies and other programs often makes welfare too attractive, he would begin by reducing benefit levels.
He would require able-bodied recipients, except mothers with small children, to work in community service jobs in return for their benefits. Women having babies out of wedlock would have to establish paternity to qualify for welfare; fathers would pay support or work in community jobs, too. Mothers on welfare who have additional children would not receive extra benefits.
If he would do more to make welfare unpleasant, Mr. Rector would also, like Dr. Ellwood and most other experts, try to ease the path to self-reliance. He supports a health care plan developed by colleagues at the Heritage Foundation in which low-income people would receive tax credits and vouchers for purchase of health insurance. He would implement a tax-relief plan that would eliminate all Federal taxes on working families near the poverty line.
"If you make people work as a condition of getting benefits, all of a sudden that makes getting married, or getting a real job in the private sector, look better," Mr. Rector said. "Plus, if you give people health benefits and tax relief, you make it more lucrative for them to do so."
Just the tax-relief plan, Mr. Rector said, would cost about $45 billion per year.
Another approach is offered by Mickey Kaus, an editor of The New Republic, in his new book "The End of Equality" (Basic Books). In an approach that he argues would gradually change the expectations and behavior of the poor, he would abolish welfare payments and food stamps for the able-bodied, replacing them with "a single simple offer from the Government -- an offer of employment for every American citizen over 18 who wants it, in a useful public job at a wage slightly below the minimum wage for private-sector work." The low wage would provide an incentive to seek private jobs.
Mr. Kaus would provide tax credits to raise the incomes of low-paid workers above the poverty line. After considering the idea of temporarily exempting young mothers with newborns from the work requirement, he concludes that it may be better not to, in order to deter reckless childbearing. He would provide "compassionate" aid -- homeless shelters, counseling, but no cash -- to those who fail to take the offered public jobs and fall into total destitution.
Mr. Kaus estimates the extra cost of providing several million public jobs, tax credits, day care and other aid at $43 billion to $59 billion a year. He acknowledges that the plan would be fiercely opposed by unions.
As the merits of various proposals are debated, some experts warn that radical change, too, has risks. It is one thing, for example, to decide to push people off the welfare rolls after two years but quite another to pay for the training, health care, child care and jobs needed to make that a humane alternative.
And even then, some people will not behave according to the legislated script. "I think that if we introduce time limits on welfare, we'll have more women and children living in Grand Central Station" said Dr. Gueron of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation. "There are a great many welfare recipients who are very marginal in terms of their ability to work. Some are clinically depressed, or were abused as young women. This is not a group that just needs a good kick to get their act together.
"The costs of cutting them off would be very high, because there are children involved."
 
 
 
ARTICLES IN THIS SERIES
 This series began on July 5 with an article about the new politics of welfare. Other articles that week dealt with chronically dependent welfare families in Newark, poverty in a small town in Iowa, and how some welfare recipients who take jobs end up poorer for it. Last Monday's article was about absent fathers and enforcement of child-support laws.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Polls Seem to Offer Respite, But Clinton Pushes the Pace

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPOKANE, Wash. July 25

 BODY:
The calls to his Little Rock headquarters have tripled in volume, the campaign's advisers are locked in almost round-the-clock planning sessions, and Bill Clinton, the Democratic nominee for President, headed for the West Coast today as if the very devil were at his heels.
In many ways, Governor Clinton and his lieutenants are still reeling from weeks of good news, good polls and the soaring potential of a campaign that, only a few weeks ago, was happy to make it through seven consecutive days without a disaster. 
 Now, as the planning for a vigorous general-election campaign against President Bush begins in earnest, the Democrats are busily remapping their strategy for a two-way race by going on the attack before the Republicans can do it first at their convention.
When Mr. Clinton landed on the West Coast today, he hoped to spread his dramatic campaign comeback to another region of the country.
Speaking to a crowd of thousands in this city's Riverfront Park, Mr. Clinton pointedly used the word "change" more than a dozen times, attempting to sell the Democratic ticket as the solution to the nation's doldrums.
"I don't care what the polls say today," he said. "It will require more courage for you to vote for Bill Clinton and Al Gore. Because it always is difficult to change. We represent hope, not fear. We represent the promise of a better tomorrow, but we have to change."
Last week, in combination with his Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, Mr. Clinton reaped more than his share of success from their eight-state bus tour. The Governor was trailed all over the country by Republicans sounding Mr. Bush's themes -- from the party chairman, Richard N. Bond, to Vice President Dan Quayle -- but they made only halfhearted efforts to pierce the Democrats' new bubble.
 
Democrats Afraid to Relax
 "I'd much rather have my problems than theirs," said Paul Begala, one of Mr. Clinton's advisers.
But even as they chortled at the Republican parade, some Democrats admitted that they were still a little nervous at the beauty of it all.
"On the Wednesday night of the convention, I looked at all that silver confetti falling, and I thought, 'What the hell do we do tomorrow?' " said Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic Party. "The balloons could be a big disappointment."
Similarly, campaign strategists are bracing for an end to poll numbers that show Mr. Clinton 20 to 30 percentage points ahead of Mr. Bush.
"If you watch Ross Perot or Michael Dukakis in 1988 or George Bush at the end of 1991, you see a lead that develops quickly can disappear quickly," said Dee Dee Myers, the campaign's press secretary. "You shouldn't go to the track and bet on these leads."
James Carville, an adviser who is putting together the campaign's attack-and-response team, has called the numbers a "souffle" that could easily fall. Others have been quick to follow his lead.
"Sure, it's soft," said Paul Tully, the political director for the Democratic National Committee. "People are just arriving. You can't go home and take a vacation and put it in the bank. You have to harden it up step by step."
Mr. Tully and others have been arguing that the Democrats will be able to break what has been a Republican lock on Electoral College votes by exploiting the advantages they gain by presenting themselves as the party of change at a time when many voters are unhappy with the economy and anything that resembles the status quo.
"Perot's disappearance freed up a set of voters who are the angriest and the most anti-Bush," Mr. Tully said. "They had operated on little information about Governor Clinton, and this last three or four weeks has filled in a tremendous amount for them. It has a geographic impact as well as an impact with various segments of the population."
 
Running as if He's Behind
 The first step for Mr. Clinton has been to set a breakneck pace. After less than 24 hours off the road and back home in Little Rock this week, he traveled to Houston to attack Mr. Bush on turf the President calls home. Next week, he plans to visit Washington State, California, Illinois, Missouri and Louisiana.
Later in the week, campaign planners expect Mr. Clinton to criticize the President about taxes in a speech from the Superdome in New Orleans, the site of the 1988 Republican convention, where Mr. Bush first said, "Read my lips: no new taxes."
Mr. Clinton previewed a bit of that attack here today, asking his supporters to reject Republican efforts to paint him as someone whose policies would raise their taxes.
"When we get into this campaign, our opponents will say, 'There they go again -- the Democrats, they're talking about taxing and spending,' " Mr. Clinton said. "Let me tell you something. We're spending 30 percent more on health care than any country in the world, and we're getting less for it."
Although Mr. Clinton and his aides insist that they are not fighting the last war, every step they have taken so far contrasts markedly with everything Michael S. Dukakis is now agreed to have done wrong in 1988.
After Mr. Dukakis won the Democratic nomination, he took time off to bask in a 17-point lead in the polls. Mr. Clinton, who spent his first week after the convention on his bus caravan, today scheduled a 20-hour campaign day, beginning with an early morning cross-country flight and winding up in Seattle at a televised "town meeting."
"We are absolutely determined to keep rolling," Mr. Brown said. "There is no rest period. You will see us very active. You won't see us taking a trout-fishing trip during the Republican convention."
Mr. Bush went trout fishing with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during the Democrats' convention.
Some of the activity seems intended to ride the crest of the positive political wave for as long as possible before enthusiasm subsides and the negative Republican campaign expected by the Democrats begins.
 
Bracing for a Slump
 "There is going to be a sorting out," said Stan Greenberg, the campaign poll taker who has been helping to reformulate the Clinton campaign's priorities. "A lot of anti-Bush and a lot of Perot voters who want to vote for change are turned on," as well as many traditional Republicans. "We have to assume we're going to shed some of these votes."
Clinton strategists have become expert at reducing expectations for their candidate, but they have scarcely been able to conceal their glee at Republican missteps, whether it was Mr. Bush snapping at veterans' families on Friday or the talk of removing Vice President Quayle from the ticket.
"Our people around the country are smelling the scent of a winner," Mr. Begala said. "Not only are the Republicans smelling the scent of a loser, but of a disaster. They're going to be pining for Goldwater."
Mr. Clinton tells Democrats he is gearing up for a nasty campaign. In Texas, where Clinton workers say phones have been ringing off the hook since the convention with new offers of support, Mr. Clinton told supporters at a fund-raiser that he was ready.
"Everywhere I go, people say, 'Are you ready for one more Republican negative campaign?' " Mr. Clinton said. "There was a cartoon today of me walking out of the Democratic convention, and it was portrayed as a bathhouse. I had a towel on, and there's a Republican there with a wheelbarrow full of mud hiding around the corner."
The audience of partisan Democrats howled.
"I'll tell you that Al Gore and Bill Clinton believe in a strong national defense," he said. "And we believe in a strong political defense."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Bill Clinton has taken his campaign to the West Coast, where he greeted thousands of supporters yesterday in Riverfront Park in Spokane, Wash. "It will require more courage for you to vote for Bill Clinton and Al Gore," Mr. Clinton said. "Because it always is difficult to change." (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Britain's Labor Party Names Shadow Cabinet

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 25

 BODY:
With Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Government stymied by the longest and most persistent recession of modern times, the British Labor Party has named a new shadow cabinet that hopes it will not be stuck in opposition for too many more years.
Less than four months after an election Mr. Major won on the promise of a British economic recovery, none is yet in sight. His Government is in the midst of the biggest political sex scandal in years, a liaison involving his close friend and Cabinet colleague David Mellor, the Secretary of State for National Heritage, and an actress. 
 A spell of warm, humid weather has also brought rioters out onto the streets of Huddersfield, Blackburn and other British cities with clashes between youths and the police that have led to the arrests of hundreds of people over the last two weeks.
With all this going on, some Labor supporters are saying that voters have already told them they're sorry they didn't vote for them on April 9, when the Conservatives won by a 21-seat majority in the House of Commons.
The last Labor Government left office in May 1979, but the shadow cabinet named on Friday by Labor's new leader, John Smith, hopes to succeed in the next elections.
Mr. Smith's deputy, Margaret Beckett, will run the party's election campaigns, while Dr. Jack Cunningham, a chemist who was the party's campaign coordinator before the election, will speak for the party on foreign affairs, filling the vacancy created by the resignation of Gerald Kaufman.
Mr. Smith said on Friday that his new team would "relentlessly expose" Government policies. More than 100 days after the election, there is still no sign of economic recovery. High interest rates have brought inflation down to about 4 percent, but the gross national product may fall this year for the second year in a row, exports are shrinking, and retail sales dropped a fifth of a percentage point last month.
With this glum background, Mr. Major's Cabinet decided this week on a four-year hold on spending that Gordon Brown, the new Labor spokesman on the economy, called "the fastest betrayal of election promises in history."
Mr. Major has not had smooth sailing since winning his election. His predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, has been criticizing his European policy since she joined the House of Lords last month, urging Conservatives to vote against the treaty on European union when it comes up for ratification.
This week, Mr. Mellor has been under daily fire from newspapers that have published transcripts of conversations that revealed he had been carrying on a relationship with a young actress, Antonia de Sancha. Mr. Mellor later acknowledged that he and his wife, Judith, had been undergoing "difficulties" in their marriage.
Since Mr. Mellor's responsibilities include deciding whether to recommend a law curbing press abuse of privacy, there have been calls for his resignation, but Mr. Major has made clear that he will stick with him.
Sporadic violence at a low-income public housing project in Huddersfield, in West Yorkshire, and in Blackburn and Burnley, in Lancashire, continued Thursday night, for the second night in a row. The police and Labor Party politicians said the violence involved rival gangs of Indian and Pakistani youths in Blackburn and occurred in areas of high unemployment.

HEADLINE: Servicewomen's Families Speak Out on Abuse

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 23

 BODY:
An American flag stirs in the breeze outside Bill Baxter's house and a National Rifle Association sticker decorates his car. He flies planes for a living, now as a commercial pilot after starting as a hard-boiled naval aviator, and attends Plymouth Haven Baptist Church, talks about "family values" and counts himself a rock-rib Republican.
His father-in-law, Dan Thomas, is cut from the same cloth. He is a retired Air Force major who flew B-52 bombers for a quarter of a century and then retired to the safe military haven of Pensacola, Fla., where he sells tractors and lawn mowers to young fellows in smart uniforms. Mr. Thomas is the sort of man who calls women "ladies," would not swear in front of them and blanches when anyone else does. 
 Mr. Baxter and Mr. Thomas never dreamed they would be speaking ill of the military establishment that nurtured and inspired them, never dreamed they would be writing impassioned letters to Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Democrat, of all things, begging her to hold the Armed Forces accountable for the sexual harassment of women.
 
Convention Changed Things
 But that was before last year's convention of the Tailhook Association, when the woman they love most in the world, Lieut. Comdr. Roxanne Baxter, Mr. Baxter's wife and Mr. Thomas's daughter, was one of at least 26 female aviators mauled by her male peers. That was before the Navy sought to whitewash the unseemly events in the Las Vegas hotel corridor, before one of the molested women decided to step forward by name and tell her story and before the subsequent public and political furor that has sent the Navy scurrying to burnish its image.
"I've watched Roxanne's hassles throughout her career, one straw after another, and I've finally gotten sick of it," Mr. Baxter said this week, explaining his decision to speak out, despite his wife's insistence that she wanted to "work through the system" and remain silent about the scandal at the convention of the private group of retired and active-duty naval aviators.
 
Speaking Up for His Daughters
 "I see speaking up as a way of helping to straighten out the Navy," he said. "It's probably too late for Roxanne, but I look at my daughters and it's them I'm concerned about. I'd like them to have a better shot."
Mr. Thomas, too, described a gathering sense that the time had come to take a public stand. Bit by bit, stingy in her details and insistent that she could take anything the men could dish out, his 37-year-old daughter only recently began telling him about the slights she suffered in a 15-year Navy career.
"She never made a big thing about it," Mr. Thomas said, "but with the perspective of history, it's clearer to me. I realize now the enormous hurdles she's had to overcome and the enormous amount of garbage she's had to put up with.
"It would not have occurred to me that these things could happen if they had not happened to Roxanne. I had tremendous faith in the system. I thought it would support the ladies and give them the same opportunities the men enjoyed. That it didn't is deplorable and makes me feel extremely disappointed."
Several times over the years, her husband and father say, Commander Baxter, was left behind from lengthy sea missions that would have furthered her career and given adverse fitness reports by superiors who did not hide their opposition to women in the armed forces, while other superiors gave her glowing assessments.
On Commander Baxter's one lengthy sea mission, in which she was the only woman among 500 men, she was the brunt of smutty skits, her husband and father say. And once, she was forcibly removed from an office by a man who did not want to take instructions from a woman, then told that if she pressed charges she would be removed as a department head.
The two men also wonder whether a recent promotion denied to Commander Baxter was because she had testified about the events at Tailhook.
In his frustration after the scandal, Mr. Baxter wrote to Representative Schroeder of Colorado, a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee and a longtime advocate for women in the military. Mr. Thomas, in a recent telephone interview, said he intends to do the same. Both men say they worry that the immediate fallout of the Tailhook scandal could be increased hostility toward the women, even if the long-term results are beneficial.
Mr. Baxter, who met his wife-to-be in flight school in Corpus Christi, Tex., said he often chats with current and former Navy aviators in his reserve unit and on the job as an American Airlines pilot. Some of these men, who do not know his wife in a pilot, grumble that women should not be aviators and that they are to blame for the recent tumult in the Navy, such as the dismissal and reassignment of highly placed officers and the end to nude dancing at officers' clubs.
 
Outrage of the Sexists
 "There are a lot of hardcore sexists out there and this only enrages them and encourages them in their conviction that women have no place in the Navy," Mr. Baxter said.
Mr. Thomas said that he, too, has seen examples of hostility. At the Sears store where he works, he often cannot resist bragging about his daughter to his customers, most of them Navy men. "A lot of them don't want to hear it," Mr. Thomas said. "Their egos are threatened and when I argue with them they huff out the door."
Ms. Schroeder's office keeps receiving letters of complaint about sexual harassment of enlisted women and officers. The majority of the two dozen letters come from fathers and husbands, not from the women themselves, who are presumably frightened that tattling will doom their careers.
Among the recent letters is a plea for help from a retired marine officer in Oceanside, Calif., whose daughter is an Air Force mechanic in Germany. She is being threatened with an unfavorable, career-threatening fitness report, he said, if she refuses sex with her commanding officer.
Another father, a 20-year Navy enlisted man and now a civilian employee at Fort McNair, Wash., wrote seeking justice for his daughter. He said that she celebrated the end of basic training in Orlando by getting drunk and wound up raped by a petty officer, abandoned in a dumpster behind the officer's club and then discharged against her wishes without an investigation into the assault.
 
Father Encouraged Her
 The rape victim's father, Frank Kochniarczyk, said he encouraged his divorced, unemployed and rebellious daughter to enlist in the Navy as a way of pulling her life together. "I believed she needed discipline and I believed the Navy would give it to her," he said during a coffee break at the Army base where he works. "I trusted them and they failed miserably."
This sense of betrayal permeates the comments of men who have beamed with pride when their daughters followed them into the military and then seen their hopes dashed.
"To see the system you dedicated your life to violate your trust is a crushing disappointment," said a senior Army officer in the Pentagon, who has had two daughters in the Armed Forces.
Carolyn Becraft, a military policy consultant in Washington and a former Army captain, agreed. "This is a system these men upheld all their lives; it is their calling, their church," said Ms. Becraft, whose husband and father are both Army officers. "Their daughter is an extension of them, a chip off the old block. When these things happen, it is a personal and painful epiphany."
For Mr. Baxter and Mr. Thomas, that epiphany includes understanding why aggrieved military women are loath to speak. It was loyalty and pride that kept Commander Baxter from publicly speaking out, her father said, adding: "She's reluctant to be a stool pigeon, so to speak. She doesn't like to gripe."
Mr. Baxter sees a more practical motive for his wife's silence: the risk to her career. "If her name is in print saying anything damaging, she could well find herself on a black list, with her next assignment on Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean," Mr. Baxter said.

HEADLINE: Income Gains Seen for Minorities in the New York Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Despite the deep recession that has engulfed the New York region since the end of the 1980's, the boom that preceded it raised incomes faster than in most of the rest of nation and pared down the huge disparities in earnings among whites, blacks and Hispanic residents, new census data show.
The data, released last week by the U.S. Census Bureau, did little to dispel the broad belief that the 1980's, more than most decades that preceded it, was one in which the gap between rich and poor widened. But it provided a fresh demographic snapshot that suggests that wealth and poverty no longer conform to traditional patterns of race or ethnicity, and that more minorities have ascended the economic order in the New York region. 
 A major factor in the economic gains of minorities was an increase in their education. Although black and Hispanic people are still far more likely than whites to drop out of school, according to the census report, the proportion of people in all groups to obtain high school and college degrees nationwide grew in the 1980's.
The census data also underscored the gains that have been made by people of Asian descent in the New York region -- which includes New York, New Jersey and Connecticut -- and elsewhere. Asians had higher incomes and more education than people of any other ethnic or racial group in the 1980's.
 
Attributed to Service Sector
 Between 1979 and 1989, median incomes more than doubled in New Jersey and Connecticut. The census data show that residents of Connecticut, with median household earnings of $41,721 in 1989, were the highest-paid in the nation. New Jersey residents ranked third, behind those in Alaska, with a median of $40,927 for 1989. Under census definitions, a household can be a single person or a family residing under the same roof. The median income is the point at which there is an equal number of people making more and making less.
In New York, the report said, median household income rose by 95 percent during the decade, to $32,956 in 1989, or 10 percent higher than the national median. Ten years earlier, the median earnings for New York State residents had been slightly lower than the national median.
Economists attributed the income growth to rapid expansion, particularly from 1980 to 1988, in Wall Street brokerage houses, law firms, engineering companies, and a host of other technologically advanced, service-oriented companies.
Indeed, while the region continued to lose factory jobs in the 1980's, economic studies show, there were far greater losses before the decade began, and the region benefited from being less dependent than other parts of the country on manufacturing enterprises.
 
Gains for Blacks
 The New York region "took its biggest hits in manufacturing during the 1970's," said William Frey, a researcher in the Population Studies Center at the University of Michigan. "By the 80's, it had moved rapidly in service industries, and they did well for most of the decade."
But the decade's economic strength was not spread evenly across the region. While median incomes rose rapidly, experts said, the rise in the 1980's, more than in any previous decade, was influenced by the extraordinarily high salaries paid to a small number of executives in the securities industry, law and other fields.
"The rich got richer," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "For most people, real wages did not grow."
Still, the census data showed that black workers in the region reaped the economic rewards of the 1980's to a larger degree than in previous decades. Although the gap between the median incomes of blacks and whites has always been huge, and has remained so, it narrowed somewhat. In at least one part of the region, in Queens, the median income for black households has virtually matched that of white households, figures show.
 
Hispanic and Asian Residents
 The data showed that in New York State, black households had median incomes in 1989 of $24,089, or 73 percent of the median for all state residents. That is compared with a median of $11,150 for black households statewide in 1979, or 67 percent of the state's overall median.
In New Jersey, the median for black households rose to 71 percent from 64 percent of the state's median during the decade. In Connecticut, the median for blacks rose to 67 percent from 62 percent of the state's median.
The data showed that Hispanic residents fared worse, but their earnings gained slightly during the decade. People who described themselves as Hispanic in New York State made 66 percent of the state's median household income in 1989, compared with 62 percent 10 years earlier. In New Jersey, their earnings rose from 68 percent to 73 percent of the median, and in Connecticut they rose from 59 to 60 percent of the median.
The group with the highest earnings in the region, as elsewhere in the nation, was people of Asian descent. The 1989 median income among Asians in New York was $36,784: in New Jersey it was $52,846, and in Connecticut it was $48,560.
The income gains by minorities were also a result of gains in education. The data show that by 1990, 64.7 percent of black residents in New York State had a high school education, compared with 57.6 percent 10 years earlier.
In New Jersey, 67 percent of the black residents had completed high school in 1989, up from 56.4 percent in 1980; and in Connecticut, the percentage of black high school graduates rose to 67 percent from 56.8 percent.
